HEADLINE: For Cultural Institutions, Art of Collaboration Is Biggest Show in Town

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Veronique LeMelle, executive director of the small Jamaica Arts Center in Queens, has grown weary of waiting in dread for each year's budget to emerge from City Hall. Whether the news is good or bad, the anxiety and uncertainty can be devastating for a small institution such as hers, planning only a few months ahead on the cultural calendar.
In 1991, her innovative combinations of art and social-service programs -- including an H.I.V. risk-reduction program in several Queens shelters for the homeless using quilt-making and theater -- suffered significant cutbacks. This year, to her amazement, she got a slight increase. 
 "It was miraculous," she said. "I was expecting the worst."
But municipal generosity is fleeting, and Ms. LeMelle is no longer taking any chances on it. For the first time, the Jamaica Arts Center has begun collaborating with other cultural institutions and community groups, joining forces in both programming and applying for crucial private grants. The center is about to announce several joint programs with the Black Spectrum Theater, a performance group not far away in Jamaica, and is also working closely with Red Hook Arts in Brooklyn.
 
New Strategies
 "Instead of competing with each other, we've started saying, hey, why don't we pool our money and do it together," said Ms. LeMelle. "You've got to do the ground work and make sure you've got a compatible marriage, or else it could be a nightmare. But it's really something you've got to do. If we spend all our time fighting with each other, someone else will come along and take the money."
Uneasily at first, but with a growing sense of necessity, the city's smaller cultural institutions are developing strategies to survive an uncertain economy. Particularly in the boroughs outside of Manhattan, boroughs where tourism is skimpy and the attention of corporate givers is flickering, institutions are teaming up and devising new ways of attracting both visitors and donations.
In those boroughs, even the larger institutions have decided to cooperate. Four of Brooklyn's largest institutions have just unveiled a joint campaign to get city residents and tourists to "Try a Day in Brooklyn." Working together on signs, brochures and advertisements, the Brooklyn Museum, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the Prospect Park Wildlife Center (formerly the zoo) and Prospect Park are touting their close proximity to each other and even the "fabulous shopping" at their gift shops.
In Flushing, where the Queens Botanical Garden nearly failed two years ago after a city investigation revealed mismanagement and corruption, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx have stepped in. Executives from the two larger gardens helped find a new director for the Queens garden and are providing horticultural assistance.
 
The Collaborators
 Not far away, the Flushing Council on Culture and the Arts, which operates the recently restored Flushing Town Hall, will be presenting a series of jazz concerts and exhibits in connection with the large retrospective on the life of Louis Armstrong that opens this fall at the nearby Queens Museum of Art.
Collaboration is not always easy for nonprofit institutions. The outgoing director of the Queens Botanical Garden, for example, objected to the presence of the other garden officials on her board of directors, complaining that they could not help raise funds for her organization when they remained loyal to their own.
"If I am Chrysler, I do not want General Motors on my board or anyone else who is or could be my competition," wrote Palmina R. Grella, the garden's acting director, in a memo to the board earlier this year.
But officials elsewhere said Ms. Grella -- who was not hired as the permanent director -- was taking a shortsighted view. "All of us have to go out there and make a strong case for all the botanical gardens working together as a group," said Lois Carswell, the chairwoman of the Brooklyn garden, who serves on the Queens garden's board.
 
Success Isn't Automatic
 Working together does not always produce results, particularly for smaller organizations. For the last three years, four regional black theaters -- the Black Spectrum Theater, the New Federal Theater in Manhattan, the Billie Holiday Theater in Brooklyn and the Theater of Universal Images in Newark -- have tried unsuccessfully to get a grant for joint productions.
But many larger institutions have found they can actually attract more money together. Alan J. Friedman, executive director of the New York Hall of Science in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, said that when the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City opened a year and a half ago, he was worried. But shortly afterward, the New York hall agreed to help train some of Liberty's staff, and the two centers went in on several joint grant proposals.
The borough cultural institutions also share a cherished sense of independence from the Manhattan cultural establishment and its internationally known museums, galleries and performing groups. Ms. LeMelle says that she remains wary of allying with the large Manhattan institutions.
"Sometimes I get calls from the big guys," she said. "They decide they need to diversify their audience, so they come out here. My feeling is, O.K., I'm helping you, but what am I getting in return? So I've been very cautious about working with them."
Manhattan continues to get the largest portion of the city's cultural budget -- 42 percent of $89 million in the last fiscal year -- but the percentage for other boroughs has grown in recent years under pressure from City Council members and borough presidents, many of whom use their own discretionary funds for borough arts groups. Getting private foundations to consider the other four boroughs remains difficult, however.
"You have to work twice as hard as a Manhattan institution," said Rochelle Slovin, executive director of the American Museum of the Moving Image in Long Island City, a film and broadcasting museum that is one of the most successful fund-raisers outside Manhattan. "But we've all learned to live within these constraints. It's not fair, but it's a fact of life."
Even more challenging is raising significant sums from corporations within the boroughs. Small galleries or arts troupes can get neighborhood funds from local businesses, but a large institution like the American Museum of the Moving Image gets almost none of its private funds from Queens, Ms. Slovin said. The borough has none of Manhattan's large corporate headquarters, and smaller or medium-size firms remain concerned about their bottom line and have not entered the philanthropic stream.
"Even in Brooklyn, some of the private funding there comes from people who were born there and made their fortunes elsewhere," Ms. Slovin said. "Queens has had a somewhat different socioeconomic trajectory. So I guess what we have to do now is find all the rich and famous people who grew up in Queens."

HEADLINE: Portrait of a Fund-Raiser: Seeking G.O.P. Friends

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
When Rudolph W. Giuliani first ran for mayor in 1989, William W. Koeppel raised money from everyone he knew. He even asked his tenants and contractors in his buildings for donations, amassing more than $100,000 for the campaign.
The young real-estate executive wanted to be sure he was the top fund-raiser at a dinner for Mr. Giuliani where President Bush was to speak, political associates said. The winner of the fund-raising contest would introduce the President. 
 Mr. Koeppel won, but the honor was not enough. During the dinner, he talked the President into giving him a ride in the motorcade to the airport, then letting him fly to Washington aboard Air Force One.
Mr. Koeppel, it seems, has a knack for getting close to Republican leaders. Last week that penchant landed him in the news when it was disclosed that he had provided choice apartments during the campaign and the early months of the administration to 15 Giuliani aides under leases that allowed some of tenants to put off paying rent for one to three months.
The leases raised questions about whether the apartments amounted to an illegal campaign contribution. But the disclosure also focused attention on a more fundamental issue: What does Mr. Koeppel want from Mr. Giuliani?
In recent months, city officials say, Mr. Koeppel has tried to influence senior mayoral aides on minor policy matters, from the cost of conventions to raising city revenues. But most of all, his acquaintances say, Mr. Koeppel (pronounced koh-PELL) has gotten immense pleasure simply from being associated with the Mayor, whose political style he would like to copy. Mr. Koeppel lost a race for Congress in 1990 and may still harbor political ambitions.
Still, it is Mr. Koeppel's role as landlord that has gotten the most scrutiny. Like most major landlords, Mr. Koeppel's company, Koeppel & Koeppel, has dozens of appeals to city assessments on his company's properties pending in court, some going back as far as five years. Favorable settlements with the city could save the Koeppels tens of thousands of dollars in taxes.
Two weeks after Mr. Giuliani took office in January, city lawyers reached an out-of-court settlement with Mr. Koeppel on two of his appeals, agreeing to reduce the assessments on a Brooklyn apartment building at 140 Bay Ridge Avenue. The city agreed to cut the assessment on the building by $60,000, from $400,000 to $340,000 in the tax years 1989 and 1990.
 
An Annual Challenge
 Apart from that case, Mr. Koeppel and his father, Robert, have challenged the annual assessments on at least seven other buildings. The city will probably negotiate settlements in about five of those cases this year, rather than going to court, officials said.
The city Corporation Counsel, Paul A. Crotty, a Giuliani appointee, has tremendous discretion over the out-of-court settlements that end the vast majority of such appeals. But James I. Lauer, who heads a team of lawyers who negotiate tax appeals for the city, said the lawyers who handled the Koeppel settlement were holdovers from the previous administration and knew nothing of Mr. Koeppel's role in the campaign.
Mr. Lauer said that major landlords challenge the city's estimates of the value of their properties every year as a matter of course, and that no one is given special treatment. The corporation counsel's office handles nearly 25,000 appeals a year, he said.
"This is not political," Mr. Lauer said. "This is based on numbers."
Mr. Koeppel and his father refused to be interviewed for this article.
Mayoral aides say Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Koeppel are not close friends. Mr. Koeppel is not, for instance, influential enough to have access to the Mayor whenever he likes. And in putting together his administration, Mr. Giuliani has hardly treated Mr. Koeppel as a favored son despite his financial support.
Senior Giuliani aides said Mr. Koeppel, who contributed $5,700 to Mr. Giuliani's 1993 campaign and raised a total of $78,000, wanted to be named the Consumer Affairs Commissioner, a highly visible position that can be a launching pad for politicians. But in the end, Mr. Giuliani selected Alfred Cerrullo, a Staten Island Councilman, and offered Mr. Koeppel a lesser job -- an unpaid position on the board of the Off-Track Betting Corporation.
"We didn't even reward him for being a fund-raiser," said the campaign aide, who requested that his name not be used. "We certainly wouldn't reward him for giving apartments to low-level campaign staff."
Members of the Koeppel family say Mr. Koeppel's eagerness to please Mr. Giuliani flows not only from political ambition but also from an almost boyish admiration for the Mayor and his staff.
"His generosity got him into trouble," said Howard Koeppel, a cousin. "He likes Giuliani and he likes the people the Mayor surrounds himself with. He wants to be a friend. He wants people to like him."
John Gross, the Giuliani campaign treasurer, said Mr. Koeppel looked up to the Mayor. "He has an incredible admiration and affection for Rudy that is more intense than I've seen coming from almost anybody else," Mr. Gross said.
Since Mr. Giuliani won office, Mr. Koeppel has used his contacts in City Hall to suggest some minor policy changes, city officials said.
For instance, Mr. Koeppel approached John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, after a North Carolina boat company from which he had bought a fishing boat complained about the high cost of showing at a boat show in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Mr. Koeppel helped set up meetings between Mr. Dyson and the sponsors of the show to discuss the high costs, Mr. Dyson said.
Some family members said Mr. Koeppel has courted Mr. Giuliani because he hopes to someday win elective office, despite a crushing defeat in his 1990 Congressional race.
"He aspires to have a political career," said his aunt, Nancy Koeppel. "I guess he felt if he could associate himself with someone successful and popular he could climb up the ladder."
Mr. Koeppel, who is 34 years old, grew up in a wealthy New York real-estate family, dividing his time between his parents' Fifth Avenue apartment and a summer home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He has lived a life of private schools, yachts and country clubs, secure in the knowledge that he would inherit a substantial real-estate business from his father, his family members said.
Mr. Koeppel attended the Bentley School in Manhattan and graduated from Adelphi University in 1981. After college, Mr. Koeppel attended Cardozo Law School in New York, though his study habits were irregular and he used to regularly fly to Florida on Thursday nights for long weekends, family members said. He graduated in 1984, but failed three times to pass the bar exam. He later sued the bar, saying the test was unfair to him because he was dyslexic. The case is pending.
Boats are Mr. Koeppel's private passion, said his spokesman, Gary Lewi. He owns a 46-foot Hatteras fishing craft, the Sahara, moored at the Tide Mill Yacht Basin in Rye, N.Y. He has spent over $1 million on the boat, adding such luxuries as chrome finish for the engines and a high-tech satellite navigational system.
As a real-estate executive, Mr. Koeppel has neither expanded the family's holdings nor hurt them, real estate executives said. He has yet to develop any property and has no projects in the works that would need city approval.
From an early age, Mr. Koeppel was sometimes hostile in dealings with cousins and siblings, several family members said, but the source of the animosity is hard to pinpoint.
In January, he used his influence in the new Giuliani administration to persuade the Finance Department to start a tax investigation of his relatives, Alfred and Bevin Koeppel, who own a separate real-estate company by the same name.
In 1964, the orginal Koeppel & Koeppel company was split in two by its owners, Max and Harry Koeppel, two brothers who over the previous three decades had built a small portfolio of properties into a sizable real- estate conglomerate controlling several office towers and East Side apartment buildings. Mr. Koeppel's father, Harry Koeppel's son, inherited several residential buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
Max Koeppel's sons, Alfred and Bevin, ended up with several office towers in Manhattan. Having lost many tenants in the recession, they have fallen behind on mortgage payments and taxes on their office tower at 575 Lexington Avenue and are in danger of losing the building.
Only a few weeks into the new administration's term, Mr. Koeppel requested a meeting in person with the Finance Commissioner, Marc V. Shaw. He charged that his cousins had cheated on their taxes by having work performed on their private homes paid for by their company, city officials said. Mr. Shaw referred the accusations to city investigators.
Alfred Koeppel denied the charges and said Mr. Koeppel had tried several times in the past to discredit his relatives. In the late 1970's, he said, Mr. Koeppel spread a damaging rumor in New York and Palm Beach business circles that his cousins were going bankrupt, he said.
"Billy has had some kind of perceived vendetta on my brother and me for a number of years," Alfred Koeppel said. "He was like a gnat. I had to swat him away. But now he's turned into a hornet."
Through his spokesman, Mr. Koeppel maintained that the feud began after his relatives tried to block him from membership at various country clubs on Long Island.
The family dispute reached an apex this year when Mr. Koeppel boasted to a reporter from The New York Observer that he had used his influence with Mr. Giuliani to denounce his relatives as tax evaders. In the article, Mr. Koeppel said of his relatives: "They're snakes and when you get a snake on the ground, you cut its head off."
Mr. Koeppel later sent copies of the Observer article to contractors and vendors with whom he does business to show that he has nothing to do with the other side of the family, his cousins said.
Mr. Koeppel's desire to distance himself from the financial troubles of his relatives may flow from his political ambitions. He got involved in Republican politics in 1987 when he became a fund-raiser for the Bushcampaign. He was also a major fund-raiser for Mr. Giuliani in 1989, collecting $103,400 from dozens of people, including many of his tenants and contractors.
The next year, Mr. Koeppel mounted a quixotic campaign to unseat Representative Theodore Weiss, the longtime Democratic Congressman from the Upper West Side of Manhattan who was considered to have an impregnable hold on the 17th District until his death in 1992.
Despite the odds, Mr. Koeppel ran anyway, spending nearly $264,000 of his own money and $150,000 from other contributors on a campaign that earned him little respect even in Republican political circles. He got less than 20 percent of the vote. "That campaign proved one thing," one Koeppel campaign adviser said. "Money alone can't beat a candidate."

HEADLINE: Contradiction Marks Revival In Real Estate

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
As the region's real-estate market slowly emerges from a five-year hibernation, buyers and sellers in both New York City and the surrounding areas are finding what seems to be a very selective and at times contradictory recovery.
Long spoiled by years of having the upper hand in most transactions, some buyers are finding that owners cannot be squeezed on prices anymore; others have found a dearth of available homes in good locations. 
 Yet a look through real-estate classified advertisements makes clear that many sellers of both apartments and houses are still desperate for deals. "Priced to Sell," "Owner Anxious," and "No Reasonable Offer Refused" were the come-ons some sellers used in their newspaper advertisements on a recent Sunday.
In Manhattan, for instance, there is a premium on family-sized apartments, priced between $200,000 and $250,000, especially those in buildings that were put up before World War II and have doormen. Since the year began, the most sales activity for Manhattan co-ops was seen in that price range, according to the Real Estate Board of New York.
But for studios and run-of-the-mill one-bedroom apartments, bank foreclosure auctions seem to be the only enticing bait.
In the suburbs, town houses in condominium developments are still a hard sell. But real-estate brokers say owners who have not priced their homes above the market and who live in neighborhoods with highly rated schools often have buyers waiting in line.
And while sellers have found the market a bit topsy-turvy, buyers are finding their expectations confounded by the new realities. Sean Kiely, who wants to move his family from Yonkers to Scarsdale or Eastchester, says he has seen a steady decline in the number of available homes in his price range -- up to $350,000.
"It's gotten to the point where brokers are beginning to take me to places I have already seen," said Mr. Kiely, who has passed on many homes he felt were not worth the money.
The partial recovery, real-estate brokers say, reflects a renewed faith among buyers in the economy and in their own financial situations. The recent increases in mortgage interest rates have been a further prod for many buyers who worry that the rates could go even higher. But if they do rise much further, potential buyers could be forced to the sidelines.
Statistics provided by industry trade groups reflect the inconsistency of the market.
In Westchester County, the median price of single-family homes has inched up a bit, to $279,500 in the first quarter of this year from $271,350 in the same period of 1993, according to the local Board of Realtors. But during the same time, co-ops lost value, dropping to a median of $71,000 from $75,000. The median price is a middle value, with half of the sales prices above the median and half below.
In Manhattan the Real Estate Board of New York reported that values for co-ops on the Upper West Side were 24 percent higher during the first quarter of 1994 than in the first quarter of 1993. But for reasons the board cannot explain, on Riverside Drive and West End Avenue the median price dropped to $388,556 during the first quarter of 1994 from $414,875 in the first quarter of 1993.
On the East Side of Manhattan, the board figures showed, the median price for co-ops increased 12 percent between the last quarter of 1993 and the first quarter this year. Yet prices for the first quarter of 1994 were 13 percent lower than for the same period in 1993.
For years, the region's real-estate market was essentially frozen, with many potential sellers refusing to take losses on property they bought when the market was high, and buyers fearful of putting money into homes they might not be able to sell.
 
Voracious Appetite
 This created a pent-up demand that brought buyers out in droves last winter, despite the region's record snow storms. In part, brokers said, the money driving the market came from New Year's bonuses from Wall Street and other industries that have seen good years recently.
"I can only describe the appetite of buyers last winter as voracious," said Bud Prince, a partner in Prince & Ripley, a real-estate brokerage company in Rye, N.Y. Mr. Prince said he brokered one deal last winter in which a potential buyer was so anxious to be first in line to bid on a house that he made an offer even though he had not set foot inside in 10 years.
"He had seen the house the last time it was on the market," Mr. Prince said. "He was sorry he did not buy it then."
That same sort of appetite may have been at work in Trish Hogan's neighborhood in Summit, N.J. After accepting a job in Virginia earlier this year, she told her new employer not to expect her until summer, figuring she might need a few months to sell her home. But the week after her open house in February, Ms. Hogan watched with amazement as a bidding war broke out. When the dust settled, Ms. Hogan got $507,000 for her three-bedroom Colonial -- $18,000 more than her asking price.
The five-bedroom red-brick house next door is under contract for $579,000, the asking price, and the owners of a three-bedroom English Tudor nearby have a deal close to their asking price of $549,000. "Summit is a great community," Ms. Hogan said before leaving for Virginia. "I knew I'd find a buyer. But I thought the economy would make it harder for me to sell."
Marcia Miller, on the other hand, who owns a four-bedroom Colonial in the Westchester County community of Crestwood, has had no such luck. Since January dozens of prospective buyers have seen the house, but so far there have been no serious bids on the $249,000 price she and her roommate are seeking. "We didn't necessarily expect it to be easy," she said, "but we thought we would have some offers by now."
One thing that has surprised brokers has been what they say is a significant demand from families who want to stay in the city -- or even to come back again after having moved away earlier.
"Two years ago many of our listings came from families trying to get out of New York," said Jo Anne Kennedy, a principal in Hunt Kennedy, a brokerage company in Manhattan. "People are still moving away, but there is not this desperate desire to leave the city as there was before."
She credits the election of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as a factor in the turnaround because buyers believe he has made the middle class a priority.
One family moving back to the city is Edward and Leslie Powers and their children, who moved from Manhattan six years ago to live in Caldwell, N.J. After selling their home the weekend it was put on the market, the couple saw dozens of apartments before settling on one in a prewar building on the Upper West Side. Even then, they almost lost their apartment to another couple in a bidding war. Mr. Powers declined to say how much he and his wife paid, but two-bedroom apartments like theirs are selling for $369,000, according to the Real Estate Board.
In the city, the market's wallflowers continue to be mainly dark and dreary studio apartments and most of the thousands of charmless one-bedroom units that went up during the 1980's building boom. For several consecutive Sundays, Taylor Hanex watched potential buyers poke around the studio she is trying to sell on West 69th Street. Despite a price cut, from $92,000 to $85,000, she has had barely a ripple of interest.
The paradox for Ms. Hanex and others in her situation is that as a rental, her apartment has held its value. She has been able to get as much as $1,350 a month for her apartment, which is completely furnished, but her co-op limits renting to two years. She has run out of time.
Foreclosure auctions continue to be magnets for bottom fishers. Celestina Dadzie emerged from an auction last month with a $120,000 contract for a two-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath apartment on York Avenue with views of the East River. In that neighborhood, some sellers are asking $200,000 and more for similar apartments.
"I've been looking for years," said Ms. Dadzie. "I kept hearing that prices were dropping and the market was bad. But I did not see anything I thought was worth the money."
While many real-estate agents and executives view the current changes with optimism, they do not believe the market is headed toward its giddy heights of a decade ago.
"Even in categories where the market is very strong, buyers and sellers seem to be more realistic," said Christopher Thomas, a vice president of William B. May, a real-estate company. "Sales are faster because both sides are close when it comes to prices," said Mr. Thomas, who is based in Brooklyn Heights and Park Slope.
Not all sellers would agree.
Cheryl Dent, who put her four-story limestone row house on the market for $250,000, said the first offers were so low as to be "insulting."
"One couple offered $150,000," said Mrs. Dent whose house is on a landmarked block in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. But Ms. Dent held her ground. Last month she signed a contract to sell it for $230,000.
"These homes are the kinds of places they are not building anymore," said Ms. Dent, who has a home furnishing design business. "People appreciate that. You just have to wait until they come along."

HEADLINE: How Low the Dollar?;
U.S. Wants Currency to Reach Own Level To Help Economy and Clinton's Re-election

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration keeps insisting that its decision to let the dollar reach its own level is the right one, even though currency traders plainly do not: the dollar has sunk by one-sixth against the German mark this year and reached a postwar low against the Japanese yen.
Strikingly, though, President Clinton is winning points from economists who are more concerned about jobs and corporate profits than the number of yen or marks that a dollar will buy next Tuesday. The White House's "rhetoric has been a heck of a lot worse than its policy," said Peter Kenen, an economist at Princeton University. 
 In fact, said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, what has been dubbed President Clinton's "benign neglect" of exchange rates is an evolving policy intended to serve both the American economy and the President's prospects for re-election. "The average person could care less about the dollar's decline," he said.
 
Above the Record Low
 On Friday, the dollar fell to 97.86 yen in late New York trading, though still above the record low of 96.60 yen set on Tuesday. The dollar was little changed at 1.554 marks.
If exchange rates could be stabilized without pain or fuss, the industrial countries would no doubt choose to stabilize their currencies at exchange rates that reflected their competitiveness in world markets -- rates that make the dollar worth more, the yen and the mark, less. That is what they have tried to do half-heartedly for the last month, purchasing tens of billions of dollars on the currency markets.
But the intervention has not worked, and for reasons that (after the fact) seem obvious. With corporations and investment institutions holding trillions of dollars worth of liquid assets that can be turned into other currencies at the touch of a computer key, the sums necessary to turn the stampeding herd have become staggering.
Indeed, Mr. Kenen said, it is now conventional wisdom that currency market intervention is effective only when it is reinforced by changes in underlying economic policies. For example, a Government-engineered rise in America's short-term interest rates combined with reductions in rates available in German marks might accomplish what buying dollars and selling marks did not.
 
Reason for Every Country
 Why, then, didn't the Group of Seven choose this route? For reasons peculiar to each of the major economies, said Van Doorn Ooms, research director of the Committee for Economic Development in Washington. All of this boils down to the reality that exchange rate stability is nobody's highest priority.
Arguably, Washington should be under the most psychological pressure to act since the dollar is the weak link in the currency chain. But as Mr. Hormats said, the howls for higher interest rates from Wall Street are more than offset by the White House's conviction that higher rates would undermine domestic policy.
America's economic recovery, it is widely agreed, is on track. But few of the President's men and women would be happy to risk another interest rate increase that would cut into private spending sometime in 1995.
Inflation is, of course, a concern to some. And the depressed value of the dollar does translate into higher prices for imports and American-made goods that compete with imports. But with foreign products and services representing just 10 percent of American consumption and the Consumer Price Index climbing at a leisurely 3 percent pace, no one in the White House sees inflation as a clear and present danger.
Indeed, some increases in prices could buttress the President's re-election campaign. Thanks to the high-flying Japanese yen (which makes Toyota and company less competitive in American markets), the Big Three auto makers will set profit records this year. And what's good for Detroit is good for those on its payroll. Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich has bragged that since the start of President Clinton's tenure, some 150,000 jobs had been created in the auto industry.
What's good for American producers, of course, is bad for their European and Japanese competitors. That, in fact, is why currency speculators figured that Washington had quietly abetted a decline in the value of the dollar after the collapse of trade talks with Japan last spring. Why, then, don't Europe and Japan fill the void left by the passive Americans, depreciating their own currencies through interest rate cuts or fiscal stimulus?
Mr. Kenen said that Europe (dominated by Germany) had yet to feel sufficient economic pinch to act. The European Union is growing, though with less vigor than the American economy. And German policy makers who wish to stimulate output in general and exports in particular still have less influence than the conservatives who control monetary policy at the central banks.
"The Europeans," Mr. Ooms said, "have learned to live with very high unemployment."
Japan is the more puzzling case since the overvalued yen seems destined to price Japanese companies out of world markets -- and price the Japanese economy back into recession. But the crazy-quilt political coalition now in charge seems unable to act decisively in the face of opposition from the inflation-obsessed bureaucracy at the Ministry of Finance. As Mr. Kenen puts it, "nobody's there to answer the phone."
All this suggests that currency neglect, benign or otherwise, is the order of the day. Does it also mean there is no bottom in sight for the dollar? While "currency speculation is self-limiting," Mr. Ooms said, there is no solid theory to explain when the brakes will catch. In fact the only circumstance in which almost everyone agrees that currency intervention would be inevitable is the "free fall" -- in which the dollar's use as a global store of value and means of exchange is threatened.
If speculation fed speculation -- if, for example, the dollar fell by another 10 or 15 percent in a matter of weeks -- the Group of Seven would most likely halt the process with coordinated changes in interest rates backed by huge purchases of dollars.
But the very fact that most experts assume that the free fall would bring on decisive intervention makes free fall very unlikely. Hence for the foreseeable future, Mr. Hormats predicted, "Main Street's interests will diverge from Wall Street's," and the dollar's exchange value will remain a low priority.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Nagging liquidity questions put a damper on T.W.A.'s stock.

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant 

 BODY:
DONALD F. CRAIB Jr., the chairman of Trans World Airlines, has made good on several predictions he made when he took over in January, save for a crucial one: the company has had to seek additional capital, despite Mr. Craib's statement that it would not need to do so.
And it is the specter of a liquidity crisis at the nation's seventh-largest airline, raised recently in reports by the Standard & Poor's and Duff & Phelps credit rating agencies, that has weighed heavily on the airline's stock price in recent weeks. T.W.A. has missed out on the modest rebound of several airline stocks recently, and many industry analysts are skeptical about its future. 
 "There are too many airlines, and T.W.A. is a vulnerable franchise," said Kevin C. Murphy, an airline stock analyst at Morgan Stanley.
T.W.A.'s shares were unchanged on Friday at $2.6875 on the American Stock Exchange.
The airline certainly cannot be accused of sitting still. Since January, for example, the chairman and two vice chairman of T.W.A. have been replaced.
On Thursday, the company said it had "empowered a companywide task force to remake the airline."
T.W.A. employees, who own a 45 percent stake in the carrier after giving up $660 million in concessions over three years, also said recently that they would cover lease payments on a jet the carrier wanted to add to its fleet.
The airline's new president, Jeffrey H. Erickson, said he was halfway through his goal of cutting $135 million from the company's expenses to insure it had enough cash to make it through the winter.
T.W.A. recently laid off 255 employees at its aircraft overhaul base in Kansas City, Mo., and said it might lay off several more hundred by the end of the year.
Despite the cuts, the airline said it expected to expand its route system by 10.9 percent by the end of the year, fulfilling one of Mr. Craib's early promises. Mr. Craib also said he would foster a sense of urgency at the airline and involve employees more in the company's day-to-day operations.
The challenge Mr. Erickson faces is to cut costs without hurting revenues. In a recent interview, he said he was also trying to refinance $190 million of asset-based loans extended by Carl C. Icahn, the airline's former owner, that come due in January.
If it does not fulfill those goals, "T.W.A. could face a liquidity shortfall during the winter of 1994-1995," Standard & Poor's said in a recent report.
In a recent Duff & Phelps report, the agency said it did not believe the airline would be able to obtain additional financing like a revolving line of credit because of its "current capital structure, poor operating performance and limited prospects in an industry characterized by overcapacity."
In the first quarter, T.W.A.'s revenues increased 8.2 percent, to $760.6 million from $702.7 million, after the airline increased its capacity 8 percent. Its operating loss narrowed to $79.6 million in the quarter, from $93.4 million.
Its cash position at the end of the first quarter was $134.9 million, compared with $170.4 million in the quarter a year earlier. At the end of 1993, the airline's cash position was $163 million.
If a cash shortage at T.W.A. sounds at all familiar, it should. Industry analysts have been predicting since 1992 that the airline would not make it through the following winter.
And like T.W.A. executives before him, Mr. Erickson, the former chief executive of Reno Air, dismisses predictions of the carrier's demise.
"We can accomplish what we need to accomplish," he said. "Otherwise, I wouldn't have joined the company."

HEADLINE: Shipbuilding Pact Reached Amid French Protest

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 17

 BODY:
Major shipbuilding nations agreed today after five years of negotiations to scrap subsidies to their shipyards, but France rejected the deal, negotiators said.
The accord between officials of the United States, the European Union, Japan, Korea and the Nordic states was hammered out at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and is seen as the widest plan yet to impose discipline on the ailing industry, delegates said. 
 "If we had failed there would have been a subsidy war, that is quite clear," said the Swedish Ambassador to the Paris-based organization, Staffan Sohlman, who was chairman of the final round of the talks.
The unsigned agreement must be ratified by all participants and would take effect on Jan. 1, 1996, he said. It would be reviewed three years later.
But France swiftly divorced itself from the pact and made clear it would oppose it inside the European Union, delegates said. Union member nations were represented at the talks by the Brussels-based European Commission.
France's opposition came in a statement read to a special final session by a French delegate, who went to the organization's headquarters after Paris tried unsuccessfully to have the proceedings adjourned.
Details were not made public, but one delegate said, "The French are not behind the agreement."
Paris argues that scrapping subsidies would harm it against competitors, including some European Union partners, who indirectly aid the ship industry in ways that France cannot, officials said.
Several delegates said the question of jobs at France's two big shipyards, Saint-Lazaire and Le Havre, appeared to be particularly sensitive a year before presidential elections.
France alone could not stop a qualified majority vote in the European Council of Ministers, except by invoking the "Luxembourg Compromise," a GATT-related formula seen as a powerful but possibly contentious tool, diplomats said.
The issue could be raised as early as Monday, when the union's General Affairs Council meets in Brussels.
Meanwhile, delegates highlighted the ambitious scope of the draft shipbuilding accord, described by a United States official as "much more comprehensive than any other sectoral agreement."
If ratified, it would be the first legally binding international trade pact ever negotiated by the organization, normally a sedate economic research center for industrialized nations.
The accord came almost exactly 24 hours after the United States and the European Commission, in an all-night session, buried differences over the Jones Act, which bans foreign-built or foreign-owned ships from United States coastal trade.
Long decried as unfair by Europeans, and regarded as politically sacred in the United States, the act will remain in place, delegates said. But unspecified countermeasures will be available if it is shown to be misused.
A proposal before Congress to fine subsidized ships on entry would also probably be sidelined, they said.
The 100-page deal includes the first "injurious pricing" code for the ship industry, drawn up in response to European concerns over Japanese and Korean pricing and regarded as a quid-pro-quo for the abolition of subsidies, delegates said.
It also overhauls dispute settlement procedures and creates a new procedure for export credits, they added.
But the effect on shipyard jobs as subsidies decline remains less clear. "To the extent that the agreement leads to a more stable situation, it should make jobs, if not more secure, then less influenced by fluctuations," Mr. Sohlman said.
Other delegates acknowledged that less competitive yards might have to close without state support, but said a price free-for-all would be worse.
"The point is that we'll at last have a reasonably level playing field," one negotiator said.

HEADLINE: Telmex in Competition, So Far With Just Itself

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO

 BODY:
It took a four-mule team to carry supplies to the top of the 6,000-foot mountain where a crew from Telefonos de Mexico built a relay station that only recently connected this desert mining town to Mexico's telephone network.
Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, as it is known, has little chance of making money in this town of 1,500 separated by 10 miles of desert and a craggy mountain range from the United States border. The town is too isolated and too small for profitable service. 
 Yet Telmex has been adding or improving service anyway in towns like this all across Mexico, because in return, this national telecommunications company -- until 1990, a state-owned enterprise -- was allowed to keep its monopoly on long-distance service, at least until the end of 1996.
 
Open Market Planned
 But with the end of that monopoly growing nearer every day, Telmex has learned -- to its dismay -- that the Government is planning a telecommunications market that will be more wide open than the company had expected. Regulators now say that there will be no limit to the number of competing companies that can enter the long-distance market.
 While the Government plan should benefit consumers by making calls cheaper, it will deprive Telmex of some revenue, and Telmex stock has fallen from earlier this year.
Still, most brokerage houses aggressively rate the company's stock a buy. The potential for growth is enormous. As the North American Free Trade Agreement encourages trade and development, the need for modern telecommunications will increase substantially over the next decade.
Telmex knows this market better than any potential competitor, and investors are impressed with its successes in improving local service. To add to Telmex's attractiveness, the company will keep its local-service monopoly until 2026.
"The theme is perfect," said Ricardo Peon, a telecommunications analyst with the Baring Securities office in Mexico City. "You've got Nafta, very low line density, rising per capita income -- all the perfect ingredients for strong telecommunications growth."
That of course is a prime reason that nearly every major telecommunications company in North America is interested in a piece of the long-distance action. Already, more than a dozen companies, including Bell Atlantic, MCI and Motorola, have formed joint ventures with Mexican banks and telecommunications companies. AT&T, which already handles 60 percent of long-distance calls to the United States, is thought to be ready to join with Telmex in a separate long-distance subsidiary.
At stake are more than just the profits and losses of one of Mexico's largest companies. Because Telmex stock accounts for 26 percent of the total capitalization of the Bolsa, the Mexican stock exchange, and 23 percent of its daily volume, even a rumor about disappointing earnings can cause the market to stumble.
Telmex is also important outside Mexico. The company's stock, through substitute paper called depository receipts, is usually among the most active issues traded on Wall Street. Since it was privatized in 1990, Telmex has served as one of Mexico's most reliable sources of foreign capital. Of the company's $33.5 billion capitalization, 60 percent is held by foreigners, mostly Americans.
 
A National Issue
 For Mexico, there is an even larger issue: how prepared is the nation to embrace open competition.
The privatization of Telmex in 1990, part of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's larger plan to modernize the Mexican economy, was one of the largest and most ambitious such efforts ever undertaken. Under a $1.76 billion contract, the Government sold its controlling stake in Telmex to a consortium comprising Southwestern Bell, France Telecom and Grupo Carso, a Mexican holding company owned by Carlos Slim Helu -- one of the richest men in Mexico, who soon became even richer.
Now Mexican regulators must decide how to enforce the privatization contract without harming Telmex and, by extension, the Mexican economy. They also have to figure out how to provide the competition that would help consumers with better service and lower rates without hurting Telmex's ability to fulfill its social obligations -- providing Manuel Benavides with phones, for example. Serving ordinary Mexicans has become more compelling since an armed rebellion shook the southeastern state of Chiapas early this year.
The rural program that just reached Manuel Benavides is one of Telmex's successes, and it illustrates how sensitive the regulators' decisions are likely to be.
Situated in a desert bowl surrounded by high mountains, Manuel Benavides is typical of the small communities bypassed by Telmex before the company was required to install at least one telephone in every town of 500 or more people before the end of 1994, as a quid pro quo for its six-year monopoly on long-distance service.
Until recently, said Baltazar Trujillo Chavez, a former mayor of Manuel Benavides, long-distance communication was possible only by shortwave radio.
 
Expensive Satellite Service
 In 1986, the state of Chihuahua hired a private company to install a satellite phone in Manuel Benavides, a service residents say was unreliable and quite expensive. With the new Telmex radio relay, the town will have three lines, much clearer connections and service that is significantly less expensive, said Gerardo Garza Varela, a Telmex engineer. If 100 residents are interested, Telmex may someday install home phones.
"We used to be an almost forgotten place, like many in Mexico," Mr. Trujillo said. "But with these new services, we can have a much more satisfactory life here."
For years, telling stories of Telmex's ineptitude and corruption was a favorite pastime throughout Mexico -- except in communities like Manuel Benavides that did not yet have telephones. Crossed lines, erratic service and bungled connections were for years the order of the day. Many public phones in downtown Mexico City are free because that is the only way to keep them from being vandalized by frustrated callers.
Some things have changed. Half the lines now in service in Mexico have been installed since 1990, and this year Telmex expects to put in 1.5 million more, at a cost to the consumer of about $600 a line. There is room to grow. Mexico has 8.8 phone lines per 100 inhabitants, far lower than the ratio of 51.5 per 100 in the United States, but a 33 percent rise over its 6.6 lines per 100 in 1990. Telmex has doubled the number of public pay phones, provided digital service on nearly 70 percent of its lines and built a national fiber optic network.
"They've generally met the conditions of the concession," said Gabriel Szekely, a Mexico City consultant who has studied Telmex operations for several years. "They've been doing the right things but doing them too slowly, considering they've got competition coming in."
 
Telmex Is Shocked
 The process of ending the long-distance monopoly started last year with a general proposal from Telmex, as Government regulations required. The potential competitors then had six months to review it and file objections. But to Telmex's shock, regulators from the Communications and Transportation Ministry rejected the Telmex plan for 10 interconnection points, through which all long-distance calls would have to pass no matter which company handled them. Instead, the regulators approved a plan for 200 such points, to be available by the year 2000.
The Telmex plan had obvious benefits -- for Telmex. All its long-distance competitors would have had to pay fees, based on time and distance, for the use of local telephone lines to the interconnection points. With 200 rather than 10 interconnection points, long-distance callers will be spending far less time on Telmex's local network, and Telmex's competitors spending far less on fees.
Regulators here said there would be no limit on the number of competing companies that can enter the long-distance market. But they did not set a date for selecting them. The issue is politically sensitive. Presidential elections are scheduled for Aug. 21, and for the first time in decades, the outcome is uncertain. The regulators did, however, authorize presubscription plans similar to those in the United States in which customers contract with a long-distance service for a set time.
Local service now makes up 43 percent of Telmex's $7.4 billion a year in sales, while long-distance calls generate more than half the company's revenues and much of its profits. Telmex has started preparing for competition, limiting its reliance on long-distance by lowering those rates and at the same time raising the cost of local calls.
"In the long run, what's best for efficiency is best for the economy," said Santiago Levy Algazi, head of the newly created National Commission on Competition.
But is stiff competition best for Telmex? "Maybe yes," Mr. Levy said, "maybe no."

HEADLINE: DANCE REVIEW;
A Bawdy and Comic Thai Troupe

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
The performers of the Pathumsilp Troupe of Phetburi, Thailand, find work by hanging out their sign in the courtyard of the city temple and waiting for patrons to come by. It is hard to imagine they are unemployed for long, given the irresistibly goofy humor and quick improvisatory skills the company displayed in a program of Lakhon Chatri, one of Thailand's oldest forms of dance-drama, on Saturday night at the Asia Society.
After three short traditional music and dance introductions, the troupe presented selections from "Phra Apaimani," which tells the story of a prince with a magic flute and his escape from a seductive sea-demon that once kidnapped him and wants him back. A burst of flute music eventually does in the demon, who dies with all the gurgling pathos of Margaret Hamilton in "The Wizard of Oz." The story then switches to a boy's attempts to save his mermaid mother from a lustful pirate. 
 Lakhon Chatri is performed by groups who travel through the Thai countryside, their services in demand as payment to the gods for favors received by grateful supplicants. The relatively modern style presented by the Pathumsilp company draws on traditional Buddhist tales, but departs from them with vernacular, often bawdy comic embellishment.
The selections from "Phra Apaimani" incorporated jokes about New York's high-rise buildings, french fries, Levi jeans and the air-conditioning in the Asia Society auditorium. One prop was a large plastic bottle of Coca-Cola. When the prince's traveling companion asked the demon for water to block his ears from the flute music, a musician ambled offstage and returned with a paper cup into which the demon pretended to urinate. The performers chatted with one another throughout, and one absent-mindedly used a handy prop to sweep a bit of debris from the floor.
One of the great charms of the evening, aside from the idea of such wild humor enlisted to appease the gods, was the way the performers and narrator frequently burst into infectious laughter over one another's antics. But this spirited play was clearly the work of trained and gifted actors and musicians who smoothly blended high chanting song, a simple gliding form of dance with palms upturned and undulating, and most of all, quick comic inspiration. Instrumentalists offered witty commentary and encouraging bursts of gleaming, lilting, raucous sound on drums, finger cymbals, wooden clappers and a wooden xylophone with a splendid musical life of its own.
Anucha Tang-on played a prince with long false eyelashes and blusher, and Pipila Tang-on was the delightfully shrewish demon. Pornthip Boonnung was the hyperactive son, Charan Chaithong the demure mermaid and Boontham Kaewprasit the determined pirate. But the show was almost stolen by Khanittha Chantrarasuk, whose nonchalant clowning in a variety of roles seemed to embody the tradition of Lakhon Chatri. Surapone Virulrak was the wry narrator. The troupe, which is directed by Temduang Wanna, also included Janya Kalnin and Chamroen Kerdrod.

HEADLINE: The German Special Relationship

 BODY:
Germany marked the passing of an era last Tuesday with the departure of U.S. troops from Berlin and the formal end of four-power occupation. President Clinton and Chancellor Helmut Kohl stood side by side at the Brandenburg Gate, where the Berlin wall once divided and disfigured the city. Germany's highest court that very day confirmed that the country's Constitution poses no impediment to involving German troops in military operations abroad. That is reassuring for those who believe Germany needs to carry its weight in securing Europe.
But the issues of America's troop presence and Germany's military role have obscured the changed relationship between the two countries. Once Germany was militarily dependent on NATO and deferred to American wishes; now the two cooperate as equals with common interests. 
 Those interests are now more economic than military. Both countries -- unlike much of Western Europe -- see the need to open markets to struggling economies in the East and to integrate all the East and West politically. As President Clinton said in Berlin, "trade, as much as troops," will bind nations in the next century.
The U.S. commitment to German security remains firm, though its importance has declined with the Soviet Union's demise. Continued cooperation between the countries is still essential, however, to deal with today's security concerns -- instability in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union resulting from traumatic economic and political transformation.
German troops must play their part; Germany is now a normal nation capable of sharing the security burden.
German politicians had hidden behind the Constitution whenever the question of committing troops abroad came up. But the real impediments remain historical and political. They accounted for the reluctance to join the coalition against Iraq: Germany did not want to give any sign of military assertiveness at the time of unification. Later, Germany hastened to recognize the independence of Croatia and Slovenia, which was right. But Germany was irresponsible to urge others to stand up to Serbia while it was inhibited from taking its own advice by its World War II legacy.
Now that the court has said a majority vote of Parliament will suffice to send troops abroad, the political impediment remains. No German government is likely to plunge ahead without a sizable majority and strong international approval, and Germany is likely to confine itself to peacekeeping.
But Germany's military contribution may be less important to future German-American relations than the economic and political commitments it shares with the United States.
Both countries have a stake in promoting the East's recovery by giving it access to Western markets. Both want to see Europe's political culture and security community extended eastward to Russia. Neither can afford a resumption of Russo-German rivalry over Eastern Europe. Together, they could reassure Russia and its neighbors; that means finding new ways to work with Moscow on security matters. Those shared values make the German-American relationship special.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Arsenals Abroad;
Export Control For the 1990's

BYLINE: By Sam Gejdenson and Toby Roth; Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, and Toby Roth, Republican of Wisconsin, are members of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Economic Policy, Trade and Environment.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The United States' system for controlling sales of technology abroad was built in the cold war, a time when the U.S. and its allies dominated export markets and controlled critical technologies. That world no longer exists. As Congress begins debate this week on a new Export Administration Act to replace the one that expired in June, it has a chance to transform the system from a cold war relic into one that responds to the security needs and economic challenges of the 1990's.
The stakes are high. The Export Administration Act governs the export of "dual use" goods and technologies -- computers, telecommunications equipment, machine tools, electronics, aerospace products and other commercial items that can also have military applications. These are our most technologically advanced industries. They offer high-wage, high-skilled jobs. Growth in these job-creating sectors depends on exports. If export controls are poorly conceived, these sectors -- and U.S. competitiveness -- will suffer. 
 Our bill would reshape the system in three ways. First, it would toughen U.S. policies to counter the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, perhaps the most serious national security threat in the post-cold-war era. Second, it would reduce unnecessary and burdensome controls on exports to friendly countries. Third, it would set new deadlines to eliminate export licensing delays that harm U.S. exporters and U.S. workers.
 To meet the threat of proliferation, the bill would prohibit the export of any item that an exporter knows would contribute to the design, development or manufacture of a weapon of mass destruction or a missile, even if the item was not on any international export control list. This would be the most far-reaching provision of its kind ever enacted. The bill would block the sale of dual-use technology to terrorist countries. No item that could be used in nuclear, chemical, biological or even conventional warfare could be sold to Iran, Iraq, Syria, Libya or North Korea. This would be the most restrictive export control ever imposed on countries that support terrorism.
 We should not, however, treat our allies the same way we treat terrorist countries. To remove unnecessary burdens on U.S. exporters, the bill would allow American businesses to sell high-technology items without licenses as long as the foreign buyer participated with the U.S. in an export control agreement. For example, computers could be sold to Britain and machine tools to Japan without first coming to the U.S. Government.
 This provision simply recognizes reality. The European Union will soon abolish export licensing among its members, and this provision would allow U.S. business to operate on a level playing field with foreign competitors. It would also provide an incentive for other countries to sign up: they could receive our exports much more quickly.
 The bill would cut back on U.S. reliance on unilateral export controls, which in today's world are rarely successful in keeping technology from nations that are determined to get it. As the National Academy of Sciences put it in a 1991 report, "Unilateralism disadvantages the U.S. economy and can rarely be justified in a competitive world economy by security concerns."
 The U.S., for example, recently imposed unilateral sanctions on China for its sale of missile technology to other countries. The effect was to prohibit American companies from selling communications satellites to China, jeopardizing thousands of jobs in California, a state hard hit by military spending cuts. After the U.S. action, Germany cinched a deal for $1.5 billion in satellite sales to China. The Chinese got their satellites, the Germans got their windfall and U.S. workers could now get pink slips.
 While reducing reliance on unilateral controls, the bill would preserve the President's ability to impose unilateral controls when our national security was at stake and when unilateral controls were likely to achieve their objectives.
 The bill would also expedite licensing. American companies suffer a competitive disadvantage because of endless bureaucratic infighting. Three years after President George Bush approved a license for a supercomputer sale to India, for example, the license was still stalled in the bureaucracy -- and India has now replicated the 11-year-old technology. No wonder U.S. companies have a reputation for being unreliable suppliers. To correct this problem, the bill would require that all licenses be processed in 40 days or less, leaving plenty of time for interagency review.
 Export control policy must be changed to reflect reality, to meet new security threats and competition for world markets. By passing a strong measure this summer, Congress can improve our nonproliferation efforts -- and our living standards.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Arsenals Abroad;
Proliferation In Disguise

BYLINE: By Gary Milhollin and Gerard White; Gary Milhollin is director and Gerard White assistant director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
This week the House takes up a bill that would make it easier for terrorist nations to build nuclear weapons, chemical weapons and the missiles to deliver them. The fateful debate will focus on the sale of strategic technology -- items like the high-tech furnaces, presses and machine tools that almost gave Saddam Hussein an atomic bomb.
The bill, whose chief sponsor is Representative Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut, would leave U.S. controls no stronger than those of Germany, Switzerland and Italy, the main suppliers of Iraq's nuclear, chemical and missile plants. The stated goal is to protect American exporters from unfair competition; instead, the bill would end American leadership in export control. 
 Since World War II, U.S. strategy has been to adopt strong controls first and then persuade other countries to follow. Mr. Gejdenson's bill would allow such unilateral controls only for six months -- too short a time for diplomacy to work. The controls could be extended but only if the President determined, among other things, that "no other means" could stop proliferation.
The Pentagon and other national security agencies would be squeezed out of export regulation; power would shift to the Commerce Department, whose main job is to promote exports, not regulate them. Mr. Gejdenson also wants to shorten the time allowed to decide on export license applications from 120 days to 30 days -- a step the Administration has said "would preclude meaningful review."
The sponsors boast that the bill would be the strongest prohibition ever enacted against exports to countries like Iraq and North Korea. But U.S. regulations have barred sales to these countries for years. The problem is that by loosening controls on exports to everyone else, the bill makes it easier for terrorist nations to buy U.S. goods abroad.
To garner support, exporters and their Congressional allies are peddling a set of myths. The cold war is over, they say, so export controls are becoming obsolete. But regional tensions are growing and so are appetites for weapons of mass destruction. As James Woolsey, the Director of Central Intelligence, said at his confirmation hearings last year, "We have slain a large dragon, but we live now in a jungle filled with a bewildering variety of poisonous snakes."
Another myth is that dropping export controls would create jobs. Only $10 billion worth of high-technology products -- less than two-tenths of 1 percent of the U.S. economy -- even go through export licensing. And the total value of exports denied under the existing controls is about $700 million a year -- less than half the price of a B-2 bomber. Gutting export controls would stimulate bomb making, not the U.S. economy.
Supporters say that too many exports are subject to controls. In fact, the Commerce Department has been steadily cutting back on the number of items it screens for export licenses; only a tenth as many items are controlled now as in 1989, and the department is cutting its staff. Export controls are but a shadow of what they were before the cold war; now the exporters want to get rid of the shadow.
Mr. Gejdenson's measure would encourage the Commerce Department to drop items from the list of controlled products as soon as they were superseded by an improved version. But "obsolete" technology can still be deadly. After the Persian Gulf war, U.N. inspectors discovered that Iraq had nearly made an atomic bomb using calutrons, a primitive technology that the U.S. abandoned in the 1940's. It is no consolation to be killed by a bomb made with obsolete equipment.
In April, the General Accounting Office reported that the Government had approved more than 1,500 nuclear-related exports from 1985 to 1992 to countries "involved or suspected of being involved in nuclear proliferation activities." A military buyer in Pakistan got two high-tech grinding machines "capable of manufacturing critical nuclear weapon components," even though the U.S. Government knew the buyer was involved in "the design, manufacture, or testing of nuclear weapons."
Instead of fighting export controls, U.S. manufacturers should welcome them; they protect companies' reputations by keeping dangerous goods out of the wrong hands. Which U.S. company would like to have seen its logo on the Russian- and German-supplied Scud missiles that hit Tel Aviv?
Officials at the United Nations have told us that they expect the embargo on Iraqi oil to be lifted next spring. The petrodollars will revive Mr. Hussein's procurement network. If Representative Gejdenson's bill passes, the companies whose products showed up in Iraqi bomb factories last time could see them there again. Mr. Gejdenson and his backers can then share the blame.

HEADLINE: REBELS IN RWANDA CALL A CEASE-FIRE; EXODUS CONTINUES

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GOMA, Zaire, July 18

 BODY:
The rebel Rwandan Patriotic Front announced a cease-fire today and declared victory in its four-year battle against the Government. But representatives of relief agencies said they still faced another huge surge of refugees.
"We have captured all of Rwanda up to the French protection zone and a cease-fire is effectively in place," the rebel leader, Paul Kagame, said today in Kigali, the capital. French troops have carved out an area in southwestern Rwanda to offer a haven for civilian refugees. 
 "There is no need for anyone to flee Rwanda," he said, according to The Associated Press. "We guarantee all Rwandans stability and security." But he warned that there were some Rwandans who "can't forget they have a lot of blood on their hands and will have to answer for it."
International relief agencies had been pleading with the rebels for more than a week to declare a cease-fire, but the reaction to the announcement today was subdued. The cease-fire came only after the front's military operations had forced more than a million Rwandans to flee into Zaire, and relief agencies are exhausted in trying to cope.
No one expects the refugees to begin returning to Rwanda soon. Most are Hutu, members of the majority group, which dominated the Government, and they are convinced that if they go back they will be killed by Tutsi, who are now dominant.
And another refugee crisis looms. In the last 24 hours, more than 100,000 refugees have fled to Bukavu, Zaire, about 70 miles south of Goma and across the border from the French-patrolled area of southern Rwanda. Another half a million may be on the move toward Bukavu, relief officials here said.
"We do not need another exodus into the Bukavu area," said J. Brian Atwood, administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, who visited here today. "We could not handle that."
He noted that Bukavu is smaller and less developed than Goma, and "it remains to be seen if we can handle" the refugees in Goma.
"It is the most extraordinary thing I think I have ever seen in my life," said Mr. Atwood, who advises President Clinton on international disaster assistance, speaking at the French airbase here. The road past the airport was clogged with refugees trying to move north, where relief agencies hope to establish a camp.
"This is 1.2 million people looking desperately for food, for medicine, for care," he said. "That's more people than live in the cities of Boston or Denver, or Seattle or Baltimore."
For the first time in many days, the border crossing here was quiet. Fields near the border that had been jammed with refugees were empty. It was the silence of death.
In a field 50 yards east of the border, down by Lake Kivu, there was a large area of debris -- straw mats, gourds, an open umbrella, suitcases, clothes. There were several dead goats -- and 15 dead humans, most of them children. Several were naked. They were clustered together. They had been trampled to death, trapped between the lake and a high wall that protected an expensive two-story, lakeside house with a Mercedes Benz in the driveway.
Charles Cyirabo, 68 years old, found his 12-year-old grandson among the dead. As he picked through the rubble, Mr. Cyirabo, who was barefoot and wore a long coat that was torn and tattered, said he was looking for a shirt to wear. He also picked out a hoe. He would use it to dig a grave for his grandson, he said. A few weeks ago, when the rebels attacked his village, 18 members of his family were killed, Mr. Cyirabo said.
 
100 Trampled to Death
 Up the road, the bodies of at least 100 refugees were found on the Zaire side of the border. They had been trampled to death on Sunday when the thud of mortars and ferocious firefights caused panic among thousands of refugees packed into a small area. Next to one rock wall was the body of a woman lying on a straw mat where she had apparently been resting, unable to move before the surge.
On the other side of the wall were the bodies of at least 35 refugees, many of them children, who were camped in a garden with a large cactus and a mango tree when a mortar shell caught them. Next to the body of one woman was a tiny baby, still alive this morning.
There were others living among the dead this morning. They were in shock, their bodies shredded by mortar fragments, still breathing. People who had escaped the attack moved slowly and silently through the carnage, a scene out of Dante's hell.
 
Search for Mother's Milk
 Martin Rwagasore held his tiny 5-month-old daughter against his chest, wrapped in a goat skin. Her mother was among the dead under the cactus tree, where he had found his daughter. "I don't know what I am going to do," he said, as he tried to convince Red Cross workers to take the little girl. Another man searched about for a woman who might provide milk for his 2-month-old son, whose mother had been killed.
In the middle of the carnage, children were sobbing. "My parents sent me to get water," said a 13-year-old boy, wiping his eyes with the sleeve of a filthy, torn shirt. "Now I don't know where they are."
A Zairian Red Cross worker, Antoine Barumwete, walked along the dusty road leading five small children; one girl carried her brother on her back. "I found them on the road," Mr. Barumwete said. Asked how many children had become separated from their parents, he said, "There are so many it is impossible to know."
A man with a withered left leg dragged himself along the dirt road, past the dead and wounded and lost. In his right hand was his brace and a crutch. Farther ahead was another crippled woman who crawled along on her hands and knees.
A Red Cross truck could not take them. The Red Cross's mandate is to take care of war victims, and there were more of those today than the agency could handle.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Haiti: Domestic Issues Complicate Choice

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

 BODY:
As its showdown with Haiti's military leaders enters its tensest stage, the White House risks being besieged with problems on at least three major fronts.
The confluence will almost certainly make the month ahead the most perilous of President Clinton's term. With Congress bitterly divided over health care and Congressional hearings on the Whitewater case coming to a crest, his advisers say that Mr. Clinton probably cannot wait much longer before deciding whether to invade Haiti and roust the Caribbean nation's ruling junta. 
 The extent to which so much at the White House this summer is shaping up as a kind of carom shot has become apparent in the calculations of aides about how a decision on Haiti, for one, might affect the President's battle to get health care legislation through Congress before the Aug. 12 recess.
If the President ordered a military strike soon, one argument goes, it would steal so many headlines and so much attention that health care could only founder. A dissenting theory (sometimes advanced by the same aides) holds that success in Haiti could so enhance Mr. Clinton's stature that his uphill struggle in Congress might become more like coasting.
 
Health, Haiti, Whitewater
 Add to this mix the Congressional hearings on the Whitewater matter, which begin next week, and the agonizing has made for more than a little midsummer uneasiness.
"Health care is the one that we want to get done," one aide to Mr. Clinton said in diagramming the tangled midsummer agenda. "Haiti is the one that we have to get done. And Whitewater -- Whitewater is inevitable."
At least for now, officials say, questions about how to attack each of the problems have been compounded by anxiety and uncertainty within the White House about what further personnel changes will be made by Leon E. Panetta, the new chief of staff, who formally took charge yesterday.
Apart from Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, the White House officials most directly responsible for leading the the day-to-day battles on the major fronts have been Mr. Panetta and his deputy, Harold M. Ickes, on health care; Lloyd N. Cutler, the White House counsel, and John D. Podesta, the White House staff secretary, on Whitewater; and Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, and his deputy, Samuel R. Berger, on Haiti.
 
Competing With Recess
 But the discussions until now have also involved a constellation of other officials, some of them in ill-defined roles. Several senior officials now say that Mr. Panetta will seek at least to make more precise the responsibilities assigned to senior advisers like Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the former chief of staff, and George Stephanopoulos, a sort of troubleshooter without portfolio who has been spread thin by the proliferation of troubles.
But even aides to Mr. Clinton respond uneasily when asked how the White House, which this time last year was devoting nearly all its energy to passing its economic plan, hopes to manage the three competing tides as Congress heads toward its Aug. 12 recess. "You just do the best you can," one senior official shrugged.
It has been evident since the year began that if the White House hoped to win passage of a health care plan this autumn, its first battles on the House and Senate floors would have to be fought before Congress left for the summer recess. Since March, when the Whitewater matter exploded into new public prominence, it has also been clear that Republican pressures will force Congressional hearings about it onto the midsummer calendar.
What has emerged as its most unexpected test has been the showdown with Haiti, which after an on-again, off-again unfolding appears to be approaching its most dangerous phase just when the White House would have preferred not to be distracted.
 
Little Time Is Bought
 By Sunday, the drop-off in the number of Haitian refugees taking to the seas appeared to be holding, a trend greeted with relief by officials who had regarded that human flow as the greatest source of pressure for quick American action. By denying boat people the right to seek asylum in the United States, one senior official said, the Administration bought some time by "demagnetizing" the lure most responsible for impelling Haitians to flee.
But no one was arguing that any time bought would be very long. After insisting for weeks that a decision whether to invade could be months away, Administration officials now cite increasing violence against Haitian civilians as the issue most likely to force Mr. Clinton to show his hand.
Administration officials still insist that the President has not decided whether to use force to oust Haiti's leaders. But now that the White House has spent its quiver of economic sanctions, few say they can envision an alternative to force if the ruling junta refuses to step down soon.
With pilgrimages to Capitol Hill and television studios and calculated disclosures in the press, it has also become apparent that the White House has begun an aggressive effort to build public and Congressional support for such an operation.
As Mr. Panetta was appearing on television to warn that the Administration could not "allow the status quo to eat us up" in Haiti, other senior White House officials were looking back with grim satisfaction on a week of television news coverage that gave prominence to scenes of brutality there.
"It's helped us," said one Administration official who advocates an invasion. Among other factors that may make it easier for Mr. Clinton to turn to military force more quickly, that official emphasized "the outrage" generated by Haiti's decision last week to expel United Nations human rights observers.
It is events in Haiti and not the President's calendar, his advisers insist, that will determine when and whether he will invade the Caribbean nation. Similarly, they say they are at the mercy of any Republicans who might seek to use the Whitewater hearings, which begin July 26, for personal attacks even at the height of the health care debate.
But in a month when each stream now appears likely to spill into the others, White House strategists are pondering how to prevent the cumulative flow from engulfing them.
