HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE STATES;
Democratic Governors Avoid Mandates

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 18

 BODY:
One day before President Clinton is to address the National Governors' Association, Democratic members of the group today endorsed his goal of health insurance for all Americans but withheld their support for the centerpiece of his proposal, a requirement that employers pay most of the cost.
The Democratic Governors' Association did not say how it would finance health insurance for the 39 million Americans who have no coverage. Without being specific, the group supported efforts by Congressional leaders to find "an equitable and reliable financing mechanism." 
 White House officials who came here to lobby for the President's health plan welcomed a statement from the Democratic governors that endorsed the goal of "providing every American guaranteed health benefits that cannot be taken away."
Marcia L. Hale, assistant to the President for intergovernmental affairs, said: "They're for us. The Democratic governors passed a resolution in support of the President."
But the Democrats' silence on the employer mandate issue was not a good omen for the President or for the many Democrats in Congress who say that such a requirement is the only feasible way to guarantee health insurance coverage for all.
If Mr. Clinton, a former Governor of Arkansas, cannot win an endorsement of the employer mandate from Democratic governors, it is unclear how he can push such a proposal through the United States Senate.
Mr. Clinton would require employers to pay 80 percent of health insurance premiums for their workers, and he would give subsidies to small businesses with low-wage workers to help defray the cost.
 
Specter of Stalemate
 Governors of both parties, gathered here for the annual meeting of the National Governors' Association, said it was imperative for Congress to pass health care legislation this year.
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat who is vice chairman of the National Governors' Association, said he was gravely concerned about signs of intransigence on Capitol Hill as partisan lines harden on the issue. Mr. Dean said he had urged Democratic leaders in Congress to make "good-faith efforts at compromise."
Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr., a Republican who is chairman of the association, has offered similar advice to Republican leaders in Congress.
 
Same Party, Different Ideas
 In an interview, Mr. Dean said, "The employer mandate splits Democratic governors." He proposed such a mandate for Vermont as part of an ambitious Clinton-style health plan, but the proposal died this year in the State Legislature.
Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana, chairman of the Democratic Governors' Association, said the employer mandate was one way to achieve universal coverage. But he added, "I haven't reached a conclusion yet in my own mind" as to whether it is the best way to achieve that goal.
President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, are scheduled to address the national governors' group on Tuesday.
Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania and Gov. Mike Lowry of Washington, both Democrats, said that they, like Mr. Dean, supported a requirement that employers pay for health benefits for their workers.
But four other Democratic governors here -- Ben Nelson of Nebraska, Jim Folsom of Alabama, Bruce King of New Mexico and Mike Sullivan of Wyoming -- said in interviews that they opposed the idea.
The Governors of Tennessee, North Carolina and Missouri, all Democrats, expressed neutrality, ambivalence or cautious interest in an employer mandate, without endorsing the idea.
 
'Not Much on Mandates'
 Mr. King, who has been Governor of New Mexico for 12 of the last 24 years and is running for re-election, said: "We're not much on mandates. We'd rather do it with voluntary participation. The poor businessman already has enough problems trying to meet a payroll. Another mandate is not exactly what he's looking for."
Mr. Nelson said, "I don't favor an employer mandate, but I'm the first to admit that I don't have an alternative" to pay for universal coverage.
Mr. Sullivan said: "I oppose employer mandates. We have to be very careful what we impose on business as an additional burden."
Mr. Folsom said the major health care proposals now pending in Congress were "somewhat nebulous to the average voter in Alabama."
"It's not a high-priority issue among our voters back home," he added. "It doesn't get as high a priority as crime, education reform, jobs and economic development."
 
Views From the Fence
 Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina said of employer mandates, "I'm open to that idea as long as we don't hurt small-business people." But he said that education, crime and jobs had higher priority for him too.
Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri, who takes over next year as chairman of the Democratic Governors' Association, said he supported the President's goal of health care for all Americans but had neither endorsed nor opposed the employer mandate.
Governor Ned McWherter of Tennessee said he favored universal coverage, but added, "I don't know if I would go about doing it through mandates."
Gov. Joan Finney of Kansas, a Democrat, said that employers should make some contribution to the cost of health insurance for workers but that the 80 percent share proposed by Mr. Clinton was too large.

HEADLINE: Japan's New Prime Minister Promises a More Open Economy

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to the New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 18

 BODY:
The Japanese were cynical and angry three weeks ago when a Socialist became Prime Minister by joining forces with his party's longstanding conservative foes and ousting a reform coalition. But in his first policy address today, Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama sought to reassure a wary public by abandoning the Socialists' opposition to the country's military and vowing to open the economy to a freer flow of goods.
Mr. Murayama, 70, who came into office with about the lowest public approval rating of any postwar Prime Minister, focused on persuading the public that his Government was interested in more than seizing power and that the Socialists' far-left policies were a thing of the past. 
 His odd coalition, he insisted during the address in Parliament, is committed to lowering the trade surplus, improving strained relations with the United States, cutting taxes, reducing astronomical consumer prices, giving the public freer access to information and cleaning up a political system that often looks, he said, like "some kind of underhanded scam."
"I intend to travel the road to reform no matter how difficult the path ahead may be," he said, trying to counter an impression that his Government, dominated by the conservative Liberal Democratic Party, may just defend the status quo.
The normally frumpy Mr. Murayama, once known for his loose-fitting pale blue suits and pale blue ties, delivered his spirited address in a smart dark blue suit accented by a wine-colored tie. He sought to deliver a reassuring message, promising continuity in Japan's foreign policies. But he did underscore a subtle but important shift.
Mr. Murayama abandoned the Socialist Party's traditionally anti-American stance and characterized the United States-Japan security treaty as the centerpiece of Japan's foreign policy.
He also apparently dropped his party's longstanding claim that the mere existence of Japan's military forces violates the Constitution, which prohibits the use of force for resolving international disputes.
He said he supported a military with "the necessary minimum defense capability."
Mr. Murayama also indicated that he had little interest in pursuing a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council, at least in the short run, saying further discussions were necessary before Japan could make such a leap.
"We should strive not to be a powerful country, but to be a caring country," he remarked.
That policy is reminiscent of the cold war, when Japan kept a low profile in foreign affairs while focusing on building its economy. It also defies growing demands that Japan contribute more. The United States Senate recently adopted a resolution calling on Japan to make troops available for United Nations peacekeeping operations.
On one other issue, Mr. Murayama described a slight shift from the previous Government, which had urged big income tax cuts to stimulate consumption and lift the economy from a long recession. The previous Government also favored a large increase in a national sales tax to make up for the lost revenues.
Some economists, and the United States, oppose the sales tax increase, saying it would counter whatever benefits the income tax cuts would bring. Mr. Murayama hinted that the Government would enact the income tax cuts and get the economy out of its rut before pushing any increases in the sales tax.
Opposition politicians sought to paint the Murayama speech as a cynical effort to woo public support.
"Apparently he was attempting to change his policies almost overnight," said Motoo Shiina, a former Liberal Democrat and now an independent. "A man or a group that changes overnight like that can change again, anytime. People have to decide if that is the group they want representing Japan."

HEADLINE: Huge Water Project Would Supply Beijing By 860-Mile Aqueduct

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DANJIANGKOU, China

 BODY:
One of the largest public works projects ever conceived -- a plan to divert water from the huge reservoir here to Beijing 860 miles north -- has been proposed by China's Communist Party leadership to save the capital from perpetual drought in the next century.
Rivaling even the construction of the 1,500-mile-long Great Wall, in the words of one Government engineer, a huge aqueduct starting here in central China and running north to Beijing and Tianjin seems the only solution to maintaining China's capital as a center for industry, commerce and government. 
 But because the project would cost billions of dollars and would benefit a relatively small part of the Chinese population -- less than 10 percent -- it is certain to ignite debate among China's regional leaders competing for scarce budget resources.
 
Leaky Toilets Are Priority
 Southern provincial officials complain, as President Jiang Zemin did recently, that Chinese cities waste billions of gallons of water each year through poor conservation practices and leaky toilets. Conservation should be tried first, they say.
"If a country can send satellites and missiles into space, it should be able to dry up its toilets," the Chinese President complained last month, sending Communist Party cadres skittering to mount a nationwide campaign against makers of shoddy toilets.
The aqueduct's path across China would equal the distance from Washington, D.C., to the Mississippi River and it would deliver a volume of water each year -- almost 4 trillion gallons -- that is more than 7 times the volume used annually by New York City, and equal to nearly half that of Lake Mead behind Hoover Dam. This volume is twice as large as the amount delivered by California's largest water-diversion system.
During the late 1950's, 100,000 Chinese peasants, seized by the political fever of Mao Zedong's call to catch up with the West in the Great Leap Forward, muscled a mountain of stone to block one of the Yangtze River's largest tributaries here and build a dam that would control floods, generate electricity for China's modernization and irrigate the land into a new era of agriculture. They abandoned their farms, lived in mud huts and ate starvation rations for the glory of Communism.
 
Completing Great Leap
 But the Great Leap's economic flaws instead brought famine to China, killing tens of millions and scaling back huge projects like this one. The hills here remain denuded, stark evidence of the desperate years that followed.
The aqueduct project has rekindled the hopes of the local population that this dam, after it is raised another 50 feet to create a mighty new reservoir to feed a northbound aqueduct, will finally fulfill the expectations of the ill-fated Great Leap.
The aqueduct's enormous flow, contained in its manmade channel, will have to cross 219 rivers and streams along its path, including the Yellow River. To accomplish this, Chinese engineers are prepared to dig either a five-mile-long water tunnel under the Yellow River or erect an elevated aqueduct over it supported by 160 giant pylons.
 
Mao's Brainstorm
 Details of the plan for the water project, conceived by Mao Zedong on a trip down the Yangtze River in 1958, are to be presented to the Chinese leadership next spring and comes at a time when China is facing a huge bill for new building that is necessary to sustain its economic boom.
"Every province has its own very ambitious plans to build bridges and power plants and infrastructure and they are all competing for national resources," said Fan Gang, an economist at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences.
One Chinese official predicted real opposition when the water project is submitted to the National People's Congress, where party members can press regional claims against it.
"I think this project will be more politically complicated than the Three Gorges Dam," Mr. Fan said.
 
Taming the Yangtze
 The Three Gorges project, a 20-year, $10 billion undertaking, was approved after four years of contentious debate within the Communist Party leadership. It is the largest public works project in China today and is designed to tame the Yangtze River while also generating 17,000 megawatts of electricity. But it has drawn opposition from environmental groups inside and outside China because it will flood one of the most scenic river settings in the world.
The South-North Water Diversion project, as the aqueduct is formally known, would be the second largest national construction project. It would require a six-year effort to expand the reservoir to roughly the same size as that of the planned Three Gorges reservoir. The expansion would displace 225,000 people, mostly farmers, in Hubei and Henan provinces.
The rescue of northern China's two most important commercial and government centers represents a large and, so far, unfinanced liability threatening the pace of China's economic expansion. Moreover, half of China's 570 cities suffer serious water shortages and Communist Party officials estimate these shortages cost the country nearly $14 billion a year in lost economic output.
The water crisis in northern China is also an indicator of how China's environment is struggling under the demands placed on it by 1.2 billion people, demands that can only grow.
 
Political Order Threatened
 China's economic expansion coincides with its greatest surge in population, which is expected to peak at 1.6 billion to 1.7 billion in the third decade of the next century.
Any threat to China's ability to provide enough water for food production, job creation and overall economic growth is a threat to the established political order.
The plan for the aqueduct project underwent final design reviews late last year, and an initial cost estimate of $5 billion was tallied. But that is certain to grow, just as the Three Gorges estimate grew -- by a factor of 10 -- during its planning stages.
"This is a bottleneck for the development of the whole north China area," said Luo Xuliu, the chief engineer at the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission, where the aqueduct was designed.
 
As Crucial as Three Gorges
 "If they cannot get enough water supply through this bottleneck," he said at the commission's headquarters in Wuhan, "they will not be able to sustain rapid development."
"There are dissenting opinions," he conceded, but, he added: "This has to be looked at from the standpoint of the whole country. I personally believe that the significance of this project is no less than that of the Three Gorges in terms of its importance to the nation."
"Guangdong Province," he continued, "doesn't have coal, so the country has found ways to send coal from Shaanxi Province down south. The south in turn has water, so it should provide water."
In the last three years, a deepening drought, the worst in 30 years, has combined with a construction boom in the capital region to accelerate the rapid drain on the region's water reserves.
 
Day of Reckoning Nears
 Local reservoirs that once fed the agricultural belt outside Beijing have been cordoned off and dedicated to urban consumption. Farmers, meanwhile, have drilled deeper and deeper into diminishing ground water supplies to irrigate their fields.
Now, Beijing's top water expert says that a day of reckoning is almost here, though the drought was weakened by three days of heavy rain recently.
"The reserve storage of water will be used up in the next few years without effective water-saving measures with the prolonged scorching weather," said Teng Shutang, chief engineer at the capital's water conservancy bureau. After that, he said, "it will be a crisis" and the capital's economic development would come to a "standstill."
If nothing is done, Beijing's annual water deficit could exceed 250 billion gallons a year by 2010, a figure equal to half the current annual consumption.
Perpetual drought, shortage and rationing are images of life in Beijing that its leaders cannot afford as they market the Chinese capital region as a future home for multinational corporations, luxury hotels, shopping districts and housing developments to support an ever larger foreign community in a population of 12 million.
 
Water Table Is Sinking
 More than two million pipe wells have been sunk in northern China to exploit once plentiful ground water supplies, but progressive overuse that came with a doubling of population since 1949 has led to huge areas of ground subsidence, or the sinking of the earth, due to loss of underground water. The water table has been retreating at least one meter a year and in 1993, it dropped 1.73 meters, or 5 feet 8 inches.
The zones of ground depression in northern China now cover an area as large as Hungary.
Early water diversion projects focused on the Yellow River, whose waters spawned Chinese civilization 5,000 years ago. But demands on the Yellow River for agricultural irrigation have left its flow dangerously oversubscribed.
That left the Yangtze River and its major tributaries, like the Han River, which feeds the Danjiangkou reservoir.
 
3 Projects Designed
 Three engineering projects, each traversing different south-to-north routes, have been designed, and Chinese leaders will have to choose among them. The leading candidate from the engineers' standpoint is the one that begins here and is called the "middle" course.
With the source waters 300 feet higher than Beijing, the aqueduct would be all downhill to its destination and would be able to irrigate a swath of farmland larger than the state of South Carolina along the way.
With a minimum of six years needed to build the "middle course" aqueduct and its related structures, Mr. Teng and other Beijing officials fear a long, drawn-out national debate. The water storage in two smaller reservoirs at Miyun and Guanting that are now flowing into Beijing "will not last beyond 1999," he said, adding, "I wish this project could start as soon as tomorrow."
But a long debate is more likely. Some Chinese officials said they fear the country will violate the spirit of the old Chinese proverb:
"Don't wait until you're thirsty to start digging the well."

HEADLINE: Congressional Memo;
In Jargon-Filled Talk About Budgets, A Debate of Politics Over Substance

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
People who have been listening to conservative talk radio recently or watching the House of Representatives on C-Span have heard an earful of exercised talk about expedited recissions and the A to Z budget plan and discharge petitions and lock boxes and closed rules.
These arcane terms may not make sense to the untrained ear, but it often sounds as if grave matters of public policy are at stake. One side makes it appear as if die-hard deficit hawks are battling the entrenched establishment to force a reduction in Federal spending. Those on the other side paint themselves as devoted lawmakers holding the line against radicals who would severely weaken the power of Congress to control the purse strings. 
 In fact, all this ventilating is much more about politics than it is about substance. This is what is going on:
Last year, two junior Congressmen, Robert E. Andrews, a Democrat from New Jersey, and Bill Zeliff, a Republican from New Hampshire, introduced legislation that would force a special session of Congress this year in which any lawmaker could bypass committees and other normal procedures, offer a proposal to cut Government spending and be guaranteed a vote on the proposal.
 
Opposed Clinton Budget
 Democratic leaders did not take the idea seriously. Both Mr. Andrews and Mr. Zeliff had voted against the Clinton budget, a measure that indisputably lowered the Federal deficit by raising taxes and limiting spending. The Congressmen's idea, which they called the A to Z Spending Cut Plan, was seen as a way to re-establish their deficit-cutting bona fides.
But several conservative talk-show hosts and editorial writers took up the A to Z cause. The idea appealed not only to Republicans, who chafe at their lack of power in the House, but also to some Democratic backbenchers who are frustrated at the extent to which the House is run by committee chairmen and party leaders. In a blink, more than 230 representatives, a majority of the 435-seat House, signed on as co-sponsors, a step that carried no responsibility but looked good in letters to constituents.
The Democratic leaders, who set the schedule for the House, refused to allow the plan for a special session to be brought to a vote. They do not want to subject their members to what might be embarrassing votes. The Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said such a session would amount to a three-ring circus.
 
Seeking a Floor Vote
 So, unable to get a vote in the ordinary fashion, Mr. Andrews and Mr. Zeliff turned to a procedure that is almost never used: the discharge petition. Under the rules of the House, if 218 members, a majority, sign such a petition, the matter in question must be released by the committee with jurisdiction, in this case the Rules Committee, and brought to the floor for an up or down vote.
By early this summer, the A to Z sponsors were on the verge of success. Almost all of the 178 Republicans, eager to portray the Democratic majority as free spenders, and about 30 of the 257 Democrats had signed the petition. To prevent enough renegade Democrats from putting the tally over the top, the House majority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, promised last month that a succession of votes on the budget process would be taken this summer and fall.
The first such vote came last Thursday on something called expedited recissions. The House voted, 298 to 121, to require a speedy vote every time the President asks Congress to withdraw appropriations it has already approved. Presidents routinely ask for such withdrawals, called recissions, but under current procedures, Congress can block a recission simply by failing to vote on it.
This change is unlikely to save much money. "It is always easier to vote for process changes than for actual spending cuts," said Stanley E. Collender, a budget specialist at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm.
 
No Support in Senate
 Votes are expected later this year on potentially more meaningful measures, the precise nature of which are not clear. One may place a cap on spending for entitlements, programs like Medicare in which benefits are automatically paid to everyone who meets the eligibility requirements. Another may limit annual cost-of-living increases in Social Security benefits and Federal pensions. Still another, called a lock box measure, may require that money cut from appropriations bills be used only for deficit reduction and not be spent elsewhere.
In a sense, these will be free votes for the representatives. The measures will not become law this year because the Senate has no intention of considering them. This is similar to the way Democratic representatives were free to vote for tough campaign finance restrictions in the Bush Administration because they knew the President would veto them.
The sponsors of the A to Z plan have something of a point. Measures dealing with Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, the Government's costliest programs, are always handled under what are known as closed rules. That means, basically, that they are not subject to amendments. And, as Mr. Gephardt noted last week, "There has not been a debate on reforming overall entitlement policies here in the House in recent memory."
Even so, it is hard to believe that many representatives will vote in an election year to reduce these benefits. Yet, this is where the money is.
 
Raise Taxes or Cut Benefits
 The budget deficit cannot be reduced substantially, economists agree, unless lawmakers raise taxes on the middle class or reduce the Federal benefits that a large number of their constituents receive.
If the people want higher taxes or lower benefits, that is certainly not apparent. It is also not clear that very many members of Congress want to take those steps. The complaint that the House is run by a small clique may be valid, but it is rare that a measure supported by a majority of members is not approved.
The truth is, the sponsors of the A to Z plan may be more interested in talking about reducing the deficit than in actually doing so. In the last two months, the House has voted on all 13 appropriations bills. These measures provide money for about one-third of the Federal budget, including all of what anyone regards as wasteful pork barrel.
The A to Z sponsors did not propose a single amendment to reduce the amount of money for spending in any of these bills.
Asked why, Mr. Zeliff said, "I could have spent my time coming up with amendments, or I could spend the time trying to get A to Z home."

HEADLINE: Severe Ancient Droughts: A Warning to California

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
BEGINNING about 1,100 years ago, what is now California baked in two droughts, the first lasting 220 years and the second 140 years. Each was much more intense than the mere six-year dry spells that afflict modern California from time to time, new studies of past climates show. The findings suggest, in fact, that relatively wet periods like the 20th century have been the exception rather than the rule in California for at least the last 3,500 years, and that mega-droughts are likely to recur.
The evidence for the big droughts comes from an analysis of the trunks of trees that grew in the dry beds of lakes, swamps and rivers in and adjacent to the Sierra Nevada, but died when the droughts ended and the water levels rose. Immersion in water has preserved the trunks over the centuries. 
 Dr. Scott Stine, a paleoclimatologist at California State University at Hayward, used radiocarbon dating techniques to determine the age of the trees' outermost annual growth rings, thereby establishing the ends of drought periods. He then calculated the lengths of the preceding dry spells by counting the rings in each stump.
This method identified droughts lasting from A.D. 892 to A.D. 1112 and from A.D. 1209 to A.D. 1350. Judging by how far the water levels dropped during these periods -- as much as 50 feet in some cases -- Dr. Stine concluded that the droughts were not only much longer, they were far more severe than either the drought of 1928 to 1934, California's worst in modern times, or the more recent severe dry spell of 1987 to 1992.
In medieval times the California droughts coincided roughly with a warmer climate in Europe, which allowed the Vikings to colonize Greenland and vineyards to grow in England, and with a severe dry period in South America, which caused the collapse of that continent's most advanced pre-Inca empire, the rich and powerful state of Tiwanaku, other recent studies have found.
Does Tiwanaku's fate await modern California?
Dr. Stine, who reported his findings last month in the British journal Nature, says that California, like Tiwanaku, presents "a classic case of people building themselves beyond the carrying capacity of the land," which is determined not by wet times but by dry ones. "What we've done in California is fail to recognize that there are lean times ahead," said Dr. Stine, "and they are a lot leaner than anything we've come up against" in the modern era.
How far ahead that reckoning might lie is, of course, uncertain. But one ominous sign may be that the earth's climate as a whole is now warming up, whether from natural causes or because of heat-trapping atmospheric gases emitted by industrial society. Any significant global warming would probably cause changes in atmospheric circulation and precipitation patterns, and the new findings suggest that "during much of medieval time the planetary ocean-atmosphere system operated in a mode unlike that of modern time," Dr. Stine wrote in Nature.
This alteration of the system could well have been caused by a natural global warming, he said. He believes that one long-term effect was to steer storm tracks and rainfall away from California. If this pattern was indeed brought about by a medieval global warming, he said, a future global warming -- whether natural or human-induced -- might bring back the decades-long droughts of yore.
Dr. Stine's findings, combined with similar evidence he turned up in Patagonia, strengthen the case of those who believe that the earth experienced a general warming at the time of the Middle Ages, Dr. F. Alayne Street-Perrott, a paleoclimatologist at Oxford University in England, wrote in a commentary accompanying Dr. Stine's report in Nature. Other experts maintain that the medieval warming was not global but instead affected only some parts of the world.
"I'm not prepared to believe that the whole world was warmer," said Dr. Malcolm K. Hughes, a paleoclimatologist who directs the Laboratory of Tree Ring Research at the University of Arizona in Tucson. Nor is it possible to say for sure that future global warming would bring back the large-scale droughts of the past. "We've not done the work on the actual mechanisms," he said.
But he said that Dr. Stine's findings, coupled with similar conclusions that can be drawn from other tree-ring studies by scientists in his laboratory, are a "serious cause for concern." There appears to be little doubt that the epic dry spells of the past did occur, he said, adding that "what has happened can happen."
The findings also emphasize the importance of precipitation changes, rather than simply changes in temperature, when weighing the potential impact of future global climate change, Dr. Stine wrote in Nature.
 
Periods of 'Epic Drought'
 The Sierra Nevada, where Dr. Stine conducted his study, is California's most important area for the collection of water. Runoff from the Sierras provides two-thirds of the state's surface-water supply for cities and farms. The study involved trees at four places: Mono Lake, Tenaya Lake, the West Walker River and Osgood Swamp. Dr. Stine's tree-ring analysis found that live trees had covered dry beds of lakes, streams and swamps for overlapping periods of 50, 100, 141 and 220 years and that these "lowstand" periods were clustered in two major dry spells separated by a century-long wet period. "Epic drought," he wrote in Nature, is "the only plausible explanation for the site-to-site contemporaneity of the stumps."
In the period separating the two long droughts, Dr. Stine said, the water in Mono Lake rose to a level higher than any in the last 150 years, suggesting that the California climate was even wetter then than it is today. The last century and a half, Dr. Stine found, has been the third wettest period in the last three millenniums. But, he said, "the vast majority of years during the past 3,500 years have been much drier than what we've come to expect to be normal in California."
The evidence for the medieval drought periods is especially strong, Dr. Hughes said, because the lake basins are closed, with no natural outlets; consequently, their water levels are influenced only by inflow and evaporation, making them ideal gauges of drought. And even though radiocarbon dating is somewhat imprecise, he said, it is good enough "to show two major phases of tree growth and lowstands; there's no doubt about that." This, he said, shows that "often, for sure, there have been periods of 100 years or more" that have been "markedly drier" than the 20th century.
The 10th to the 14th centuries, encompassing the prolonged droughts reported by Dr. Stine, saw "dramatic changes" in Western Hemisphere civilizations, Dr. Street-Perrott wrote in Nature, and some have been attributed by archeologists to changes in rainfall. One example is the sudden decline of the Anasazi cliff-dwellers in the American southwest at about the year 1300. Another, even more striking, is the collapse of Tiwanaku.
Tiwanaku was a flourishing empire that lasted seven centuries and reached its zenith near the end of the first millennium A.D. It commanded an area about the size of California, extending from the Andean plateau around Lake Titicaca to the Pacific Coast and covering parts of present-day Bolivia, Chile and Peru.
The empire's economy was based on intensive agriculture carried out on raised fields: acres of end-to-end rectangular platforms created by digging the dirt from areas between them. The dug-out areas became canals from which silt was taken to provide fertilizer. This highly productive and environmentally sound system dominated Latin American agriculture for centuries.
 
Death of a Civilization
 But several lines of evidence, including analyses of fossilized pollen grains and isotopes of oxygen in lake sediments, make it clear that an extended drought afflicted the region starting between A.D. 950 and A.D. 1000 and continuing, with fluctuations, until 1410, concluded a study last year by Charles R. Ortloff, a fluid-mechanics specialist at the FMC Corporate Technology Center at Santa Clara, Calif., and Dr. Alan L. Kolata, an archeologist at the University of Chicago. That period mostly overlaps the one in which the California mega-droughts occurred.
The South American drought was of "horrendous proportions," said Dr. Kolata, and it destroyed Tiwanaku's agricultural base. The empire's cities were abandoned by about 1000. Dr. Kolata believes that the raised fields could no longer support the cities, and archeological evidence shows that the fields were abandoned between 1000 and 1100. The political state collapsed, the population dispersed and, with agriculture no longer possible, the people relied on raising alpacas and llamas.
Tiwanaku's agricultural system had been able to adjust to the less drastic cycles of drought and inundation that were thought to be normal, but "Tiwanaku agro-engineers were incapable of responding to a drought of unprecedented duration and severity," Mr. Ortloff and Dr. Kolata wrote in a 1993 paper in The Journal of Archeological Science.
Like Tiwanaku's engineers, those who draw up California's water-management plans do so on the basis of what are believed to be normal droughts but in fact are not nearly as severe as what has occurred in the past and can occur again, said Dr. Stine.
"The assumption they've made for a long time -- that California is subject to droughts of a maximum of seven years -- could be harmful in the long run," he said, because "they have doled out water on that assumption.
"This could be destructive if you get hit with a 9th or a 10th or a 15th year of severe drought."
In gauging the length and frequency of droughts for planning purposes, California officials rely on a tree-ring study extending back to about 1560. Over that period, the 1928-1934 drought was the longest and worst. The problem, said Dr. Stine, is that the study period includes not only the wet 19th and 20th centuries, but also the even wetter 16th and 17th centuries. "They're using the wettest period of the last 3,000 years to define the duration and severity of the droughts we can expect in the future," he said.
Maurice Roos, the chief hydrologist of the California Department of Water Resources, said he had not read Dr. Stine's report in Nature. But he did acknowledge that a mega-drought of the kind described in the report would probably cause much of the state's lush irrigated cropland to cease producing. The cities would probably have the money and political power to appropriate enough water to get by, he said, adding, "There will always be some water; there is not going to be no water." He said he would not expect farming to cease altogether, or cities to be deserted.
Modern California has at least one coping weapon that Tiwanaku did not: the ability to turn sea water into fresh water. The 1987-92 drought did, in fact, prompt Santa Barbara to build a desalinization plant, Mr. Roos said, though he was quick to point out that this solution at present would be "enormously expensive."
At the very least, Dr. Stine wrote in Nature, a recurrence of the medieval droughts "would be highly disruptive environmentally and economically." Planning for a mega-drought now, while heads are a little cooler, would help, he says. The planning might include, for example, deciding which crops are to be taken out of production first, what restrictions to place on the pumping of groundwater and how cities are to obtain water.
But in the end, he said, a reprise of the medieval droughts would simply overwhelm California's efforts to cope. And he said: "We don't need 200 years of drought to bring us down. At some point, in the 9th year, or the 15th year or the 19th year, the damage is done and it doesn't matter any more."

HEADLINE: NASA's New Ploy: Meld With Moscow

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
HAVING achieved a host of spectaculars in its 35 years of existence, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has now embarked on a goal so bold, risky and surprising that the venture at times seems to unnerve the most daring of its visionaries. The agency is merging many of its leading activities with those of the Russian space program, its preeminent foe and rival during the long decades of the cold war.
The East-West partnership involves much more than building an orbital outpost for astronauts, which is to be assembled piecemeal in space between 1997 and 2002. The two sides are also cooperating in manned space flights, aeronautics research and Earth monitoring, and are talking about joining forces to fire robotic probes toward such distant and mysterious worlds as Pluto. 
 "We're merging our programs even more," Daniel S. Goldin, NASA's Administrator, said in a recent interview. "Given the tight budgets, it would be very wasteful to duplicate efforts. So we're trying to bring them together."
Mr. Goldin conceded: "Yes, there's risk and, yes, we may have a few failures. But in the long run, it's the right thing to do. Prudent interaction will strengthen the science programs of both countries. We're at a turning point."
Cooperation with the Russians in space is an important foreign-policy initiative of the Clinton Administration. It is intended to symbolize a new era of East-West cooperation and to engage Moscow in constructive space work in return for ending practices that upset Washington, like exporting advanced rocket gear to developing countries.
"The space program has always been about the relationship between Washington and Moscow," said John E. Pike, director of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington. "Clinton's just reversed the spin that Kennedy put on it."
From its earliest days, the space agency was dedicated to one main job: fighting Moscow symbolically in the space race and showing the world that America was the planet's technological leader. On the heels of Moscow's triumphs in lofting big rockets and satellites, the message was to be that capitalism, not Communism, was the best way to conquer space, lift the human spirit and generate a flood of material benefits.
In May 1961, NASA's Administrator, James E. Webb, and Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara joined forces to send a memorandum to President John F. Kennedy, warning that "lunar and planetary exploration" were increasingly important weapons in "the battle along the fluid front of the cold war." Two weeks later, President Kennedy began the Apollo program, which culminated 25 years ago, in July 1969, with the landing of two Americans on the Moon.
Russia threw its best technology into the race, but failed to get its enormous Moon rockets into space. Four of them exploded on the launching pad or in flight.
After the American triumph of landing men on another world, the space program still had ambition but lacked focus. The agency was given no overarching goal by the White House and soon settled into a broad technological rivalry with the Soviet Union. Its approach tended to be revolutionary, while that of the Russians was evolutionary. NASA shot planetary probes past Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune, even as the Soviets had trouble sending spacecraft to such nearby worlds as Mars.
Closer to Earth, the United States used its technological edge to embark on the world's first winged, reusable spaceship, known as the shuttle. It devised extraordinarily high-powered engines for the craft that though temperamental, were wonders of miniaturization. In contrast, the Soviets were forced to rely on big, bulky engines and rockets that were thrown away after each use.
In 1984, the agency got permission from the Reagan Administration to push ahead into the one sphere where the Russians were unquestioned leaders -- the building of space stations in Earth orbit. The American outpost was to be bigger, better and more expensive. By 1990, plans called for the station to measure a staggering 508 feet in length, nearly the size of the Capitol building in Washington. Costs over its 30-year lifetime were estimated at up to $120 billion.
"NASA's argument of choice was always heroic exploration -- the great mission on which the future of humankind would depend," Alex Roland, a former NASA historian who now teaches history at Duke University, said in an interview. "But it never hesitated to invoke the Russians when it served its purposes."
 
Lost in Space
 By the early 1990's, with the cold war won, battling the Russians was no longer relevant and the agency seemed to lack the will to probe the unknown for its own sake. NASA seemed adrift, if not lost in space. Shuttle launchings were repeatedly delayed by mechanical snags. Satellites mysteriously failed in orbit. Space probes broke down on the way to Jupiter and Mars.
As the competitive frenzy of the cold war ended, President George Bush in March 1992 appointed a new NASA Administrator, Mr. Goldin, who pledged an era in which the agency's endeavors would be "smaller, cheaper, faster, better," ending a trend to bigness and complexity that marked many aspects of NASA's rivalry with Moscow.
The Clinton Administration married this cost-cutting goal with a broad initiative to join the Russians in cooperative space projects. Last year, it hammered out a plan to have the Russians become partners in the space station project, which was mired in design studies after expenditures of more than $10 billion. The White House said the East-West outpost, in addition to rewarding Russia for good behavior and helping stabilize the Russian economy, would do more, cost less and be in orbit faster than it would if America did the project exclusively with its Western partners, Europe, Japan and Canada.
Vice President Al Gore, speaking recently in Washington, hailed the joint outpost as "a powerful physical symbol of what can be done here on Earth when governments replace obstruction with partnership."
Another area of accord is Earth-resources monitoring. For instance, NASA and the Russians are working to monitor the volcanoes of the Kamchatka Peninsula in eastern Russia, 29 of which are active, at times explosively so. Last August and September a NASA research jet, with a Russian co-pilot, carried a $1.2 million infrared multispectral scanner and an advanced camera over some of the volcanoes in a study meant to help predict eruptions. It was a first for such American gear. The area, rich in top-secret facilities, has been off limits to Westerners.
Analysts say such collaborations are likely to expand to satellites and environmental monitoring in general, where Russia has much experience and the United States has embarked on ambitious, multibillion-dollar plans for new fleets of spacecraft. In one developing program, NASA is to fly gear for mapping atmospheric ozone and aerosols aboard a Russian satellite. Another would have American teams fly as many has five new Earth-monitoring experiments aboard Russia's Mir space station.
 
Missions to Other Planets
 Another area where NASA is forging a broad alliance with Moscow is aeronautic research. It is negotiating to test American scramjet engines on Russian rockets, and plans to use the Russian Tu-144 supersonic transport jet from the Tupolev Design Bureau as a flying test bed for high-speed aeronautic research.
"The Tu-144 is a perfect fit between our needs and their capabilities," said Louis J. Williams, NASA's director of high-speed research. "This effort will give us up-to-date information on the real-world conditions that a supersonic airliner operates in -- data we wouldn't otherwise be able to obtain easily."
Perhaps the most visionary aspect of the emerging alliance centers on joint missions to send robotic probes to such places as Pluto, the outermost and most mysterious of the planets, the only one never visited by a spacecraft. Seeds of the union were sown as NASA planners found that tight budgets allowed them either to design a probe or buy a rocket for its launching -- but not to do both. That led to serious discussions with the Russians about their launching the probe, and evolved into plans to have them help design the robotic mission as well.
Mr. Goldin has asked his Pluto team to cut projected costs from $600 million to $400 million, and NASA officials believe that the goal may be possible only with the aid of the Russians.
NASA is also working closely with Moscow on the possibility of joint explorations of the planet Mars. Again, Russia would provide a rocket for the launching and some of the exploratory gear, including vehicles that would descend through the thin atmosphere to crawl on the planet's surface. The United States would provide the overall carrier vehicle, which would probably orbit the red planet to make remote observations after releasing the descent module.
The general merging with Moscow is seen by some experts as not only bold but laden with political and technical risks. An economic or political crisis in Russia could leave the United States suddenly partnerless, its joint endeavors on hold. More subtly, some experts say, the high-stakes politics of the merger could kindle disaster.
 
Fostering World Peace
 "Whenever a technical project is subordinated to political ends, the temptation grows to underestimate the technical problems that will arise and substitute enthusiasm for sound engineering," James E. Oberg, author of "Red Star in Orbit" and a long-time advocate of joint East-West programs, said in an interview.
"The end result can be a series of shocking technological surprises that everyone but the enthusiasts had forecast all along. We can hope it doesn't happen. But hoping is no substitute for realism."
NASA says it is taking every precaution to make sure the merger works as well as possible, and adds that not everything it plans to do in the future is tied to the Russians. New programs are getting under way that are entirely indigenous, such as a series of small satellites for solar-system exploration and Earth monitoring.
The White House says the merger is a judicious gamble needed to help Russia maintain its equilibrium and good behavior as centrifugal forces vie to tear that country apart. Most importantly, it says, such engagements and relationships can help foster global peace.
"Our partnerships and efforts to work together in space benefit the world, not just the United States and Russia," Vice President Gore told a gathering in Washington last month. "There are important real benefits for each country, not only in terms of technology, but also in terms of bridges of understanding that develop when we work toward common goals."

HEADLINE: Europe Ponders Future Outpost on the Moon

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
A MOVE is afoot in Europe to establish a manned scientific station on the Moon, an initiative that may eventually challenge America's primacy in space exploration.
Officials of the European Space Agency, a consortium of scientists from 14 countries, are seeking some $350 million from member nations to pay for the first in a series of lunar programs that could culminate in a manned Moon station within 25 years. Dr. Roger Bonnet, science director of the Paris-based agency, said in an interview that the first European emissary to the Moon, a small, unmanned craft named LEDA (for Lunar European Demonstration Approach) could land on the Moon by 2001. 
 LEDA, weighing only a few hundred pounds, would carry instruments to measure the darkness of the lunar sky, the frequency of meteorite impacts and the stability of the ground, all factors that would affect the functioning of a future astronomical observatory. Among the lander's other tasks would be an analysis of the lunar soil for components that could be used in the construction and operation of a permanent station.
Subsequent lunar landers carrying increasingly sophisticated equipment would pave the way for the establishment of a permanent manned lunar station in about the year 2020, Dr. Bonnet said. The new European initiative, which was enthusiastically endorsed at an E.S.A. workshop earlier this summer in Beatenberg, Switzerland, would bypass the large orbiting space station NASA plans as a preliminary to manned solar-system exploration.
For astronomers, an observatory on the far side of the Moon would allow telescopes and antennas to be shielded from light and radio interference from Earth. Like a space station, a lunar observatory would avoid the problem of atmospheric turbulence that afflicts Earth-based telescopes, but unlike a space station, it would rest on solid ground -- a more stable platform than an orbiting spacecraft.
European space officials acknowledge that the United States, despite the difficulties it faces, is still the world's leader in space technology. Dr. Bonney had particularly high praise for the Defense Department's recent Clementine mission to the Moon, the first American lunar mission since 1972. For a cost of only $80 million, the little spacecraft, which had been developed as part of a ballistic-missile defense program, carried out a major mapping project during the two months it spent in lunar orbit. Clementine was praised as an example of the kind of lean space program that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration should try to emulate.
But the European Space Agency has become disenchanted with some aspects of its collaboration with America's space programs. For example, the 14 full members of the European agency and an associate member, Canada, have so far invested about $850 million in the space station, an American initiative that has had international investment from the outset and whose continued financing by Washington is uncertain.
Dr. Bonnet joins many other European scientists in asserting that the United States is no longer a reliable partner in major scientific undertakings requiring multinational cooperation.
"Even when American scientific agencies intend to cooperate with foreign partners," he said, "they cannot commit themselves to more than one year in advance, which is the time necessary to review next year's budget. As long as this system exists, there will be a big risk in engaging in big cooperation with the United States in space as well as in other big science fields."
This is clearly bad news for many American scientists, who increasingly depend on international collaboration for jobs as well as research support. Another major American science project, the superconducting supercollider, was killed by Congress last year, casting hundreds of American physicists adrift and stunning European partners who had invested money, equipment and talent in the $8 billion project.
American high-energy physicists have been scrambling for jobs at the European community's CERN accelerator laboratory, whose Large Hadron Collider, currently under construction, seems destined to lead the world in particle physics research.
A similar collaborative challenge to American astronomy has come from the European Southern Observatory, a European consortium whose astronomical observatories in Chile are already among the world's most important. By the end of this century, the European Southern Observatory will have completed its Very Large Telescope, a monster array of instruments at Cerro Paranal, Chile, equivalent to a telescope about 52 feet in diameter. The device is likely to remain the largest telescope in existence through much of the 21st century.
 
Americans as 'Poor Relations'
 Some American astronomers work at the European consortium's observatories, just as some American physicists work at CERN, but increasingly the Americans are treated as poor relations, and unless they begin bringing American funds with them they are expected to find jobs in Europe scarce.
France's latest heavy-lift rocket, Ariane 5, is scheduled for a maiden flight next year, and if it works as expected, it could transport nearly one ton of equipment to the surface of the Moon, Dr. Bonnet said. An existing rocket, Russia's mighty Energia, could even place astronauts on the Moon right now, if Russia had the funds to prepare and launch a lunar mission, he said.
But European Space Agency officials hope to persuade the space ministers of their respective countries that a stepwise approach to colonizing the Moon (and then reaching out to the planets) will be both effective and economical.
"This may not be the best time to ask for more money for space ventures," Dr. Bonnet said, "but you have to start somewhere. Japan is very interested in this and wants to collaborate with E.S.A. on a Moon project. The Russians would like to join, but their idea of collaboration right now is asking for money, and we don't have any to spare."
Asked if the United States could be accepted as an associate member of the European collaboration, Dr. Bonney laughed and said, "It's probably possible in principle, but no one envisions it."
While aware of the risks involved in an American collaboration, European science administrators are willing to join forces with American counterparts under certain circumstances.
"But to minimize the risk," Dr. Bonnet said, "we have to know that there is at least consensus between all the American players -- NASA, the Congress, the White House and the scientists themselves. If that consensus is not total, the system can break down very quickly and end a project, as it did with the supercollider."
In the past, many European space projects have depended upon collaboration with outsiders, particularly with NASA. "But it's certainly time to change our attitude in E.S.A. and look for what is possible to do ourselves," Dr. Bonnet said.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
A Judge Comes Down Hard On the N.B.A. Players Union

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Pro basketball players' quest for unfettered free agency in the National Basketball Association was dealt a major setback yesterday when a Federal judge in Manhattan ruled that the league's salary cap, college draft and right of first refusal do not violate antitrust law.
The union immediately filed a motion of appeal in the 2d Circuit Court of Appeals, where it hopes to have its case heard in early September. 
 "You'll recall that the judge said that anyone who thinks this fight will end here needs a psychiatrist, not a lawyer," said Charles Grantham, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association. "Well, we don't need a psychiatrist and we're appealing expeditiously. We knew this would be a long fight."
 
Clearly Disturbed
 United States District Court Judge Kevin T. Duffy clearly seemed disturbed that the impasse found its way into his court. The parties, he wrote, were "using the court as a bargaining chip in the collective bargaining process."
The disputed policies have been central elements of N.B.A. economics for a decade. Without them, Commissioner David Stern argued, the league would be in chaos. The union said there would be greater player freedom, without anarchy.
Although the league and the union have portrayed theirs as a model labor relationship, their negotiations have often been fractious, and the union has sued the league several times in the past before labor agreements were reached.
 
Wins Its Point
 But the league wants to stay out of court, and it won the point.
"The judge said it's a labor matter and it has to be resolved in collective bargaining," Russ Granik, deputy commissioner of the N.B.A., said. "He's saying that the benefit of being a union is you have the right to strike. If the union wants that remedy, it can't also use the antitrust law."
Duffy's decision forces the league and union to continue their collective bargaining relationship although their 1988 labor agreement expired on June 23. It also lets teams sign rookies and veteran players to new contracts.
The union had obtained a temporary restraining order against any signings, but Duffy lifted the ban.
Grantham said he is advising players' agents to have their clients sign new contracts with one- or two-year "out clauses."
The N.B.A. launched the legal fracas last month by filing suit to prove that its labor stalemate with the union did not belong in Federal court, but at the negotiating table. The union countered by securing the restraining order and making its antitrust claims against the N.B.A.'s policies.
In its papers and in a one-day trial ordered by Duffy last Tuesday, the union argued that the N.B.A.'s policies restrained players from selling themselves to the highest bidder starting with their rookie days.
 
Judge Has His View
 The union, the judge said, "failed to show that the alleged restraints of trade are on balance unreasonably anti-competitive" and the "maintenance of competitive balance may outweigh their restrictive consequences."
The union failed to persuade the judge that the N.B.A.'s policies violate antitrust law because their 1988 labor agreement had ended. He said that a "nonstatutory labor exemption" immunizes the league from antitrust laws.
"The challenged measures," Duffy wrote, "do not violate the antitrust laws as long as the collective bargaining relationship exists" -- even if a new agreement does not.
The union has argued that although the players had gone along with disputed policies to help the N.B.A. during trying economic times in the early 1980's, they were no longer necessary to insure the league's financial future.
 
The Union View
 "It's not good law to have a rule that says employees who have agreed to some restraints, because the employer says it's in financial difficulty, must be struck with the restraints as long as it continues to be a union," said Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., a union lawyer.
Duffy said the players are not "stuck" with the N.B.A.'s polices, suggesting they can strike, or decertify the union as its collective bargaining agent, as the National Football League Players Association did to fight the N.F.L. in Federal court.
Schwarz said if the union wins a reversal in the court of appeals, the league may be liable for damages, based on the difference between what players signed for under the current system, and what their market value would be in an unrestricted environment.

HEADLINE: Governor Hasn't Changed on Death Penalty;
Time to Exit Gracefully

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's grandstanding on the death penalty is just his way of grasping at straws in an attempt to get re-elected. 
 Mr. Cuomo has vetoed the death penalty ever since he has been Governor. He even went so far as to have a convicted murderer extradited from Oklahoma. Taxpayer cost to house this convicted murderer in New York's penal system will run into the hundreds of thousands of dollars because Mr. Cuomo refused to allow him to be executed.
The time has come for Mr. Cuomo to leave political office gracefully and allow someone else to pull this state out of its economic demise. The Governor has done nothing to bring industry back to the Big Apple. During his tenure we have faced increased taxes, increased crime and the downfall of quality of life.
 
ROY W. GUTTMAN
Greenlawn, L.I., July 11, 1994

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Can health maintenance groups maintain better stock prices?

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim 

 BODY:
MOST health maintenance organization stocks headed south in the last few weeks, after news that three large health care purchasers in California had negotiated decreases in the premiums they will pay to health maintenance organizations next year.
What pulled the stocks lower, some analysts said, was the fear that the glory days might be ending for the H.M.O.'s, where profits have regularly exceeded analysts' estimates for several years. H.M.O. membership is high in California, and the state has long been regarded as a bellwether for managed health care. 
 But other analysts argue that California is a special case, which the rest of the country is following only slowly. And the California-based H.M.O.'s do not seem to be hurting. A number of them are still gaining business; some are expanding into nearby states, and some are even jumping cross-country to Florida.
Moreover, with medical inflation dramatically lessened, some analysts say the health maintenance organizations have been able to cut their own costs and force doctors and hospitals to accept lower payments for each person covered, relieving the H.M.O.'s of much of the pain.
Reductions in 1995 premiums were negotiated by the Bay Area Business Group on Health, a San Francisco-based employers group. It announced last month that a dozen big employers -- including the Bank of America, Bechtel, Chevron, McKesson, Pacific Telesis, Safeway and Wells Fargo Bank -- would receive cuts in premiums averaging 5 to 10 percent. Together, they cover 300,000 employees, retirees under 65 and dependents.
The California Public Employees Retirement System also negotiated cuts of at least 1.1 percent for the 920,000 people it covers. And the Health Insurance Plan of California, a state-sponsored small-business group covering 45,000 employees, won reductions averaging 6.3 percent.
Margo Vignola, a Salomon Brothers health care analyst, said the stocks of California-based H.M.O.'s, which fell as much as 24 percent since late May, have always traded below comparable companies in the Midwest and the East because of worries about competition. For years, prices and profits have been lower because of competition from the giant, nonprofit Kaiser Foundation H.M.O.'s. Even so, she said, "the California H.M.O.'s have generated better than expected growth."
Ed Keaney, an analyst in St. Louis at Stifel Nicolaus, said that in the San Francisco Bay area negotiations, Healthsystems International and Pacificare agreed to the deepest premium cuts. But he said they could offset most of the lower premiums by reducing payments to doctors and hospitals compensated on a per-person basis.
Both analysts recommend the shares of Healthsystems. They also like Foundation Health Plan, which has been aggressively gaining new business to make up for big military dependents' contracts it lost in December to a lower bid by Aetna Health Plans, a unit of Aetna Life and Casualty.
And investor gloom about H.M.O.'s may soon lift a bit, Mr. Keaney said, when the companies report what he expects will be another round of 20 to 25 percent earnings gains and strong increases in enrollment in the second quarter. "I think the stocks will come back to life soon," he said.
But Kimberly A. Purvis, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said per-person payments to California doctors and hospitals, and the utilization of hospital beds there, were already "at a low base level, to a point where it would be hard to extract another pound of flesh." She added: "The H.M.O.'s can pass along some of the pain, but not all of it. They are victims of their own efficiency."
No California H.M.O. is on her "buy" list, but Pacificare is "worth a look," she said. It focuses on Medicare patients "and is doing an excellent job of managing an older and sicker population."
Shares of Healthsystems closed at $27.75 yesterday, up 50 cents, and Foundation Health declined 12.5 cents, to $39, both on the New York Stock Exchange. Pacificare class A shares fell $1, to $51.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chase and Nationsbank Earnings Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Strong growth in lending and higher fees from consumer banking services increased second-quarter profits at two leading banks. The Chase Manhattan Corporation saw earnings rise 31.8 percent, while those at the Nationsbank Corporation were up 42.8 percent.
Consumers charged more on their credit cards while businesses borrowed more money to pay for expanding operations, fueling double-digit loan growth. But the banks felt a pinch in their mortgage businesses, as fewer consumers sought to refinance housing loans because of the higher interest rates. 
 Checking account fees and service charges helped lift fee income at many banks. With loans up, banks earned more from interest payments than they paid in interest on deposits. Fees from managing money for individuals and businesses also rose in the second quarter.
Chase, which is based in New York, earned $307 million, or $1.46 a share, compared with $233 million, or $1.20 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.
 
Global Corporate Banking
 Fees and commissions from consumer and global corporate banking activities grew 24 percent, to $480 million. Credit card fees, as well as fees from money management and corporate finance were up, too. Unlike many banks, Chase booked higher fees from mortgage banking activities, which the company attributed to its acquisition last year of a mortgage company and because the bank booked losses in its mortgage business a year earlier.
But a downturn in the stock and bond markets and volatility in foreign exchange caused Chase to make less money from buying and selling securities and currencies on behalf of clients and for their own accounts.
Trading revenue fell 19 percent, to $151 million. Foreign exchange trading revenue fell $7 million, to $78 million, while trading account revenue dropped $29 million, to $73 million.
Bad loans and foreclosures were down 53 percent, to $1.46 billion, compared with the corresponding period a year earlier.
In the first six months of the year, Chase earned $671 million, or $3.27 a share, compared with $386 million, or $1.95 a share, a year ago.
Chase's shares closed down 12.5 cents, to $38.625, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
At Nationsbank, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., earnings totaled $437 million, or $1.58 a share, compared with $306 million, or $1.20 a share, a year ago.
The number of new loans and leases rose 11 percent, to $94.6 billion. Loans to consumers were the biggest contributor to the overall increase, the bank said. Loan growth was also higher because Nationsbank bought several banks last year.
Net interest income -- representing interest earned on loans minus interest paid on deposits -- grew by 18 percent, to $1.3 billion.
The growth came from making higher-interest loans while keeping interest rates on deposits steady.
Nationsbank continued to make improvements in its problem loan portfolio. The number of loans that are in default fell 13 percent, to $1.4 billion.
Profits for the first six months rose 8.5 percent, to $854 million, or $3.10 a share, compared with $787 million, or $3.09 a share after a gain of $200 million, 79 cents a share, from a adjustment in accounting in the corresponding period last year.
Nationsbank shares rose 62.5 cents, to $55.125 yesterday, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Weaker vs. Mark But Gains Against the Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed against other currencies yesterday as foreign officials offered a variety of views about America's economic policy and exchange rates.
In Germany, a Bundesbank Council member, Otmar Issing, said the United States was "expanding its position as the world's biggest debtor almost on a weekly basis." 
 The central banker's comments came on top of numerous statements from German officials recently, many of whom have criticized the Clinton Administration and its stance toward the dollar.
Traders said Mr. Issing's remarks prompted an early bout of dollar selling, leaving it at 1.5485 German marks in late New York trading, off from 1.554 marks on Friday.
Against the Japanese yen, however, the dollar finished firmer, aided by official Japanese concern over the yen's strength.
In his first speech before the Japanese Parliament since taking office June 30, Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama emphasized the need for the "stabilization of currency exchange markets," a problem he said was compounded by "the yen's rapid appreciation."
 
Dollar at 98.45 Yen
The dollar rose to 98.45 yen in New York, from 97.86 yen on Friday.
U.S.-Japan trade relations remain at the center of the dollar's recent troubles, and late yesterday there were reports that the Clinton Administration might impose trade sanctions later this month.
Administration officials said there had been insufficient progress between the two countries.
"We're willing to negotiate, but obviously we are realistic," one senior official said. "There is a much greater desire on our part to have a results-oriented package, but we have this deadline."
Last month, the Administration gave Japan until July 31 to avoid trade sanctions by opening up its public contracts business in telecommunications and its purchasing of medical technology.
Several dealers said there was concern about the potential for a further deterioration in the United States trade balance. The Commerce Department will release May trade figures today.
"The trade numbers could underline problems for the market," said Dennis Pettit, chief dealer at the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan.
Separately, the Italian lira came under severe downward pressure amid fresh political turmoil. The lira's troubles erupted after Interior Minister Roberto Maroni said on Sunday that he was ready to step down in a political dispute. While the lira ended little changed against the dollar at 1,549 versus 1,550, it plunged to 1,003 against the mark, its lowest level this year.

HEADLINE: Dow Edges Ahead 1.62 in Light Trading

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
After a remarkable two weeks in which the Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 107 points, or 3 percent, the stock market barely roused itself at all yesterday. The Dow gained just 1.62 points to close at 3,755.43 on light trading volume.
Still, the market, as measured by the Dow and other major leading indexes, has returned to its mid-June highs, prompting talk that the summer rally is around the corner. 
 True, the rally has been around the corner since Memorial Day. But bears have dominated market sentiment for so long since the Federal Reserve Board raised interest rates last February, that traders feel the market is headed for a major tectonic shift toward bullishness simply because everyone has been so bearish.
Indeed, a few analysts say the rally is already here. Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist at Kemper Securities in Chicago, said, "The summer rally is already occurring -- it just started late and will probably extend into September." Mr. Chalasani said the currency markets seemed to be betting that the dollar had either reached bottom or was close to it and that the United States' strong economic fundamentals will eventually assert themselves and steady the dollar. That in turn helps the bond market.
Essentially, currency traders will simply tire of outmaneuvering themselves, he said. "You have to remember that less than 15 percent of daily currency trading is for business purposes," he said. "The rest is speculation."
While the Federal Reserve may still raise interest rates in the short run, he said, defending the dollar is unlikely to be the main reason. "The Fed wants the dollar to strengthen on its own and it can," Mr. Chalasani said. Many stock traders are betting that the Fed won't raise rates until later this year, thus helping corporate earnings and stock prices.
David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers, said the Dow could rise 100 points or more over the next three weeks, especially because traders see rising inventories and flattening car and home sales as evidence of a slowing economy with little inflation.
But Mr. Shulman cautions that a large market decline, of up to 400 points in the Dow, is still possible by the end of the year because of market skittishness over sensitive and volatile numbers, like monthly unemployment figures.
The market evidence yesterday was far from ferocious in either the bullish or bearish direction. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.06 points, to 455.22. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 1.26 points, to 722.62.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was somewhat below normal at 227.5 million shares, or more than 20 percent below this year's average of 288 million shares.
Rising software issues, especially Microsoft, and retail stocks offset declines in telephone stocks. Microsoft rose because Wall Street analysts said that, despite criticism from the Justice Department, there was little in the antitrust settlement that would hurt Microsoft's business. Wal-Mart, Kmart and Dayton Hudson saw their shares rise following strong rises in June retail sales announced earlier this month.
But U S West and AT&T declined after U S West agreed to buy cable-television properties and the Justice Department cleared AT&T's merger with McCaw Cellular. Such mergers acquisitions often hurt profits in the short run.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.38 point, to 251.44, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,135 to 1,023. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.04 points, to 432.59.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 13 rose, led by Aluminum Company of America, which rose 2 1/8, to 82 1/2, on no immediate news. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, only 131 rose, led by Wal-Mart, which rose 1/2, to 25 7/8.
