HEADLINE: Mastercard Plans to Move 540 Employees to Westchester

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Mastercard International will move all of its 540 employees in New York City to Westchester County next year, the company said yesterday.
While negotiations on a new building have not been completed, real-estate brokers familiar with the situation said the most likely new site is a vacant building owned by I.B.M. in Harrison, N.Y. 
 In June, company officials had said that they were considering moving most of the New York employees to a new suburban site. But they had insisted that the company would at least keep its global headquarters division, about 90 people, in the city.
"Employees and managers alike kept asking us, wouldn't it make more sense to keep everyone together in one place," F. David Brangaccio, a senior vice president of Mastercard, said in an interview on Monday. "So we reopened that question."
 
Turnaround for Company
 Although the number of jobs moving out of the city is small, the symbolic impact could be greater. "This is a sign that a major company feels it can operate effectively outside New York," said the chief executive of a large New York real-estate company, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Officials of the New York City Economic Development Corporation declined to comment on Mastercard's plans, since the company has not officially announced its move. Mastercard has scheduled a meeting to announce the move to its employees tomorrow.
The planned move represents a major turnaround for Mastercard.
Four years ago, the company, which was fast outgrowing its space at 888 Seventh Avenue at 53d Street, began an intensive study of where to set up shop. Last year, it announced its decision to stay in Manhattan. It leased nine floors at 1345 Avenue of the Americas at 55th Street, the old Burlington Industries building, and began making plans to move in by next May.
 
Seeking Option to Buy
 But Alex W. (Pete) Hart, who was Mastercard's president and was one of Manhattan's biggest champions, resigned in January, and his successor, H. Eugene Lockhart, decided that Manhattan was too expensive.
An internal memo faxed to The New York Times by an employee yesterday said that by moving to Harrison rather than to Burlington House, Mastercard will save $200 million over 20 years. The company has already sublet most of the Burlington House space, Jana Weatherbee, a spokeswoman for Mastercard, said.
The company is down to the wire on negotiations with the International Business Machines Corporation to take over the vacant I.B.M. building, at 2000 Purchase Street in Harrison, N.Y. I.B.M. had wanted to sell the building, which it vacated as part of its retrenchment, but Mastercard is holding out for a lease with an option to buy. But Mr. Brangaccio said the company was also still talking to Gateway One, a 525,000-square-foot building on North Lexington Avenue in White Plains, and may announce the move to its employees without specifying a new location.
The I.B.M. building, at 425,000 square feet, is much larger than the 350,000 square feet that Mastercard had leased in Burlington House. It could easily accommodate the 55 data-processing employees Mastercard has working in rental space in Lake Success, L.I., and the company is considering moving those employees to Harrison, too, when its lease at Lake Success expires at the end of 1997.
Mastercard had considered nine office buildings, primarily in White Plains and Stamford, Conn. The I.B.M. building in Harrison quickly rose to first-place status, real-estate brokers said. The 11-year-old building, on a 47-acre site that has turned into a luxury corporate park, was designed by the architect I. M. Pei. Mastercard would be the only tenant in the building, which would carry Mastercard's name.
"It's a special building that makes a really special statement," Mr. Brangaccio said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies Against Yen As Japan Trade Gap Is Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against the Japanese yen and most other leading currencies yesterday after the Government reported that the trade deficit with Japan narrowed in May, even though analysts doubted that the one-month decline marked a turning point in the American trade imbalance.
The dollar also gained amid talk in the currency market that the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, might hint at raising interest rates when he testifies before Congress today. Higher interest rates would make dollar-denominated investments more attractive. 
 Yesterday's gains prompted speculation that the dollar's five-month slide against the yen and the German mark might be ending.
"I think the dollar's slump is over," said John Hardy, managing director at Intercap Investments Inc. "Traders sold it without much regard for logic, and now it's coming back."
Some traders also said rumors of a power struggle in North Korea led to a brief flurry of dollar-buying.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 99.30 yen, up from 98.45 yen on Monday.
The dollar's resurgence was especially evident against the mark. The dollar jumped two pfennigs, to 1.5682 marks, up from 1.5485 marks.
The dollar started rising after the Commerce Department said the merchandise trade deficit with Japan narrowed to $4.39 billion in May from $5.48 billion in April.
Many analysts cite the United States' $60 billion annual trade deficit with Japan as the most compelling reason for the dollar's slump against the yen this year.
But a number of analysts questioned whether the May trade numbers represented more than a one-month blip. "This isn't a turning point in Japanese-U.S. trade," said Mark Vitner, economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C. "The deficit is going to get worse before it gets better."
Analysts said the slide in the dollar's value would widen the deficit in dollar terms, even though in volume terms Japanese exports to the United States were falling as the country's imports from America rose.
Mr. Vitner said the Japanese trade number was deceiving because it was not adjusted for seasonal factors.
Despite this skepticism, the dollar held onto its early gains amid speculation that Mr. Greenspan might hint at raising interest rates in his Congressional testimony today, even though many bond trader believe that the Fed is unlikely to push up rates in the next month. Still, many currency traders who sold dollars short earlier in the week bought them back yesterday to cover their positions in case Mr. Greenspan calls for higher rates to keep inflation in check.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
G.E. Earnings Up 14% Despite Some Setbacks

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The General Electric Company, the nation's fifth-largest industrial concern, reported yesterday that its profits jumped 14 percent in the second quarter, as strong gains in many of its manufacturing and financial operations offset weakness at NBC, G.E. Aircraft Engines and Kidder, Peabody, its troubled brokerage subsidiary.
G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., said its second-quarter net income totaled $1.52 billion, or 89 cents a share, up from $1.33 billion, or 78 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Revenue rose 10 percent, to $16.2 billion from $14.76 billion. 
 "G.E. once again demonstrated the earnings power from its diverse mix of businesses, which are continuing to expand their global presence," said John F. Welch, the company's chief executive. He noted that G.E.'s profit margins averaged 15.3 percent for the company's 12 major businesses in the second quarter.
 
Letting the Fittest Survive
 "We never did 10 in 116 years," he said in a recent interview, "and now we're doing 15 with lower prices." G.E. has been focusing on businesses where it is No. 1 or No. 2, shrinking or selling weaker operations and pushing productivity higher.
G.E.'s second-quarter results were close to what Wall Street analysts had expected and what Mr. Welch had estimated earlier this month. Nonetheless, the favorable earnings report pushed G.E.'s stock up $1 to close at $48.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Martin A. Sankey, an analyst at CS First Boston, was upbeat about G.E.'s near-term prospects, saying that the company's cyclical businesses should do well enough to offset the drag from weak businesses like jet engines. "This has essentially been the pattern for the last several quarters and should continue," he said
Profits were down from a year ago at G.E.'s jet engine division. The division has been struggling for several years as military and commercial aircraft orders have dried up and the company has been forced to slash thousands of jobs. And since December, the division has also been the target of an unusual Federal investigation into an employee's allegations of military contract fraud and safety violations.
Earnings were also lower at NBC. Last year, the highly rated broadcast of the final episode of "Cheers" -- with its increased advertising revenues -- helped give NBC's profits a one-time lift.
 
Leading Businesses Booming
 But most of G.E.'s leading businesses are thriving. Appliance sales have received a strong lift from consumers who are remodeling their homes as well as from a rebound in new house construction. G.E.'s plastics division is busy meeting heavy demand from car factories and computer makers. And its power systems division is shipping a lot of electrical generators and gas turbines overseas, particularly to vibrant emerging markets in Asia.
Despite a $90 million decline in profits from last year at its Kidder, Peabody brokerage subsidiary, GE Capital Services managed to post a 12 percent earnings increase in the second quarter, to $463 million. That gain dwarfed the already-announced $29.3 million loss at Kidder, mostly related to its huge mortgage trading operation. The huge financial services arm does everything from financing retailers' inventories to leasing aircraft, and most of its businesses are booming.
Kidder, whose chief executive resigned earlier this month, is still struggling to overcome a scandal on its bond trading desk that resulted in a $210 million charge against G.E. earnings in the first quarter.

HEADLINE: Classrooms on the Information Highway

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C.

 BODY:
Prof. Maria Domoto stood alone in a quiet broadcast room on the campus of the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, ready to teach her Japanese course to high school students. She checked the television monitor. The large screen was divided in four and all of the quadrants were on. She could see her three high school classes taking their seats.
"Jamie, you don't have your glasses on today," she said, glancing at the lower left quadrant of the screen, the North Mecklenburg High School class. 
 "Contacts," said Jamie Stubbs, a sophomore, who was sitting eight miles from the teacher.
Professor Domoto viewed the upper right quadrant, her Harding High School class. "Where's Calvin?" she said.
"He's at executive council inductions," answered Eric Riggs, who was sitting 15 miles away.
 
Moans From Over the County
 "O.K., you now have the tests for Chapter 18," Professor Domoto said. "I faxed them to you a half hour ago."
From all over the county, she could hear the moans.
In the last year, educators and officials in business and government from across the United States and 20 foreign countries have made the pilgrimage to North Carolina to see what the information highway is going to do to the classroom. "North Carolina's out in front, no question about it," said Linda Roberts, a technology expert for the Federal Department of Education.
Visitors are impressed. "People are amazed at how well the technology works," said Jane Smith Patterson, the technology adviser to Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina. "As soon as they see it, they realize what we have here."
It is this interactive: Jason Puryear sneezed at East Mecklenburg High, and before classmates could react, Professor Domoto, 20 miles away but visible in a quadrant of all screens, said, "Bless you."
 
New Course Opportunity
 The new technology excites educators because it can be used to give students in poor and rural parts of North Carolina their only chance at courses like Japanese, Latin and statistics.
But all this carries a sizable price tag at a time when public school budgets are being pared. State officials estimate that a high school must spend $110,000 to $150,000 to buy the equipment to hook into the fiber-optic system that instantly transmits these images, another $40,000 to $50,000 a year in telephone company user fees, as well as hire extra employees to maintain the system.
While the state heralds a futuristic technology that "increases efficiency" and "saves taxpayer dollars," many experts say that is stretching the system's attributes. "It's never going to be less costly," said Dennis Bybee, associate executive director of the International Society for Technology in Education. He compares the changes the new communications technology will bring to the classroom with the changes that have already occurred in modern business offices.
 
'Need More Teachers'
 A few years ago no one had a fax, Mr. Bybee said, but now every business needs one. "It's not less costly, but it will be better -- and better will be the standard," he said. "You actually will need more teachers," but he added they would be able to do more.
North Carolina began its pilot program last year with 16 public schools. The Legislature recently passed a bill to take the program beyond the experimental stage, providing $7 million for start-up costs. By January nearly 100 schools are expected to be hooked up, from Cape Hatteras High School on the Atlantic Coast to Tri-County Community College in Murphy, 400 miles away on the state's far western end.
The fiber-optic cable connection between sites allows electronic signals to travel so rapidly, back and forth, that interaction is instantaneous to the eye and ear. Last year it meant that several isolated schools had access for the first time to courses usually limited to well-to-do suburbs.
Ricky Poovey, a junior ranked No. 10 in his class of several hundred at East Lincoln High School on the rural outskirts of Charlotte, had long wanted to take Latin. He plans to study marine biology in college and knows that Latin would help with species identification. But there were not enough students interested for his school to create a course.
As part of the pilot program, however, Ricky and six other East Lincoln students were hooked up via two-way video with the 22 students in first-year Latin at suburban East Mecklenburg High, 50 miles away.
At a parent-teacher night last fall, the East Lincoln parents visited their children's East Lincoln classroom and met the East Mecklenburg Latin teacher, Joan Lewis, over the two-way system.
The parents were not used to meeting strangers on two-way television. "My dad didn't say too much," said Christian Lucas. "He's kind of shy."
As with any cutting-edge venture, a leap of faith is involved on everyone's part. While a consortium of telephone companies here, led by Southern Bell, GTE Telephone and Carolina Telephone, is putting fiber cable in the ground, the state's Public Utility Commission has not yet set tariff rates.
The agreement calls for the phone companies to build and own the system and for the state to be its biggest user. Though high schools and colleges are expected to be the major customers in the first phase, hospitals, government offices and prisons are also expected to apply for state financing to participate in the program. The expectation is that business will soon follow government and will be willing to pay the phone companies a higher fee for commercial interactive service.
From the start, the Governor's office has insisted that poor andrural areas be included. This has not been the rule in many states. A recent study by the Consumer Federation of America criticizes efforts in other parts of the country for not including the poor and, instead, letting market forces dominate, so that well-to-do communities are the main beneficiary of fiber-optic systems.
The new technology is also creating new quandaries. For example, what is the optimum size of the video classroom? Technology experts give the impression that money will be saved because two-way video can match one teacher with several classrooms at once. A representative from Northern Telecom, one of the companies providing equipment for the North Carolina system, emphasized in an interview the economies of pairing one teacher with 100 youngsters in six classrooms across the state.
But several teachers who worked with the technology last year, including Professor Domoto and Ms. Lewis, say they cannot handle more than a normal high school classroom of 20 to 30 students. "Beyond 20 to 30, you lose any personal contact," Professor Domoto said. "I want to see the students I'm teaching."
This year's oceanography course, for example, originated 200 miles of here on the Atlantic coast, at Haggard High in Wilmington, and included 58 students at five schools. Students here at East Mecklenburg High, a "receiving site," say that with so many schools on the screen at once it was hard getting noticed by the Wilmington teacher. "It's a big process to jump in with a comment," said Kim Miller, a senior.
Next year, instead of using two-way video to teach oceanography, East Mecklenburg will use its own teacher in a standard classroom.
 
Extra Help a Problem
 The new technology requires extra manpower. Each school needs a technician to run the equipment and supervise the video classroom at a cost of about $30,000 in salary and benefits, Ms. Patterson says.
Teaching assistants may be necessary, too. If a teacher is 15 or 50 or 300 miles away, a student who needs help after school has a problem. Professor Domoto's college-level Japanese class started with 26 high school students last fall and by the end of the year was down to 11 because of youngsters who failed or dropped out. This fall, two teaching assistants will be available for extra help, either by telephone or on visits to the high schools. It is likely that on-screen time for remedial help will also be scheduled, but that, too, adds to costs.
Nor do all subjects seem well suited to the new medium. Two-way video is impressive in foreign language classes like Professor Domoto's. Her homework typically involves preparing a passage, and it is easy to determine who did the work by how well they recite in class.
But a course like English composition, with written homework, would be harder to conduct long distance. It could mean either hiring an aide to handle the fax machine or using computers with modems to transmit the compositions back and forth. Both methods add costs.
And while the new teaching medium offers immediacy, it is not the same as being there. For example, Jon Leary, an East Mecklenburg senior on the receiving end of a three-day-a-week oceanography course, said the course was a much richer experience for the originating class in Wilmington. "They get to play with the plants and we get to look at the pictures," he said. "They'll show us an octopus over the TV so we get the visual idea. They tell us it's gooshy. We don't feel it's gooshy."
Also, the video classroom where East Mecklenburg students go for two-way learning has no running water, exhaust fans or other basic necessities of a science laboratory.
 
Rethinking Workplace Rules
 Improved technology is generally equated with efficiency, but efficiency requires lots of planning. For the oceanography course, science teachers from the five schools were supposed to meet via the two-way video system regularly after school to coordinate lessons.
But Walt Modrell, an East Mecklenburg science teacher, said there was only 90 minutes a month available to them on the network for five-way planning conferences. "It wasn't enough," he said. As a result, instead of team-teaching, the course was run from the Wilmington school. And Mr. Modrell spent several days a week sitting with his East Mecklenburg class in the video room watching his students being taught.
The new technology will force educators to rethink workplace rules. Ms. Lewis, the Latin teacher, said that she was supposed to have a maximum of 150 students a semester, but that if her video students were counted, her load exceeded 160 each semester last year.
Discipline is another uncharted area. Thus far, most distance learning classes have involved motivated high school students taking specialized courses, often for college credit. But as the technology reaches more average students or those who need remedial help, how will a teacher handle a problem youngster 300 miles away?
There is no question that the technology has a powerful, almost hypnotic effect. As Julie Yin, an East Mecklenburg student who took psychology on the system, says, "You grow up with TV, you pay attention more. You stare at the monitor and just listen -- it really holds you."
But the power of the medium cuts two ways. You expect more from TV -- a fast pace, good editing, quick cuts, some laughs. "A bad teacher," Ms. Patterson said, "looks even worse on a TV screen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: North Carolina has an interactive television system that lets an instructor teach students at several sites with the students able to respond instantaneously. Jason Puryear, front left, and Ayako Shimada, front right, are in a Japanese class at East Mecklenburg High in suburban Charlotte being taught by television from Charlotte. They are viewing their teacher on a screen like the monitor behind them. (Donna Bise for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Extend a Rally; Traders Await Fed Chief

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The bond market extended its rally yesterday as traders awaited Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman.
Treasury prices were bolstered in part by strong international demand for dollar-denominated securities. 
 The Treasury's 30-year bond rose 14/32 of a point, or $4.38 for $1,000 of bonds. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 7.46 percent, from 7.50 percent on Monday.
Bonds rallied amid "a change in sentiment as the market went from expecting a Fed tightening soon to expecting the Fed to wait" before raising interest rates, said Fred Leiner, market strategist at the Continental Bank in Chicago.
 
Greenspan Scheduled Today
 Mr. Greenspan is scheduled to give Congress his six-month review of Federal Reserve policy, beginning today. Many bond traders and analysts say the Fed will delay increasing interest rates for at least a month because inflation appears to be in check, even though there was some speculation in the currency market that Mr. Greenspan might hint at raising rates in his testimony.
Indeed, Mr. Greenspan said this week that the nation's money supply was not expanding at an inflationary rate. Last week, he said inflation was slowing.
Mr. Greenspan's "comments suggest that interest rates are on hold," said Troy Bowler, a market strategist at Paine Webber International in London.
The Fed has pushed up short-term interest rates four times this year in an effort to rein in inflation.
Recent reports show inflation is subdued. Producer prices did not rise in June, while consumer prices rose an expected three-tenths of 1 percent.
The bond market was also helped yesterday by a revival of the London-based Eurodollar bond market and a growing appetite for Treasury securities by non-American institutions, traders said.
There's been a rebound "of demand for Eurobonds" denominated in dollars, including a $1 billion sale of five-year bonds by a large Dutch bank, said Charles Quigley, a bond trader for Chemical Securities in London.
"People are attracted by five-year dollar bonds," said a trader at the Generale Bank in Brussels. "It's not very usual for an issue to be sexy for both" institutions and individuals.
London investors bought as much as $1 billion of Treasury securities maturing in as many as 10 years, some traders said. The 10-year Treasury note rose 12/32 of a point to yield 7.13 percent, down five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from Monday.
 
Unfazed by Trade Gap
 "The market overreacted to perceived strength and the fear that we'll have inflation," said Brooks Nelson, who handles $230 million at Nelson Capital Management.
Treasury prices advanced yesterday, even though the Government said the nation's trade deficit rose 7.6 percent in May, a figure that had little impact because it's almost two months old. Bonds initially fell amid concern that a wider trade gap would cause a drop in the dollar, traders and analysts said. A weaker dollar often causes declines in dollar-denominated investments, like Treasury bonds.
But the dollar rose after the report, which also noted that the nation's merchandise trade deficit with Japan had narrowed. That in turn helped bond prices, traders said.
Since July 11, the 30-year Treasury bond's yield has dropped 26 basis points, as prices rose in their biggest seven-day rally since April.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
American Expansion For Honda

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 19

 BODY:
The Honda Motor Company, the first Japanese auto maker to build vehicles in the United States, announced a series of steps today that are intended to increase its North American car production. The expansion should help to mitigate the high costs, caused by the soaring value of the Japanese yen, of building cars in Japan and exporting them to the United States.
The expansion, consistent with Honda's decade-old strategy of seeking growth mainly outside Japan, is expected to tap emerging Latin American markets, especially Mexico, and raise Honda's market share in the United States and Canada. 
 "We will undertake new sales, manufacturing and R.&D. activities to increase the efficiency and reach of our operations throughout the Americas," said Koichi Amemiya, who heads Honda's activities in the Americas.
 
Making a Political Point
 By producing more cars in North America, Honda may also strengthen its political case that it is a global manufacturer that has provided numerous jobs and benefits to the American economy, and therefore should not be subject to protectionist pressure. Honda and other Japanese auto makers are annoyed by a law, written with the help of the Big Three auto makers, that takes effect this fall and requires new cars to carry a sticker disclosing the percentage of their foreign and domestic content.
"Honda already has the highest local content of the Japanese auto makers building in this country," said David Healy, an auto industry analyst for S. G. Warburg & Company. "Honda has been criticized that their operations are only screwdriver factories that assemble parts imported from Japan. If it ever was true, it certainly is not true now."
All of the Japanese auto makers, attempting to use their global production systems as a way to serve world markets, have been shifting more car production to the United States in recent years and exporting a higher percentage of their North American production. Part of the strategy is to blunt the costly effects of the yen's rise in value against the dollar by building cars in America and pricing them in dollars, instead of building them in Japan and converting the price to dollars from yen.
Jay W. Chai, chairman and chief executive of Itochu International, a Japanese-owned trading company based in New York, said: "All the Japanese auto makers have to find ways to get their costs out of yen and into dollars. Honda is a creative company, but it has to be a company that makes money."
But Scott Whitlock, executive vice president for North American manufacturing, said: "This strategy isn't a reaction to the recent rise of the yen. We've been saying that we want to localize our operations for years."
 
 
 
$310 Million Project
 Today company executives set forth details of a $310 million expansion of production capacity in the United States, Canada and Mexico during the next three years.
In addition to expanding capacity at factories in Marysville, Anna, and East Liberty, Ohio, as well as in Alliston, Ontario, Honda will build a small plant in Guadalajara, Mexico, to make automobiles from kits. Over all, Honda said it would add about 1,100 workers to its North American work force of roughly 15,900. Honda said it would also increase its North American research and development, marketing activities and opportunities for American suppliers.
Although Honda is small compared with competitors like the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Toyota Motor Corporation, its steady expansion has shown that it can make big waves in the market with relatively little financial investment. The amount Honda is planning to spend is tiny by automotive standards, and includes no new floor space or assembly lines for its existing factories. Yesterday, for example, Ford said it was investing $500 million over the next few years to expand a single steering-gear plant in Indiana.
During the next few years Honda said it would also introduce two new Acura luxury models, both designed and assembled in North America. One model will be sold in the United States and Canada, and the other only in Canada. Honda announced in January that it would be the first Japanese auto maker to assemble a luxury vehicle in North America. About 60 to 65 percent of its sales in the United States are of cars made in the United States and Canada, a proportion that will rise to 75 to 85 percent in the next few years, a spokesman said.
 
 
 
18% Rise in Car Capacity
 Honda's annual production capacity will increase 18 percent, to 720,000 vehicles by 1997 from 610,000 now, and its engine capacity will rise 50 percent, to 750,000 from 500,000. The increase in engine production will include a new V6 in 1996, the first Honda car engine larger than a four-cylinder to be built in the United States. Honda's single largest investment, $200 million, will go to expand its engine plant in Anna.
By 1999 Honda expects to export about 150,000 vehicles annually from the United States and Canada, double the 75,000 vehicles it expects to export this year.
The Mexico plant, the spokesman said, will initially supply the budding Mexican market. Most of the parts will be exported to the plant from Honda factories and those of suppliers in the United States. But Honda said it hoped eventually to export from the Guadalajara plant as well.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Swelled Again in May

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit soared again in May, as the American economy pulled in more and more manufactured products from abroad while the weak dollar did only a little to spur foreign buying of American goods and services by the still sluggish economies of Europe and Japan.
The Commerce Department reported today that the shortfall between exports and imports climbed to $9.17 billion, from $8.53 billion in April. American imports rose 1.2 percent, to a record $65.45 billion, while exports grew only two-tenths of a percent from April, to $56.27 billion. 
 The trade deficit with Japan actually fell in May by almost 20 percent, to $4.39 billion, but economists say that is largely a seasonal phenomenon, not a harbinger of change. The figure has declined in May each of the last four years, only to come roaring back in subsequent months.
On Monday, in fact, Japanese officials in Tokyo, who get their trade data out sooner than Washington does, released their statistics for June, which showed the imbalance in trade with the United States sharply widening again.
Today, Clinton Administration officials met at the White House to rethink trade strategy with Japan. Officials are saying that unless there is some movement out of Tokyo in the next 10 days, they will set in motion trade sanctions on Japan for its failure to meet a July 31 deadline to open its public contracts market for medical equipment and telecommunications.
The United States deficit with Japan for the first five months of this year is still 10 percent ahead of last year's pace, at a total $24.9 billion -- although Japanese products are more expensive with the weak dollar and the strong yen. The deficit with Japan remained by far the nation's largest and accounted for just under half the total American trade deficit.
If there is good news for the American economy in these trade numbers it is that American exports to Japan for the first five months of this year are up 8 percent, with healthy increases across the board in consumer goods, machinery and autos. The reason these exports have not improved the overall trade balance with Japan is because American imports from Japan are up 9.3 percent over the same period, despite the steadily weakening dollar and strengthening yen.
This raises some interesting theoretical questions. Standard economic theory says that if a country's currency devalues, the immediate impact is a worsening of its trade deficit, because buying patterns take time to shift, so initially it is paying more for the same volume of imports. Over a two-year period, the theory says, volumes of imports will decline in the country whose currency is devalued and its exports will rise, because its cheaper currency makes all of its products easier to sell abroad.
 
Theory Hasn't Worked
 But the dollar has steadily declined against the yen -- sharply in the last two months, but steadily for the last few decades -- and the theory has not worked out as expected. That may be in part because Japanese markets are not as open as they should be, so even cheaper American exports cannot penetrate in high enough volumes to affect the deficit.
In addition, the United States imports certain products from Japan that are not easily replaced, even when the price goes up because of currency fluctuations. These include ceramic packages for microcomputers, flat panel displays, certain machine tools, chemicals used in growing silicon crystals for semiconductors and luxury cars with zero defects.
So for the moment, the American economy seems to be experiencing the worst of all worlds with Japan: The United States appetite for Japanese imports remains high, despite their higher costs, which means that the trade deficit may continue to worsen or hold steady, even with the dollar having lost about 10 percent of its value against the yen in the last six months.
"The trade deficit reflects both the growth differentials between the U.S. and its trading partners and the need for further market openings around the world," said Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown.
 
China Trade Gap Grows
 The trade gap with China also ballooned in May by $400 million, jumping to $2.22 billion from $1.79 billion in April. While much attention has been focused on Japan, the United States had a record $22.8 billion trade deficit with China last year and the deficit with Beijing is up 22 percent on that level already this year.
The trade gap with the newly industrialized Asian countries also widened by $525 million, to $1.1 billion, and the deficit with Western Europe surged from $83 million in April to $1.43 billion in May. The sluggish European economies simply are not buying as they used to from the United States, while American imports from them remain very healthy. The trade deficit with Germany is now the largest it has been since December 1988.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Profit Is Down Sharply At Merrill and Lehman

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest securities firm, and Lehman Brothers Holdings, a large stock and bond underwriter, reported sharp declines in second-quarter earnings yesterday.
Two major regional firms -- Raymond James of St. Petersburg, Fla. and the Inter-Regional Financial Group of Minneapolis -- also reported big drops in their profit. 
 The declines reflect the substantial advance in interest rates that have disrupted stock, bond and commodity markets this year and made the second quarter the worst for the securities industry since 1990.
"It highlights how cyclical these businesses are," said Douglas Eby, vice president of Robert E. Torray & Company, a money manager in Bethesda, Md. "When you can't move the product and the price is going down, it has a dramatic effect on earnings."
Merrill Lynch's stock fell 87.5 cents yesterday to close at $36.25 and Lehman Brothers dropped 62.5 cents to close at $15.125.
 
Six-Month Period Better
 Profit at Merrill Lynch declined 27 percent, to $252 million, or $1.18 a share, from $345 million, or $1.52 a share, in the similar period of 1993. For the first half of the year, net earnings slipped 4 percent, to $624 million, or $2.87 a share, from $652 million, or $2.88 a share, after adjustment for an accounting change in the corresponding period of 1993.
Daniel P. Tully, the firm's chairman and chief executive, called the second quarter "the most difficult operating environment for our industry in over three years." He cited "rising interest rates, unsettled currency markets, investor caution and a sharp decline in global underwriting volume, industrywide" as contributing factors.
Principal-transaction revenue decreased 25 percent, to $561 million, and investment-banking revenue dropped 22 percent, to $322 million. Still, Merrill Lynch remained the leading underwriter of both debt and equity securities.
Earnings at Lehman Brothers declined 79 percent in the second quarter, to $20 million, or 11 cents a share, from $95 million a year earlier, when the trading firm was owned by American Express. It would have earned 90 cents a share in the second quarter of 1993, had it been publicly owned and separately listed. The 1994 quarterly results include a $12 million charge related to the spinoff on May 31.
 
Financial Effect of Spinoff
 For the first half, profit was down 52 percent, to $62 million, from $129 million in the April-June quarter of 1993. On a per-share basis, earnings were 40 cents, compared with 63 cents before charges for the spinoff and accounting changes.
Trading revenue fell 17 percent, to $361 million, in the second quarter, while investment-banking revenue dropped 27 percent, to $151 million. These declines were attributed to "adverse market conditions in both the United States and Europe."
In an effort to provide greater incentive, Lehman Brothers said it would begin paying part of some employees' compensation in stock. Under the arrangement, for instance, Richard Fuld Jr., the chairman and chief executive, and T. Christopher Pettit, the president and chief operating officer, would receive 62.5 percent of their total compensation in restricted stock. Other senior executives will get 50 percent of their total compensation in this kind of stock, which is convertible to common stock on a one-to-one basis in five years.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Corn and Soybeans Tumble On Report of Thriving Crops

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Corn and soybean futures prices slumped to their lowest levels in more than a year yesterday after the Government said the crops were thriving in the warm, humid Midwest.
The Agriculture Department rated 86 percent of the corn crop and 79 percent of the soybeans in good-to-excellent condition as of Sunday. The marks were among the highest for those crops since the department began the rating system in 1985, said Dale Gustafson, grain analyst with Smith Barney Shearson. 
 Corn for September delivery sank 3 1/2 cents on the Chicago Board of Trade, to $2.21 3/4 a bushel, and August soybeans dropped 13 1/4 cents, to $5.99 1/4 a bushel. Both contracts notched intraday lows that were the lowest for an active contract since June 1993.
September wheat rose 2 1/4 cents, to $3.30 1/4 a bushel, amid concerns about scab disease, a fungus, in the spring wheat crop. September oats slipped 3/4 cent, to $1.16 1/2 a bushel.
Green coffee beans for September delivery plunged 7.55 cents, to $2.335 a pound on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.
Stephen Platt of Dean Witter said the drop was part of a continuing correction in coffee prices, which more than doubled to $2.74 a pound from June 24 to July 13 after two severe frosts in Brazil, the largest coffee producer.
 
Cold Forecast in Brazil
 Losses were limited by forecasts for more cold weather in Brazil this weekend, Mr. Platt said.
Silver and copper futures rose strongly on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting simmering inflation fears and prospects for stronger European and Chinese demand for copper as those economies pick up steam. Gold followed silver higher.
August gold rose 90 cents, to $387.10 a troy ounce; September silver rose 7.3 cents, to $5.345 a troy ounce, and September copper rose 3.75 cents, to $1.162 a pound.
In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, August light sweet crude oil slipped 5 cents, to $19.46 a barrel, while September deliveries rose 14 cents, to $19.23 a barrel; August heating oil rose 0.64 cent, to 49.48 cents a gallon; August unleaded gasoline rose 0.28 cent to 54.25 cents a gallon, and August natural gas rose 1.4 cents, to $1.959 for 1,000 cubic feet.
In livestock trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, August live cattle fell 0.52 cent, to 68.80 cents a pound; August feeder cattle dropped 0.25 cent, to 78.80 cents a pound; August live hogs rose 0.27 cent, to 44.77 cents a pound, and August frozen pork bellies rose 0.43 cent, to 32.75 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Kellogg enlists real people to stress the value of its breakfast.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE Kellogg Company is extending ambitious efforts to change consumer perceptions that the prices of its cereals are as high as the corn in Kansas in August.
Humorous television commercials and print advertisements by Leo Burnett U.S.A. promote the notion that the prices of three best-selling Kellogg brands -- Frosted Flakes, Raisin Bran and Rice Krispies -- are "just part of the value in a Kellogg's breakfast." 
 They began appearing in June, five months after a similar campaign for another popular Kellogg cereal, Corn Flakes, which asserted that its average price of less than a quarter a bowl was "another reason to taste them again for the first time."
Kellogg's strategy is to pour money -- just how much, the company won't say -- into campaigns aimed at altering shoppers' beliefs that after years of Kellogg's raising prices by an average of 5 to 6 percent annually, private-label and store-brand cereals have become more economical buys.
By one count, Kellogg raised prices five times between January 1991 and March 1994, compared with three times for General Mills, No. 2 behind Kellogg in the nation's estimated $8 billion ready-to-eat cereal market.
"We believe the ads reinforce for consumers that they are getting a great value when they eat a Kellogg cereal," Karen MacLeod, a spokeswoman for Kellogg in Battle Creek, Mich., said.
"We feel we've always been the value leader," she added, "and continue to be."
A leader, yes, but Kellogg's lead has been shriveling faster than flakes under milk. From 1988 to 1993, Kellogg's market share fell from 42.2 percent to 35 percent, according to data compiled by John C. Maxwell Jr., an analyst with the Wheat First Butcher Singer brokerage firm in Richmond. Rising sales of lower-priced alternative brands, though still tiny over all, have cut into Kellogg's results, as have a paucity of successful new products and gains by rivals like Post, Quaker and Ralston Purina.
The commercials for the three brands, like their Corn Flakes precursor, feature unscripted vignettes of consumers rather than actors. They were directed by Gary Weiss of 1/33 Productions in New York, who formerly made short films for "Saturday Night Live."
Each spot centers on a brand's familiar characters or slogans. The commercial for Frosted Flakes asks, "Would you spend 30 cents to have breakfast with Tony?" referring to the brand's tiger mascot; it is set, appropriately, in a zoo.
The commercial for Raisin Bran plays off that brand's longtime "Two scoops of raisins" theme to ask, "Hey, have you heard the latest scoop?" The answer comes as a man holds aloft a stack of newspapers -- presumably The Battle Creek Enquirer -- bearing the banner headline "Kellogg's Raisin Bran for 45 cents."
And the commercial for Rice Krispies, shot at a college, offers a "Snap, Crackle, Pop quiz," invoking the brand's trio of elf-like pixies. After people fail to guess that a serving of Rice Krispies costs 35 cents, one man mangles their names as "Snackle, Crack, Apop."
Walter Maes, an executive vice president and group creative director with Burnett in Chicago, said, "You could never write anything like that."
"There's a level of communication there I can't explain," he added. "When a real person's talking about something, I believe it much more than an announcer."
The belief levels among cereal industry analysts vary.
Nomi Ghez of Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York called Kellogg's campaign "a good idea."
"From a public relations and consumer relations point of view, it's better to maintain lower prices," she said, "but that's clearly not Kellogg's decision."
Data "show consumers with split personalities," she added, because while private-label brands "are growing at a faster rate than branded cereals, at the same time consumers continue to buy more cereal and the total market is growing."
"If consumers really thought cereal was way overpriced and there were less expensive alternatives," Ms. Ghez said, "they'd buy them."
Mr. Maxwell of Wheat First said that General Mills "has gone one-up on Kellogg" by trying to raise its market share, at 29 percent last year, by reducing suggested retail prices of 10 best-selling brands like Cheerios, Trix and Wheaties. General Mills is promoting those reductions, which average 11 percent, in a campaign carrying the theme "Good cereal, good value."
"When your major competitor puts banners on 40 percent of its boxes saying 'Now! Lower price!,' it puts some pressure on you to either lower your prices or tell consumers your prices are low enough," said John M. McMillin of Prudential Securities in New York.
"I guess Kellogg took the lesser of two evils," he added.
The Kellogg campaign also serves to "tell consumers it's O.K. to buy cereal without a coupon," Mr. McMillin said -- a crucial goal because Kellogg, as well as General Mills, is trying to wean shoppers from short-term promotions by reducing the flood of cents-off coupons they issue.

HEADLINE: AT LUNCH WITH: Richard Hughes;
An Actor Prepares; Vietnam Interrupts

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
RICHARD HUGHES, fabled as the last American to leave Saigon in the 1970's, is finding that Vietnam still refuses to let go of him. And vice versa.
In fact, he believes Vietnam has a way of following him around. So Mr. Hughes was hardly surprised when, rehearsing for an Off Off Broadway production of "The Seagull" in 1992, he stepped off the A train at Canal Street and came face to face with the big green sign of the Kinh Do Vietnamese Restaurant. 
 As an omen, not to mention an eating place, it was hard to pass up. So Mr. Hughes, a 51-year-old Pittsburgh-born actor who looks like Clint Eastwood in his less craggy days, surrendered to the lure of a bowl of pho in the same way he had given himself to Vietnam and the cause of the homeless urchins he sheltered in his Shoeshine Boys hostels in wartime Saigon a quarter century ago.
That's where I first met him, and as a correspondent for The Times in Saigon, I wrote the first piece about the Shoeshine Boys.
Since he first discovered Kinh Do ("Big City"), Mr. Hughes has come back to the restaurant at 19 Avenue of the Americas for pho, a hearty rice-noodle soup with beef, and for the crispy pork and shrimp rolls called cha gio. In fact, he chose Kinh Do as the place to have lunch recently and talk about how Vietnam derailed the budding acting career that he is now trying to get back on track.
He also recounted his campaign to gain freedom for two former Vietnamese colleagues jailed in Ho Chi Minh City (formerly Saigon) in 1990 for what the Government called "anti-socialist activities," a costly cause that has drained him financially, leaving him more than $35,000 in debt.
"I made a couple of copies," he began, turning up at the table in a blue work shirt and sliding his rangy six-foot form into a seat.
A couple of copies? His briefcase bulged with dogeared correspondence with Tom Cruise, Paul Newman, Robert De Niro and others who have helped his cause; newspaper clippings and fund-raising appeals; briefing papers, and manifestoes focused on the cases of Doan Than Liem, a lawyer who is reported close to release, cutting short his 12-year term, and Do Ngoc Long, an economist who was freed last year and is awaiting asylum in the United States.
Exuberantly boyish, with blue eyes and salt and pepper hair, Mr. Hughes seems to know he can be a pain but leavens his passion with good humor. "I'm committed," he said. "Not obsessive."
He remembered enough Vietnamese to banter with the restaurateur, Tu Van Nguyen, a former South Vietnamese Army major who spent 10 years in Communist re-education camps and jails.
Mr. Hughes would have been satisfied with a bowl of pho, but Mr. Tu would not hear of it. Nothing but the house special would do. Mr. Tu scurried off to see to it.
He soon emerged with a compromise. A double order of cha gio to start, along with a plate of lettuce leaves and mint sprigs to wrap around them and a dipping bowl of nuoc mam, the fermented fish sauce.
Over the crunchy rolls and iced glasses of sweet lemonade the menu charmingly calls so da, Mr. Hughes recalled his early acting career, all but hijacked by the Vietnam War.
After graduating in 1965 from Carnegie Tech and two years later from the Boston University Graduate School of Drama, where his classmate was Paul Michael Glaser, who later starred in the hit television series "Starsky and Hutch," he started off at the Theater Company of Boston. There, he acted in "The Local Stigmatic" by Heathcote Williams and was Jon Voight's understudy in "The Dwarfs" by Harold Pinter.
In 1968, as a conscientious objector, he refused the Vietnam draft, only to borrow $1,500 and travel on his own to Saigon, where he helped found the Dispatch News Service -- later it distributed Seymour Hersh's exclusive on the My Lai massacre -- and opened a shelter for street children called the Shoeshine Boys Project.
The low-key charity, so named because the children commonly subsisted by shining shoes, was lionized in news articles. Richard Avedon took pictures, and Mr. Hughes was even flown back to the States in 1974 for a surprise family reunion with his parents and six siblings on "This Is Your Life," which included a tribute by the United States representative at the United Nations, George Bush.
By the mid-70's, Mr. Long and Mr. Liem were taking more responsibility for the charity, which expanded to eight group homes -- six in Saigon and two in Danang -- before they were phased out and Mr. Hughes was told to pick up his exit visa. That was in 1976, three years after the last G.I.'s left Vietnam and more than a year after the Communist victory reunified North and South Vietnam. The charity aided some 1,500 youngsters, mainly boys but also some girls.
After waiters cleared the table, Mr. Tu re-emerged proudly with platters of crispy fried flounder, peppered salt jumbo shrimp nesting in tomatoes and onions, soft-shell crabs fried in butter, and sweet and sour sauteed lobster.
Mr. Hughes snapped off pieces of flounder, placed them in his cup of white rice and used his chopsticks Vietnamese-style to shovel the dish into his mouth. Mr. Tu shelled him chunks of lobster tail.
In 1976, when he got back from Vietnam, Mr. Hughes continued, he tried to restart his acting career, landing some parts in regional theaters and then a prime supporting role as Bernardo in Kevin Kline's "Hamlet" at the Public Theater in 1986. The same year, he appeared as a Pentagon bomb sleuth in Marshall Brickman's film "The Manhattan Project," and in 1987 he portrayed Ross in a Shakespeare in the Park production of "Richard II."
In 1992, he played Shamrayev, the estate owner in Chekhov's "Seagull," at the Muse Theater, and last year he appeared as the train engineer in the Disney film "Iron Will," about a dog-sled race.
But Vietnam was claiming his life again. In 1990, Mr. Long and Mr. Liem were arrested, along with a former American colleague, Michael Morrow, a development consultant, over their meetings with a freelance writer who had angered the authorities by visiting a group of former Vietcong guerrillas critical of the Government.
Bang! Gesturing, Mr. Hughes knocked over his lemonade. Calmly, he swept the ice shards into his palm and onto a napkin.
Mr. Morrow was released after three weeks, Mr. Hughes said, but the two Vietnamese were more harshly treated, in large part, Mr. Hughes is convinced, because of their alliance with him two decades earlier. They were a very close threesome, he said. "You can't get any closer than taking care of a kid who dies."
A week ago, Mr. Hughes learned in a call from Mr. Liem's family in California that he, too, was about to be released.
The worst part of the story, Mr. Hughes continued, was having to be defensive for taking his loyalty to his friends to such lengths.
"I had to explain who these people are and why I'm doing what I'm doing," he said. "I felt there was almost something wrong here because I cared. It's been an uphill battle. People are usually not that loyal for so long."
But now, he said, "I got to the point I'm no longer apologizing for the natural thing to do."
Meanwhile, he said, he passed up other acting roles to devote time to the campaign. To earn money, he worked all night long at law firms, proofreading legal briefs.
His finances have taken a beating, he said. Faxes alone have cost at least $3,500 so far, not to mention the time he has spent running around the corner to send them.
His companion, Sherry Hall, a public-school teacher, is the financial mainstay, supporting the family in an apartment in Inwood, in upper Manhattan. Their daughter, Tara, almost 10, attends the Manhattan Country School with some financial aid.
Having reached the point that he addresses Mr. De Niro and Mr. Newman as "Dear Bob" and "Dear Paul" in his letters, Mr. Hughes is seeking their help to wipe away the $35,000 debt.
He has made so many contacts with celebrities and former Vietnam hands, he said, that when he ran into Arthur Miller on the street one day, he thought he was talking to David Halberstam.
Mr. Tu brought infusions of strong French coffee with sweetened condensed milk that he poured into smoking glasses of ice.
Mr. Hughes said he longed to revisit Vietnam. One of his brothers recently traveled there and found the old Shoeshine Boys home on Pham Ngu Lau Street was crowded by hippie bikers and stalls selling novelties.
When lunch was over, Mr. Hughes headed uptown to pick up his daughter from school. He had just had lunch, he told her, with someone he knew from Vietnam.
"Oh, no," Tara said with a groan, "not another long story."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Once More, Jackson Is the Giants' Receiver

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FLORHAM PARK, N.J., July 19

 BODY:
In the National Football League's wacky and not-always-wonderful world of free agency, winners sometimes become losers and then, if they are lucky, they more or less become winners again. Just ask Mark Jackson, a starting wide receiver for the Giants last year, an unemployed player 10 weeks ago and now a Giants starter again.
A year ago, when unrestricted free agency came to the N.F.L., Jackson left the Denver Broncos after seven seasons and signed with the Giants. One attraction was the Giants' new coach, Dan Reeves, his coach with the Broncos. Another was the money: $4.5 million over three years. 
 Jackson led the Giants in receptions (58) and receiving yardage (708). But he was 29 years old and small (5 feet 9 inches). He also led the Giants in dropped passes with 9 (no one else had more than 3), and he tailed off late in the season.
On May 6, struggling with the new salary cap, the Giants waived Jackson and his 1994 salary of $1.35 million. But on Monday, when training camp began, they re-signed him for $450,000. Now, in the two-a-day practices, he is back in business, back in the starting lineup.
 
Philosophical Optimist
 Jackson is a philosophical optimist, and that approach, he said today, has helped him through what could have been a devastating period.
"Last year, I was sort of uncomfortable: new environment, new people," he said. "And when Mike Sherrard went down and was gone for the season, it was a different scenario. I began to fatigue. I was sleeping less."
The off season was troubling, too.
"I didn't know what was happening," he said. "The cap was new, like free agency the year before. You didn't know what to expect. And when the Giants drafted a receiver as No. 1, I didn't know if they wanted me back. But they did want me back at a lesser price."
So for two and a half months, Jackson was jobless. He said his lawyer received inquiries from 10 or 11 teams, but, as Jackson said, "What does that mean in a league with all this juggling with a salary cap?"
It meant nothing until the Giants called again. And this time, it meant a job for much less money. The Giants tried to re-sign Ed McCaffrey, another wide receiver, for $450,000. McCaffrey balked, so the Giants rescinded their offer to him and re-signed Jackson for the same amount.
 
A Starter Once Again
 "Sure, it's less money than last year," Jackson said. "But I'm working. And if you average the money over two years, it isn't bad."
In the Giants' training camp at Fairleigh Dickinson University's campus here, the key wide receivers are Sherrard (recovering from a dislocated hip), Jackson, Chris Calloway, Arthur Marshall, Keith Crawford and the first-round draft choice, Thomas Lewis. For now, the starters are Sherrard and Jackson, which means Jackson has gone from the penthouse to the doghouse to the penthouse again.
"Mark is starting because he started last year," Reeves said. "You don't lose your starting job because you were released."
 
Work to Do
 Jackson still has work to do. Last year, his quarterback was Phil Simms. This year, with Simms gone, it will be Kent Graham or Dave Brown.
"You can't have a feeling for a quarterback in one year," Jackson said. "Now we will have another quarterback. It's tough on everyone, but that's part of the game, You work around it."
Jackson has resolved another problem.
"Last year," he said, "I just started getting comfortable with the Jersey roads. If you don't know them, you see where you want to go and you can't get there, so you have to go 30 miles before a U turn."

HEADLINE: In America;
The Monkey Wrench

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
So I went up to Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx to see the so-called monkeys and the colored boys doing their thing, but it had been raining for a couple of days and the park was deserted.
Monkeys and colored boys are terms (not quite of endearment) that refer to the black and brown youngsters who play in the park, which is next door to the gleaming blue and white baseball palace called Yankee Stadium. 
 Yechhhhhhh! Colored kids! You could almost feel the disgust emanating from the hefty form of Richard Kraft, the dim-witted white Yankee executive who, according to New York magazine, let loose a nasty simian simile while discussing the kids who play near his ball park.
"It's like monkeys," he was quoted as saying. "Those guys can all go up and hang on the rim and crack the rim and bend the hoops."
Like monkeys. How dare they be allowed anywhere near the pristine wonderfulness of Mr. Kraft's Yankees and their true fans, the well-scrubbed, well-behaved, well-heeled whites from the idyllic suburbs of northern New Jersey, Westchester and Connecticut.
I stood outside the deserted park and let my gaze drift from right to left, left to right, seeking movement, evidence of wildlife in the dark and savage environs of the South Bronx. I saw a boy about 12. He was walking by himself, minding his own business. But I approached him cautiously. They were like monkeys, Mr. Kraft had said. I half expected this kid to leap high in the air and start swinging from the streetlights or something. But the boy stayed on the ground.
He said his name was Kevin. When I asked if he was a Yankee fan, he smiled and said: "Yeah! Sometimes my uncle takes me to the games."
So much for the wildlife. I didn't bother to mention Richard Kraft, a monkey's uncle if there ever was one. If you want a clue as to what's wrong with the Yankees, just consider that Mr. Kraft is the team's vice president for community relations. His grand qualification for this important post apparently is that he was a college roommate of the team's principal monkey's uncle, George Steinbrenner.
Almost as soon as Mr. Kraft's comments were on the newsstands, the ball club, through a spokesman, said: "The New York Yankees offer an unequivocal apology for the statements attributed to Mr. Kraft. His comments in no way reflect the opinion of the Yankees."
Later, Richard Kraft denied that he had ever made the statements. You can take the denial with a grain of salt. Faced with the hideous prospect of unemployment, a middle-aged, marginally talented baseball executive might say anything. Richard Kraft will do what he has to do. By next week you can expect him to be lecturing on multiculturalism.
The problem with the Yankees is not Richard Kraft, it's George Steinbrenner. For years he's been stuffing his vaults with millions and millions of dollars from the taxpayers of New York, and from the proceeds of a team whose glorious history is totally and irrevocably entwined with the very idea of New York.
Nevertheless, Mr. Steinbrenner takes every opportunity to bad-mouth the city in general and the Bronx in particular, characterizing them as vile places populated by lowlifes intent on bringing him ruin. He should no longer be allowed to get away with this. The politicians who have spent long years crawling after Mr. Steinbrenner and kissing his shirttails should get off their knees and give him an ultimatum: Either stay in the Bronx and become part of an effort to revitalize the area surrounding Yankee Stadium, or get lost.
The Borough President of the Bronx, Fernando Ferrer, is one of the few politicians who hasn't been cowed by Mr. Steinbrenner. Mr. Ferrer has in hand an ambitious revitalization plan that would include substantial improvements in parking and other facilities for the Yankees, and an extensive renewal of the triangle of land where the stadium and the Bronx Terminal Market are located.
It is time for George Steinbrenner to stop leeching off the city. If he wants to be part of a South Bronx revitalization, fine. If not, good riddance. No other offers should be made. New Yorkers are not beholden to Mr. Steinbrenner. Let him pack up his team, his millions and his flock of co-dependents and get out of here.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Hussein, King of Realpolitik

BYLINE: By Abba Eban; Abba Eban, former Foreign Minister of Israel, is writing a book on diplomacy after the cold war.

DATELINE: HERZLIYA, Israel

 BODY:
The pioneer of realism in the Arab perception of Israel was not President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, who made peace with Israel in 1979. It was King Hussein of Jordan, who was talking amicably, but secretly, with Israeli leaders when Egyptian and Israeli forces were still exchanging bombardments and casualties.
As an ardent Arab nationalist, King Hussein would probably have preferred a Middle East without Israel, but he was quicker than any other Arab leader to understand that Israel had passed the threshold of destructibility. 
 As the years went by, he must have become painfully aware that nothing protected Jordan's survival more effectively than Israel's interest in preserving it. Israel made it known throughout the Middle East that an Iraqi or Syrian invasion of Jordan would probably incur Israeli intervention -- a rare case of a deterrent strategy that really worked.
Now King Hussein's realism seems about to pay off. A new Middle East is in the making.
The decision of King Hussein, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and President Clinton to confer in the White House on Monday is an immense boost for the peace process. Coming after the establishment of the Palestinian self-governing authority in Gaza and Jericho, it has left Israelis more sanguine about ultimate diplomatic success.
But this does not mean that the negotiations will come to a brisk conclusion. Even the Egyptian-Israeli treaty required 17 months of negotiations after President Sadat's visit to Jerusalem in 1977.
Nor will the Jordanian-Israeli dialogue be free of surrounding contention. King Hussein will feel pressure from many Jordanians with strong Palestinian affiliations on the West Bank and in Gaza who wish he would take more militant positions in support of Palestinian statehood.
But most Israelis believe that the strong leadership of King Hussein and Prime Minister Rabin, reinforced by President Clinton, will carry the day and ultimately sweep Syria into their momentum.
King Hussein's biography is studded with disasters that seem to indicate a habit for personal miscalculation. This is only partly true. Jordan's gravest tragedies have flowed from intimidation by other Arab states.
In 1967, President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt tricked King Hussein into entering the Six-Day War, in which he suffered a debacle. Nasser claimed to have already brought Israel to its knees. In the Persian Gulf war, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq lured King Hussein into the appearance of being on his side. King Hussein's position was untenable. Accused in the West of acting with cynical calculation, he alienated his natural allies in America, Europe and Saudi Arabia.
Until recently, it seemed probable that Syria would force its own rejectionist policies on Jordan. But for King Hussein to have lagged behind other Arab participants in the peace process would have been reckless. Jordan never gained any advantage by sacrificing its own national interests for the mystique of Arab unity.
How could a disgruntled Syria now do serious harm to a Kingdom of Jordan protected by American support, European sympathy and an agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, without which the Jordanian-Israeli accord would not have been signed?
King Hussein's slogan today is "Jordanian interests" -- which are not inferior to other interests. This is the hour for a show of Jordanian self-confidence, and King Hussein has so far exploited it impressively.
Jordan does not regard itself as the leader of the Arab world, but it may have more to contribute to a system of regional cooperation than any other state. The proximity of rival ports at Eilat and Aqaba, the need for sharing the Dead Sea and the Jordan-Yarmuk water systems, the large-scale potentiality for tourism once the barriers fall, the rapidity of land communication, the ties of the Jordan population with the self-governing Palestinian areas -- all point to a particular intimacy of relations among Israelis, Jordanians and Palestinians.
As King Hussein looks out across the Jordan, either from the eastern bank or from Aqaba, he may well be impressed by the spectacle of a dynamic Israeli society. His own kingdom has prospered, too. Israelis who have crossed over to Jordan speak respectfully of well-tended landscapes, a developed university and hospital network and a tradition of civility in the working of institutions.
The causes that brought the lengthy Israel-Jordanian talks to a deadlock since 1967 are not obscure. Israeli governments, haunted by Arab threats, felt it necessary to claim boundary changes beyond anything that Jordan could accept. But King Hussein's difficulties were not only territorial. His central concern was whether as the head of a small country he could audaciously take responsibility for leading the vast Arab world to peace with Israel. Was it not the duty of Cairo, Damascus, Baghdad and the holy cities of Islam to carry that burden?
This situation no longer prevails. All of Israel's neighbors are now negotiating in detail with Israel beyond the vague formalities of the largely ceremonial Madrid conference. In addition, King Hussein has skillfully passed the Palestinian issues to Palestinian leaders. He must feel satisfied with that decision, since it relieved him of potential responsibility for the chaos in Gaza that has tormented Yasir Arafat, especially the rioting on Sunday that led Israel to seal off Gaza.
Unlike its predecessors, the current Israeli Government is not killing the idea of peace by trying to rule permanently over nearly two million Palestinians without offering them equal citizenship or the chance to establish a separate jurisdiction.
Israel is also making cordial contacts with Arab states in North Africa and the Persian Gulf area. Jordan would not be a lonely adventurer in establishing relations with Israel.
When the time comes for the determination of permanent boundaries, which ought to be much less than three years away, the three peoples -- Israelis, Jordanians and Palestinians -- will probably move toward a community relationship, combining independence for each with close economic cooperation. (The European Union is a relevant example.)
The ultimate guarantee for peace lies in the creation of common regional interests with such entanglement of reciprocal advantage and such mutual human accessibility as to make future wars inconceivable.

HEADLINE: Italy's Economy Posts Gains, Not Losses

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 6 news article on Italy paints a grotesquerie of "very real fiscal problems" that differs sharply from reality. During the entire month of June, my wife and I toured the country, speaking with people at every stratum of society, getting the feel of post-election Italy. 
 The "trade deficit" you claim is "galloping" is a horse of a different color: a surplus of $18.7 billion for the last 12 months. That is the second highest in Europe. Your "creeping inflation" has crept downward by .4 percent in the last reporting period.
The Italian economy is strong compared with the rest of Europe and the United States. Gross domestic product rose at the rate of 3.2 percent in the last three months, the highest for the larger European economies. It compares well with our growth of 3 percent in the last trimester.
Italy's current account (budget) surplus for the last year of $8.3 billion is second only to France among major countries of Europe.
As an indicator of the optimism of small and large investors, the Italian stock market in the year to date is up about 21 percent in dollar terms.
Although Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's leadership has been questioned by you and by several leaders of European countries, Italians had their first opportunity since the national elections in March to pass judgment on their new leader during elections for the European Parliament in June. With 81 percent of eligible voters voting, in a country where voting is not compulsory, Mr. Berlusconi's Government saw about a 17 percent increase in support. This is significant inasmuch as the governing party or parties of most other countries in Europe lost support.
Your reference to the menace of "the brown shirts" seems to apply to a fear of a recrudescence of Fascism, a highly unlikely prospect, given the political attitudes of a preponderance of Italians in and out of public office. But it was brown shirts for Hitler's Nazis and black shirts for Mussolini's Fascists.
 
VINCENT R. TORTORA
Port Washington, L.I., July 11, 1994

HEADLINE: Italy's Economy Posts Gains, Not Losses;
Cellular Necessity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 6 news article made reference to merchants busily speaking on cellular phones in an unnamed city between San Sepolcro and Monterchi in Umbria. Your tone indicated they were so rich (or indolent) they could afford to use a cellular phone. 
 Having lived in Citta di Castello, near both villages, I can tell you that the absence of public telephones, lack of sufficient private lines and higher quality of cellular communications often make the use of cellular phones advisable if not indispensable. When traveling by car, a cellular was a must, as roadside phones were either broken or vandalized except at superstrada gas stations. On standard roads they were almost nonexistent.
In Italy you pay air time only when originating a cellular communication. In my job working for a ballet company with extensive ties to Poland, we often had to use the cellular phone to reach Poland, as the land lines were impossible from about 8 A.M. to 10 P.M. With our cellular phone the redial was automatic, and connection was usually within five minutes.
 
STEPHEN SANDERS
Annapolis, Md., July 12, 1994

HEADLINE: Out-of-Wedlock Births Up Since '83, Report Indicates

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
With the debate over reducing the country's welfare rolls focusing renewed attention on the rising birthrate among unwed women, the Census Bureau reported today that the number of children living with a parent who had never married -- a reflection of out-of-wedlock births -- soared by more than 70 percent from 1983 to 1993.
According to the bureau, 6.3 million children, or 27 percent of children under the age of 18, lived in 1993 with a single parent who had never married, up from 3.7 million in 1983. 
 While indicating that the annual increase in the number of children born out of wedlock slowed somewhat in the 1980's, the report also documented the sharp rise in these kinds of births over the last three decades. While there were 243,000 children living with one parent who had never married in 1960, by last year that number had climbed to 6.3 million.
"It's astonishing," said Kristin Moore, director of Child Trends, a Washington-based research organization that studies adolescent pregnancy. "It's really a substantial social change, and it's happened really fast."
The figures are compiled in an annual report by the Census Bureau titled "Marital Status and Living Arrangements." The findings mirror the results of other studies in recent years -- including those done by the Census Bureau -- that show out-of-wedlock births still on the rise.
The report demonstrated the extent to which blacks are affected by the changes that are roiling the traditional family structure. According to the report, 57 percent of black children are living with one parent who has never married, compared with 21 percent of white children and 32 percent of Hispanic children.
The latest figures are likely to fuel the debate over competing Democratic and Republican proposals on how to cut the country's welfare rolls.
In its bill, the Clinton Administration emphasizes the need to identify the fathers of children born out of wedlock and hold them responsible for financial support of their children, requires single mothers under the age of 20 to remain in school to continue to receive welfare benefits and allows states to limit additional cash benefits to women whose babies are conceived while they are on welfare.
But a group of Republicans in the House, contending that welfare provides a financial incentive for poor, unmarried women to bear children, goes Mr. Clinton one step further, freezing welfare payments at current levels and denying cash benefits to single mothers under the age of 18.
"I think these figures dramatize, once again, that our welfare policies are going in absolutely the wrong direction," said Representative Jan Meyers of Kansas, who is the architect of the Republican bill.
But some researchers say that freezing or denying welfare benefits would not have much, if any, effect on the soaring out-of-wedlock birthrates. They note that the out-of-wedlock birthrate rose in the 1960's when the value of welfare benefits went up. Yet the rate continued to rise in the 1970's and 80's, even though the value of the benefits declined because they did not keep pace with inflation.
"Research suggests that welfare accounts for some, but not all of this phenomenon," said Martha Farnsworth Riche, director of policy studies for the Population Reference Bureau, a private research group.
 
Family Trends
 The statistics included in the annual report also document other trends associated with the breakdown of the traditional American family:
*The number of unmarried adults nearly doubled, to 72.6 million from 37.5 million, from 1970 through 1993, with 58 percent of this group made up of adults who have never married.
*The number of people who are divorced tripled to 16.7 million in 1993 from 4.3 million in 1970.
*Men and women alike continue to delay marriage, with the median age at first marriages rising last year to 26.5 years for men and 24.5 years for women. The figures represent the highest median age at marriage for both men and women since 1890.
*The delay in marriage is greatest among blacks, with 22 percent of black women age 40 to 44 never having been married, compared with 7 percent of white women and 9 percent of Hispanic women.
 
Role in Social Problems
 But it is the drastic rise in the birthrate among unwed women and girls that is most likely to draw attention in the coming months as Congress debates several issues. The phenomenon of out-of-wedlock births has been cited as a factor in a host of social problems, including increased crime, drug abuse, welfare dependency and poor educational attainment.
Indeed, the bureau's report presented stark evidence of the socio-economic disadvantages confronted by children living in one-parent households, as against those in two-parent families. And the report indicated that those disadvantages were much more acute for a parent who never married.
According to the Census Bureau, the median family income in households where two parents were present was $43,578. In contrast, in one-parent families where the mother was divorced, the median income was $17,014, and where she had never been married, the median income was $9,272.
Similarly, 10.6 percent of children living in two-parent families were living below the poverty line. But 38.4 percent of children living with divorced mothers and 66.3 percent of those living with mothers who had never married were living below the poverty line.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 21, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article and headline yesterday about a Census Bureau report on unwed mothers characterized the statistics incorrectly in some copies. The figures reported were for children living in single-parent households with a parent who had never married; the figures were not birthrates -- the number of births to unwed mothers.

Graphs track number of children living with single, never married parent, and number of children living with single divorced parent. Graphs run from 1960 through 1993. (pg. A16)
