HEADLINE: Investment In Tobacco Is Questioned

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
The trustees of New York City's largest public employee pension fund have taken what could be the first step toward eliminating the stocks of tobacco companies from the fund's portfolio of investments.
The trustees, who oversee $23 billion in pensions for city employees and retirees, have sent letters to eight tobacco manufacturers or suppliers whose stocks the fund holds, asking them to show how they will protect the fund's investments despite growing efforts across the country to restrict smoking. 
 The move, announced yesterday at a news conference by Public Advocate Mark J. Green and aides to Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, underscored the varied political pressures on the tobacco industry at a time when Congress is scrutinizing industry practices and when governments are considering wider restrictions on smoking in public places.
But Mr. Green and Deputy Comptroller Jon Lukomnik said they were acting more out of an economic concern rather than moral or social considerations. They said the pressures on the industry raised questions about the future risks of investing in tobacco companies.
 
Concern About Liabilities
 The officials also emphasized that they had not yet decided whether to sell the pension fund's tobacco company stocks, now valued at $295 million, or about 1 percent of the total. But they said their requests for information, in letters dated July 13, could lead to that.
"None of us, as trustees, officials or citizens, can be unaware of the dangers posed by this product and therefore the potential long-term liabilities and costs of this product," Mr. Green said.
The initial step by the trustees of the fund, the New York City Employee Retirement System, came as a growing number of municipalities, universities and hospitals have given up tobacco stocks, much as, in a protest against apartheid in the 1980's, they gave up stock in companies that had holdings in South Africa.
In 1990, Harvard University and the City University of New York voted to eliminate stocks of tobacco companies from their investments. Since then several local governments, like including Pittsburgh, Cambridge, Mass., and Fulton County in Georgia, have also decided to divest, according to the Tobacco Control Resource Center at Northeastern University in Boston.
 
Action Could Take Years
 Brad S. Krevor, the executive director of the center, a nonprofit group that has pushed local governments and institutions to drop their tobacco stocks, said that local governments that invested in tobacco companies also were paying education and health-care costs related to smoking.
"We shouldn't be profiting from addiction," he said.
The city's public employee pension fund holds about 7.5 million shares in six tobacco manufacturers: Philip Morris U.S.A., RJR Nabisco Holdings, United States Tobacco Company Inc., American Maize-Products, the Loews Corporation and the Culbro Corporation. It also holds 1.5 million shares in the Eastman Kodak Company, which produces cigarette filters, and the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, which supplies paper to cigarette makers.
The pension fund's trustees -- the Mayor's office, the Comptroller, Public Advocate, the five borough presidents and three union leaders -- asked the companies to provide details of how they plan to cope with potential liability from lawsuits, restrictions on smoking and other matters that could hurt the companies financially.
 
'We're a Good Investment'
 "Many investors are seriously concerned about both the social and economic implications of their investments in companies that manufacture cigarettes and other tobacco products," the letters to the companies said. The letters added, "We too are concerned."
The pension fund sold off its stocks in companies doing business in South Africa in 1990 -- the only time it has divested a type of stock -- after a five-year process of review that began under Mayor Edward I. Koch. It lifted the ban last October after that country moved toward democratic elections.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 23, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the New York City pension system's investments in tobacco stocks referred incorrectly to Eastman Kodak's involvement in the tobacco industry. Although a former subsidiary, Eastman Chemical, produces material for cigarette filters, the company is no longer affiliated with Eastman Kodak. In some editions the article also misidentified one company in which the pension system has invested. It is RJR Nabisco, not RJR Reynolds.

HEADLINE: Bacterial Evidence Forces Cruise Liner To Stop All Service

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 20

 BODY:
The cruise ship Horizon was taken out of service today, and the vacation plans of more than 1,000 passengers were upended, after test results came back showing the possible presence of the Legionnaires' disease bacteria in the ship's water system.
Spokesmen for Celebrity Cruises, which operates the luxury liner, said it would arrange flights back to New York on Thursday for the passengers. They had been evacuated from the ship Tuesday and put up in hotels here while the Horizon's water systems were being disinfected to eliminate any bacteria that might have caused four confirmed cases of Legionnaires' disease and 18 possible cases among passengers who had traveled on recent cruises. 
 Today's news caused anger among the passengers, who had showed up to board the ship in New York on Saturday only to be greeted by leaflets announcing that they faced a small risk of getting Legionnaires' disease.
They talked of being whipsawed emotionally by sudden announcements of troubling new developments, including midnight notifications slipped under their stateroom doors, and they accused Celebrity of knowingly sending them off on vacations that were likely to be disrupted if not dangerous.
Celebrity officials said that they had acted in good faith and that Federal health officials had not recommended last weekend that the cruise be canceled. They are promising full refunds to passengers on this cruise as well as for travelers who have already booked other trips on the Horizon. The company has canceled the Horizon cruise scheduled to leave this weekend.
"Everyone is entitled to a worry-free vacation, and this has been anything but that," said John Largan of Floral Park, L.I., as he angrily prepared to retrieve his luggage from the ship for the flight back to New York on Thursday. "And on top of all of this they are cutting our vacations short by three days."
When the passengers do get home, they can only wait out the incubation period of the disease to see if they fall ill, and even then it will take a blood test to determine whether they have Legionnaires' disease rather than another form of pneumonia.
 
Disease Is Readily Treatable
 The disease can set in from 2 to 10 days after infection and produces headache, fever, coughs, chest pains, diarrhea and some delirium. It is readily treatable with the antibiotic erythromycin, but death rates in cases where patients are sick enough to be hospitalized have reached 15 percent.
The news of the possible presence of Legionnaires' bacteria on the Horizon grew out of an investigation begun on the ship Saturday by officials of the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention after three recent passengers turned up at a New Jersey hospital with symptoms of the disease.
Bob Howard, a spokesman for the C.D.C. in Atlanta, said today that the agency took some 32 specimens from a variety of locations on the 12-deck ship, including samplings from shower heads, basins, water faucets and Jacuzzi's. The specimens were sent to Atlanta, where they were grown in cultures, and it was the results of those efforts that were reported today.
Mr. Howard said the tests had actually found the presence of the "DNA of legionella bacteria" and not the live bacteria themselves, in "several locations among those from which specimens were taken." The DNA material suggests the presence of the live or dead bacteria that could actually cause the disease, but it does not completely and conclusively confirm that presence, he said. Additional cultures would be required to determine that.
Mr. Howard would not specify where on the ship the material was found. And he noted that the cruise line, in its diligence to remove all potential dangers, might have washed the ship clean and disinfected it of any remnants of the bacteria. During the stay here in Bermuda the ship's systems for handling and desalinating ocean water were flushed, bathed in a concentrated solution of chlorine and rinsed clean.
"It could very well be that they killed and washed away all active bacteria with this process," Mr. Howard said. "We still can't say that those people were made ill on that ship, and we may never be able to say that for sure. But at this point our investigation is by no means over."
Windell Bradford, deputy director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, praised the cruise line for its cooperation and noted that Celebrity had acted to cut the risk of infection to passengers throughout the trip and always without prodding from the agency.
 
Insufficient Information
 He said the C.D.C. did not recommend that the Horizon stay in New York on Saturday because the agency did not have sufficient information to warrant such a decision. The only recommendation that the agency made when the ship left New York was that it flush and decontaminate its systems as soon as possible.
At a news conference in Manhattan hours after Celebrity Cruises learned of the C.D.C.'s findings, Al Wallach, senior vice president for passenger services for the cruise lines, said that although "C.D.C. and we believe the vessel is completely safe now and ready to sail," the company is arranging a place in the United States to dock the ship so more tests can be done if necessary.
He also said he did not know where on the ship the Federal officials found the suspect specimens. Mr. Wallach said the ship is routinely inspected by the New York State Department of Health as well as routinely chlorinated. The ship was last inspected in February.
Horizon, which made its debut in 1990, is one of three ships owned by Celebrity Cruise Lines. It has a capacity of 1,500 passengers and spends half of its season in Bermuda and the other in the Caribbean. The other two ships are the Zenith and Meridian. The Meridian also travels to Bermuda.
 
Refund Applications
 Mr. Wallach, who said passengers should contact their travel agents about obtaining refunds, declined to comment on how much the episode is costing the company, saying, "It's not an economic issue."
And he expressed sympathy for the passengers angered with how the cruise company has handled the situation.
"Passengers are frustrated because information has not come in even flow," he said. "It's perfectly natural to be frustrated and display some disbelief when you make people wait for something.
"We hope they would understand this is a dynamic, moving situation," Mr. Wallach said.
But here in Hamilton today, the passengers were not in an understanding mood.
It was pandemonium at tea time in the lobby of the luxurious Hamilton Princess Hotel as angry passengers who had checked out earlier today in expectation of returning to the ship were clamoring to get new rooms in which to stay until they left Thursday. A day earlier, many had joked about the stay in the Bermuda hotels, luxurious by most standards, and viewed it as an unexpected but pleasant interlude. Some even called it an adventure.
Today, that all changed.
Referring to the refund from the cruise line, a livid Ann Marie Prisco, from Wantagh, L.I., said through tears: "Forget the money. And forget the lost three days. They have jeopardized our lives."
Steve Savona, of Clifton, N.J., was trying to take it all in stride, noting that all that had happened was unforeseeable and not anybody's fault. What was disastrous, he said, was the "bumbling way" in which officials of the cruise line had handled things.
"It's been a comedy of errors from the beginning," he said. "Every time we started feeling comfortable and relaxed, some new thing happened, and now this."

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve's Chief Suggests A New Rate Rise May Be Needed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
The hairman of the Federal Reserve said today that the four increases in interest rates this year might not have been enough to keep inflation under control. His remarks caused a drop in American stock and bond markets as investors concluded that a further increase was more likely than many had thought.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman, stopped short of actually declaring that he would raise interest rates, saying that Government economic indicators were not currently providing a clear signal of future inflation. 
 But he gave some indications of his plans by telling the Senate Banking Committee that it remained an "open question" whether the rate increases so far were sufficient to prevent future inflation. And he added for the first time that it would be better for the nation's economy if rates were too high than not high enough.
If the central bank raised rates again and the economy slowed sharply, Mr. Greenspan said, it could easily lower rates and the economy would bounce back quickly. But if the Federal Reserve failed to raise rates high enough, he said, inflation could return and could be beaten back only at the cost of a prolonged economic slowdown.
His comments today prompted traders and investors to sell securities now because another interest rate increase might force prices lower. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.04 points, to 3,727.27, while the interest rate on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.54 percent, from 7.46 percent on Tuesday. [Pages D7 and D8.]
Mr. Greenspan, often called the second-most-powerful man in the country after the President and the most powerful in economic terms, had carefully avoided saying in recent weeks that he would not raise short-term interest rates again, so his comments today did not signal a new policy. He has said repeatedly since the Federal Reserve began raising its short-term interest rate target in February that the central bank would take whatever action necessary to prevent inflation from returning to the American economy.
But after the fourth interest rate increase in May, when the rate for overnight loans between banks was increased to 4.25 percent, Mr. Greenspan did say that the Federal Reserve had "substantially" completed its program of monetary-policy tightening. Today, he avoided such language.
The threat of another increase in short-term interest rates is not a new one for the financial markets. Many traders, analysts and economists have been predicting that the Federal Reserve would have to move rates up again one or more times this year. In fact, many analysts were expecting a fifth rate increase to come just after the Federal Reserve's policymaking committee met earlier this month. So Mr. Greenspan's hint of another increase should not have been a total surprise.
But when the Federal Reserve refrained earlier this month from raising rates -- and when new economic data indicated that inflation remained in check and that the pace of economic growth might be slowing -- there was talk in the financial markets that the Fed might be able to wait a while before a next move. But today, Mr. Greenspan's comments seemed to indicate and were interpreted as a signal that the Fed's next move would be sooner rather than later.
 
Debate Over Inventories
 He also emphasized today that the dollar's recent fall could fuel inflation. And he criticized the popular view among some economists that a recent increase in businesses' inventories meant that prices would not be rising soon.
Some of the increase in inventories consists of imported goods, and some may reflect a desire by companies to have more products on hand for consumers to buy, Mr. Greenspan said. Either case suggests that American factories may continue working at full speed, he said.
Future inflation is a risk because continued economic growth means that the nation's businesses are operating ever closer to full capacity, which means that inflationary bottlenecks could appear, Mr. Greenspan added.
Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers, said that while Mr. Greenspan did not send a clear signal of more interest rate increases, "all the language was tilted to one side, in the direction of tightening."
Another interest rate increase in the coming weeks could produce considerable rancor in the Fed's relationship with the Clinton Administration -- a relationship that has already frayed over the last few months.
Administration officials largely abstained from publicly jawboning the Fed during the spring. But that reticence has faded this summer.
Asked on July 8 whether the Fed should raise interest rates to help support the dollar in international currency markets, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen responded, "Not at this point."
Mr. Bentsen was more circumspect today. "I do not try to predict what the Federal Reserve is going to do," he said at a White House news conference on health care. "I think that the Federal Reserve and Alan Greenspan shares with us the objective of long-term growth with low inflation."
 
Differing Assumptions
 The White House's economic forecast for the second half of this year, which was released last Thursday, assumed no further increases in short-term interest rates until the end of this year or early next year.
The White House also forecast that consumer prices would rise 3 percent this year, 3.2 percent next year and 3.4 percent a year in the late 1990's. Mr. Greenspan criticized this as undesirable.
"I should note, however, that most Federal Reserve policy makers would not regard the inflation projections of these other forecasters, which generally do not foresee further progress toward price stability over the medium term, as a desirable outcome," he said.
Mr. Greenspan predicted today that the American economy would grow 3 to 3.25 percent this year and 2.5 to 2.75 percent next year. The estimates are similar to a White House forecast last Thursday that economic growth would be 3 percent this year and 2.7 percent next year.
He predicted that consumer prices would rise 2.75 percent to 3 percent this year and the same or slightly higher next year, and provided no estimates beyond that.
 
Action vs. Inference
 "It is an open question whether our actions to date have been sufficient to head off inflationary pressures and thus maintain favorable trends in the economy," Mr. Greenspan said in his opening remarks.
In the closing minutes of the three-and-a-half hour hearing, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Banking Committee, told Mr. Greenspan that his initial remarks had been widely interpreted in the financial markets as signaling another interest rate increase. Mr. Greenspan then responded with his comment that it would be better to raise rates too much than too little.
"If we fail to recognize emerging inflationary forces, remedying that will be far more difficult and far more of a problem for the long-term stability of the economy in 1995 and beyond," he said.
Marc W. Wanshel, an economist at J. P. Morgan in New York, said that the comment made an additional tightening of monetary policy and higher interest rates likely.
"He's setting up a very severe test that you have to pass not to have a further tightening," Mr. Wanshel said. "What he's saying is that any further up-creep in inflation could provide the basis for further tightening."
But Wayne D. Angell, who left the Fed in February and is now an economist at Bear, Stearns, said that Mr. Greenspan had kept enough balance in his remarks to keep the central bank's options open as further evidence emerged this summer of the economy's health. "He didn't close any doors, which is really very appropriate," Mr. Angell said.
With some exceptions, Senate Democrats were less critical of the Fed's interest rate increases than earlier this spring.
 
Insensitivity on Unemployment
 The main disagreement came over unemployment, with several Democratic Senators accusing the Fed chief of insensitivity. "This is about real people, flesh and blood, and not numbers on an economist's work sheet," said Senator Carol Moseley Braun, Democrat of Illinois.
Mr. Greenspan said that unemployment, at 6 percent, was already so low that faster growth from low interest rates would not put the remaining unemployed Americans back to work. People still without jobs now are unemployed because they lack skills that employers need, he said. "Monetary policy, which works mainly by influencing aggregate demand, is not suited to addressing such problems," Mr. Greenspan added.
Mr. Greenspan repeated today his recent contention that low inflation helped to increase productivity in the economy. But when pressed by Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, about whether he was making too much of a recent Fed study that reached this conclusion, Mr. Greenspan said that the evidence for his position was "fragmentary," and not conclusive.

HEADLINE: A Cheap New York? For Foreign Visitors, Yes.

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
Last week, Alain Tobier waited in line two hours to climb the Statue of Liberty. He marveled at the view from the World Trade Center and had his picture taken with a dinosaur at the American Museum of Natural History. But now he was concentrating on what really drew him to New York: shopping.
Standing at the counter at 47th Street Photo, Mr. Tobier, an aerospace engineer from Toulouse, France, looked through the viewfinder of the Pentax autofocus 35-millimeter camera recommended by a salesman. He had already bought an Epson portable computer upstairs. One of his companions was carrying a new Wilson tennis racquet in his bag. The other had a box of Timberland shoes. 
 "Everything is so much more expensive at home," Mr. Tobier said. "We have a list of all the things we're supposed to buy for our friends. This is so much fun."
Join the club. Tourists from abroad, spurred on by the fall in the dollar that makes many foreign currencies especially valuable here these days, are spending their francs, marks and yen more freely than ever this summer. Together with a revival in visitors from elsewhere in the United States, New York City appears to be experiencing its best tourist season in years.
"New York is the shopping mecca of the world," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "The decline of the dollar is doing more to boost tourism here than all the promotional campaigns put together."
To Brett Spencer, a journalist from London, New York is everything he expected -- and more. "It's too hot, too crowded and too noisy, and we can't get enough of it," said Mr. Spencer, 25, who was visiting the Empire State Building with his father. "People told us we'd either love it or hate it. So far, we love it."
Visitors accounted for more than $14 billion in economic activity in 1992, the most recent year for which figures are available, the United States Travel and Tourism Administration reports. Travel and tourism support 154,000 jobs, according to the City Economic Policy and Marketing Group. Cultural activities, heavily attended by visitors, add another 58,000 jobs. To put that in perspective, the entire banking and credit industry accounts for fewer than 150,000 New York City jobs.
Foreign tourism, which is up all over the country, is particularly important. While visitors from abroad made up only about 20 percent of the 25 million people who stayed overnight in New York City in 1992, the city's Convention and Visitors Bureau estimates that they spent more than 40 percent of the dollars that tourists left behind.
Europeans account for the bulk of the visitors from abroad, but tourism officials also note that visitors from Latin America are on the rise. There has been a slight decline, they say, in the number of visitors from Japan.
This year, signs abound of increased visits by Americans and foreigners alike. Moreover, it is not just the World Cup, the Gay Games and other highly publicized events that account for the improvement. Hotel business is up sharply since the beginning of the year. After slumping from 1987 through last summer, hotel occupancy rates began to creep higher late in 1993. Now they are climbing steadily.
Despite a harsh winter, hotel occupancy rose nearly four percentage points, to 64 percent, during the first quarter this year, compared with the same time last year. In May, 77 percent of the roughly 65,000 hotel rooms in the city were full, according to the Pannell Kerr Foster consulting firm. That is up from 71 percent in May 1993, and just 68 percent the year before.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art, noting an unusual number of European visitors, reported attendance up by 8.2 percent in the first quarter. Visits to the Statue of Liberty, which was closed frequently this winter because of harsh weather, nonetheless are running even with last year and were up by 4 percent in June, to 307,000, compared with last year.
 
High-Rising Attendance
 Meanwhile, attendance at the Empire State Building, which reopened from repair work on May 20, has risen by 17 percent over the same period last year.
"This is turning into one of our best years ever," said Laura Fries, director of visitor marketing for the skyscraper. "The whole world knows about the Empire State Building. This is a true Tower of Babel."
It is not just international visitors who flock to the observation decks on the 86th and 110th floors. Chris and Cyndi Mooney, heading to upstate New York from Wilmington, Del., were not planning to visit the city this summer. But their daughter, Jenny, 5, persuaded them to spend a couple of days seeing the sights, specifically the Empire State Building.
"She wanted to see where Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan met in 'Sleepless in Seattle,' " Mr. Mooney said. "How could we say no?"
To most Americans, New York stands out as perhaps the most expensive city in the country. The average hotel room rate today is $144. The cost of restaurant meals, from McDonald's to the Rainbow Room, is higher than elsewhere.
David Jackson, a director of a private school who lives in Corona, Calif., is still in shock. Hoping to save money, he stayed in Fort Lee, N.J., as his travel agent suggested. But the savings quickly disappeared, swallowed up by renting two cars and paying tolls and gasoline. He spent $455 for his family, which includes his wife and five children, to see "The Phantom of the Opera" on Broadway "and the seats weren't even that good," he complained.
Still, Mr. Jackson said: "Everybody needs to see New York at least once. There's nothing else like it."
To visitors from Europe and Japan, however, New York is a bargain. "Most things here seem pretty inexpensive," said Henning Groenbaek, a Danish visitor.
Most products like cameras and electronics equipment are heavily taxed in Europe and Asia, making them substantially more expensive there than in the United States. In addition, the exchange rate of most European currencies against the dollar is up about 10 percent since the beginning of the year, making goods bought in the United States even more of a bargain.
Yuko Kitani, from Osaka, Japan, has visited SoHo, Greenwich Village, Central Park, the Brooklyn Bridge and the World Trade Center in her two-week visit. "You can find something to do 24 hours a day," she said. When not sightseeing, though, she particularly enjoys shopping. "There are a lot of speciality shops," she said. "There is a shop for everything."
Indeed, foreign tourists appear to be on a spree. The amount of foreign currency exchanged last month at American Express offices in New York City rose by 25 percent over June 1993, said Nancy Muller, a spokeswoman for American Express. Part of the increase was a reflection of the World Cup games, she said, but not all of it.
Glenn Weilgus, a spokesman for the South Street Seaport, said the number of visitors at the enclosed marketplace, a prime tourist attraction, was up at least 5 percent from last year. "Foreign tourists just love American name brands," Mr. Weilgus said. "They go nuts in places like J. Crew and Gap Kids."
Adrienne Cleere, vice president of international marketing at Bloomingdale's, agreed. "We're even starting to advertise on CNN International in Asia, Latin America and Europe," she said.
Still, not everybody comes to New York just to spend money. Mirco Schumann is a schoolteacher who lives in the eastern section of Berlin, behind the wall before it was torn down in 1989. He said the high point of his trip with his parents, Dietman and Monica, was their visit to the Statue of Liberty.
"It was important to see the Statue of Freedom," he said. "For us from the East, freedom is more valuable than anything else."

HEADLINE: Stocks Tumble Over Fears of a Rate Rise

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan managed to spook the financial markets yesterday by merely telling them generally what he has said before and refusing to rule out further increases in interest rates. But there were some nuances in his testimony before Congress that put traders' teeth on edge.
The stock, bond, and currency markets all nose-dived on the Federal Reserve Board chairman's statement to the Senate Banking Committee that Fed policies "need to remain disciplined and focused." 
 That statement, combined with Mr. Greenspan's comments that inflation might still accelerate and a declining dollar is inflationary, made some traders conclude that a rate increase could come sooner rather than later.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.04 points, to 3,727.27, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 fell 2.26 points, to 451.60. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 6.55 points, to 712.77.
 
Below-Average Volume
 Moderating the price decline somewhat was below-average volume on the New York Stock Exchange, the nation's largest exchange, with its most valuable stocks. A total of 268 million shares changed hands.
Some analysts said that the markets were right to decline but not as much as they did. "The magnitude was out of proportion," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at CS First Boston. "I saw nothing in Greenspan's testimony that was a declaration of war on business expansion."
On the other hand, he said, "the financial markets may have lulled themselves into a false complacency" that the Fed would not raise rates soon. The Fed's policy-making committee earlier this month declined to raise rates, as some traders had expected.
What was striking about Mr. Greenspan's testimony yesterday was its pointed declaration that the dollar's fall against the Japanese yen and European currencies hurt the American economy. That could mean there is another reason for the Fed to raise interest rates soon -- to defend the dollar.
What made the declaration noteworthy was that on a so-called trade- weighted basis, taking into account major trading partners like Canada and Mexico, against whose currencies the dollar has not declined that much, the dollar has been stable or rising slightly for much of the year, calling into question the inflationary effect of the dollar's volatility.
But even if a declining dollar does not contribute that much to inflation, Mr. Soss said, it does make borrowing from Asia and Europe more expensive. "We don't finance the economy across the Rio Grande or the St. Lawrence Seaway," he said. "We finance it across the Atlantic and Pacific."
The financial markets were not the only ones to decline yesterday. Also falling was the commodities market, but falling prices there for agricultural goods and other raw materials are taken as a good sign for the economy.
 
Fall in Commodities Market
 Coffee prices declined on weak demand, lumber dropped on weak housing construction, and crude oil prices slipped on unexpectedly ample supplies. The Commodity Research Bureau futures price index dropped 2.42 points, to 231.78, a steep drop that on another day would have prompted rallies in the stock and bond markets.
The reaction to Mr. Greenspan's testimony was sharp among bond traders. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose about 10 basis points in only two hours, finally closing at 7.54 percent, up from 7.46 percent .
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.19 points, to 249.70, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks by 756 to 1,401. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.90 point, to 433.00.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 15 fell, led by Caterpillar, which dropped 1 1/2, to 107 5/8, on no immediate news. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 304 fell, led by Microsoft, which dropped 1 3/4, to 48 3/8, in advance of announced fourth-quarter earnings of 59 cents a share versus 43 cents.
The most active stock, at 11.2 million shares, was Sybase , which fell 8 3/4, to 39 3/4, following news that in the second quarter sales of its key software product, a way of searching through large data bases, was slowing.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Fall in Price

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday after the chairman of the Federal Reserve indicated that another increase in interest rates might be needed
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 28/32 , to 8424/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, jumped to 7.54 percent, from 7.46 percent on Tuesday. 
 "The bond markets are going to run scared for a while," said Ed Labenski, chief investment officer for $4 billion at IDS Fixed-Income Advisors in Minneapolis.
The fall in the market was touched off in the morning when Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told a Senate panel the Fed might raise interest rates again to contain inflation. The comments surprised investors who had been buying bonds in the last week on the assumption the Fed would not soon increase rates.
Mr. Greenspan's comments shook the bond market, even though some economists had expected the central bank to raise rates 50 basis points this quarter.
 
'Robust and Rapid' Economy
 "It's the first time in a while that the Fed described the economy as robust and rapid," said Michael Strauss, chief economist at Yamaichi International. "If you read through the text, everything is one-sided. The market was betting on great news out of the testimony."
Some investors now expect the Fed to raise rates as early as the middle of August, when the Fed's policy-making committee meets again, to pre-empt inflation. The Fed chairman said yesterday that there was evidence that inflation was building.
"In recent months, we have seen some of these signs" of possible accelerating inflation, like labor shortages, slower deliveries of goods and rising commodity prices, Mr. Greenspan said.
The Fed has raised short-term interest rates four times this year to rein in inflation, which erodes the value of bonds. Thirty-year bond yields were 6.3 percent before the Fed began raising rates in February.
Municipal bond pricess fell as concern about higher interest rates dampened investor demand for large California and New York City offerings yesterday.
California sold a record $4 billion in revenue-anticipation warrants to raise cash needed to cover its mounting bills. Seven underwriting syndicates submitted winning bids on California's sale, with the series C warrants priced to yield between 4.75 percent and 4.80 percent at maturity in April 1996.
 
General Obligation Bonds
 New York City sold $791 million in general obligation bonds in an offering managed by Prudential Securities Inc. The bonds were tentatively priced to yield up to 6.45 percent in 2010.
In the corporate bond market, five companies sold $1.25 billion of debt even as rates rose.
The Columbia HCA Healthcare Corporation sold $200 million of three-year floating-rate debt, MCM Corporate Watch said. Avco Financial Services Inc., a unit of Textron Inc., sold $200 million of five-year notes and the Chemical Banking Corporation sold $150 million of 12-year subordinated notes, according to Corporate Watch.
Elsewhere, Daimler-Benz A.G., the German auto maker and industrial giant, sold $606 million of certificates backed by truck loans through its North American unit, MCM Corporate Watch said. The Green Tree Financial Corporation sold $92.4 million of asset-backed securities.

HEADLINE: Haiti Holding Up Relief Supplies as a Bargaining Chip to Gain Recognition

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 20

 BODY:
In an effort to win some form of diplomatic recognition, Haiti's military-appointed Government is holding up shipments of food and other relief supplies until foreign embassies apply to the two-month-old Government for a special tax exemption on imports.
In some instances, food shipments from donor countries, which include the United States, Canada, France and the European Union, have been kept on the docks here since April and have rotted or been pilfered. 
 The usual practice here is for the donor countries to transport food and medicine to Haiti by ship and then turn over the supplies to international volunteer organizations, which then distribute the supplies throughout the country.
Diplomats said the Government of Emile Jonassaint, installed in May to lend legitimacy to the rule of Gen. Raoul Cedras, is demanding that embassies of donor countries formally apply to Government ministries for an exemption from a tax levied on imported goods. In the past, relief supplies have been granted the exemption as a matter of course, but with foreign governments continuing to recognize the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide as Haiti's constitutional President, those in power have decided to force the issue.
 
Blackmail, Pure and Simple'
 "It's blackmail, pure and simple," one diplomat here said. "The Government claims it is the embargo that is starving people, but then won't let food shipments in."
The delays have not yet begun to significantly hamper the extensive feeding programs sponsored by relief organizations because most of them have large amounts of food stockpiled around Haiti. But the director of one such group said he was perturbed by the game of political brinksmanship going on and said his group would be crippled if the Haitian Government makes good its threat to force payment of the tax.
Similar problems have developed with a shipment of fuel, intended for use by aid groups, that is due to arrive this week. Diplomats said a letter sent to the Haitian Army asking for permission to unload the cargo and hand it over to relief organizations, the procedure that has been followed in the past, was returned with instructions that the request be made to the Jonassaint Government.
At a news conference this week, Foreign Minister Charles David denied that the Haitian Government was using food supplies as leverage to seek concessions from the approximately 15 foreign countries that still recognize Father Aristide and maintain embassies here. "There is no new policy" concerning the distribution of relief shipments, he said.
But diplomats here said they were informed as early as April that if the economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations were increased, General Cedras might suspend all food aid programs.
Elaborating on the issue of food supplies and diplomatic status, Mr. David accused foreign embassies here of abusing their privileges. He said he found it "extraordinary" that foreign diplomats could fly in food and other items "that make their daily lives more bearable" while Haitians suffer from the embargo. He warned that reprisals might be taken.
Diplomats described Mr. David's accusation as fanciful, pointing out that luxury items such as French wine are readily available in grocery stores in upper-class neighborhoods where Cabinet ministers and other officials live.
 
Order to Journalists
 The broader question of the Government's lack of international status is extremely sensitive here. Last week, the Ministry of Information issued a communique ordering journalists to stop referring to Mr. Jonassaint and his Cabinet as a "de facto" Government, insisting that it was a "provisional and constitutional" Government. The order has mostly been ignored.
Haitian officials have also told the United States to register Radio Democracy, the new radio station set up by Washington to broadcast Father Aristide's message to the Haitian people, with the authorities.
The United States provides the Haitian Government with flight information on Coast Guard planes monitoring the flow of refugees trying to flee Haiti by boat, but has turned down requests for other information on the refugees.
Mr. David also said that the Haitian Government was abiding by all the terms of the Vienna Convention, the international agreement that establishes the rules for the treatment of diplomats and embassies. But diplomats here challenged that assertion, saying the Government has recently threatened on several occasions to open diplomatic pouches at the Port-au-Prince airport.
"Their attitude is 'if you won't recognize us, we won't recognize you,' " a diplomat said. "And since we will not deal with their Government, that is where the matter stands."

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
A Panama Enemy Becomes an Ally

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Panama's President-elect, a stalwart in the political party that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega controlled until American troops ousted him in 1989, is suddenly the darling of official Washington.
The President-elect, Ernesto Perez Balladares, says he would allow up to 10,000 Haitians to stay in temporary havens in Panama after he takes office on Sept. 1. The Clinton Administration thought it had a deal with Panama's incumbent President, Guillermo Endara, to take in the boat people. But Mr. Endara, who was installed by American troops after General Noriega's downfall, abruptly withdrew his offer this month, leaving the White House strategy in shambles. 
 Mr. Perez Balladares has set strict conditions on his offer: the Haitians must stay at American military bases in Panama under American supervision, and for no more than six months.
 
'Do Whatever We Can'
 "We have to do whatever we can without hurting our own national interests to bring about a reasonable solution to the Haitian crisis," said Mr. Perez Balladares, a wealthy 48-year-old businessman whose stocky build has earned him the nickname Toro, or bull.
The flow of boat people has ebbed in recent days so the question of safe havens may be moot. But Mr. Perez Balladares has also pledged to help the United States in anti-drug efforts and to press for new laws to prevent money-laundering in Panama and increase penalties for violators.
That President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore met with Mr. Perez Balladares at the White House today to discuss Haiti, among other issues, offers an instructive tale of how mutual economic, diplomatic and security interests of the present can outweigh the differences of the past.
"We'll judge the guy more on his performance and less on his record as a member of Noriega's former party," said one Administration official.
 
Questioned for Several Hours
 Five years ago, Mr. Perez Balladares managed the campaign of General Noriega's handpicked presidential candidate, Carlos Duque, who lost to Mr. Endara. In the 1989 invasion that ousted General Noriega, American troops seized and questioned Mr. Perez Balladares for several hours before eventually releasing him.
Since then, he has resurrected his discredited Revolutionary Democratic Party by distancing it from General Noriega and embracing the legacy of another former dictator, Gen. Omar Torrijos. General Torrijos remains a national hero for building public housing for the poor and negotiating the 1977 Panama Canal Treaties with President Carter.
"Noriega kidnapped our party more than we got together with him," said Mr. Perez Balladares, who won a narrow victory in May over six other candidates in Panama's first democratic elections in more than a quarter of a century. "We've been able to separate that. People understand that Noriega had no political following in Panama. He was a strongman whose leadership was based on force."
 
Who's Who of the Opposition
 Although a disciple of General Torrijos, Mr. Perez Balladares says he will not repeat that regime's curbs on the press and political dissenters. Indeed, the President-elect has packed his Cabinet with a who's who of Panama's free-market economists and former opposition leaders. His foreign minister-designate, for example, is Gabriel Lewis Galindo, a respected former ambassador to Washington who led the political fight against General Noriega from exile in Washington.
The makeover of his party and his own image, and the accompanying layers of irony, are no't lost on Mr. Perez Balladares, a former Citibank executive who was schooled at the University of Notre Dame and at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. So far he is saying what the Administration wants to hear, but will he deliver?
"I want to make sure we make a difference," Mr. Perez Balladares said in an interview. "We want to make sure that the American public understands we're representative of the Panamanian people. We want to maintain a good working relationship."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Four interest-rate increases this year may not be enough to rein in inflation, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, told the Senate Banking Committee. Although Mr. Greenspan stopped short of indicating that the Fed would act, he said for the first time that it would be better for the nation's economy if rates were too high than not high enough. [Page A1.]
Alternatives to the Clipper chip may be considered by the Clinton Administration, in a reversal of its position on the Clipper, a coding system designed by the National Security Agency. [D1.] 
 Home construction slowed in June, hampered by higher mortgage rates. Housing starts declined nearly 10 percent, continuing a decline that began in the spring. [D1.]
Fifty years after the Bretton Woods conference created a global financial system, a group of economists, bankers and diplomats is trying to put together a more durable system for coordinating currency exchange rates. [D1.]
The American steel industry is booming, after decades of collapsing markets, bankruptcies and mill closings. Steelmakers, helped by smaller work forces, new technology and a weaker dollar, are reporting strong demand and sharp gains in earnings. [D1.]
Many small-business owners say they would not be able to afford health insurance for their employees. [A1.]
 
Companies
AMR, the parent of American Airlines, said earnings tripled in the second quarter despite a 2.6 percent decline in revenue. USAir's net income, before preferred dividends, doubled. [D1.]
Sears showed strong gains in merchandising and insurance. Operating income rose 9 percent for the second quarter. [D2.]
Compaq Computer's earnings more than doubled from a year ago. Problems meeting demand hindered sales. [D3.]
Sybase shares slid 18 percent, prompting a selloff in other software-company stocks, too. [D3.]
MCI, Bell Atlantic and Ameritech reported gains for the second quarter. Pacific Telesis reported a slight drop in profit. [D3.]
Five big health care companies announced double-digit gains in United States pharmaceutical sales. [D4.]
Two small computer companies are offering specialized news. The services allow search of large commercial data bases. [D4.]
A New York retailer, 47th Street Photo, is being investigated by a Federal grand jury looking into its cash transactions. [D4.]
 Ford announced prices for its new compact sedans. [D5.]
 
Markets
Treasury prices fell sharply after the Fed chairman indicated that another increase in interest rates might be needed. [D7.]
Stock prices also declined after Mr. Greenspan's testimony. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.04 points. [D8.]
Copper and lumber prices tumbled after the Government reported that housing starts fell sharply in June. [D15.]
The dollar slipped against the yen and mark. [D15.]
 
Today's Columns
The Microsoft case shows that busting trusts isn't what it used to be. Many antitrust economists and lawyers say the company's settlement was about as tough as the antitrust statutes would support. There is also fear that the Government will do more harm than good when it tries to play market referee, especially in technology. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Style -- the way portfolio managers pick stocks and the kind of stocks they stay with -- has not been very important this year. The two major style categories -- growth and value -- are down, and by almost an identical rate. Market Place. [D8.]
Three big brewers are running tongue-in-cheek commercials that are as much about the conventions of television as they are about beer. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Bentsen on Derivatives

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen told an important House committee today that a panel of top regulators was working to tighten oversight of the derivatives markets, but that the panel did not see an immediate need for legislation.
Mr. Bentsen, who is also chairman of the panel, the Working Group on Financial Markets, said that instead of pushing for legislation, financial regulators were amending and updating regulations to cope with the derivatives market. 
 Derivatives are complex contracts whose values are tied to -- or derived from -- the performance of an underlying asset, like a currency, or the performance of a financial market, like the one in interest-rate securities.
Mr. Bentsen issued a report to Representative John D. Dingell, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which has oversight over financial markets, on Monday. Mr. Dingell's office released the report today.
Mr. Bentsen's panel includes the heads of the Federal Reserve, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The panel was originally formed to examine the causes of the October 1987 stock market crash.
Mr. Dingell, a Democrat from Michigan, asked the group in May to comment on issues raised by a General Accounting Office report that called for regulations in the face of the explosive growth of the derivatives markets.
Responding to Secretary Bentsen's report, the Congressman said he was "encouraged" by actions taken so far by regulators to address concerns raised by the G.A.O., which is the auditing and investigative agency of Congress.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE CAMPAIGN;
Clinton Insists He Won't Retreat on Coverage for All

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
After a torrent of criticism from supporters who feared that he was retreating on health care, President Clinton and his Administration went all out today to insist that he would never compromise on his goal of legislation providing health insurance for all Americans.
The President told reporters before a meeting with Congressional leaders that while he was "flexible" on how to reach the goal, he would not abandon it. "If we tinker around with the system and don't try to do something comprehensive," he said, "we could actually make it worse for ordinary Americans. We could increase the cost to middle-class Americans and decrease coverage." 
 At a meeting of the nation's governors on Tuesday in Boston, Mr. Clinton said he might settle for legislation that would produce 95 percent or 98 percent coverage. Today, two House Democrats, Representatives David E. Bonior of Michigan and Butler Derrick of South Carolina, told him that his remarks had not helped those pushing in Congress for universal health coverage and had rattled many of the President's supporters.
"We're past the time for intellectual rationalization," Mr. Derrick, a deputy chief whip, said with some exasperation.
Senior White House officials conceded that Mr. Clinton might have miscalculated the impact of his comments before the governors. "I think he got into a technical discussion about finance with a group who could understand it," one White House official said, "and maybe he wasn't thinking about how it would be interpreted by people who were poised to see the first sign of a cave-in."
But Mr. Bonior, who is the Democratic whip, or No. 3 in the leadership, said he had also told Mr. Clinton that his clarifying remarks today were reassuring.
 
Angry Calls to White House
 White House telephone lines had been hammered on Tuesday night by calls from angry supporters of universal coverage. Their arguments were reflected today in a statement issued by another high-ranking House Democrat, Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, chairman of the Appropriations Committee.
Mr. Obey said that he was not sure what the President's meant to say in Boston but that if Mr. Clinton was "backing away from universal health care reform that covers every citizen in this country, then I will walk away from the Clinton health plan." He added, "This is not the time for the Administration to create confusion about its commitment."
To counter those criticisms, the Administration made an unstinting effort to dismiss Mr. Clinton's remarks on Tuesday as inconsequential. Vice President Al Gore started shortly after 7 A.M. on network news shows. Three hours later, Hillary Rodham Clinton, holding a child with multiple birth defects at a televised new conference, proclaimed, "Health reform without universal coverage will not work."
Mr. Clinton said that all he had meant by citing percentages below 100 was: "We have Social Security, but about 2 percent somehow don't get covered. We have universal school attendance laws in every state in the country, but there are always a couple of percent who fall through the cracks. But you have to write it into law to get there."
 
Bentsen Emphasizes Stand
 Lloyd Bentsen, Secretary of the Treasury, told reporters at a luncheon gathering that Mr. Clinton "still feels very strongly about universal coverage." Mr. Bentsen, who once sponsored legislation that would only change insurance laws, said he now believed such a partial approach would not work. And while he said the Administration was not absolutely insistent on requiring employers to help pay for insurance as the route to universal coverage, that was "sure the easiest way to do it."
Echoing the 1992 Clinton Presidential campaign, when supporters were given a single theme to emphasize each day, the White House health care "war room" sent its allies "talking points" to be used in comments today, including these:
*"The President's bottom line is what it has always been: guaranteed health care coverage."
*"Obviously, we are not going to achieve universal coverage overnight. That's why we phase it in. There will be a road toward universal coverage, but the road must achieve universal coverage."
*"There is no change in strategy. The President remains absolutely committed to universal coverage."
The Administration also made a strenuous effort today to argue that there was not only a social value to universal health insurance, but a strong economic case to be made, too.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, contended that relying only on changing insurance laws would "not improve the system." Instead she said, "You may make it worse."
She argued at the Bentsen lunch that without universal coverage, there would continue to be people without insurance who would get inadequate preventive care and then use expensive health facilities like emergency rooms for conditions that did not require them.
She also said that two changes for which there is widespread support -- requiring insurance companies to insure anyone who asks, regardless of pre-existing medical problems, and community ratings, which charge everyone the same premium regardless of age or health -- could backfire without universal coverage.
If people did not have to be insured but could get insurance whenever they wanted, she said, some people would not buy it until they were ill. That would drive up charges for everyone else. She also argued that young, healthy people would drop out of the system, leaving the pool of insured relatively less healthy and more expensive to cover, again raising rates.
 
Budget Control Emphasized
 Alice M. Rivlin, acting director of thy Office of Management and Budget, argued that universal coverage was the only way to get control of costs and hold the Federal deficit in line.
The officials did not identify any particular percent of the population that had to be covered for these economic gains to be achieved, but clearly implied that it had to be close to 100. Whether 95 percent or 98 percent of the population is covered makes a big human difference, especially when compared with the 84 percent now covered. At 98 percent, several million more people would have the security of health insurance than at 95 percent. But achieving that extra coverage would require larger Government subsidies or larger employer payments.
 
Doubts on Capitol Hill
 Despite the White House insistence that nothing had changed, doubts persisted on Capitol Hill about why Mr. Clinton had spoken as he did to the governors. Some lawmakers speculated that he had been tempted to retreat because he had gotten a gloomy account of Senate prospects for universal coverage from the majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, with whom he met on Monday night. Many in Congress are worried about the high cost of covering everyone, which may require large public subsidies or an unpopular mandate that all employers contribute.
Mr. Mitchell said he would not discuss his conversations with the President. White House officials said they did not know what Mr. Mitchell had told Mr. Clinton.
Others said they believed Mr. Clinton was only trying to sound accommodating without substantively changing his position but stumbled into difficult territory in the process of trying to impress the governors with his good intentions.
Another White House official supported this view, saying that by mentioning any percentage below 100, Mr. Clinton had trod dangerously onto his opponents' turf, the political territory that argues for partial measures.
"We've been very disciplined as an Administration about not saying it for two months now, because we're afraid of it," the official said. "And we were certainly right. You can't use their language, because you get trapped in it."
It also remained to be seen what effect Mr. Clinton's remarks would have on the process of assembling health insurance bills for the House and the Senate to vote on. The majority leaders, Mr. Mitchell in the Senate and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri in the House, are trying to firm up their ideas by the end of the week. Mr. Gephardt is also trying to overcome disputes over jurisdiction of the legislation among three committee chairmen.
 
Dole Is Encouraged
 The suggestion of retreat plainly encouraged Mr. Clinton's opponents, from Senator Bob Dole of Kansas to Senate moderates led by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island.
But it also fired up his most liberal backers, who held news conferences and rallies all over the Capitol today and worked hard at encouraging Mr. Mitchell to go for a strong bill and take a chance on losing, rather than abandon universal coverage and required employer payments at the beginning.

YESTERDAY
 In a coordinated effort, the White House insisted that President Clinton had not retreated from his goal of universal health insurance when he told the nation's governors on Tuesday that he might accept legislation that resulted in coverage for 95 percent or 98 percent of Americans.
 
THE ADMINISTRATION
 The White House made an unstinting effort to dismiss Mr. Clinton's remarks to the governors as inconsequential. Vice President Al Gore made the case on morning television news programs and Hillary Rodham Clinton, holding a child with multiple birth defects at a televised new conference, proclaimed, "Health reform without universal coverage will not work." Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen released a study offering a breakdown by state and Congressional district on the 37 million Americans without health insurance. "They're middle-income Americans that are your neighbors," Mr. Bentsen said at a White House briefing. "Eighty-four percent are in working families."
 
CONGRESS
 The President told reporters before a meeting with Congressional leaders that he was flexible on how to reach his goal of coverage for all Americans but that he would not abandon it. Two House Democrats, David E. Bonior of Michigan and Butler Derrick of South Carolina, told him that his remarks had not helped his supporters' efforts to draft health care legislation and had rattled many Democrats in the House. Some members of Congress saw the President's comments as tantamount to a surrender. "Many people rejoiced yesterday," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas. Others saw a door open to compromise. "I think the President is just waking up to the fact that if he wants a health care bill, it has to be reasonable," said Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a conservative Utah Republican who surprised some observers by sitting down for closed-door meetings today with health care moderates in his party.
 
LOBBYISTS
 The American Association of Retired Persons, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the American Medical Association issued an unusual joint appeal to Congress to overcome its differences and enact a comprehensive health bill this year. They said any bill must achieve universal coverage, give Americans free choice of doctors and health plans, and slow the rate of increase in public and private spending.

HEADLINE: Rabin Sees Walls of Suspicion Crumbling

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 20

 BODY:
Even without trumpets and shouts, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin says, walls will come tumbling down when he and King Hussein of Jordan appear publicly for the first time at the White House next week.
The barriers are in the national minds, the Israeli leader explained, built brick by brick through "an accumulation of hatred, suspicion, animosity, bloodshed, antagonistic perception of one another." 
 "I try to focus on one issue: how to bring down the psychological walls," he said today, his voice characteristically rumbling along like a freight train, slow but insistent. It can be done, he added.
When President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt journeyed dramatically to Jerusalem in 1977, he said, Israelis quickly concluded that he was serious about peace. Within a few years the Egyptians got back Sinai, captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war.
 
Handshake With Arafat
 When Mr. Rabin and Yasir Arafat shook hands on the White House lawn last September -- an act many Israelis found distasteful -- it raised hopes that maybe Israelis and Palestinians could live together, after all.
Now the spotlight is on Israel's newly invigorated peace talks with Jordan, focused on the coming White House encounter between the Prime Minister and the King.
Speaking before a parliamentary committee on Tuesday, Mr. Rabin cautioned that it does not mean that all of a sudden the two countries will clear up their land and water disputes and end five decades of a technical state of war.
No, he said today, warming to a lecturer's role from a soft chair in his office, the point of the meeting is not what it produces. The point is simply that it takes place.
"By itself, it will signal in a meaningful way the kind of atmosphere that no doubt will facilitate solving the practical issues," he said.
 
Not a Matter of Numbers
 "The questions cannot only be solved by computers. It's not just practical issues. The issue is much more about emotion, sometimes irrational. Changing attitudes one toward another is much more important than one kilometer of area this way or that way."
It is tempting to contrast this White House gathering with the celebrated one in which Mr. Rabin shook Mr. Arafat's hand. Yitzhak Rabin was having none of it. "I don't try to compare," he said.
Still, it seems clear that for him and his country the meeting with King Hussein carries much less emotional baggage. After all, the Prime Minister acknowledged today, Mr. Arafat "symbolized barbaric terror against innocent people."
Just before that White House session, he was emotionally jumbled, confessing to an interviewer that his very viscera were in rebellion. There is no such turmoil in regard to King Hussein, a man the Prime Minister is known to have already met several times secretly and whom Israelis regard as a relatively benign figure.
 
'A Great Leader'
 "I will not talk about any meeting that took place or didn't," Mr. Rabin said when asked about the King. But he added, "He's a great leader of his country and his people, and I see him as a partner for the effort to achieve peace between Jordan and Israel."
As for Mr. Arafat, the Prime Minister declined to discuss his feelings about him now that they have met several times. But the new self-rule in the Gaza Strip and Jericho cannot succeed, he warned, unless the Palestinian leader reassures would-be foreign donors who are skittish about where their money is going.
Can Mr. Arafat learn?
"If he will not learn it will bring an economic disaster, and we see the beginning of it in the Gaza Strip," Mr. Rabin said. Israel will not agree to expand the Palestinians' self-rule, he added, until they show they know how to "run a business in a way that it has to be run."
Whatever happens next week in Washington, the 72-year-old Prime Minister says he intends to take Israel further along on perhaps its most challenging voyage since its founding in 1948. For the first time in those 46 years, the outlines of peace with the Arabs are distinct and ready to be fleshed out.
 
Accusations From the Right
 His opponents on the political right accuse him of leading the country, lemming-like, to disaster; the Arabs, they say, will renew their war on Israel once it is lulled by false peace. His detractors on the left accuse him of failing to move more swiftly to disentangle Israel from territories that it captured in 1967.
Mid-term in office, Mr. Rabin also faces disarray on domestic fronts.
His Government has lacked an assured parliamentary majority for many months. His Labor Party recently lost control of two important power bases, the Histadrut union federation and Jerusalem City Hall.
One by one, senior advisers have walked out on Mr. Rabin, and he has yet to find replacements.
Routinely, he is criticized for trying to do too much himself, especially by serving as both Prime Minister and Defense Minister. His tendency to secretiveness and to make important decisions on his own makes some Israelis wonder if the two ministers talk to one another.
Yet even people who are not admirers of Mr. Rabin have marveled at his flexibility in changing Israel's course with the Arabs.
 
'Believes in Tomorrow'
 "For the first time in many years, Israel has a Prime Minister who believes in tomorrow instead of yesterday," wrote Zeev Chafets, a columnist for The Jerusalem Report.
Daniel Ben-Simon, a writer for the newspaper Davar, said: "His value system has changed. The No. 1 soldier here, Mr. Security, has turned into something else, talking about what occupation does to society."
Two months ago, Mr. Rabin startled some Israelis by declaring that "ruling over another people has corrupted us." That from a man who, as Defense Minister in the late 1980's, had advocated beatings as a way to end the anti-Israel uprising in Gaza and the West Bank.
The 27-year military occupation, he added, has "perverted" Israel's economy and its soul, leading it, for example, to depend on cheap Palestinian labor instead of rolling up its own sleeves. The only alternatives, he said, are to annex the territories, an idea he rejects, or to deport the Arabs, a rightist demand that he calls "a racist proposal."
There is one other alternative, Mr. Rabin said: End the occupation.
"The Palestinians are different than us, religiously, politically, you might say nationally," he said. "Jews are not accustomed to become occupiers of another people."
To Israelis who argue that holding onto the land is a supreme Zionist value, Mr. Rabin noted that "we did not keep Mount Sinai." It went back to Egypt a dozen years ago.

HEADLINE: Blacks Press the Case for Reparations for Slavery

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
The phrase "40 acres and a mule," recalling a post-Civil War proposal to compensate former slaves for their servitude, has become the rallying cry among a small but outspoken group of African-Americans.
Some invoke the phrase as they seek financial redress from the Government on behalf of their ancestors. Others, who admit that seeking payment is impractical and the chances of receiving anything improbable, still maintain that gaining attention for the plight of their forebears is well worth their energies. 
 Beginning tomorrow, about 1,000 people who favor reparations are expected to attend the fifth annual Conference on Reparations at Cobo Hall in Detroit. The three-day conference is part of a grass-roots movement that includes petition drives and support from some prominent black politicians, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan.
 
Framing the Debate
 For years, blacks have joked bitterly about exacting reparations. "This is my 40 acres," some looters were heard to say during the urban riots of the 1960's. "I'll be back for the mule." But until recently, any organized movement had been largely ignored or dismissed by most blacks as a foolhardy and unwinnable effort by people whose time could be better spent addressing issues like crime, unemployment and teen-age pregnancy.
Robert Woodson, the president of the Center for Neighborhood Enterprise in Washington, disagrees with the idea of seeking reparations, saying that blacks' efforts should be directed toward dealing with the problems of the present. "The issue isn't whether reparations are justified," Mr. Woodson said. "The question is, Is this an effective way to address problems facing black Americans?"
The success in recent years of other groups, including Japanese-Americans and American Indians, in winning reparations for internment and illegal seizure of land, has fueled the determination of some blacks to ask the Government to make good on what they view as a 133-year-old unfulfilled promise by members of Congress and the Lincoln Administration. But even the most impassioned proponents of reparations do not expect Government action anytime soon.
"Our primary function is raising consciousness and activism," said Efia Nwangaza, a lawyer in Greenville, S.C., who became involved in seeking reparations six years ago. "Not only are we finding more awareness of the concept, but a sense that we indeed are entitled to reparation."
But many people, including historians and politicians, say the issue of reparations for the descendants of slaves raises these questions:
*Who is to pay reparations -- the Government or the descendants of slave owners?
*What form would reparations take? Money? Land?
*Who would be entitled to compensation: all people of black ancestry currently living in the United States or only those who can directly trace their ancestry to slaves? Would they include people of mixed ancestry?
"The Government might make the argument that Japanese-Americans who received reparations were those who were directly injured or harmed as opposed to those who are descendants of" them, said Stanley Mark, a lawyer who is the program director for the Asian-American Legal Defense and Education Fund, which was involved in the class-action that won reparations for Japanese-Americans.
Others say that any effort to identify direct descendants of slaves would be a complicated and probably futile exercise, one compounded by a lack of historical records and vague definitions of who is -- and is not -- black.
 
The Historical Proposals
 The issue of whether to grant land or provisions to former slaves or their descendants was debated during the Lincoln Administration. In 1861, two white abolitionists, Representative Thaddeus Stevens, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Senator Charles Sumner, Republican of Massachusetts, introduced the first of several such bills.
One proposal would have allowed land confiscated from slave owners to be turned over in 40-acre plots to former slaves. After the Civil War, nearly a half-million acres divided into 40-acre parcels -- from Charleston, S.C., to the St. Johns River near Jacksonville, Fla. -- were turned over to former slaves under a field order by Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman. Sherman guaranteed "40 acres of land, plus provisions including mules, horses and foodstuffs" to the former slaves who had fought under him. But in 1869, President Andrew Johnson rescinded the order.
Advocates of reparations cite recent examples of payments to various ethnic groups as precedents for their case. In 1980, the Supreme Court ordered the Federal Government to pay $105 million to eight tribes of Sioux Indians for land seized by Congress in 1877. And in 1988, Congress pledged restitution of $20,000 to each of the 60,000 surviving Japanese-Americans who had been interned in the United States during World War II. That came to a total of $1.2 billion.
Support for the concept has come from sources as diverse as Representative Conyers and rap groups like Public Enemy and KRS-One. Spike Lee, the film director, named his company 40 Acres and a Mule and has said that the name is intended to prick the nation's conscience.
In 1991, Mr. Conyers sponsored a bill to establish a commission to study reparations, but the bill, which has 20 co-sponsors, has never moved out of the House Judiciary Committee. He said that some opponents of reparations argue that blacks have already been compensated through affirmative-action programs, antipoverty programs and race-based scholarships.
 
Forms of Compensation
 Mr. Jackson has sought reparations not just for American blacks but also for African nations for what he has called the illegal importation of Africans to America. "The voices that cry out for reparations have been seen as marginal or radical," he said. "What is America willing to do to repair the damage done?"
But even the advocates of reparations differ on what form the compensation should take.
"Some think $20,000 to every living black American is enough; others want land," said Chokwe Lumumba, a lawyer who heads the New Afrikan People's Organization, a black nationalist group based in Jackson, Miss. "Blacks have a retarded economic infrastructure. We're saying we need reparations to develop that: land, machinery, technology. All of that has to come with billions of dollars."
Kalonji Tor Olusegun of Washington, a leader of the reparations movement, said blacks would never get "the amount due us" and thus must consider other forms of reparations.
"For many blacks, relief from Federal taxes would be sufficient reparation," said Mr. Tor Olusegun, who is a chairman of the National Coalition of Blacks for Reparations in America, or N'Cobra, an umbrella organization of more than 20 social, civic and political groups that represents about 5,000 people.
Other proposals include establishing a national museum devoted to the history of slavery and offering unlimited college scholarships to blacks. Many proponents say that whether or not reparations come, they take some satisfaction in the heightened awareness of the issue.
 
'We Mean Business'
 Last October, Robert Brock, head of the Self-Determination Committee, a Los Angeles group that assists black businesses and community groups, filed suit against the Internal Revenue Service seeking tax exemptions on behalf of 49 million descendants of slaves on the grounds of involuntary servitude.
"We mean business," said Ray C. Jenkins, the coordinator of the Conference on Reparations and a Detroit real estate broker who has worked for 27 years on the reparations effort.
"There is no statute of limitations on injustice," Mr. Jenkins said. "We've been waiting patiently. Our patience has run out."
