HEADLINE: Why American Steel Is Big Again

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GARY, Ind.

 BODY:
The blast furnaces, rolling mills and slab carriers at U.S. Steel's six-mile-long lakefront plant here are running flat out these days, producing coil after coil of sheet steel for the automotive, appliance and container industries.
The plant, despite having the latest technology, is struggling to keep up with demand -- which is precisely the way U.S. Steel and the nation's other big steelmakers have planned things. After a decade of collapsing markets and bankruptcies by the dozens, mill closings and layoffs by the hundreds of thousands, prosperity has returned to the American steel industry.
 
Not Everything Matters
 But this time, having learned the hard way how easily booms can go bust, the industry is prepared to let some business slip away rather than gear up to meet a peak demand that may be fleeting. 
 Although the social costs have been staggering in the last two decades in terms of lost jobs and economically ravaged mill towns, Big Steel's makeover is now reaping big payoffs. The industry is expected to earn $1 billion this year, compared with losses of about $350 million in 1993.
Inland Steel Industries and AK Steel have just reported strong second-quarter profit, compared with losses a year earlier. And the USX Corporation's U.S. Steel Group is expected to soon report earnings in the range of 47 cents a share, compared with a huge loss in the 1993 quarter.
Moreover, the big steel companies, after years of winning only grudging price increases, now find themselves in a position to demand more.
 
Demand Increases
 Thanks in part to the weak dollar, which makes importing foreign steel more expensive than it used to be, domestic mills are being flooded with orders from revived manufacturers in the American industrial heartland.
Analysts estimate that the nation's integrated steel mills -- those that convert raw material like iron ore, coal and limestone into finished steel -- operated at 96 percent of capacity last year. Forecasts are that demand will stay high, and that the industry will operate at 97 percent of capacity this year and 98 percent in 1995.
"The steel industry is in pretty good shape for at least the next 5 to 10 years," said Harry W. Paxton, a former steel executive and now a professor at Carnegie Mellon University. "They cut back on manpower, put in new equipment and did a whole bunch of things to improve on quality."
Steel has even started to reclaim some of the market share lost to plastics and other materials in automobiles and appliances. And a shortage of suitable timber may provide a long-sought opportunity for steel to replace wood in some residential construction. "Steel demand has gone from 90 million tons in 1991 to 106 million this year," said Peter F. Marcus, an analyst with Paine Webber.
And yet, any assessment for steel must be tempered with caution. Some analysts note that the industry's financial position was weakened by the losses and debt taken on during during the 1980's and that it has huge pension and benefits liabilities that are yet to be financed. And they say that the world's steel companies have the capability of making more steel than is consumed, so that any forecasts are subject to trade issues.
 
Accusations of Dumping
 The "voluntary restraint agreements" that limited imports in the 1980's expired in 1992, but the industry has continued to try to limit imports by filing complaints that many products are being dumped -- sold at less than the cost of production.
Students of the industry say that the American companies are now as good or better than European and Japanese steelmakers in quality and cost. Some steel will continue to be imported, industry officials say, largely because the domestic industry has cut back to the point that it cannot meet all the demands of a vigorous economy.
"The American steel industry is, on average, the most productive in the world in terms of man-hours per finished ton of steel," said Christopher Plummer, a steel analyst with Resource Strategies, a consulting company in Exton, Pa.
For every ton of steel produced, American steelmakers spend 5.3 man-hours, compared with 5.6 for the Japanese and Canadian industries, and 5.7 for the British, French and Germans, Mr. Plummer said.
But all this progress for the industry has come at a vast cost to many individuals. According to the American Iron and Steel Institute, the principal trade group, domestic steel employment peaked at 650,000 workers in 1953. Four decades later, the total is close to 175,000. Some companies, including U.S. Steel, have five retired workers for every active employee.
At the Gary Works, during the plant's peak employment in 1953, as many as 30,000 workers toiled there, earning some of the highest wages and best benefits in blue-collar America. The wages and benefits were still good at $29.57 an hour in 1992, but far fewer people were receiving them.
 
But Where Are the People?
 The cavernous buildings here seem almost devoid of human beings. Employment at the 4,000-acre complex still totals close to 8,000, but few workers are to be found on the plant floors where solid steel is processed. Today's steelworkers typically run plants from computerized, air-conditioned control rooms high above the production floor.
Only in the blast furnace, which looks like a first approximation of hell as streams of liquid iron spew sparks and flame, do a few hundred workers in protective clothing work close to the dangerous metal that flows from the furnace at nearly 3,000 degrees Fahrenheit.
The industry's geography has also changed. In the traditional steelmaking regions, primarily the Monongahela River valley near Pittsburgh and along the Mahoning River near Youngstown, Ohio, mills were built to be close to the sources of iron ore and metallurgical coal. But such locations often limited their space, making plant layouts difficult and adding to transportation costs. As part of the industry's overhaul, many of those mills have been closed and torn down.
Between 1977 and 1987, 45 million tons of steel-production capacity -- the equivalent of five Gary works -- went out of service as a result of bankruptcies in the industry or scale-backs leading to partial or complete plant shutdowns.
Today, the American steel industry's center of gravity is in northern Indiana. In addition to U.S. Steel's Gary Works, which has operated at this site since 1909, there are big, integrated mills along the southern shore of Lake Michigan operated by Inland Steel Industries, LTV and Bethlehem Steel. A flat lakefront location allows the mills to be laid out more efficiently and lets producers bring in bulk material cheaply, by freighter across the Great Lakes.
Companies that once boasted of making every steel product from "nails to rails" have conceded low-value items like concrete reinforcement bars to foreign steelmakers and the mini-mills operated by smaller American companies like the Nucor Corporation and the Chaparral Steel Corporation, which produce steel from scrap, rather than ore.
One of the key technological changes for American steelmakers has been the installation of continuous casters, machines that turn molten metal into solid slabs that can be handled and processed while still red hot. The previous method, in use since the earliest days of steelmaking, was to pour molten metal into individual molds, wait for it to cool, strip off the mold and reheat the steel so it could be processed.
Continuous casting greatly reduces manpower and energy requirements. Today, 86 percent of American steel is continuously cast, compared with about 20 percent in 1980.
 
Pendulum of Labor Relations
 A decade of adversity has changed some workplace attitudes, as well. The steel industry bitterly resisted unions until changes in the laws began to give workers the upper hand in the 1930's. But even with the recognition of unions, labor relations in the industry were highly adversarial.
In recent years, though, the United Steelworkers union has negotiated contracts with the major steelmakers that have given the companies more flexibility in assigning workers. In return the union has gotten, among other things, the right to name a member of the board of directors.
Together, continuous casting and greater labor flexibility have produced sizable reductions in costs. The Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington-based research organization, said in a recent report that the labor portion of steel costs declined from $262 a ton in 1982 to $161 a ton in 1992.
Over all, the cost of producing a ton of steel in the United States declined from more than $650 a ton in 1982 to about $525 a ton in 1992. "Consequently, U.S. companies went from being among the world's highest-cost producers, to among the world's lowest-cost producers," the study concluded.
Until last year, steel prices had been steady or declining, which has helped other industries that are large steel users. Analysts say one of the factors in the comeback of the American automobile industry is that it has been building 1990's cars out of steel at 1980's prices. But with demand now nearly surpassing supply, American steelmakers are in a position to raise prices. Last year, they rose about 15 percent in spot markets and have gone up 5 to 8 percent more so far this year.
The steel industry says it has other problems, notably "legacy costs" -- obligations to pay pensions and health benefits to the tens of thousands of involuntary retirees and their spouses. Of the 50 most underfinanced pension plans, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation says, five are in steel: National, LTV, Inland, Bethlehem and AK Steel.
LTV, which operated under bankruptcy protection for seven years, largely because of its pension liabilities, still has $3.68 billion in pension obligations -- and more than 40 percent of it remains unfinanced.
"Pensions and health are the biggest millstones" the older companies have to bear, said Mr. Plummer, who estimated that they added $4 to $8 a ton in costs. "That's a lot in a when you are competing in a market with mini-mills, which do not have them at all."

HEADLINE: KING HUSSEIN HINTS JORDAN CONSIDERS A SEPARATE PEACE

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, July 20

 BODY:
Signaling his independence from Syria and his desire for peace, King Hussein of Jordan suggested today that he was prepared to move without President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and sign a separate peace treaty with Israel.
The King's remarks were couched in his characteristically elliptical style, and he added that it could take some time before an agreement could be reached. 
 But the King's remarks to reporters at a joint news conference with Secretary of State Warren Christopher in Amman, were echoed later by Prime Minister Abdel Salam Majali of Jordan. There were other signs of progress in negotiations and gestures of friendship between Israel and Jordan after the announcement last Friday that King Hussein would meet with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel in Washington on July 25.
Shortly after King Hussein spoke, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres became the first Israeli Cabinet minister to publicly set foot on Jordanian soil.
He arrived by helicopter at a spa on a remote area of the Dead Sea for talks with Mr. Majali and Mr. Christopher that outlined specific economic projects to link the two countries and affirmed the goal of ending a formal state of war that has existed since 1948.
The site was not far from where Golda Meir, as Israeli Foreign Minister, secretly met King Abdullah, the present monarch's grandfather, in the late 1940's. Over the years, King Hussein has met a number of times with Israeli officials, but always in secret.
It was 43 years ago on this day, Mr. Peres noted, that King Abdullah was assassinated outside the Al Aqsa mosque in Jerusalem in front of his grandson.
"Today, Israel and Jordan are stepping out from the old and into the new," Mr. Christopher said in prepared remarks after the three-way meeting near the town of Shuna. "An era of war is coming to a close. This ancient land's cries for peace are finally being heard."
King Hussein was asked when he would sign a peace accord with Israel and whether it could come at the White House next Monday when he meets with Mr. Rabin. "I believe the answer is as soon as possible, but certainly not next week," King Hussein replied. "We've still got a long way to go."
Pressed by one reporter on whether peace could come in a month, he added: "I don't know. Maybe a month might be too soon."
But King Hussein stated that he was willing to go his own way, despite his repeated pledges to Mr. Assad, the man he still calls his "brother," that a comprehensive peace of all the parties is necessary.
"The Syrian track is active as we are," King Hussein said when asked whether he would sign a peace treaty ahead of Syria. But, he added, "We have taken a sovereign decision regarding our right to move to deal with every aspect and every problem that is included in the agenda which we ratified in Washington some while ago and we are beginning."
King Hussein referred to the signing of a framework agreement in Washington by Jordan and Israel last September that provides the basis for resolving differences between them.
Although on paper the Israeli-Jordanian agreement merely set out a formal agenda for negotiations, it represented a major step toward peace and has provided a basis for progress in specific areas.
"It is our fervent hope that at the end of this process, there will be a comprehensive peace in the region," the King said.
The new independent tone was echoed later by Prime Minister Majali, who told reporters at the Dead Sea that it was not important whether Syria or Jordan signed first. "Who is to be signing peace first or second?" he asked. "This is immaterial."
In a joint communique, the United States, Israel and Jordan spelled out some of the areas of cooperation. The three sides pledged to hold regular meetings on the ministerial level and work on a master plan for the development of the Jordanian Rift Valley that is expected to be announced at the White House on Monday.
 
Framework for Trade
 They also said they would formulate a framework for trade and commercial relations between Israel and Jordan, marking a new willingness by Jordan to discuss those subjects without first settling water and territorial disputes. Finally, they agreed on a plan to develop tourism and on the creation of a joint team to explore aviation routes and conduct a preliminary survey of a major road linking Jordan, Israel and Egypt.
Essentially, Jordan and Israel are making peace in practical ways -- what one senior Admninsitration official called "pieces of the peace" -- in preparation for the day when they sign an overall agreement.
In his prepared remarks, Mr. Peres captured the historic sense of the meeting: "It took us 15 minutes to fly over. It took us 46 years to arrive to this time and this place."
Jordanian waiters watched news of today's meeting on Israeli television; Israeli journalists were able to use their cellular phones to make calls to Jerusalem. The Jordanian side handed out glossy brochures titled, "Investing in Jordan, Your Profit Center in the Middle East."
There were small hints here and there that, for all the enthusiasm, peace may not be waiting just around the corner. In a news conference with Mr. Peres and Mr. Christopher, Mr. Majali repeated that Jordan would not be rushed into peace.
"In Arabic, we say, 'He who hastens things before its time, God will prevent him from having it.' Not to try to push things before it is time. When it is time, it is right, it is delicious, it is good. If it is before its time, if you eat the apple before its time, you will get tummy cramps."

HEADLINE: Bosnian Serbs Said to Reject Mediators' Partition Plan

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 20

 BODY:
In a new blow to efforts to end the Bosnian conflict, Bosnian Serb authorities were reported today to have rejected a territorial division that was the central pillar of a new Bosnia peace plan proposed by international mediators two weeks ago.
Under the plan, which was presented to the warring parties on a take-it-or-leave-it basis, Bosnian Muslims and Croats would be given 51 percent of the new republic, while Bosnian Serbs, who now hold 70 percent of territory, would see their share reduced to 49 percent. 
 Although Bosnian Serbs indicated on Tuesday that they might be ready to work with the plan, Charles Redman, the United States special envoy to the Balkans, said that the Bosnian Serbs told a five-nation group of international mediators that they could not accept the territorial proposal.
 
A Negative Reply
 The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, who presented his delegation's response today, refused to meet reporters here. But senior European officials who attended today's meetings confirmed that there was no ambivalence about the Bosnian Serbs' negative position, and that the mediators were united in perceiving the Serbs' response as a rejection.
Earlier today, a joint Bosnian Government and Bosnian Croat delegation confirmed their acceptance of the plan in a separate meeting with the international mediators. The Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government and the Bosnian Croats agreed earlier this year to form a federation.
The Bosnian Serbs' rejection of the proposed map opens them up to a series of reprisals by the international community, including tightening of sanctions against their Serbian backers in Belgrade and a possible lifting of the arms embargo on Bosnia, which has impeded Bosnian Government efforts to overcome the Bosnian Serbs' advantage in weapons.
 
Decision on Sanctions
 The decision on what new punitive measures will be adopted against the Bosnian Serbs will be taken by Foreign Ministers of the United States, Russia, France, Britain and Germany at a meeting provisionally scheduled for Geneva on July 30. These same Ministers proposed the peace plan here July 5.
The Bosnian Serbs' response, which was the result of two days of intense and secretive meetings of the Bosnian Serbs' self-styled parliament in Pale, was conveyed today to a so-called "contact group" of senior officials from the same five mediating countries at two closed-door meeting here today.
"At the first meeting, the Bosnian Serb delegation said it had not accepted our territorial proposal," Mr. Redman said. "At the second meeting, our group expressed its disappointment at the lack of a positive reply."
 
Other Issues Raised
 He said the Bosnian Serb delegation had raised other issues, but was reminded that all other discussions depended on acceptance of the territorial proposal. He added that the "contact group" would present a detailed "incentives and disincentives package" next week.
One European envoy said that, while in the past there have been differences within the "contact group" there was "no divergence" among the mediating countries today in their reaction to the Bosnian Serbs' response. "You can talk of unity of the group," he said. "For all of us, the territorial division is the key question."
Bosnia's Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, and the Bosnian Croat leader, Kresimir Zubak, left Geneva soon after presenting their response this morning. Bosnia's Vice President, Ejup Ganic, stayed on to be briefed on the Bosnian Serb response by the American, Russian, French and British envoys. Mr. Karadzic and his delegation are expected to leave here Thursday and no further meetings with the "contact group" are scheduled.
Western diplomats said that the Bosnian Serbs seemed anxious to reopen discussions about the map even though they had been asked for a yes or no answer. But despite reports from their headquarters in Pale, Bosnia, on Tuesday that the Bosnian Serbs might want to give an equivocal reply, the mediators read it as a rejection.
 
A 'Yes' Is Not Heard
 "This wasn't a 'yes, but' or a 'yes, and'," one Western diplomat said. "There was not a 'yes' involved here. The territorial proposal was not acceptable."
The diplomats said the Bosnian Serb reply presented to the "contact group" in a sealed pink envelope raised such questions as constitutional arrangements within the proposed Bosnian union, the status of the capital city of Sarajevo and Bosnian Serb demands for an access to the Adriatic Sea.
But one well-placed Western diplomat recalled that the international mediators had decided that the territorial division was the "core problem" and should be dealt with first. He added that by trying to deal with other issues first, "the Serbs are talking about a different kind of process -- not what we have been working on for the last three months."
United States and European diplomats refused to speculate about measures that might be adopted when Secretary of State Warren Christopher joins his Russian, French, British and German colleagues here later this month, but they noted that a lifting of the arms embargo is still considered "a last resort."
One Western diplomat noted that the mediators' objective was still to make the Bosnian Serbs accept the peace plan and that there was still some hope that Russia could persuade them to do so.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Microsoft case shows that trustbusters won't be referees.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
MICROSOFT v. the United States and the European Union: What had all the makings of the global antitrust case of the decade ended with a whimper. Microsoft had been rumored to be facing strict monitoring of its relations with competitors and clients, or even a breakup of its operations into two companies. In the end, however, the Justice Department and its European counterpart demanded only modest changes in the way the giant software maker markets its products.
Not surprisingly, the consent decree was greeted with dismay by rivals most vulnerable to Microsoft's juggernaut, notably those that produce software applications like word processing, along with those that produce utilities -- anti-virus programs, for example -- that are often sold as a package with Microsoft's basic operating system. What may surprise is the lack of a passionate response from antitrust economists and lawyers. 
 Many of them simply agree with Assistant Attorney General Anne Bingaman that the deal was about as tough as the antitrust statutes would support. To win, she reminds, "you have to have the law and the facts" on your side.
But times have changed, and so have trustbusters: Many now fear that the Government will do more harm than good when it tries to play market referee, especially in high-technology industries: "You want to make it as easy as possible to compete with Microsoft," said Frank Fisher, an economist and antitrust expert at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, "but you don't want to confuse Microsoft's success with monopoly."
The deal struck between Microsoft and the Justice Department bars a Microsoft pricing plan that looked fishy on its face.
The department objected to "per processor" contracts in which, to earn volume discounts, computer makers were required to fork over a royalty to the software maker on every machine shipped, regardless of whether Microsoft's "operating system" -- the coded instructions that link the machinery to the user -- was shipped with it. The arrangement effectively forced computer makers to pay a double royalty if they chose to sell an operating system not made by Microsoft.
Michael Sohn, a lawyer at Arnold & Porter who represents the Novell Corporation, one of Microsoft's few competitors in the sale of operating systems, professes satisfaction with the decree. "It levels the playing field," he said, giving Novell and others a fair shot at the market for software that comes out of the box with a new computer.
But that does not mean competitors will come up with products that persuade millions of reasonably satisfied customers to go to the trouble of switching from Microsoft's MS-DOS operating system and the Windows graphics software that converts MS-DOS mumbo-jumbo into user-friendly pictures. Nor will it prevent Microsoft from integrating ever more applications into its operating systems, undermining software producers in niche markets ranging from appointment calendars to cutesy "screensavers." Nor should it have the slightest impact on Microsoft's rapacious appetite for a greater share of the market for word processing, spreadsheet and data organization programs, the meat and potatoes of the software industry.
Competitors care, but should the public? It is possible that Microsoft will parallel I.B.M.'s path in computer hardware, dominating the software market by being good enough, if not always best. In this scenario, Microsoft would one day lose its edge and be overwhelmed by hungrier rivals. Indeed, Microsoft's saga may prove to be another chapter in the chaotic but benign process the economist Joseph Schumpeter called "creative destruction."
It is also possible, though, that the Microsoft juggernaut will be sustained by inertia long after it has ceased to be a leader in technology. It may end up looking less like I.B.M. in 1990 than like General Motors in 1980 -- a failed organization still able to command vast quantities of capital and labor that could be used more productively elsewhere.
What, then, is to be done? Antitrust lawyers have no trouble answering "very little." The antitrust laws are written to punish conduct, not to generate desired outcomes in markets, Ms. Bingaman said. "We don't live in a planned economy," she added.
One might expect economists, who lack the reality check of the law, to be more tempted to intervene. Certainly many would have been tempted in the 1970's, before Washington tossed away billions of dollars on synthetic fuels to compete with Arab oil. And a good number would still have taken the chance before the political debate over who lost high-definition television ended in a rush to take the credit for waiting until the next broadcast technology came along.
But economists are humbler today. The $64 question is no longer "Do markets work well?" but rather "Will markets work better after the Government tries to fix them?" And few are optimistic that Washington is up to the task, especially when it includes predicting the path of innovation.
So what about Microsoft and the awful possibility that it will someday become General Motors? "We'll just have to deal with the problem, when and if it comes," said Alfred Kahn, an economist at Cornell who has regulated businesses ranging from electricity to telephones to airlines.

HEADLINE: Quest for Return of the Timber Wolf;
But Not Everyone Is Eager to See Predator in Adirondacks

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TUPPER LAKE, N.Y.,

 BODY:
Scott Thiele was bouncing down a rutted logging road in the Adirondacks recently, thinking about Jack Nicholson and the feral music of the backwoods, when the thought struck him: what a perfect spot for a howling party.
Amid the secluded bogs, hemlock forests and placid lakes where fishermen dreamily canoe, he envisioned tourists at dusk and a guide who mimics the mournful cry that has sent shivers down spines for centuries. 
 No full moon needed. Just real wolves to howl back.
So goes one of Mr. Thiele's many pitches for an idea he has been single-mindedly selling to the north country: to return the eastern timber wolf to the Adirondacks, the vast and sparsely populated state park that covers most of northern New York State.
 
Wolves for Yellowstone
 In his quest, Mr. Thiele, 33, has joined a loose-knit national movement to repopulate state and national parks in Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Montana and Wyoming with North America's once top predator. In the movement's latest and perhaps largest victory, the Department of Interior agreed recently to reintroduce 30 wolves into Yellowstone National Park and central Idaho over the next year.
Mr. Thiele argued that repopulating the Adirondacks with wolves, which probably disappeared from the region around 1890, would make the natural order healthier because wolves prune away aged and infirm animals, particularly deer and beaver. But wolves will also make the economic order healthier, he said.
"Nobody will come to the Adirondacks just because coyotes are out there," he said. "But the wolf gives a mystique to the wilderness. A lot of people just want to know the call of the wild is still out there."
Plenty of Adirondack residents disagree. Residents worry about wolves killing pets and livestock. Hunters argue wolves will decimate the deer population. A few biologists even question whether wolves ever lived in the region.
Property-rights groups see wolf restoration as a veiled attempt by environmentalists to increase state and Federal control over the region, since the wolf is protected under the Federal Endangered Species Act.
"This isn't a zoo here," said Larry Reandeau, a businessman in Tupper Lake who is active in the Adirondack Solidarity Alliance, a property-rights group. "We come under regulations that no one else has to face, all in the name of environmentalism. But it isn't environmentalism. It's socialism."
 
A Tough Sell
 Even Mr. Thiele's supporters say he faces an uphill battle. A proposal by the state to bring moose from Canada and New England foundered last year when Adirondack residents raised fears about car accidents with the 1,200-pound animals. Wolves, with all their negative baggage, could prove an even tougher sell.
Langdon Marsh, the State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, said: "I recognize there is a lot of unwarranted fear and superstition about the wolf. But nevertheless, there is the reality of significant public concern."
Though he has a handful of helpers, Mr. Thiele is something of a one-man sales team for the wolf. A six-footer with a soft voice and long beard, he has sold time-share condominiums, computers and office equipment. But he said he became fed up with what he called "the lies of the corporate world" and decided to get involved in environmental causes.
He learned of the Yellowstone wolf-restoration project while traveling in Montana last summer and decided to bring the idea east. So he formed the Adirondack Wolf Project, raised $7,500 in foundation grants and hit the road.
Though he owns a home in Montrose, Pa., he has been living out of his rusty 1986 Hyundai as he crisscrosses the north country, living on oats and yogurt, bathing in mountain streams and sleeping in campgrounds and friends' backyards.
In the small towns where he gives lectures to advance his cause, Mr. Thiele has faced some tough crowds. His notes were stolen at one session, a videotape at another. He has received death threats on his special phone line, (800) 310-WILD. In Silver Bay, someone asked, "If we're going to bring back the wolf, why don't we bring back smallpox, too?"
But elsewhere, support has been substantial. "The wolf is such a wonderful family animal," said Janet Chapman at a session in Tupper Lake. "Man could learn a lot from them."
Peter O'Shea, a retired police officer who lives in the town of Fine, contended that only a vocal minority opposed wolves. "They have set a stage so people are loathe to speak up on any environmental issue," he said outside the meeting in Tupper Lake. "But 80 percent of the people love these woods and they want these animals."
The goal of Mr. Thiele's crusade is to prod state and Federal agencies to study where wolves could thrive in the Adirondacks. He believes that the region can sustain 20 to 30 packs, about 100 to 150 wolves; he envisions starting out with wolves captured in eastern Canada and released in the Adirondacks.
 
'Symbol of Wilderness'
 Though wolf-repopulation efforts are under way in several states, Minnesota is the only place outside of Alaska with a sizable wolf population. There, wolf advocates say, evidence is growing that wolves, hunters and farmers can coexist.
But biologists who are critical of Mr. Thiele's proposal say the Adirondacks are more densely populated than northern Minnesota, so wolves and people would cross paths more often here. They noted that in the recent lynx restoration in the Adirondacks, many of the 83 animals released in the wilds were struck by cars.
The biologists also contended that the wolf's place atop the predatory ladder has been filled by coyotes.
"The wolf is a symbol of wilderness, it is a critter that just by its presence stirs the imagination," said Dr. Rainer Brocke, professor of wildlife ecology at the State University College of Environmental Science and Forestry in Syracuse. "But as far as the ecosystem goes, it wouldn't do a whole lot. The coyote has largely taken its niche."
But Mr. Thiele said there was more to his effort then just filling a niche. "It's about nature's health," he said. "It's about the wholeness of the ecosystem."

HEADLINE: Bretton Woods: A Policy Revisited

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
A half century after the about-to-be victorious Allies of World War II put in place bold plans for a global financial system and two decades after that system was formally abandoned, a high-profile group of economists, bankers and diplomats is trying to put it back together again. But the privately sponsored Bretton Woods Commission, which meets today in Washington amid dramatic erosion in the value of the dollar, is sure to meet resistance from a host of sources.
To some, the effort led by Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, to invent a more effective form of economic super-government to coordinate currency exchange rates, is ideologically offensive. "It's against the trend of the times," said Ian Vasquez, the director of the Cato Institute's Project for Global Economic Liberty. 
 But probably the more telling opposition will come from pragmatic economists. They find the call for tighter harmonization of monetary and fiscal policies unrealistic. "Would President Reagan have decided not to cut taxes in order to defend the exchange rate of the dollar?" asked William Branson, an economist at the Woodrow Wilson School of Princeton University.
And they are skeptical that the gain in stabilizing exchange rates would be worth the pain.
"There's just not a compelling case that exchange instability exacts a heavy cost" on the industrial countries, which, typically for domestic political reasons, put domestic economic and social priorities first, said Jeffrey Sachs, an economist at Harvard University.
In July 1944, the original Bretton Woods conference, named for its New Hampshire site, pitted ally against ally. The American delegation, led by Harry Dexter White, wanted to fix exchange rates and abandon controls on trade after the war, because it believed in free trade and because it wanted to consolidate American influence. The British, led by John Maynard Keynes, were eager to slow Britain's loss of authority in the world economy by retaining considerable power to adjust rates and to limit trade.
The deal struck was widely interpreted as a compromise between the American and British views. Changes in exchange rates would be permitted, but only in exceptional, though undefined, circumstances and only under the supervision of a new organization, the International Monetary Fund. To back its authority, the I.M.F. would offer a carrot of loans to countries that needed time to adjust domestic policies to shore up the exchange value of their currencies.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development -- the World Bank -- would mobilize capital to rebuild the shattered world economy. Most of that capital would be American. And the two countries agreed to disagree about free trade, postponing a resolution until the postwar recovery.
But as Ronald McKinnon, an economist at Stanford University, has noted, the supranational structure created at Bretton Woods served mostly to camouflage the reality of American dominance over postwar economic policy. Most of the money used to rebuild Europe and Japan came directly from Washington under the Marshall and Dodge plans -- not from the I.M.F. or the World Bank.
And as The Economist magazine has pointed out, Washington actively encouraged the creation of a regional payments union which wrestled with Western Europe's currency exchange problems into the late 1950's, without the help or interference of the I.M.F.
 
Shattering of a System
 What the United States created, it did not hesitate to destroy. The fixed exchange-rate system invented at Bretton Woods was shattered when its main supporter, the United States, put the goal of domestic economic growth ahead of the goal of global exchange stability.
Thus President Nixon's 1971 decision to devalue the dollar by cutting it loose from the price of gold rather than risk recession in an election season was merely the formal end to a rule-based currency system that had largely been honored in the breach. Today's informal arrangement, by which the major economic powers seek to stabilize currencies only when it suits their collective interests, represents less of a break with the past than is generally understood.
Why, then, is the Bretton Woods Commission trying to go back to the way we never were?
"There is good evidence that exchange rates fluctuate excessively," in the sense that the movements do not reflect underlying economic changes, Mr. Branson said.
And few economists disagree with the commission's assertion that exchange misalignment both wastes resources and adds a head of steam to the pressure for protectionism. In the mid-1980's, for example, the overvalued dollar accelerated the demise of heavy industry and led Washington to curtail imports of steel and autos; today the Japanese are accusing Washington of driving down the value of the dollar to aid American exporters.
 
A Two-Step Approach
 Hence the commission is seeking a two-stage revival of the spirit of Bretton Woods. In the first, governments would pledge to work toward coordination of fiscal and monetary policies through the I.M.F., reducing the pressures for currency realignments. In the second, they would agree to maintain formal exchange rates within bands -- say a few percent up or down against the yen, mark and dollar.
"The world isn't capable of maintaining a true fixed exchange-rate system," said John Williamson, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics. But he said exchange rates could not be left to currency traders, who treat it all like some giant Nintendo game. "Someone has to take the long view," Mr. Williamson argued.
One voice of dissent comes from the ideological right, which has no use for any plan adding to the power of the international bureaucracies created at Bretton Woods. Indeed, a number of organizations use the slogan "50 years is enough" as they campaign in Congress to withdraw American sustenance from both the I.M.F. and the World Bank.
"These institutions are simply trying to invent reasons to survive" in a world that has passed them by, said Mr. Vasquez of the Cato Institute.
Mr. Sachs shares this suspicion of bureaucracies that keep on running and running and running. And he has no particular affection for the I.M.F. "They give bad advice," he said. "I'd never give them more power."
 
Little Economic Effect
 His broader objection to a move toward globally managed exchange rates, however, is that it would not be practical. European countries, he argued, have a strong incentive to coordinate policies because their economies are exceptionally interdependent. But the current mini-crisis over the dollar, he suggested, illustrates that even sharp speculative shifts in major exchange rates rarely have much effect on jobs, prices or profits. In spite of -- and perhaps because of -- the weak dollar, the American economy is in the best shape in years.
In any event, Mr. Sachs said, policy coordination is often not the key to fixing what is broken. For example, if Japan, the biggest potential loser from a weak dollar, had felt strongly enough about its exporters' competitive position, it could have cut taxes or lowered interest rates. "It really was not necessary," he said, "to raise interest rates in America," which he believes would have done more harm than good to the United States economy.
Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International and a participant at the Bretton Woods forum today and tomorrow, offered what is likely to prove the dominant sentiment at the meeting. "It's useful to have the proposal on the table," he said, because the "essentials -- greater policy coordination -- make sense."
But a return to the Bretton Woods system, Mr. Hormats suggested, "just wouldn't be credible without a major change in attitude" -- on the part of currency traders and governments. "We've moved well beyond a world in which a single set of currency rules is practical," he concluded.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Gain Turns to Loss After Greenspan Testimony

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell slightly against leading currencies yesterday, following the bond and stock markets, which weakened after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, rekindled inflation fears in testimony before Congress.
Though Mr. Greenspan indicated concern about the dollar's weakness and its effect on the economy, the dollar still fell against the Japanese yen and the German mark. Such talk usually drives the dollar higher by putting traders on notice that the central bank may intervene in its defense. 
 Traders said yesterday that sliding securities prices and profit taking from the dollar's recent rally undermined the positive effects of Mr. Greenspan's testimony.
 
Another Rate Increase?
 The dollar started higher in Europe but began to fall with stock and bond prices after the release of Mr. Greenspan's prepared testimony. He told the Senate Banking Committee that this year's four interest rate increases might not be enough to rein in inflation.
"Greenspan may have reopened a can of worms," said Lisa Finstrom, currency analyst at Smith Barney Inc. "It rekindled inflationary expectations. The market had become somewhat more calm and had faith coming into this. The dollar's value reflects overall financial health of the United States and inflation is no good. The expression of concern fed dollar negativity."
The dollar was quoted in late New York trading at 98.80 yen, down from 99.30 late Tuesday. The dollar dropped to 1.5650 marks from 1.5682 marks on Tuesday.
 
An Impact on Policy
 In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan said the currency's slide was bad for the United States economy and was beginning to have an impact on the Fed's monetary policy because of the inflationary consequences.
A protracted slide could ultimately fuel inflation by pushing up the price of imports, and has already set off investor flight from dollar-denominated assets.
Some market participants shrugged off the comments, which they said shed no new light on the Government's currency policy, and attributed yesterday's dip mainly to profit taking.
"The selloff started before Greenspan opened his mouth. I think it was largely technical," said Hubert Pedroli, manager of currency trading for Credit Suisse in New York.

HEADLINE: Building Small . . . Thinking Big

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS 

 BODY:
A COTTAGE as pretty as a picture postcard, nestled behind the sort of tidy wooden fence that Tom Sawyer so famously whitewashed. Cozy and eminently affordable, it was the American dream for much of this century, until the decade of the leveraged buyout caused the average middle-class home to balloon from 1,710 square feet in 1982 to more than 2,100 square feet last year.
But even as houses continue to grow, the small, sensible cottage is coming into vogue again. A band of architects and builders is trying to shake some sense into their industry, spurred on by statistics that show that the American family is shrinking, and by the rise of single-person and single-parent households. Such people say they don't need and can't afford the bodacious four-bedroom house that has strong-armed the suburban landscape for more than a decade -- "the junior embassy look," as Michael Walsh, a syndicated columnist, has called it. 
 "It's the architect's duty to bring people to their senses," said Max Levy, a Dallas architect. "Excess square footage is the architectural equivalent of overeating, with all its overtones of nervous disorder."
A prime example of how this nascent less-can-be-more movement can work stands in a grove of pines at the end of a winding gravel road in Dutchess County, N.Y. Clad in cedar shingles and topped by three vast interlocking peaked roofs, Tobias Picker's house resembles a Russian dacha by way of Stanford White. Packed into its two-floor 1,100-square-foot plan are two bedrooms (15 by 13 feet and 14 by 11 feet), one and a half baths and a semicircular living room (17 by 17 feet) dominated by a baronial fireplace. Out back is a covered porch (21 by 13 1/2 feet), which functions as a dining room for much of the year.
The cost of the house was $110,000 -- $100 a square foot, said its architect, Dennis Wedlick, a young New Yorker with a talent for cottage-size homes with poetic silhouettes. Judicious use of stock windows, a prefabricated fireplace, ready-made columns and asphalt roofing allowed Mr. Wedlick to incorporate luxuries like doors made of fine-grained Douglas fir.
From the owner's perspective, the house is "huge." "And it's cheaper and nicer than anything I've seen already built," said Mr. Picker, a composer, who shares the house with a friend. He added that the different ceiling heights (8 feet in the halls, 10 feet in the bedroom and study, a cavernous 16 feet in the stairwell) remind him of old cartoons. "You know, where a cat chases a mouse into what appears to be a tiny house but they run through dozens of rooms," he said.
Growing interest in small-scale houses is spurred in part by "hometown" developments like Seaside, Fla., and by the reissue of turn-of-the-century house-plan books like "Bungalows, Camps and Mountain Houses" (AIA Press, 1993).
"There's a real need for intimacy," said Melanie Taylor, an architect in New Haven who has developed a thriving sideline selling plans for neo-Victorian, 875-square-foot cottages based on her designs for Seaside.
One of her latest projects is for Kathryn George, an editor in chief of American Homestyle magazine. Measuring 16 feet wide by 36 feet deep and replete with fireplaces, porches and a bunk room for guests, Ms. George's three-bedroom, 1,152-square-foot house in Ashfield, Mass., is expected to cost about $120,000.
Mr. Levy, Ms. Taylor and their fellow revolutionaries have their whittling cut out for them. According to a recent study by the Economics and Housing Development division of the National Association of Home Builders, of the million or so single-family American homes built in 1993, 29 percent measured 2,400 square feet or more. Thirty percent of all homes built last year had four bedrooms or more, while 48 percent were equipped with at least two and a half baths. In six years, it is predicted that the average American home will increase by nearly 10 percent, to about 2,500 square feet.
Ironically, census statistics point out that the size of the American family has decreased, from an average of 3.6 people in 1971 to 2.7 in 1993. The end-of-the-decade family unit is expected to be even smaller, just 2.4 people.
"Everybody wants a media room, a home office, an exercise room, three bathrooms, a family room, a living room and a huge, beautiful, eat-in kitchen that nobody cooks in," said a plainly exasperated Gopal Ahluwalia, the director of research for the home builders' association. "It's incredible. All this increased size has nothing to do with use of space, because the space that we have is wasted. My wife and I are perfect examples. Our dining room is used maybe three times a year."
But for many people, cutting back a floor plan means "invading the category of hope," said Anne Lewis, a partner at McCartney-Lewis, an architectural firm in Washington.
"We all have a long list of people we want to invite over, and 20 years later, we still haven't given that big party," she said. "But, hey, you never know."
One reason big homes are so prevalent is economics, said Marshall Taylor, a senior reporter at Real Estate Finance Today, a publication of the Mortgage Bankers Association.
"Builders want to make the most money they can, and the bigger the home, the bigger the profit," Mr. Taylor explained. "They just don't make nearly as much building a small house. Consequently, we have an affordable-housing crisis. The average family can't afford a home because there aren't enough homes being built for less than $150,000."
According to a guideline cited by officials at the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, a family with a median yearly income of $39,950 can afford a $113,000 home -- if they can find one.
Dr. Jamie Horowitz, an environmental psychologist and associate professor of architecture at Iowa State University of Science and Technology, says home-buying habits are partly to blame for the housing shortage. Ten years ago, "it was addictive," she said, "like high-stakes gambling: buy a big house, sell it for more than you paid, buy a bigger house." She continued: "Builders built big and expensive because that's the only way they could recoup what they paid for the land. Then the bottom of the market fell out."
"Today, we're in need of balance, not bombast," she said. "Showing off doesn't give us the same sort of thrill anymore, which explains part of the renewed interest in the cottage. It's discreet, it's comforting and the lower price tag means that you end up with money in the bank that you can spend on enjoying life instead of paying an outrageous mortgage."
Several other societal factors play a role in the small-house revival, from concern for the environment (smaller houses generally cost less to build, heat, cool, decorate and maintain) to the knowledge that the average American family no longer resembles the Cleavers.
As market research shows that single men and women, single-parent families and gay and lesbian couples are as eager to buy houses as are more traditional families, farsighted builders are testing the waters with alternatives to condominiums.
Town and Country Homes, a leading developer in Oak Brook, Ill., has embraced the small-house ideal for subdivisions in the Chicago and Minneapolis areas. Town and Country's two-story houses of the Saturn series are expected to cost between $120,000 (1,180 square feet) and $145,000 (1,630 square feet), said the company's president, William J. Ryan Jr.
Each has details that recall the golden age of the Craftsman-style bungalow, circa 1915: a wood pergola connects one model to a garage, while another features tapering columns that support a shaded front porch. All have picket fences.
Similarly neo-traditional touches are ornamenting housing developments across the country. Greystone Homes' Windsor subdivision in Pleasanton, Calif., has peaked rooflines and multipaned windows. For a project in St. Albans, Vt., Turner Brooks has designed a neighborhood of 900- and 1,000-square-foot two-story houses in a corn-fed country vernacular, replete with welcoming porches and clapboard siding. The projected cost? Less than $45 a square foot.
Design magazines, once the domain of the grand and glorious, are slowly following suit. The August issue of House Beautiful, for example, is devoted to the joys of small spaces.
"Good living is not related to an excess of square footage," said the magazine's editor in chief, Louis Oliver Gropp, who points out that the challenge is for architects to make small spaces interesting and for potential homebuyers to understand that less space doesn't necessarily mean cramped space.
For Andre Sala, a toy designer and father of three who lives in Albany, Calif., the architect Christopher Alexander designed a three-story, $103,000 tinted concrete house with ingenuities that not only save space but are what Mr. Sala calls "spiritual enrichments."
Making the house vertical rather than horizontal, for example, masked its small size, 1,080 square feet. "If you don't have a lot of actual floor area, then stack it," said Mr. Alexander, whose user-friendly architectural theories are put forth in "A Pattern Language" (Oxford University Press, 1977). "The psychological distance becomes great, adding privacy, intimacy and separation."
Upstairs, the Sala children share a 9-by-14 1/2-foot room, their beds built into the thick walls, thereby freeing floor space for play and study. Downstairs is the family's alcove sitting area, its low ceiling, built-in seats and overhead bookshelves providing the cozy atmosphere of the captain's quarters on a galleon.
When trying to build an affordable house, alternatives count. Richard Mogas, an architect in San Antonio, sheathed an 1,800-square-foot ranch house in board and batten siding, more often found in farm structures than in custom housing. The barn-red porch is just a slab of concrete.
Ted Flato, a founder of Lake/Flato Architects in San Antonio, designed a 30-foot square, four-bedroom house using corrugated sheet metal for the roof and painted plywood for the bedroom floors. The 1,000-square-foot house is built around an 18-by-18-foot octagonal great room that serves, Mr. Flato said, "as entry hall, screened pavilion and living-dining-kitchen space." Its ceiling soars to a skylight 25 feet above the stained concrete floor, and when opened wide, the room's glass-and-pine double doors (each 5 feet wide and 12 feet tall) give the house the personality of a gazebo. This spatial attraction more than makes up for the minuscule bedrooms, all big enough for a double bed and little more.
But for some people, small is more than enough. "All you need is a place to sleep, a place to eat, a place to work and a place to read," said Mr. Picker, who thinks his 1,100 square feet are perfect. "How big can that possibly be?"

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH Matilda Raffa Cuomo;
Working to Renew the Lease

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 20

 BODY:
Matilda Raffa Cuomo surveyed the parade of anniversary cards atop a mantelpiece in New York's Executive Mansion and feigned disbelief at the durability of her marriage. "Forty years," she said. "One man."
The last 12 of her 40 years with Mario M. Cuomo have been spent on Eagle Street in the 40-room mansion that the state has lent its governors since 1877. It is easy to understand why the Cuomos might want to avoid eviction. 
 The elegant three-story house in the Queen Anne style, with a distinctive wraparound porch, has been lovingly restored during the Cuomo years. It is currently their only residence, although they use Mr. Cuomo's mother's house in Hollis, Queens, as a voting address and are looking for a home of their own in Queens.
Three men who went on to become President lived in the mansion, as did two vice presidents, four unsuccessful Presidential candidates and one Chief Justice. Mr. Cuomo has chosen not to extend that legacy. But he is seeking to make history of a different kind this year by running for a fourth consecutive four-year term. If he is successful and if he completes the term, the Cuomos will become the mansion's most enduring residents.
Mrs. Cuomo has used her time in Albany to become an energetic ambassador for the state, traveling to more than a dozen countries on trade missions and taking advantage of countless appearances to promote programs for children and families. As a spokeswoman, she is warm and effervescent, refreshingly uninhibited, impeccably dressed and seemingly ageless.
Her secret? Regular walks around Lincoln Park in Albany and "Buns of Steel" workout videos, produced by her son-in-law Howard S. Maier. "They're very good, by the way," she said. "The No. 3 is fantastic."
Despite their common history, Mario and Matilda Cuomo often seem remarkably different. If the Governor's mind functions like an appellate brief, manufacturing logic even where there may be none, Mrs. Cuomo's moves like a skimming stone, capable of veering in new directions each time it touches water.
The Governor listens to her, he said, because she is intelligent, but he declined to identify specific policies that she has influenced. She unquestionably has the ear of her own small state-salaried staff, as well as the Governor's commissioners and aides. "I can call them whenever I want, and they're at my disposal," she said.
Some hear from her more than they want and roll their eyes when she calls. But none question her commitment to preserving families. "She eats it, works it, breathes it," one Cuomo aide said. "And she's very impatient that she can't improve things immediately."
Mario and Matilda Cuomo met in the cafeteria at St. John's in Queens, where they both attended college. They shared a first date at Larry's Bar and Grill, where the cash-poor Mr. Cuomo put the bill for their chopped steaks on his tab. She wore his college ring on a chain and waited for him while he played minor-league baseball in Georgia, walking to the post office each day to pick up his letters. When she didn't hear from him for two weeks, she told herself: "That's it. He's dead. I never want to see that guy again."
All was forgiven when she found out he had been beaned, an injury that ended his baseball career and led him to seek another one. After all, her mother, a Sicilian who had prophesied the baseball injury after dreaming about it, had always liked him. "I kept saying, 'Why do you like him so much?' " Mrs. Cuomo recalled. "And she said, 'Well, he's serious, and he won't hurt you.' How would she say it? 'He's sincero.' That's it -- sincere. My God, if she said that once . . ."
She became pregnant with Margaret, the first of their five children, on their honeymoon in Puerto Rico, or close to it ("She's 39, and I'm married for 40 years, so you figure it out," said Mrs. Cuomo, who, like her husband, is now 62.)
When he displayed early symptoms of workaholism as a young lawyer, she raised the family. And when he detoured into politics, she went along for the ride, although she has never been happy about the loss of potential earnings. "I mean, he made senior partner," she said. "He was going to make loads of money."
During her tenure in Albany, Mrs. Cuomo has served as chairwoman of the Governor's Decade of the Child program. She has been responsible for creating computer data bases to coordinate state programs for children, developing a public-school curriculum on nutrition and distributing booklets on parenthood in hospital maternity wards. She often speaks on issues related to breast cancer.
But her signal achievement is the state's Mentoring Program, which has paired 3,200 adult volunteers, Mrs. Cuomo among them, with schoolchildren in need of academic and social support.
The program, said Mrs. Cuomo, a former elementary-school teacher, is not just for the poor. "I know when I was raising my kids, there's such a rebellious point there when they're preadolescent," she continued. "The hormones seem to be running amok. They get the pimples. They don't like the way they look. And that's the reason for all that punk and all that stuff. Look, you go crazy. You look at them and say, 'Is this my kid?' "
Mrs. Cuomo's other obsession has been renovating the Executive Mansion, which she has opened to the public for Thursday afternoon tours and for civic group luncheons. "The way it was was not proper for people to come here from other countries visiting the Executive Mansion of this great state," she said of the house, which dates from 1856. "I said, 'My God, it's going to be not only a bad reflection on us personally but on the state, the people.' " An upstairs bathroom was "so cruddy you cannot believe it," she continued, adding: "It had all the little gray institutional tile. It was so awful, disgusting."
Downstairs, there were "drapes that looked like, at best, you'd put them in your den, you know what I'm saying?" she said. "They were a beige, like a linen look, and straight across and with a salmon and a brown," she continued. "It was not for this type of a home and this period. It was an eyesore. It really was."
After raising $2 million in private gifts and commanding a team of interior designers, Mrs. Cuomo believes the mansion is now as it should be. She is diligent enough about preserving the restoration that she covers the hand-loomed seat cushions with plastic when her four young grandchildren, all girls, sit at the dinner table.
And yet, despite her obvious pride in rehabilitating the mansion, Mrs. Cuomo exhibits a certain sensitivity about the place these days.
Given the electorate's impatience with incumbents, it might be impolitic to seem too much at home, even if the Cuomos have spent a fifth of their lives there. Furthermore, the mansion, with its 11-member staff and its $445,000 budget (down from $772,000 four years ago), does not exactly fit the "son of a ditch digger, born above the grocery store" image that Mr. Cuomo has nurtured throughout his political life. When the Cuomos' elder son, Andrew, really wants to needle his younger brother, Christopher, hecalls him "Mansion Boy," because Christopher spent his formative years in the big house with servants.
"It's never really been our home," Mrs. Cuomo said. "It's a public place. That's the way it is, and that's the way it's meant to be. It's a lodging. It's a place to come to be at night, to eat together."
Mrs. Cuomo was at first reluctant even to be interviewed at the mansion, lest it be thought that she has spent the last 12 years as a homemaker, the occupation she lists on the Cuomos' tax returns. Once she relented, she emphasized that her family rarely uses the ornate formal rooms, with their luxurious wallpaper and Hudson River School landscapes. And she said that she travels so much that she usually spends only two or three nights a week in Albany.
When not in Albany, she frequently stays with one of her daughters: on Long Island with Dr. Margaret Cuomo Maier, 39, a radiologist, or in Westchester with Maria Cuomo Cole, 32, the chairwoman of the nonprofit Help for the Homeless. Mrs. Cuomo's other children are Andrew, 36, an Assistant Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development; Madeline Cuomo O'Donoghue, 29, a lawyer and Cuomo campaign official, and Christopher, 23, a student at Fordham Law School.
The Cuomos have kept their personal lives remarkably private for a family that has lived so long in the spotlight, largely by using the mansion as a cloister.
Governor and Mrs. Cuomo do not dine out in Albany (their last outing was to a Japanese restaurant for their 39th anniversary in June 1993) or use the mansion for state dinners. They rarely go to movies, plays or sporting events. Their time together is spent at the mansion, where the Governor reads, watches television or videos ("Gunga Din" is a personal favorite) and writes at his roll-top desk in a small study equipped with a fax machine and three telephones.
"I'm not going to kid you," Mrs. Cuomo said. "He is constantly on the phone."
When he is at home with his family, Mr. Cuomo is not always the Jesuitical combatant he may seem at the Capitol, Mrs. Cuomo said.
"He is really fun," she said. "I'm not kidding. It means nothing to him to put on, you know, the hat he wears with the brim. And he puts it way over his ears." Then, Mrs. Cuomo said, her husband sticks his tongue out and makes her laugh. "I said, 'Don't do that,' because it used to scare the kids."
As she girds herself for what may be their roughest campaign, Mrs. Cuomo says she is prepared to defend her husband against all manner of Republican brickbats.
Mr. Cuomo, she argued, has not received his due from a negativist press, particularly given the difficulty of leading such a diverse and populous state through a long recession.
"My God, if you didn't have this kind of Governor, if you didn't have this kind of perspective, if you didn't have this kind of focus and commitment long term, what would it have been like?" she said. "We'd have rebellions worse than L.A. We would have people killing each other."
After so many years in power, she finds the notion of leaving right now unthinkable. To trade what she describes as "the productivity" of the Cuomo administration for a new agenda would be "such a waste."
And of course, there is the issue of the Decade of the Child, which Mr. Cuomo announced in 1988. "We have four more years to go," she said. "It's a decade, right? I mean, that's the whole point. You know, give us a break."

HEADLINE: Reinvestment Law Aids Poor Areas

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A July 11 news article offers two explanations for growing interest by banks to lend in New York's poorer areas: banks are stronger, and city and neighborhood development groups have helped rejuvenate many areas over the last decade.
I believe there is a third factor: renewed emphasis on the Community Reinvestment Act and the obligations it places on lending institutions to reinvest in neighborhoods from which they take deposits. The law, passed in 1977, has been criticized by neighborhood development groups because of the soft approach the bank regulatory agencies have taken to enforcement. 
 One of the Clinton Administration's early endeavors was to order the regulatory agencies to review the act and to hold public hearings. New regulations have been drafted and will soon be promulgated. These will make direct lending a top priority.
With stronger regulations and stricter enforcement, poor neighborhoods, like better-off ones, will be assured of the availability of credit essential to keeping neighborhoods alive.
 
GEORGE C. SCHMITZ
Executive Director
Leviticus 25:23 Alternative Fund
Yonkers, July 15, 1994

HEADLINE: Numbers Game on Health

 BODY:
President Clinton says he thought his remarks sounded innocent enough. Speaking to the nation's governors on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton said he would be satisfied if health-care reform managed to insure "somewhere in the ball park of 95 percent" of Americans and that he would not insist that Congress impose an employer mandate. Neither remark deviated one iota from Administration policy.
But that did not stop a torrent of speculation that the President was retreating on universal coverage and was backtracking from mandates. Yesterday a rattled White House disclaimed any such signals. And the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, visited Capitol Hill to reassure Democratic leaders that the President was not wavering. By the end of the day, the Hill was supposed to believe Mr. Clinton was singing the same old tunes -- for now. 
 Judging from reactions, it would seem a grave matter of statecraft whether President Clinton sets sail for 95 percent coverage or 93 or 98. But to fixate on the numbers is to miss the important structural questions in the debate.
Universal coverage is, foremost, a statement about public values: the richest country ought not to terrorize parents with the fear of bankruptcy because their child becomes chronically ill. But for those who need a harder-edged reason, universal coverage is also necessary to make health-care markets work. If the rules allow healthy individuals to opt out of insurance, many will do so -- at least until they become sick. Then insurance companies would find they are mostly catering to the chronically ill, whom they will have to charge prohibitively high premiums. The answer is to require healthy individuals to enroll when they are well and pay premiums to help cover the cost of care when they become ill. In a phrase, universal coverage.
Does that mean every living American must be covered to the point of statistical perfection? Not really. Indeed, the President's bill would not achieve 100 percent coverage; nor do the Europeans or Hawaii -- which has a mandate on employers to buy their workers coverage. What is needed is a bill that, as a practical matter, brings coverage to the rich and poor, sick and healthy, young and old, employed and unemployed, in the same way that Social Security, as a practical matter, provides retirement benefits for all Americans and requires contributions from every worker. If the medical insurance rules, like those of Social Security, allow odd exceptions -- whether they add up to 2, 3 or even 5 percent of the population -- this amounts to no moral or medical catastrophe.
Mr. Clinton's loose lips did not help negotiations. His words encourage recalcitrants on Capitol Hill to spend time figuring out how to get the President, and his Democratic supporters, to retreat -- rather than accepting the goal of universal coverage and figuring out what else the bill can have to win bipartisan support.

HEADLINE: Destructive Entitlement Caps

 BODY:
The House votes today on a defective proposal by Representative Charles Stenholm of Texas to place a cap on overall entitlement spending -- programs like Medicare, food stamps and Social Security. Mr. Stenholm's bill would limit annual increases to an amount that would offset inflation and increases in the number of eligible recipients. That may seem reasonable, but it fails to account for many other reasons spending rises -- such as health-care prices that drive up the cost of Medicaid faster than inflation, or import surges that drive up the cost of agriculture subsidies.
A Congressional committee estimates that the Stenholm cap would require cutting entitlements by a whopping $150 billion over five years. Under the bill, Congress could close the gap by cutting entitlement programs or raising the cap. If it did neither, programs would be cut across the board. 
 The cap, contrary to Mr. Stenholm's representations, would victimize health-care reform. To make $150 billion in cuts, Congress would be forced to go after the only two programs that are huge and growing: Medicaid and Medicare. But Congress already plans to cut these programs to pay for health-care reform. The cuts cannot do double duty.
The cap would also victimize the poor. Mr. Stenholm would allow Congress to cut spending, but not raise taxes to meet his cap. That preserves "entitlements" doled out through the tax system -- like unlimited tax deductions for medical insurance provided to high-paid employees. But it leaves welfare and other poor people's programs at risk.
The House will also vote today on a bill by John Kasich of Ohio to control entitlements by having Congress set an overall limit and limits on individual programs each year. If the limits are breached, individual programs would be cut back. Mr. Kasich's bill would also punish the poor. He, too, would not allow Congress to meet entitlement limits by raising taxes; to make matters worse, he would exempt Social Security from cutbacks -- thereby directing cuts to programs targeted on the needy.
The only acceptable bill the House will consider is by John Spratt of South Carolina. Mr. Spratt would require the President to propose a solution to Congress if total entitlement spending were to rise above target; Congress would then have to vote on the President's proposal -- which could be to do nothing. The Spratt bill would force Congress to face up to the problem. But unlike the other plans, it would allow Congress a full menu of responses -- including tax hikes and cuts in discretionary spending. Mr. Spratt does not believe Congress should single out the needy.

HEADLINE: Now Put Africa on Foreign Policy Agenda

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Last month's White House Conference on Africa was a good first step in raising the profile of the continent among policy makers.
The United States has been a leader both in providing humanitarian relief to Africa and in designing effective population programs. Moreover, our diplomacy has been very effective in several countries; in South Africa, for example, steadfast United States support for the transition to nonracial democracy played an important role in that country's astounding success. 
 While we have made progress, Africa needs and deserves more attention from the Clinton Administration. I believe we must take action in three critical areas.
First, we must increase the level of our development aid to Africa, which is stuck at $800 million. Africa contains 18 of the world's 20 poorest countries, and 30 of the poorest 40.
In last year's House foreign aid authorization bill, we authorized $900 million for Africa; unfortunately, this sum was later reduced. The Administration should demonstrate its commitment to Africa by requesting a higher level of assistance in the next foreign aid budget.
Second, the United States should develop a comprehensive approach to conflict prevention and resolution in Africa. As anyone who reads the daily paper knows, wars dominate Africa's political landscape. Not only do these wars cause tremendous suffering, but they also severely retard the growth of sub-Saharan Africa's economy.
Members of the Africa subcommittee recently introduced legislation to help the United States more effectively address the scourge of war in Africa. This bill helps build indigenous African capacity in conflict resolution and provides critical assistance in demobilizing oversized African armies.
Third, Africa should be engaged at a higher level within the United States Government.
To implement an upgrading of Africa in United States foreign policy, the Clinton Administration should schedule a Presidential visit to Africa, encourage officials above the level of assistant secretary to become more actively engaged in Africa policy and undertake higher level and higher profile diplomatic engagement in African conflicts and problems.
 
(Rep.) HARRY JOHNSTON
Washington, July 14, 1994
 
The writer, who represents Florida's 19th Congressional District, is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa.
