HEADLINE: THE RWANDA DISASTER: RELIEF;
AID FOR RWANDANS STARTS TO ARRIVE AT REFUGE IN ZAIRE

BYLINE: By JO THOMAS 

 BODY:
The first significant deliveries of food and medicine to treat cholera arrived yesterday in Goma, Zaire, as foreign governments and relief agencies worked to organize help for up to four million Rwandan refugees as they continued to flee at the rate of 2,000 an hour.
In Goma, where more than a million refugees have gathered, the camps were filled with hundreds of bodies. Doctors Without Borders, a medical relief agency, has set up tents to begin treating thousands stricken with cholera. The group predicted as many as 50,000 cases, half of whom could die. 
 The first convoy of trucks carrying food shipments arrived from Uganda yesterday, and some flights carrying medicine landed at the Goma airstrip.
President Clinton said the United States planned to "try to lead the United Nations in responding to the cholera problem and dealing with the other aspects of this human catastrophe." This would include $35 million in United States aid, added to $41.4 million approved several days ago, and bringing the total to more than $120 million.
Many details of the relief plan are still being worked out by military planners and diplomats in the United States, Europe and Africa. Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch met with the Joint Chiefs of Staff yesterday to discuss how the military would carry out its part of the plan.
"We are literally in a race against time to save lives," warned the American Red Cross President, Elizabeth Dole. "It's a race we simply cannot lose, or it will be a tragedy of unimaginable proportions."
With estimates of Rwandans who have fled their homes now reaching four million, nearly half the population has been killed or displaced because of the civil war.
In a briefing yesterday afternoon, Brian Atwood of the United States Agency for International Development, who had just returned from Zaire, said he expected the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, to appeal today for $274 million to help the growing number of refugees.
Mr. Atwood said the United States would send 33,000 tons of grain and an immediate shipment of water supplies and 20 million packets of oral rehydration kits to treat cholera and diarrhea.
The Defense Department is also prepared to set up an air installation in Entebbe, Uganda, to ship food, medicine and equipment to the entire area. According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Germany and Britain have also offered planes for the airlift.
Francoise Derron, spokeswoman for the International Committee of the Red Cross in New York, said the airstrip in Goma "cannot accommodate more than 20 planes a day." Reporters in Goma said up to 30 planes landed yesterday, although the air traffic was causing damage to the runway.
"The difficulty is that you have planes arriving, and you have to unload the planes and load trucks," she said. "All that takes time."
Marie Okabe, senior liaison officer for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said in New York yesterday that 10 flights had arrived in Goma by midday. But she said that the impression in New York was "that very little aid is reaching the refugees in spite of the agencies' best efforts."
The United Nations has said the refugees need nearly 8 million gallons of water a day, and it has asked governments to send 50 water trucks, 300 additional trucks and 100 light vehicles to move supplies.
Water can be pumped from Lake Kivu, but until systems can be set up to do that, adequate supplies of clean water are crucial, relief workers said. Water and oral rehydration are essential to the treatment of cholera.
 
Water Difficult to Reach
 According to CARE, one of the relief agencies on the scene, ground water is difficult to reach because it is covered with volcanic rock, which also makes it difficult to dig latrines. The United Nations has asked for aid to build 60,000 latrines.
In Goma, workers using megaphones have urged refugees to go to four camps -- Katale, Kibumba, Mugunga and Lac Vent -- north of the town. Food distribution began Wednesday in Kibumba and Katale, where a dispensary was also set up. Kibumba, 18 miles north of Goma on the road to Katale, has about 300,000 people.
The first of 20 trucks from the World Food Program arrived in Goma yesterday, each carrying 30 tons of corn, cornmeal and beans from Kampala, Uganda. Thirty more trucks were loading in Nairobi, Kenya. Half will go to Goma and the rest to Bukavu, on the southern end of Lake Kivu. Twenty more trucks are on their way to Nairobi from the organization's fleet in Eritrea and Ethiopia.
"In this situation, you have to use trucks," said Douglas Coutts, deputy director of the North America office of the World Food Program of the United Nations. "The airlift is so expensive and difficult."
 
Problems at Airport
 The runway at the airport in Goma, Mr. Atwood of the Agency for International Development said yesterday, can handle large planes. "The problem is the apron area and the cargo-lift capacity," he said. "We badly need to turn planes around there very quickly."
Kathleen deLaski, the Pentagon spokeswoman, said, "The biggest problem in Goma right now is that there's one airfield which is already saturated, so in order to bring in more equipment or more people, we have to either build another ramp at Goma or identify some other airfields."
It is not clear how many United States troops may be involved in the relief operation, but Mr. Atwood quoted an estimate by Mr. Deutch, the Deputy Defense Secretary, that it could be as many as 1,000.
Mr. Atwood said he expected that 1,500 tons of food would reach the Red Cross in Goma by today, along with 120 tons of blankets, 135 tons of plastic sheeting and 4 temporary warehouses. These would be sent on eight Boeing-707 aircraft.
 
Hutus Still Fearful
 Mr. Atwood said the United States was also trying to work with the newly formed Government in Rwanda. But the Hutu fear of the Tutsi-dominated Rwanda Patriotic Front, which won the country's civil war, has contributed to the continuing flow of refugees.
"We know that this situation will not be handled until conditions are such that refugees will return to their country," he said. "We are going to be prepositioning food distribution centers in Rwanda to encourage people to stay and to encourage people to return."
Mr. Coutts, of the World Food Program, said the turn of events in Rwanda had caught the relief organizations by surprise.
"We thought we could address the needs of the population within the country once there was a settlement," he said. "Who would have predicted that the opposition to the Rwanda Patriotic Front would have continued with these hate broadcasts, telling people, 'They're going to kill you.' This is our worst nightmare."
Mr. Atwood said yesterday that he had discussed "the problem of the clandestine radio that is urging Hutus to leave, and within a matter of hours I hope we will have equipment on the ground to deal with that problem."
"We will in the next few days have our own radio facilities -- meaning the international community, the United Nations -- in order to send more positive messages to the people of Rwanda," he said.
He said he had been assured that the French would be able to detect or jam the clandestine radio.
"We believe the French can handle this," he said. "Nonetheless, we're watching this very closely because this radio station is not only inciting people to leave the country, it's also putting out a lot of anti-U.N. rhetoric in recent days, and after the closing of the Embassy of Rwanda here in Washington, there was even a lot of anti-American rhetoric."
 
Hopes for New Government
 The United States, Mr. Atwood said, was hoping for cooperation from the new Government. "We're going to need them not only to be sending the right signals rhetorically to people on the outside," he said. "We're also going to need to see them taking actions to show their good will."
The Rwandan Government, he said, must set up a legal system that meets internationally recognized judicial standards and must show that it intends to deal with war criminals through that system.
"They have agreed already to do that, but even all that is not enough," he said.
"We will also require an effective Unamir force that makes all of Rwanda a safe zone," he added, referring to the United Nations Assistance Mission in Rwanda.
 
U.S. Said to Move Too Slowly
 Lionel Rosenblatt, president of Refugees International, said the Clinton Administration was not moving quickly enough.
"More Rwandans are dying than in any other population in the world," Mr. Rosenblatt said. "The trick is to turn it around in a matter of days and not to have it soar over a matter of weeks.
"We've had eight days now, and we basically wasted those eight days. We need the water and the airlift in the next two weeks, or we'll have tens of thousands dead. This has to be done in the next few days. It's got to be a Berlin airlift kind of response."
Mr. Atwood said: "I think the announcements that I've made today incidate that we're moving aggressively and immediately. The international community has never seen anything quite like this."

HEADLINE: Pirelli's Savior Faces New Headwind

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy

 BODY:
It took near disaster at Pirelli S.p.A., Italy's giant rubber company, to bring Marco Tronchetti Provera to the helm. Rapid expansion in Europe and the United States in the 1980's had spawned a mountain of debt, and by 1992, when Mr. Tronchetti took over as chief executive in the midst of recession, the company's anchor businesses of automobile tires and electrical cables were floundering.
The success of Mr. Tronchetti, who is 46, in refloating Pirelli made him just about the most-talked-about man in Italian business, raised the company's sagging share price, and last year landed him on the cover of Fortune magazine's international edition as one of Europe's tough new generation of managers. 
 This year, the question is whether the tall, lean and energetic Mr. Tronchetti is tough enough to face down what may be a stiffer challenge -- keeping Pirelli from sinking in the new storms swirling in Italian politics.
The storms threaten to swamp his strategic plan for the future of the company's electric cable division, on which many analysts think the future of the company as a whole rests. And they have come at time when drastic retrenchment and a strike at the company's tire division in the United States, the Pirelli Armstrong Tire Corporation, are highlighting the survival risks confronting all in the tire-making industry except the giants, like the Michelin Tire Corporation, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Bridgestone Corporation.
For all of this, investors remain bullish about Pirelli. By the end of the second week in July, when Pirelli closed at 2,725 lire ($1.77) the stock had shown a 9 percent increase since the start of July. Since, the stock, like all stocks traded in Milan, has been buffeted by the near collapse of the Government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.
Pirelli is the world's third-largest maker of optical fiber cables, and Mr. Tronchetti's strategic plan is this: He badly wants to acquire a sizable stake in Telecom Italia, a company still on the Government's drawing board as part of its work to privatize the state-controlled telecommunications industry. The acquisition, he says, would assure the nation a major telecommunications company with the scale to compete when Europe's telecommunications monopolies break up. It would also preserve a base for Pirelli's cable manufacturing.
"I think it important there be movement on both wings of the business," said Luca Comi, a share analyst at Milan's Intereuropa brokerage. "But Telecom is very important, also at a psychological level. Optical fibers is where the company is lagging, and it would provide Pirelli with a privileged access channel."
Italian politicians take a different view. With Telecom being taken public this fall, Mr. Tronchetti is under assault by two key groups.
 
Facing Multiple Roadblocks

 
 One group is the state industries' professional managers, worried about their jobs if an aggressive industrial shareholder of the likes of Pirelli with clear business goals assumes a major share.
The other group is made up of small businesses central to the uneasy coalition that keeps the right-wing government of Mr. Berlusconi, himself a tycoon turned politician, in power; the small businesses have long feared the weight of large industrial concerns.
In Rome, legislators are accusing Mr. Tronchetti of trying to transform what had been a public monopoly into a private one, and have vowed to block any attempt by Pirelli to obtain a controlling share of Telecom.
Mr. Tronchetti rejects all such charges. "Whoever accuses us is speaking in bad faith," he said, stiffening his back during an interview at Pirelli's headquarters here.
"Liberalization will cause two phenomena: first will be a lowering of rates, and second, a reduction of everyone's market share," he continued. "We've got to seize the opportunity, or Italy risks becoming marginalized, forced to cede development to third parties."
 
A Leader Who Seizes the Moment

 
 If history is any guide, Mr. Tronchetti is a master at seizing opportunity. A graduate of the management school of Milan's Bocconi university, Mr. Tronchetti got his start in the Tronchettis' $320-million-a-year family business, Camfin S.p.A., , trading raw materials and petroleum products. After a spell in London as a trainee with a marine transport company, he returned to Italy to set up a shipping agency, and at age 28 married Leopoldo Pirelli's daughter (they have since separated).
He succeeded Mr. Pirelli, grandson of Giovanni Battista Pirelli, who founded the company in 1883, as chief executive of the company at time when its shareholders were badly shaken by debt resulting from a failed attempt to buy Germany's big Continental rubber company in 1991. His first goal was to return the company to its industrial roots. He jettisoned about 40 subsidiaries making everything from sneakers to conveyor belts. Shedding the philosophy of bigness, he dismissed 170 executives, nearly one-quarter of management.
He dramatized his hands-on approach by moving the company headquarters from fashionable Piazzale Cadorna in downtown Milan to austere quarters on Pirelli's original factory grounds north of the city.
And he has been advertising the company's new look with a provocative campaign that recently plastered much of Europe with billboards featuring the American sprinter Carl Lewis bent over in a starting position, sporting bright red women's high heels. The ad's message promotes the sure grip of Pirelli tires: "Power is nothing without control."
This year, the company expects to turn a modest profit, after losses of $27 million in 1993, on global sales of $5.7 billion. (In telecommunications, for example, Pirelli is a major supplier of cables to American telephone and power companies. It also sells sophisticated components like optical amplifiers, which strengthen signals in glass fiber cables, to long-distance carriers like the MCI Communications Corporation.)
Net debt, which stood at $2 billion in 1991, has been almost halved to $1.1 billion. The company is leaner than it has been in a long while, employing 43,000 people, 8,500 fewer than in 1991.
 
U.S. Operations Displeasing

 
 Mr. Tronchetti has not been pleased with operations in the United States, where roughly 16 percent of Pirelli's total sales has been generated through sales of Armstrong replacement tires at big retail outlets like Sears, Roebuck & Company. For the last two years, Pirelli Armstrong has been restructuring, to focus on car and light-truck tires and on productivity gains. In the second week of July, Pirelli Armstrong announced the company intended to phase out health care benefits for 3,000 retirees. And since, the New Haven-based subsidiary announced it had reached an agreement to sell its Des Moines factory, which makes tires for farm vehicles, to Titan Wheel International Inc. of Quincy, Ill.
The Des Moines factory is one of three Pirelli plants -- the others are in Nashville and in Hanford, Calif. -- struck by 1,700 members of the United Rubber Workers July 15. The union says Armstrong's health and pension offers are unacceptable. Paul Calvi, chief executive of Pirelli Armstrong, says "the financial viability of Pirelli Armstrong is being threatened by health costs."
Mr. Tronchetti declined to comment. What is going on with Armstrong, said Giancarlo Rocco di Torrepadula, a Pirelli spokesman, is a local problem being dealt with by local management.
According to Stephen Reitman, an auto industry analyst at UBS-Philips & Drew in London, Pirelli Armstrong's problems provide one more piece of evidence for the strains in the the world tire market, where recovery awaits a revival of Europe's sluggish automobile market.
"Maybe the shakeout is just taking longer than expected," he says. "Maybe it's the smaller manufacturers, the Continentals, the Pirellis, the Dunlops, that are going to go."
 
One Possible Key to Survival

 
 Such an analysis highlights the importance of Pirelli's telecommunications division -- and of a stake in Telecom -- to the company's future. To foil any single investor taking control, Rome has been insisting on limiting share purchases to about 3 percent of equity. One way to skirt such restrictions is to get a group of allied companies to snap up 3 percent packages, and then act in concert as a shareholder group.
In any event, Mr. Tronchetti is not saying what strategy Pirelli will use until he sees which way the present government plans to go. In the meantime, he takes every opportunity to hammer away at what he sees as Italy's need to shed a mentality based on government ownership.
"Our problem remains learning to understand the state as a regulator, not as owner and operator," he said.
Mr. Tronchetti is a passionate yachtsman and owns a Finnish-built boat named Kauris, Finnish for Capricorn, his zodiac sign. His abiding interest in the sea is reflected in the antique maps of Italy and its surrounding waters that adorn his office walls.
And does he see a connection between boating and business? "I enjoy being at the helm," he replied.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: SPECIAL INTERESTS;
Health Care Bills Bring Benefits For Some Specific Constituents

SERIES: The Fine Print: A periodic look behind the law.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
A hospital in Representative Dan Rostenkowski's neighborhood in Chicago is getting Federal aid for a $580 million construction project. Representative Charles B. Rangel has secured similar assistance for a hospital on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. And Representative Barbara B. Kennelly of Connecticut has obtained special dispensation for the Hartford Life Insurance Companies.
Those are a few of the little-noticed provisions tucked into health care legislation for the benefit of specific hospitals, drug companies and insurance companies. 
 The highly contentious health care bills moving through Congress are chock-full of such narrowly focused provisions, and they illustrate how shrewd lobbyists or sympathetic members of Congress on strategically important committees try to write law for clients and constituents.
Michael D. Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, a trade group for 1,400 hospitals, said the manipulation of Federal largess would become more common if the Government gained control over a larger share of the nation's health spending.
"Once you give Congress the power to play with a trillion dollars a year, it will be tempted to shift money around in pork-barrel fashion," he said.
And there may be unforeseen consequences. "If you do a special deal for Hospital A," said Mr. Bromberg, "Hospital B across the street will be hurt."
The health care bill is far from the first piece of legislation to include such benefits. Similar provisions for specific recipients are found in many tax bills and appropriations bills.
Such provisions are customarily written to help specific groups without mentioning them by name. The health bill approved by the House Ways and Means Committee, for instance, provides Federal interest subsidies to reduce the cost of financing major construction projects planned by teaching hospitals.
This provision, sought by Mr. Rostenkowski, would make Federal aid available only for construction projects that cost $500 million or more, were approved before June 1, 1994, and will be finished by Dec. 31, 2002. In practice, it benefits only a small number of hospitals.
Although Mr. Rostenkowski was forced to step down as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee after he was indicted on Federal corruption charges in May, he can still do favors for constituents.
One institution that would qualify for the interest rate subsidies is Northwestern Memorial Hospital in downtown Chicago, which has a $580 million project to replace most of its existing beds. Joseph K. Dowley, a Washington lobbyist who was chief counsel of the Ways and Means Committee from 1985 to 1987, helped Northwestern land this prize.
Another beneficiary of the same provision is New York Hospital, on the Upper East Side, which has an $820 million project. New York Hospital got assistance from Mr. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat who serves on the Ways and Means Committee, and from William A. Signer, a lobbyist who used to work for Mr. Rangel.
Aides to Mr. Rangel said the assistance to a few major teaching hospitals was justified as a way to help them through the financial uncertainties of a transition to a new health care system. The hospitals serve large number of poor people and need to replace buildings constructed more than 50 years ago, they said.
Here are other provisions that address the concerns of specific constituents:
HARTFORD INSURANCE All the major health care bills would establish Federal standards for private health insurance. Insurers could not cancel or deny coverage for a person who became sick or had an illness or disability, and they would have to offer a standard package of health benefits to all applicants.
In general, the bill says, "a carrier may not refuse to enroll, refuse to renew the enrollment of, or terminate the enrollment of, an individual or employer in an insured health benefit plan." But there is an exception for companies leaving the health insurance business "pursuant to a joint marketing agreement entered into prior to Jan. 1, 1994."
That obscurely worded provision applies to only one case: Hartford Life Insurance Companies, subsidiaries of the ITT Corporation, is leaving the health insurance market and transferring most of its group-medical business to the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company of Springfield, Mass., which uses the trademark MassMutual.
John E. Shelk, Federal affairs counsel for the ITT Hartford Insurance Group, a unit of the ITT Corporation, said he had secured this provision after laying out his concerns to Mrs. Kennelly, a Democrat from Hartford who is a member of the Ways and Means Committee.
"We are fortunate that our Congresswoman is on the committee," said Mr. Shelk. "She did a good job and helped us get a technical clarifying amendment.
"The purpose of the bill is to prevent companies from jumping out of the health insurance market on the date of enactment," he continued. "But we made a business decision in the late summer of 1993 not to continue in the traditional group health insurance market. We negotiated a joint marketing agreement with MassMutual. The new rules should not apply retroactively to a transaction that was already negotiated."
INSULIN The Ways and Means Committee bill, like President Clinton's health plan, would expand Medicare to cover prescription drugs given to elderly patients outside hospitals. The Government seeks to use its buying power to obtain a discount on drug prices. It insists that drug manufacturers pay a rebate to the Government for every prescription dispensed to a Medicare beneficiary.
These rebates are modeled on those already required under Medicaid, the program for low-income people. In Medicaid, the rebates are larger for prescription drugs and insulin than for over-the-counter medications and generic drugs, which are low-cost copies of brand-name products whose patents have expired.
In general, the new Medicare benefit would cover prescription drugs, not over-the-counter products. But it would also cover insulin, a hormone for treating diabetes, which is sold without a prescription. Under the bill, the rebate would be 15 percent for brand-name prescription drugs and 10 percent for generic drugs.
Eli Lilly and Company does not want to pay the higher rebates for its insulin products. Accordingly, the company, whose headquarters are in Indianapolis, went to Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr., an Indiana Democrat, and asked for help. Mr. Jacobs, a member of the Ways and Means Committee, offered an amendment to specify that the rebate for insulin should be only 11 percent. The committee later decided to set it at 10 percent.
Lilly contends that it should not be penalized with the higher rebate because insulin costs no more today than it did 70 years ago.
GROUP HEALTH INC. With a network of doctors and hospitals across New York State, Group Health provides coverage to more than two million people. It competes aggressively with Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. But Group Health is concerned that it may not have all the tax breaks available to Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
So it enlisted the help of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former New York Congresswoman. They persuaded the Ways and Means Committee to stipulate, as part of the health care bill, that Group Health shall be treated the same as a Blue Cross and Blue Shield organization in the future and for tax years back to 1987. The Senate Finance Committee approved a similar provision.
Group Health and the Blue Cross plans in New York all describe themselves as nonprofit corporations. Congress ended the tax exemption for such companies in 1986, after concluding that many were indistinguishable from commercial insurers. But the 1986 law authorized special tax breaks for Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans that meet certain criteria. Group Health contends that it should have received the same tax breaks.
In an interview, Frank J. Branchini, the president of Group Health, said: "We are organized in exactly the same manner as Blue Cross plans, so we should receive the same tax treatment under Federal law. This is not a special provision for a specific company. All we seek is fair, equitable treatment."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "DIARY: Health Care Developments"
 
YESTERDAY
President Clinton had the Democratic leaders over to the White House to plan their push for the health care plan, and 50 of the nation's largest corporations gave a boost to the proposal by supporting coverage paid by employers.
 
WHITE HOUSE
The Democratic leaders of the Senate and House met with President Clinton and declared that they were ready to push forward with legislation to guarantee health insurance to every American. Earlier, the Clinton Administration got the kind of support it had been seeking for some time when a coalition of major corporations argued in favor of employer-paid health insurance. The companies urged Congress to pass "comprehensive health care reform that provides for universal coverage through shared employer responsibility." The 50 corporations included Ford, Chrysler, General Motors, H. J. Heinz, Bethlehem Steel, I.B.M., Manpower Inc., Giant Food, Champion International, Time Warner and Westinghouse.
 
CONGRESS
Members of Congress have tucked into health care legislation various provisions that are intended to benefit specific hospitals, drug makers and insurance companies. In New York, for example, Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Manhattan Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, has secured millions of dollars in assistance for New York Hospital on the Upper East Side.
 
LOBBYISTS
The health care legislation probably involves the largest amount of money ever spent on lobbying and the greatest number of former Congressmen and former executive branch officials working on behalf of various organizations, according to a study by a research group. "We believe that health care reform has become the most heavily lobbied legislative initiative in United States history," said Charles Lewis, the executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, which conducted the study. (pg. A20)

HEADLINE: Upsala College Decides to Stay Open

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 21

 BODY:
Debt-burdened, its enrollment shrinking, its accreditation slated to be revoked, its faculty unpaid for a month, Upsala College will nevertheless remain open for at least another semester while the 100-year-old college looks for a way to solve its financial crisis.
The decision to stay open was one of three choices before the Board of Trustees today; the others were to close outright or to reopen in the fall without a freshman class. In a unanimous decision, the trustees chose a very difficult path. It depends on reducing enrollment further, from last year's 1,000 to 600 this fall, cutting course offerings, reducing salaries of the faculty and reassigning teachers to administrative positions, and hoping that the state will come up with money to save the school. 
 In any case, today's decision will take Upsala (pronounced UP-suh-luh) only through the end of the year -- unless the college finds a new source of money or a way to refinance its crushing debt.
 
Cheering May Be Premature
 A large group of summer students and faculty members cheered today when the Dean of the Faculty, Warren Funk, announced the decision to remain open.
"I must be very clear," he said, "that the plan that has been adopted will require a very austere budget and considerable sacrifices from all, sacrifices that we may not all want to cheer as this plan works its way out."
Already, Dr. Funk said, the college's administrative staff has been cut from 70 to 40, and 14 custodial positions have been eliminated. The annual payroll of the college is about $5 million.
Today's decision comes at the end of several years of mixed fortunes for the college, which is affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America. The college survived a drastic plunge in enrollment in the 1980's, and reached a low of 475 full-time undergraduates in 1990, less than a quarter of its peak enrollment in 1950, when Upsala was crowded with returned World War II veterans studying on the G.I. Bill.
Fearful that many students would avoid a college with an enrollment less than 1,000, Upsala undertook a vigorous campaign to increase student numbers and brought enrollment up to just over 1,000 today, a figure reached in part by increasing the minority enrollment from surrounding urban communities in northern New Jersey.
Although Upsala, founded here in 1893, was built on the style of a small rural campus, the urban sprawl of northeastern New Jersey has grown up around the college since World War II. Today, the streets off Prospect Street, which cuts through the campus, are decayed and stained with graffiti; here and there, a once-grand house stands boarded up.
As the area around Upsala crumbled, so did the attachment of the oldest, and most prosperous alumni.
 
Borrowing at High Interest
 "Our alumni are disaffected with the campus," said Frederick H. Jarvis, a retired insurance executive who is chairman of the trustees. "They remember East Orange from the days when it was the all-American city, and they don't find that here anymore."
Partly to make the college more attractive to visitors and prospective students, Upsala also borrowed about $12 million in the 1980's for long-deferred maintenance in classrooms and dormitories.
It was the debt, at high interest rates, that eventually brought the college low. Creditors were unwilling to refinance the debt, and several other campuses that were approached as possible partners for Upsala -- Dr. Funk would not say which ones, or how many -- refused to make cooperative agreements with the college until its debt problem was solved.
"We tried to get our debt restructured," Dr. Funk said, "but it seems every time we got close to success something would happen to stop us from consummating the restructuring, until our string finally ran out."
Last winter, the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools warned Upsala that its precarious finances put its accreditation in jeopardy. On June 13, the college told its faculty that it could not afford to meet its payroll after June 30, and last week, the accreditation agency formally notified Upsala that its accreditation would be revoked Dec. 31. If that happened, any credits granted by the college would not be honored by any other accredited undergraduate or graduate program.
Upsala College has been appropriated $1.1 million in annual aid from the state for the 1994-95 fiscal year under a program of support for private colleges in New Jersey. $400,000 of that amount has already been paid, with the balance due in December. The college hopes that the state will pay out the additional aid money by next week.
 
No Pay Since June 30
 "If they do not," Dean Funk said, "our contingency plan has the faculty and staff essentially going without pay for the six or seven weeks until students arrive for the fall."
In any case, the college will appeal any loss of accreditation, and would retain accreditation during the appeal, said Debbie Kotch, the director of information for the college, who like everyone else on the campus has not been paid since June 30.
"I consider myself basically a volunteer," Ms. Kotch said. "You've got to keep the faith."
While the trustees deliberated in the Agnes Wahlstrom College Center, members of the faculty liaison committee were poring over staffing lists and payrolls in an effort to produce a plan of survival.
 
One Semester at a Time
 Upsala faculty salaries, at less than $35,000 a year for a tenured full professor, are already low by regional college standards. Members of the committee said they were prepared to work for less, or work longer and harder for the same amount. Both the teachers and the administration agree that there will have to be reductions in the faculty.
"We have some options," said Lincoln Brown, a mathematics and computer sciences professor and a member of the Liason Committee. "Staying open for another semester gives us another semester to try to make something happen."
For the students, however, the prospect of losing the college is daunting. John Mack is a 32-year-old junior in theology; his undergraduate fees are being by the Lutheran Seminary of Philadelphia on a program that would send him to the seminary and eventual ordination as a Lutheran minister.
"Sure, I could always go to another Lutheran college," he said. "But I'm married, my wife works, so having to move would really put a damper on things for me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eric Harrison, a second-year student at Upsala College, waiting yesterday on the school's East Orange, N.J., campus while the board of trustees met to find a way to solve the 100-year-old institution's financial crisis. (Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Affordable Home Survey

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
Despite slightly higher mortgage rates during the first quarter, housing remained affordable in many areas of the country, particularly in the Midwest and South, a builders group said today.
"Although there are many places where affording a home is out of reach for many families, the low mortgage interest rates that we have been enjoying for nearly a year make housing more affordable everywhere," said Tommy Thompson, president of the National Association of Home Builders, which conducted the check. 
 Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.56 percent during the January-March period, up from 7.27 percent the previous three months, the association said. Mortgage rates were in the double digits during most of the 1980's.
The Housing Opportunity Index measures the ability of a typical family to purchase a home in its own market by comparing median family income with median home price. The median income nationally was $39,900 in the first quarter and the median home price was $112,000.
"Regional trends remained steady, with the most affordable markets found primarily in the Midwest and in the South, and the least affordable markets mostly in the West, particularly California, and the Northeast," the group found.
The Vineland-Millville-Bridgeton, N.J., area topped the index with a 95.6 score. The area, about 40 miles southeast of Philadelphia, replaced Jackson, Mich., as the most affordable.
San Francisco remained the least affordable market, a position it has held since the Home Builders began the studies in the first quarter of 1991.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Mixed Amid Rate Uncertainty

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday as investors awaited a move by the Federal Reserve on interest rates. Remarks on Wednesday by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, led investors to conclude that another rate increase was imminent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged yesterday at 8424/32 to yield 7.54 percent. Prices of short-term and intermediate securities fell. Bond yields are not expected to make any pronounced changes in direction "until we get rid of the uncertainty of the Fed move," said Jerry Harris, who manages $600 million at First Alabama Bank. 
 Notes and bills may seesaw as "short-term traders buy the dips and sell the rallies," he said, based on conflicting notions of slower growth and rising inflation, which diminishes bonds' value. "It's going to be choppy," he added.
 
Big Offerings Are Coming
 Notes also fell yesterday because most investors expect "rates will have to go higher to underwrite the supply that's coming," said Marcello Frustaci, a bond trader at Daiwa Securities America.
In the next three weeks, the Treasury is expected to sell as much as $85.75 billion of securities with maturities of up to 30 years, according to Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. In yesterday's auction, the Treasury sold $16.89 billion of one-year bills at an average rate of 5.20 percent, the highest since 5.26 percent in September 1991.
In testimony before the Senate Banking Committee on Wednesday, Mr. Greenspan said it was an "open question" whether the agency's tightening to date had been sufficient to head off inflation.
Mr. Greenspan's comments killed the bond market's biggest rally in three months. Many analysts interpreted his remarks to mean that the Fed would raise rates, perhaps by as much as 50 basis points and as early as mid-August. The Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making committee, meets on Aug. 16.
Mr. Greenspan testifies before a House subcommittee today in the second leg of the Fed's semiannual testimony on monetary policy.
 The central bank may raise rates by a quarter-point next month, said Marilyn Schaja, money market economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, "depending on the next employment report and consumer price index." The Government will release reports on July employment on Aug. 5 and on July consumer prices on Aug. 12.
If the Fed raises rates again, long-bond prices could still rise, she said.
Higher rates would help choke off any incipient inflation, which recent reports show is subdued.
Even so, she said, "a lot of deterioration in bonds has been because of the dollar," which has fallen 10 percent against the German mark and 12 percent against the Japanese yen this year.
The bond's yield could fall to 6.75 percent to 7 percent because higher rates support the dollar, she said.
 
Philadelphia Fed Report
 In economic reports yesterday, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said prices for raw materials and finished goods rose this month as economic growth slowed in the Philadelphia area. The Philadelphia survey's price index for raw materials rose to 36.4 from 28.7 in June, while the index for prices received for manufactured goods increased to 15.8 from 11.0.
The report of higher prices echoed Mr. Greenspan's comments yesterday that inflation might accelerate, economists said.
"The prices-paid figures suggest that there are some price pressures built in at the producer level," said Ward McCarthy, economist at Stone & McCarthy.
Even so, the bond market "is too concerned about Greenspan's testimony" to pay attention to any single indicator, said Elias Bikhazi, money market economist at Deutsche Bank Government Securities.

HEADLINE: Soros in Call To Cooperate

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
George Soros, the billionaire financier, urged leading nations today to agree on a system of economic coordination to help stabilize currency rates.
"We are in a very serious situation not only in the monetary field, but politically also," Mr. Soros told reporters at an international conference here. 
 He said the collapse of the Soviet Union had robbed the United States and its allies of a reason to stay together, raising the chances of nationalism and beggar-thy-neighbor policies.
"The collapse of the Soviet system could easily lead to the collapse of the free world," Mr. Soros said.
"The important thing is you have to recognize that there is a need for cooperation," he said. "It can be very subtle and not announced.
"All exchange rate systems are flawed. They work for a while and then they break down. So you have to be constantly flexible and adjust the system." But, he said, "we need to have a system."

HEADLINE: Donald Turner, Lawyer for U.S. And Writer, 73

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Dr. Donald Frank Turner, a legal scholar and economist who was the Government's chief antitrust lawyer in the Johnson Administration, died on Tuesday in a nursing home in suburban Washington. A Washington resident, he was 73.
The cause was complications of Alzheimer's disease, his family said. 
 Dr. Turner was appointed Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice by President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1965. During his three years in the post, he became known as a strong enforcer of the antitrust laws. He also established a set of guidelines for mergers in the private sector.
He argued that antitrust laws should not block natural economic growth, although they should be used to keep business concentrations within bounds. As he once put it, "Substantial competitors can't merge."
Dr. Turner took the office as a scholar well versed in both the law and economics. In his view, a corporation's being large was not necessarily an evil in itself, and he advocated always giving first consideration to the economic consequences of an antitrust move by the Government.
Born in Chippewa Falls, Wis., the son of a Presbyterian minister, he worked his way through Northwestern University. He served in the South Pacific as a lieutenant in the Navy during World War II before receiving a doctorate in economics from Harvard University and a law degree from Yale University.
He was a law clerk to Justice Tom Clark of the Supreme Court and joined the faculty of Harvard University Law School in 1954 as an assistant professor. He was appointed a full professor in 1957.
He was the author, with Carl Kaysen, of "Antitrust Policy: An Economic and Legal Analysis," published in 1959. The book won esteem as a legal and economic examination of the country's antitrust laws. He returned to Harvard after his stint in Washington and was the co-author of a five-volume treatise on antitrust law and policy, "Antitrust Law," published in 1980.
He retired in 1979 as Harvard's Bussey Professor of Law. After that, he was counsel to the Washington firm of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering, a visiting professor at Georgetown University Law Center and a fellow at the Brookings Institution.
Dr. Turner is survived by his wife of 38 years, Joan Pearson Turner; a son, Paul A., of Washington; a daughter, Katherine T. Alen of Lynnfield, Mass.; two brothers, John P., of Hudson, Wis., and W. Bard, of Lexington, Mass., and a sister, Elizabeth T. Hall of New Haven.

HEADLINE: Buyouts in the Heart of Texas

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 21

 BODY:
The Texas banks might all be owned by people in New York, Charlotte, N.C., and Columbus, Ohio. The department stores, long ago swallowed by national chains, have few remaining regional distinctions. But Thomas O. Hicks will gladly testify that one thing in business here has not changed. Texans still like to do deals with Texans.
As controlling partner in the Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst leveraged buyout firm here, Mr. Hicks makes a decent living (estimated net worth, $150 million) by not being from New York. 
 Donald J. Carter, the multimillionaire owner of Home Interiors and Furnishings, a giant household-items company, first thought that selling control to a leveraged buyout firm meant dealing with one of the Gordon Gekko types from back East. Around here, Mr. Carter is best known for showing up in a white cowboy hat to cheer on his own professional basketball team, the Dallas Mavericks.
 
A Gift, Then a Deal

 
 So it made good sense for Mr. Carter's investment banker to introduce him to Tom Hicks. Mr. Hicks, whose firm owns the company that makes more than 80 percent of the nation's cowboy hats, began by presenting Mr. Carter with a top-of-the-line Stetson.
"You are Dallas's most visible western hat wearer," Mr. Hicks told him. "We want you to wear one of our products."
A couple of months later, Mr. Carter wore his new white hat to the meeting that put the final touches on a $1 billion deal, announced last week, that is Hicks, Muse's largest yet. No other firm that does leveraged buyouts -- financing the acquisition of corporations largely through debt -- was even given a shot.
Hicks, Muse partners, all of whom are Texans, say that the majority of their deals still come through their Texas connections. With sellers like Mr. Carter, for whom leveraged buyouts still reek of ruinous machinations on faraway Wall Street, the firm's four partners have had to do more disarming than the United Nations' peacekeeping forces.
Including the Home Interiors deal, Hicks, Muse has made $4.3 billion in acquisitions since the firm's founding in 1989, among them the G. Heileman Brewing Company, which happens to make Lone Star beer. That doesn't count another few billion in deals by a predecessor firm, Hicks & Haas, where Mr. Hicks was co-chairman.
A first investment fund of $255 million is likely to far surpass a goal of 40 percent gross annual returns, giving outside investors 28 percent at the very least. A second fund has already passed its goal of raising $500 million by the end of the year.
"It seems like Hicks, Muse is doing a better job of screening, getting to, executing and closing deals than anyone in the country," Richard Rainwater, a Fort Worth investor, said.
Hicks, Muse partners say that being based away from New York is essential to the company's success, not to mention their sanity.
"For people in the heartland -- the Midwest and the South -- they click better with us than with some guy with a yellow tie and slicked-back hair from New York City," said John R. Muse, the firm's co-founder. Sitting in the Dallas Country Club's 19th Hole lounge last weekend, in golf shirt and shorts, he pantomimed an antsy New Yorker straightening his tie and smoothing back his hair. "We're just regular guys," he said.
Not that the guys at Hicks, Muse revive the tired old caricature of the Texas wheeler-dealer -- the one who bought and sold on gumption, instinct and Jack Daniels. The Hicks, Muse partners come equipped with computer spreadsheets, M.B.A.'s and resumes that include the New York offices of Morgan Guaranty, CS First Boston and Morgan Stanley.
If the Texas economy might have once seemed independent, now the fortunes of Tom Hicks, John Muse and almost everyone else here rely heavily on outside investors.
Mr. Hicks travels the nation to find investors like General Electric, Bankers Trust and the state pension funds of California, Oregon, Michigan and Wisconsin. He recruited his old friend from the University of Texas, Charles W. Tate, a former Morgan Stanley managing director, to open what amounts to a Hicks, Muse consulate in New York. The firm's fourth partner, Jack D. Furst, came with Mr. Hicks from the previous firm.
 
Rebuttal From New Yorkthe East

 
 Some New York rivals see only a twang's difference between what they do and what Hicks, Muse does. They, too, work their networks to generate and capture their own deals.
Thomas C. Franco, a spokesman for the Clayton, Dubilier & Rice buyout firm in New York, said that of three major acquisitions the firm has made since December, two remained exclusive and the third initially had been. "The Hicks, Muse model is a successful model -- and one that Clayton, Dubilier & Rice has employed since 1978," Mr. Franco said.
The decor at Hicks, Muse's Dallas headquarters suggests a style having more to do with imperial 19th-century France than regular-guy Texas. Swag curtains, inlaid furniture with gilt serpents slithering along the edges -- it's as if the Hicks, Muse partners had backed up some pickup trucks to Napoleon and Josephine's yard sale.
But in some quarters here, a distinctive approach to business survived the collapse of the region's real estate, energy and banking industries in the 1980's. Even in New York, Mr. Hicks, who is 48, sometimes shows up in boots (great for middle-age fallen arches, he says) and a cowboy hat, with an Armani suit. When he needed someone to run a new $250 million real estate partnership with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette investment bank of New York, Mr. Hicks turned back to Dallas to hire David B. Deniger, who worked here as chief executive of the GE Capital Corporation's real estate arm.
In Texas, he is becoming one of the state's most powerful business people. Gov. Ann Richards, seeking advice on what to do with the $7 billion investment pool that supports the University of Texas system, named him to the system's board of regents earlier this year -- even though he had given $25,000 to the campaign of her Republican foe.
Now Mr. Hicks, although a Republican, is finance chairman for Richard Fisher's Democratic campaign to unseat Republican Senator Kay Bailey Hutchinson. Mr. Fisher is to his liking as a fiscal conservative, Mr. Hicks explained. Besides, Mr. Fisher lives next door in Highland Park, a executive enclave near downtown Dallas.
If New York's business leaders usually disperse at day's end, to city co-ops or distant suburbs, most of those in Dallas live within a 15-minute drive of each other. They are more likely to take part in political, civic and social groups, developing ties that reach across industries. Ability with a balance sheet matters, but so does ability with a hunting rifle or golf club.
Mr. Hicks (handicap 16, and impatient to get lower) and the managers of his corporate investments sometimes meet in the morning, then tee off in the afternoon. This Sunday, it's the Castle Pines course, near Denver.
At breakfast recently in Dallas, Mr. Hicks, who is 6 feet 3 inches tall, shambled up in jeans and hiking boots. Later that day, he said, he planned to explore the hiking trials at the gathering of business leaders and other big shots at the Bohemian Grove near Guerneville, Calif., where he was invited for the first time.
 
Three Simple Guidelines

 
 The payoffs of the Hicks, Muse approach -- no hostile deals, thank you -- come not only in clinching the purchases. They also avoid what the partners privately call "drunken sailor" prices. Mr. Muse has three messages for investment bankers trying to shop companies around: "We don't do auctions. We don't do auctions. We don't do auctions."
If Mr. Carter had opened up the bidding to other buyout firms, Mr. Muse said, "He probably could have gotten more." Although Mr. Carter set and won a take-it-or-leave-it price well above what Hicks, Muse had offered, he agrees.
"We did not put ourselves up for auction," Mr. Carter said. His mother had founded the company in 1957, and he and his children, who will own 49 percent of the company, wanted to remain involved. "This was much like a marriage with us," he said. "I don't think a bride likes to be auctioned off."
Mr. Carter certainly wanted his company to have a wealthy groom. But he also wanted one about whom he could sleep soundly after his evening prayers. "If I pray on it and I don't sleep well that night, forget it," Mr. Carter said.
Though Mr. Carter hadn't known Mr. Hicks well, he had no trouble talking with several mutual friends who did before he even let Mr. Hicks in the door. He respected Mr. Hicks for reviving, through his previous firm, the company that makes Dr Pepper, a hometown favorite.
At the first meeting, Mr. Carter asked mostly about family, friends and background. Receiving the Stetson -- "He knew how to get my attention" -- and hearing Mr. Hicks talk about his own six children from two marriages, strengthened Mr. Carter's inclination to sell locally.
"In the N.B.A., I've dealt with people from all over the country,' said Mr. Carter, the Mavericks owner. "But if you give me a choice, I'm going to take care of my own backyard first. Because Dallas took care of me before New York or L.A."

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Profit Far in Excess Of Estimates

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
I.B.M. surprised Wall Street yesterday with second-quarter earnings far in excess of analysts' estimates, attributing the gain primarily to cost reductions. It was was the third consecutive profitable quarter for I.B.M. after a long series of losses.
I.B.M. shares were buoyed by the news, surging $6.50 to close at $62.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Analysts said the results indicated that the International Business Machines Corporation was making progress on its path to recovery, and that the outlook for the second half of the year was bright. But while lower costs and repeated profits have lifted earnings for now, analysts said it remained unclear whether I.B.M. could generate the significantly higher revenue that would sustain long-term growth.
 
What Is Still Uncertain
 "The revenues have to pick up, the strategy has to pay off, and that's the part you don't have visibility on yet," said Steven Milunovich, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company.
For the quarter, I.B.M. had earnings of $689 million, or $1.14 a share, compared with a loss of $8 billion in the second quarter of 1993, when the company took charges to cover job cuts and a corporate reorganization.
Revenue for the most recent quarter was $15.35 billion, an increase of 2.7 percent over $14.95 billion in the comparable period last year. The comparison with 1993 was adjusted so as not to include revenue from I.B.M.'s Federal Systems Company, which it sold at the beginning of 1994.
"I'm pleased with our continued progress," Louis V. Gerstner Jr., I.B.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "We are still far from where we need to be, but we are showing steady improvement."
I.B.M. said expenses fell 18 percent in the quarter compared with the period a year earlier as a result of continued focus on expense cutting, work force reduction and plant consolidation.
Last July, I.B.M. announced plans to reduce its expenses $7 billion by 1996, compared with 1992. Yesterday the company raised the target, saying it now planned to cut costs $8 billion. By the beginning of this month, I.B.M. said, it was more than halfway toward this goal, having reduced expenses by $4.8 billion.
Jerome York, the chief financial officer, indicated in a telephone interview how the company had been able to move ahead of plans on expense cuts. "We had budgeted to take out $3 billion this year so we would expect we would have done $1.5 billion by now, and we did $2 billion," he said.
 
Sales Strongest in Asia
 While I.B.M.'s hardware sales were flat in the United States, Europe and Latin America, the Asia-Pacific area showed a gain of 14 percent, despite the recession in Japan.
In its mainframe line, I.B.M. said demand exceeded supply in the second quarter, although mainframe revenue declined from last year's period as a result of price reductions.
Daniel Mandresh, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, estimated that I.B.M.'s mainframe sales, excluding software and support, would decline to $5.4 billion for all of 1994, down from $6.8 billion in 1993. That compares with about $10 billion in 1992 and $11 billion in 1991, he said.
Mr. Mandresh expects total revenue this year to be flat, at $63 billion. "The legacy is in the mainframe but the leverage is not," he said. More and more, he said, I.B.M. should not be looked at so much as a maker of mainframes or personal computers but as a provider of a full line of information technology products.
 
PC Sales Decline in U.S.
 Although the company did not provide figures, it said personal computer sales, its single-largest product category, were up from last year's second period. But the numbers were below the company's expectations, and the growth came entirely from international sales. In the United States, I.B.M.'s sales of PC's declined.
Mr. York said the company misjudged demand for its personal computers and produced too many of some models and too few of others. I.B.M., which now has more than half a dozen lines of personal computers, said it would simplify this lineup. "We ended up with so much product complexity that it almost became impossible for our customers to understand the lineup," Mr. York added.
While analysts expressed some concern that the company's work-force reductions had not proceeded as rapidly as planned, Mr. York said this was not a serious issue. In the second quarter, staffing was reduced 8,000, after a cut of 3,000 in the first quarter, part of its plan to reduce employees by more than 35,000 in 1994. Mr. York said the company still had about 20,000 to go to reach a goal of 215,000 employees.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
U.S. Intensifies Effort to Talk the Dollar Up

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration intensified its public campaign today to talk up the value of the dollar, declaring that a higher dollar had crucial benefits for the American economy and that another slide in the American currency would slow global growth.
The President's top economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, also said that the White House would not object to another quarter-point increase in short-term interest rates before the end of this year, a move that could bolster the declining currency. 
 The remarks by Ms. Tyson and Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs, came a day after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman hinted strongly that another interest rate increase was likely and gave a strong boost to the dollar, which rose sharply today against the German mark and inched higher against the Japanese yen.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5927 marks, up 1.8 percent from 1.5650 marks on Wednesday, and at 99.20 yen, up from 98.80 yen.
Currency traders said that the Administration's repeated message -- that it does not want to see a weaker dollar in order to club Japan over the head on trade, and that the fundamentals of the American economy do not justify further dollar selling -- may finally be getting through to the markets.
"We believe a renewed decline of the dollar would be counterproductive to global recovery," Mr. Summers told the Senate Banking Committee. In contrast, he added, "a strengthening of the dollar against the yen and mark would have important economic benefits for the United States." He said, "It would restore the confidence in financial markets that is important to sustaining recovery."
Mr. Greenspan told the committee on Wednesday that a weak dollar could fuel inflation in the United States. He signaled that another quarter- to half-point increase in interest rates was likely in order to dampen inflationary pressures and indirectly support the American currency, by making it more attractive to investors to keep dollars in American banks.
Ms. Tyson, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers, echoed that view today, telling reporters that there was room for a quarter-point increase in long- and short-term interest rates by the end of the year, without much risk of sapping economic growth.
 
'Room for Some Increase'
 "Our forecast is consistent with a 25-basis-point increase in short- and long-term rates," she said. Ms. Tyson said an examination of the Administration's economic forecast released last week showed "there actually is room for some increase before year's end."
Only two weeks ago, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen declared that he did not think any increase in interest rates was justified at this time. Although Ms. Tyson was circumspect about the appropriate timing of the next rate increase, the fact that she affirmed that another rate rise was legitimate within the next five months would certainly make Mr. Greenspan's decision easier.
The comments by Mr. Summers and Ms. Tyson the day after Mr. Greenspan's testimony were the most pronounced effort by the Administration to persuade the financial markets that the White House and the Federal Reserve are in harmony and that the Administration does not secretly covet a weaker dollar. Some investors interpreted the Administration's willingness to let the dollar drop earlier this year as an intentional move, aimed at putting pressure on Japan to open some of its closed markets.
But while the Administration is trying to talk up the dollar, it has also indicated that it is not willing to take other steps now, like heavy central bank intervention, to support the American currency.
 
Message 'Getting Through'
 The Administration "is defending the dollar and that is important as compared to where they were earlier," said Scott Pardee, chairman of Yamaichi International (America) Inc. a leading currency trader. "Their message is gradually getting through. Traders are still leery, though, that someone in the Administration, either consciously or unconsciously, will link the exchange rate with trade negotiations with Japan."
Mr. Pardee said his company had seen "a little bit of buying" of American securities by Japanese investors in the last few days, which suggests that "they think the dollar is oversold." At least, he added, there is now more of a difference of opinion in the markets about the future direction of the American currency -- with fewer people thinking it could only go down -- and "this may be enabling the dollar to stand on its own two feet." There is certainly a logic to the Administration's argument for a strong dollar: If the American currency continues to erode in value, foreigners will be less willing to invest in dollar-denominated assets in the United States and they will be less willing to buy American Treasury notes needed to finance the deficit at reasonable interest rates.
At the same time, a weaker dollar fuels inflation to some degree, because it takes more dollars for Americans to buy imported cars from Japan or chemicals from Germany. When import prices go up, American producers of similar products feel less competitive pressure to hold down their prices.
A stronger dollar "would boost the attractiveness of U.S. assets and the incentive for longer-term investment in the economy, and help to keep inflation low," Mr. Summers said.
Since early January, the dollar has fallen 13 percent against the yen to a 50-year low and 8 percent against the mark.
 
Speculators' View
 In recent weeks, the financial markets have not really paid much attention to Administration declarations, because speculators have looked at the huge trade surpluses run up by Japan, as well as the weak Government in Tokyo that seems unable or unwilling to do anything about those surpluses. They have concluded that even if American officials are telling the truth -- that they don't want a weaker dollar -- the only way to deal with Japan's huge surplus is by devaluing the American currency against the yen.
In addition, the Germans have made clear that they have no interest in joining further interventions to prop up the American currency, and the German central bank signaled today that it was not going to be lowering interest rates any time soon -- a move that would likely strengthen the dollar against the mark.
The Bundesbank president, Hans Tietmeyer, said that until the central bank gained further evidence that German inflation and the money supply were under control it was going to put a four-week hold on interest rate reductions.

HEADLINE: Banks Are Warned on Derivatives

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
Citing some banks' heavy losses from risky investments, a senior bank regulator issued a legal warning to the industry today that many banks should avoid the potentially volatile securities known as structured notes.
Structured notes are debt securities that make payments based on various indexes of interest rate, options or contracts that lock in future interest rates. These notes are derivatives, which are financial securities that are based on prices in other markets and may be subject to big fluctuations in value. 
 Today's warning was the latest sign of regulatory concern about the extent to which community banks and other small financial institutions may be speculating in derivatives with little understanding of the risks.
 
Aimed at Small Banks
 The regulator who issued today's warning, Douglas E. Harris, a senior deputy comptroller of the currency, said that while the warning went out to all of the nation's 3,300 federally chartered banks, it was mainly aimed at smaller banks.
One bank with $80 million in assets lost a quarter of its $8 million in equity from a bad investment in structured notes, Mr. Harris said. He refused to identify the institution, adding that it still met Federal standards for capital adequacy.
The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which is part of the Treasury Department, is still trying to calculate industrywide losses from derivatives, Mr. Harris added.
"We have some significant losses, but not substantial losses -- nothing large enough to imperil the capital of a bank," he said.
Mr. Harris sent an official advisory letter to the chief executive of each of the 3,300 federally chartered banks. These letters, which carry close to the force of regulation, are rare -- today's is only the second that the comptroller has issued this year.
"Because of the risks involved and the difficulty in assessing those risks, some types of structured securities are inappropriate investments for most national banks," Mr. Harris wrote in his letter.
Federal bank regulators have consistently told Congress this year that they do not see a need for additional legislation to control speculation in derivatives with federally insured deposits, saying that they have more flexibility if they deal with institutions individually, using their powers to declare some banking practices to be sound and others to be unsound.
The comptroller's office oversees these institutions, which hold 60 percent of the assets in United States commercial banks.
State regulators oversee state-chartered banks, and have varying rules on the extent to which the institutions they regulate can invest in volatile securities.
Diane M. Casey, the executive director of the Independent Bankers Association of America, a trade group here that represents small banks, said that the comptroller's warning was needed. Despite public attention on derivatives since the sharp drop in bond markets last spring, securities firms continue to try to sell complex derivatives to community bankers who may not understand the risks, she said.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Rise

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for state jobless benefits shot up last week, the Government said today, but analysts shrugged off the sharp gain as attributable to temporary layoffs in the auto industry.
The Labor Department said new claims for state unemployment benefits in the week ended July 16 climbed to 392,000 from a revised 365,000 the prior week, putting them at the highest level since 408,000 in late January. 
 The number far exceeded Wall Street economists' forecasts of 358,000 new claims in the week.
The average climbed to 363,500 in the week ended July 16 from a revised 353,500 the prior week.
