HEADLINE: The New, Wide-Open Restaurant District

BYLINE: By RUTH REICHL 

 BODY:
IT has taken 35 years, but Borough President Hulan E. Jack's idea has finally paid off.
On May 18, 1959, he persuaded the New York City Council to rename Fourth Avenue in his borough from 17th to 32d Street. Upgrading the street's name to Park Avenue South, he argued, would give the area a "psychological lift." Besides, he added, it wouldn't cost anything. 
 Mr. Jack would undoubtedly be pleased to know that Park Avenue South, whose only former claim to fame was Tammany Hall, has suddenly become the heart of the city's newest restaurant district. Eleven restaurants have opened in the blocks flanking Park Avenue South below 23d Street in the last 10 months, and at least three more are in the works.
It was bound to happen. Over the last decade the neighborhood has come to life as a center for publishing and advertising. New businesses have sprung up on all the side streets, and the Greenmarket at Union Square has attracted shoppers from all over Manhattan. The neighborhood has turned into a place where the hip and the harried come comfortably together. Nowhere is this more evident than at the casual, upscale Union Square Cafe, whose enormous success lured other restaurateurs into the area.
They liked what they found. The convergence of two major Manhattan arteries provides easy access. And the growth of night life in SoHo and TriBeCa has made the formerly forgotten Flatiron district suddenly seem central to people who live farther north. Mark Strausman, who has just opened Campagna on 21st Street, puts it this way: "At this location east meets west, north meets south and downtown meets uptown."
Economics also plays a part: rents are reasonable. "We get a lot more bang for the buck per square foot here," Mr. Strausman admits. Indeed, space is a neighborhood asset. Look in any window and you find expansive rooms with soaring ceilings.
The sheer sweep of the interiors has been inspirational. These big, bold spaces are now home to some of the city's most audacious culinary creations. If you are looking for the latest in American cooking, this is the right place.
 
Gramercy Tavern
42 East 20th Street, (212) 477-0777.
 A new room often has a wonderful buzz; at just under two weeks old, this one's got it. The air prickles with expectation. The people sitting at the tables and milling around the bar look proud of themselves just for being here. And why not? Reservations are already impossible to get and sitting in this dim, expensively casual room is fun. (Gramercy Tavern is booked through Aug. 22 and will not take reservations more than a month ahead.)
Millions have reportedly been poured into this collaboration of Danny Meyer of Union Square Cafe and Tom Colicchio of the former Mondrian, but to its credit it does not show. Already the room feels lived in. It would be easy to believe that Gramercy Tavern had been here for years, quietly accumulating the paintings on the walls. Each table has ample breathing room and the chairs seem built more for comfort than effect. If the waiters, in their understated Armani-designed clothes, don't quite know what they are doing, for the most part they hide it. Is the room noisy? A bit, but the sound never reaches shouting level.
The menu is exciting and while much of the food offers evidence that the kitchen staff is new, everything I ate was good. The meal began with a little slice of tomato on a Parmesan cracker drizzled with bright green basil oil; the flavors were intense and so delicious one bite filled the mouth with flavor. After that, my favorite dish was a large ricotta raviolo layered with the flavors of summer vegetables. Tuna tartar had a fabulous sea urchin vinaigrette that sent the taste of the fish shooting off in a new direction. Sauteed cod was served with a brandade and tomato confit so deliciously sweet that it transformed the dish. Perhaps the beans on the tuna were undercooked and the squab was served in a bowl that made it difficult to eat, but those things will undoubtedly improve as the restaurant matures.
Desserts were wonderful. I loved the peach tarte Tatin with sweet basil syrup and cracked-pepper ice cream. And the cherry salad with sour cherry sorbet was unusual, refreshing and just the thing for a summer night.
 
C. T.
11 East 22d Street, (212) 995-8500.
 What happens when the son of one famous French chef and the nephew of another, a man who worked at the Paul Bocuse and Taillevent restaurants in France, goes off to Brazil and falls in love?
This.
Claude Troisgros has opened one of the most impressive new restaurants of the year. If Trader Vic had been trained in classic French cuisine, he might have come up with something as sophisticated as this sleek, cool room where tropical ingredients collide with a French esthetic. The results are stunning: breast of duck on a passion fruit and apple puree, foie gras with caramelized daikon, ravioli filled with taro root and truffle oil.
In the hands of a minor chef, these combinations might be silly, but Mr. Troisgros works with extraordinary assurance. These foods join together in harmony. If the menu is sometimes flip, the restaurant is smoothly run; it is clear that Mr. Troisgros has big plans.
 
Patria
50 Park Avenue South, at 20th Street, (212) 777-6211.
 "I wish I had a little more finesse," Douglas Rodriguez once said. "Everything I do is big and exaggerated." True, but that's what we love about this chef.
Mr. Rodriguez is trying to change the way New Yorkers think about plantains and yuca and guava, taking them out of the realm of the ethnic and giving them star status. The former Positano has become a three-level Latin fantasy with a mosaic over the door and suave service. There are fabulous rum drinks, beer from seven countries, a wine list that wanders the world. And the menu is unlike any other in the city.
Oysters come with spinach, plantains, Manchego cheese and horseradish salsa. Oh, go ahead, try it. Lentils are served with bananas, a delicious notion. Empanadas come in six flavors; one is filled with lamb, raisins, peppers and onions and served on a spinach salad with mint. Not for the timid. Ditto the salmon, which is served on a bed of mashed blue potatoes. And when the chef touts "oxtail in a chilified red wine sauce," he is not talking about temperature.
The food is uneven but always interesting. Most of it is absolutely extraordinary, and unlike anything anyone has tasted before. You may be amazed or amused, but you will not be bored.
 
Cafe Beulah
9 East 19th Street, (212) 777-9700.
 Cafe Beulah takes you right to the country. It is so cozy and comfortable you find yourself listening for the chirping of crickets and imagining that if you stepped outside, a friendly dog would wander up and sniff your fingers.
A basket of Beulah's breads is the best way to prolong the illusion: this is the finest collection of corn bread and biscuits in the city. It goes well with a bottle of Voodoo beer.
Beulah's specialty is Low Country cooking; big food with big flavors. Baked ham is drenched with praline bourbon sauce, the smoky ham edging up against a painfully sweet sauce until your mouth is vibrating. The flavors are echoed in the lemon candied yams on the side.
There is a mean fried baby chicken with barbecued red beans. Hominy grits with smothered shrimp is so soft and soothing it is like savory cereal. And who else serves an appetizer of okra and barbecued shrimp, or a salad combining cabbage and apricots?
Best of all, this food is reasonable. If you stay away from the expensive house specials, you can eat a big meal for a price that makes you especially happy that Cafe Beulah has arrived on 19th Street.
 
Zen Palate
4 Union Square East, at 16th Street, (212) 614-9291.
 Zen Palate confirms a carnivore's worst fears about vegetarian restaurants: after spending a great deal of time and money in this extremely beautiful restaurant, I invariably leave hungry. It is the ultimate triumph of style over flavor.
The restaurant looks like a Zen temple, all calm, peaceful beauty. From the dining room on the second floor, patrons can look out over the trees of Union Square Park before reading the menu, a self-conscious construction of nubby brown paper tied up with a chopstick and red ribbon. But the dishes, which have names like jewel of happiness (mini-mushroom steaks with endive and sweet peas) and mushroom forest (minced shiitake mushrooms, soy bean protein, wheat gluten and pine nuts all wrapped in lettuce) are ultimately unsatisfying.
Those hoping to fill up on dessert are out of luck. A gelatinous mango pudding was one of the worst things I have ever tasted (although I did like the seaweed cracker chips that came with it), and just the thought of tofu cheesecake covered with a sticky, gooey blueberry sauce makes me shudder.
 
Metronome
15 Broadway, near 21st Street, (212) 505-7400.
 "Don't get mad at me," the waitress said when we asked, for the third time, for a bottle of mineral water.
And that was the high point of the evening.
Well, there was the moment when the waiter started doing magic tricks; he was really good, managing to turn a deck of blue cards into red ones and making watches appear and disappear at a dizzying rate.
If only he could have magically improved the food! But the meals I have eaten in the huge, expensively decorated room have not been impressive. Doughy rigatoni with broccoli rape and chunks of sausage, slimy baby chicken with a soy-and-peanut sauce, a "California spinach salad" sprinkled with mangoes and pecans.
"Isn't the food wonderful?" breathed our waiter as he finished his tricks. He really seemed to mean it.
 
Bolo
3 East 22d Street, (212) 228-2200.
 For sheer happy energy, few restaurants can beat Bolo. The restaurant is visually exciting, with edgy graphic collages on the wall and dizzy tiles around the oven. The food fits right in.
Flushed with the success of his Mesa Grill, Bobby Flay decided that he wanted to try cooking Spanish food. But he is not a chef who follows rules, so the food, like the decor, takes its cues from Spain without ever leaving Manhattan. The paella contains roasted duck and lobster; rice is cooked with curry, and the Bolo salad has so much cabrales cheese and chorizo that no Spaniard would recognize it as his own.
Does it matter? Not a bit. Bolo is a lively restaurant with exciting food that is always delicious. What should you try?
Fried squid with anchovy vinaigrette is terrific, and the steamed baby clams in green-onion broth are a joy. Grilled scallops are served on an intense pasta cooked in squid ink. At lunchtime there are terrific sandwiches, and caramel sorbet is a great dessert.
And deep in summer, that Sangria really hits the spot.
 
Campagna
4 East 21st Street, (212) 460-0900.
 It said a lot for the neighborhood when the pretentious Luxe was replaced by the eater-friendly Campagna. The room was stripped of its silly gold accents and repainted in rustic tones. On the tables, where flowers once were, vases filled with rosemary have appeared. And the menu, once so complicated the waiters had to explain it, now speaks for itself.
The best way to begin an urban rustic meal at Campagna is with a selection from the antipasto table, an appealing array of marinated and grilled vegetables, cheeses, sliced cured meats and salads. A plate would make a wonderful meal. But that would mean missing the terrific frito misto and all those appealing pastas.
At the moment, the restaurant is full and frantic. The chef and owner is Mark Strausman, whose many admirers have followed him from Coco Pazzo, thrilled that his food is now more affordable. When the hoopla dies down, this will probably mature into a wonderful restaurant.
 
Chutney Mary
0 East 20th Street, (212) 473-8181.
 It bills itself as "New York's first organic-Indian restaurant," but there are other attributes Chutney Mary might brag about. New York's first Indian restaurant with an indoor fountain, for instance, or New York's first Indian restaurant with a jungle. The latter is a remarkable creation made of murals, dripping water and plants; there are even a couple of fake mangoes hanging way up near the ceiling, inspiring a person to wonder if a couple of monkeys or parrots might not be appropriate additions.
After all that, the food is something of a letdown. The usual range of Indian fare includes pleasantly spicy samosas; a range of tandoori breads, meats and fish; a few quite spicy vindaloos. As befits an organic restaurant, the most interesting dishes turn out to be vegetarian: I was especially taken with one called silk and jewels, a fragrant mixture of spinach, homemade cheese and fresh spices.
 
City Crab and Seafood Company
35 Park Avenue South, at 19th Street, (212) 529-3800.
 Here comes the tray, piled high with festive red-clawed creatures. The waiter lifts it, angles it over the table and slides the crabs right onto the paper-covered surface. For the next half-hour, conversation stops.
Nothing is more fun than an old-fashioned Maryland crab boil; it takes the teeth and every one of the fingers to pry the sweet, recalcitrant meat from the shells. When you have finished, your hands are pleasantly prickly, your lips atingle with spices. What a good thing that there are so many fine beers on draft at the City Crab and Seafood Company!
The menu offers many other appealing options. Great clams and oysters, on the half shell, at reasonable prices. Good fresh fish (the tuna has been particularly impressive). Crisply roasted chicken. Fabulous fries served in big heaps.
Afterward? Key lime pie, of course. You may even find yourself leaning toward the next table and belting out a couple of bars of "Happy Birthday" when the staff gathers to toast one of the many revelers in the room. It's a perfect place for a party.
 
Park Avalon
25 Park Avenue South, near 19th Street, (212) 533-2500.
 Every neighborhood needs a place to hang out. In this part of town, Park Avalon provides it. The restaurant has something for almost every appetite at extremely reasonable prices. Nothing on the menu is more than $17.95, and most entrees are less than $15.
The huge high-ceilinged room is usually filled with a cross section of neighborhood people. Celebrities and hip young things mingle happily with the Gramercy Park crowd in the pleasingly casual space.
The menu offers hits of the 90's: Caesar salad, pizza, pasta, grilled chicken, roast chicken and so forth. In my experience it is best to stick with the basics; the more experimental dishes can be pretty silly. But nobody could quarrel with a chicken paillard served on a bed of garlicky mashed potatoes, or a generous bowl of penne with roasted tomato sauce.
The wine list is good and fairly priced. Desserts are impressive. There is even a daily diet dessert so delicious it is hard to believe its low-calorie claims.

SECTION: Section C; Page 22; Column 3; Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1302 words

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Ruth Reichl 

 BODY:
Do you remember the scene in the movie "Gigi" in which the aging courtesan teaches her niece to eat ortolans? The bones of the tiny birds crackle horribly in the old lady's mouth but she remains the picture of elegant ease. Gigi, attempting to imitate her aunt, merely looks uncomfortable.
Every meal I have eaten at Les Celebrites has reminded me of that scene. Unfortunately, I am always Gigi.
The setting is undoubtedly what brings this to mind. No restaurant in New York so perfectly recreates another time and place. Les Celebrites is a precious Art Deco parlor, all lacquer and Lalique. To those who appreciate the opulence of that ebony and gold period, the intimate room with just 18 tables will seem the last word in luxury. Those who do not may find the atmosphere slightly suffocating. Personally, I always have the fear that when I sit back in those well-padded sofas my feet will not quite touch the floor. 
 Well-meaning waiters hover anxiously; they do not enliven the atmosphere. The dismay of our captain, who went hopping around the table one night trying to provide the correct cutlery as we passed our plates to taste one another's food, would have been comical had it not been so oppressive. At one point I actually found myself crossing knives with him as he snatched a fish knife away to replace it with the proper one for meat. He looked triumphant; I was embarrassed.
Yet another captain, on another visit, steadfastly refused to allow us to order a fish course between the appetizer and the entree. "Our portions are very large," he said firmly. "It will be too much for you." We persisted, he insisted. We finally gave up.
Another time our captain murmured approval of my choice of Ferrari-Carano, a rich California chardonnay. "I'm glad you like it," I replied, attempting irony. He drew back a bit. "Oh no," he said severely. "It is not a wine for me."
In this restaurant you must play by the rules. Stick to the proper cutlery, don't try to order too much and be grateful for wine advice, even if uninvited. You will be rewarded with some of the city's finest food. After a few forkfuls of foie gras, even the most anxious waiter fades into the background where he belongs.
Foie gras is one of the signatures of the chef, Christian Delouvrier, who piles it onto his plates with joyous abandon. He might plunk morsels onto a bed of baby pea sprouts and top them with a deep, dusky prune sauce as a tidbit to offer diners before they order. Or stuff fat slices of foie gras between rings of green apple and turn it into the world's most decadent burger. He hollows out an onion and fills it with a seductive mixture of foie gras, prosciutto and sweetbreads. Sometimes he just sautes the rich liver with fresh figs: when a dish is as simple as this one, the sheer generosity of the serving is heady.
Mr. Delouvrier can be equally cavalier with caviar. Once last winter he used caviar like mustard in a sauce for scallops and shrimp. The graininess of the roe was a treat and a surprise in a playfully delicious dish.
He is no more respectful of truffles, handling them as if they went for the price of potatoes. Rock shrimp ravioli arrive in a wild mushroom broth scented with truffle oil. The perfume of the dish is dizzying. And in truffle season, a small mountain of crushed potatoes arrived hidden beneath shaved black truffles; it was the most wildly indulgent dish I've had all year.
Even a simple salad of green beans becomes a luxury in Mr. Delouvrier's hands. In springtime the beans shared the plate with morels so large and so black they were shocking. Long after the morels had disappeared, their musky flavor was still echoing on the tongue.
The appetizers are a continuous kaleidoscope of surprises. Tomato consomme with scallops sounds unimpressive. But the soup is topped first with a scoop of icy tomato sorbet, then with a single leaf of fried basil. In this company, the sliced white scallops are mere threads in a tapestry of textures.
The wine list is equally impressive. It is tempting, faced with so many good choices, to succumb to the excesses of the room and decide that this is not the time to economize. But those who keep their heads will discover that a surprising percentage of the wines are affordable, especially to people willing to venture beyond Burgundy and Bordeaux. They will also find that if they ask for advice, it is reliable.
If only the entrees were as dependable. Many are. Honey-and-orange-lacquered duck, perfumed with coriander and cumin and served with a fig puree, is a reminder that Mr. Delouvrier once worked with the three-star French chef Alain Senderens. With its spicy medieval flavors, the duck is irresistible. Squab with garlic confit and wonderfully truffled polenta is rare, gamy, satisfying. Tiny chops and saddle of extraordinary lamb are served with sweet little tomatoes. And a special one night, the loin, saddle and rack of baby goat, was fine enough to revolutionize the image of that unlovable animal: surrounded with thyme, it was gently flavorful and absolutely tender.
But much of the fish is disappointing. Turbot is more notable for its vegetable mosaic of green asparagus, bright carrots, red and yellow beets and fava beans than for the flavor of the fish. Crispy-skinned salmon steak, ordered rare, is overcooked and the skin is nothing but a small oval on the side. Worse, the compote of leeks on which it sits is so salty that the masterly sauce, shot through with the flavor of grapes, is almost ruined. Strips of sole are large, rubbery, dull and salty. A special tuna is dry. The waiters standing by with worried looks make it all worse.
But when dessert appears, everyone relaxes. The sweets are a loving reminder of a time when calories were not counted. Sorbets arrive in an ornate chocolate basket, luxury within luxury. Ice cream is served in a tall chocolate "crocus" piled high with creamy chocolate, praline and caramel confections. An apple tart is still warm, its thin slices of fruit riding a gossamer crust; the Calvados ice cream obligingly takes its time melting across the top. And a perfect raspberry souffle collapses upon itself with a fragrant sigh of hot air.
Petits fours arrive with the coffee. They are arrayed around an arrangement of pulled sugar flowers. Each time, I find myself tempted to reach out and see what the flowers feel like. But then I see that the captain has his eye on me and I fold my hands meekly and place them in my lap.

Les Celebrites
***
 Essex House, 160 Central Park South, (212) 247-0300.
Atmosphere: Some of Manhattan's most impressive food is served in an opulent jewel box room that is a masterpiece of Art Deco overstatement.
Service: Careful, correct and lacking in imagination. The hovering waiters aim for perfection and occasionally achieve oppression.
Recommended dishes: Sauteed foie gras, burger of foie gras, rock shrimp ravioli, cold tomato soup with poached sea scallops, warm salad of green beans, honey-and-orange-lacquered duck, roast squab, roast lamb, hot apple tart, bouquet of sherbets, ice cream, souffles.
Wine list: Large, wide-ranging and well chosen with a surprising number of affordable bottles.
Price range: Degustation menu $95 a person, $145 with wines. Appetizers $15 to $22; entrees, $29 to $39; desserts, $9 to $14.
Hours: 6 to 10 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays. Closed Sundays and Mondays. Closed Aug. 14 to Sept. 8.
Credit cards: All major cards.
Wheelchair accessibility: Everything on one level.

**** Extraordinary
 Ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction primarily to food, with ambiance and service taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.

HEADLINE: How Aid Makes Argentina's Poor Poorer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"In Argentina, the Poor Seem to Get Poorer" (news article, July 7) observes that while President Carlos Saul Menem "has focused on macro-economic issues, he has neglected new social programs." You do not mention, however, that lending practices of such international institutions as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are as much to blame for the widening gap between rich and poor as the skewed economic policies of the Argentine President. 
 For years, these agencies promoted structural adjustment programs, which have contributed to the spectacular growth from which President Menem, their loyal servitor, has benefited. But while export sectors expanded and trade deficits shrank in the mid-1980's, poorer Argentines were getting squeezed when the international lending agencies imposed a fiscal austerity program as a precondition for rescheduling the country's burdensome debt payments.
To compensate for the reduction of social public spending in Argentina, the best the World Bank could do was to disburse $328 million to the Argentine health care, housing and other social sectors from 1985 to 1990, just 15 percent of total outlays to the country for that period. The International Monetary Fund doesn't even extend such loans to the "social sectors," preferring instead to remain institutionally blind to the poverty it helps create and sustain.
It is these giant lending institutions therefore, as much as Mr. Menem, that are primarily responsible for an earnings growth rate of -0.8 percent and public health expenditures that totaled only 4.2 percent of gross domestic product in 1990, the last year for which figures are available.
Even when the World Bank finances a project to ameliorate the living standards of Argentines, corruption and mismanagement transform it into a behemoth. After 15 years of loans, the vast Yacyreta Dam, constructed to supply water to Buenos Aires, is $7 billion over budget and still not completed. This figure does not include the enormous social cost of relocating 50,000 people and destroying four local ecosystems.
Washington, as the main sponsor of many of these lending projects, must be held at least indirectly accountable for the worsening condition of millions of Argentines. It is time for the United States, as the architect of the Bretton Woods system, to re-examine its blueprint for loan programs that merely pay lip service to perilous living conditions not only of millions of Argentines, but also of populations throughout most of the third world.
 
DAVID L. BERNSTEIN
Washington, July 15, 1994
The writer is a research associate for the Council on Hemispheric Affairs.

HEADLINE: As It Moves to Privatize Schools, Hartford Is Keeping Some Control

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 21

 BODY:
The Board of Education is preparing to hire a profit-making company to manage Hartford's 32 schools, although fierce opposition from teachers and questions about the financial arrangements have caused city officials to reject the company's bid to take nearly full control of the system.
The school board's vote, perhaps as soon as Friday, would make Hartford the nation's first city to hire a private manager for its entire school system. But instead of having wide latitude to squeeze millions in savings from the budget to pay for improvements to the city's troubled schools, the company, Education Alternatives Inc., will be given control over only a small part of the system's $171 million budget and will be asked to reorganize the schools from within, working with the bureaucracy that is acknowledging its own failure by hiring the company. 
 Board members who support hiring the company said the board was likely to insist on keeping control of hiring and firing and to require that its expensive contracts with teachers and other employees be respected. Education Alternatives, the Minneapolis-based company that runs 12 schools in Baltimore and one in the Miami area, will be allowed to revise the Hartford district's curriculum, retrain teachers, bring computers into classrooms and search for economies. But, under the board's latest proposal, the company will have to do so with approval by Hartford's school superintendent or the school board itself.
As cities across the country consider privatizing their schools to make better use of scarce resources, Hartford's experience shows how reluctant even the most desperate districts are to hand over control to companies that answer to stockholders instead of taxpayers.
In exchanging proposals, city and company officials have agreed that the company, over five years, would aim to raise standardized test scores and attendance rates by specific percentages. The board would be able to cancel the contract at any time.
The company has proposed that Hartford pay its expenses out of the savings the company hopes to find within the school budget. If after those expenses are paid, money is left over, those savings would be divided equally among the company, as its fee, the school board and the city. While neither side has estimated the potential savings, the company has projected its operating costs in the first year at $6 million. If it could not find that much in savings, it would have to bear those costs itself.
In a city that spends more per pupil than most of its suburbs yet achieves the worst academic results in the state, critics say they cannot see how the company will be able to accomplish more than the Board of Education with the same budget, while taking a profit.
"There's no question that Hartford's no different from any other large city," said the school board's chairman, William Meagher, one of only three people on the nine-member board who oppose private management. "Problems exist and we want do something about it. But I don't think sending millions to Minnesota is the way to go."
The company is a young publicly owned corporation whose stock soared after it won management and consulting contracts for 12 public schools in Baltimore in 1992. Its efforts to go citywide here have made Education Alternatives, as much as education itself, the focus of controversy. Education Alternatives has bet much of its corporate future on winning a districtwide contract.
Opponents have attacked not only its claims for improving the Baltimore and Miami schools but also its motives.
 
Helping the Balance Sheet?
 If the school board agreed to pay over its budget to Education Alternatives, for example, the result would not only be more control for the company, but an immense lift to the balance sheet it shows stockholders, since it could count that $171 million as its own revenue.
"We are aware that would build up their balance sheet, but we don't see how that would result in any improvement in the education of our kids," said Ted Carroll, a school board member who is one of the company's strongest defenders but who has been convinced that the company should not control the board's budget.
At its national convention this week, the American Federation of Teachers, which represents Hartford's teachers, called on districts not to sign contracts with the company.
"E.A.I. has lied about test results, shifted money from classroom instruction to overhead and profit, and denied services to special education and disadvantaged youngsters," said the federation's president, Albert Shanker.
 
Answering Some Challenges
 Education Alternatives said the company's record was being misrepresented. The test results in question did not involve standardized tests, the company said, but only its own monitoring of Baltimore students' progress on a computer curriculum that is central to the company's educational plan. The number of students reported to be progressing was overstated by mistake, the company said.
A spokeswoman for the company, Lory Sutton, said the company did spend extra money on repairing the Baltimore schools in the first year of its contract, but the repairs were needed and more money was now being shifted to instruction.
The charges involving the classroom assignment of special-education children, she said, were made by the Baltimore federation, and a state investigation found problems at only one school. The American Federation of Teachers opposes placing special-education students in regular classrooms, a practice known as mainstreaming that Education Alternatives favors.
The mounting attacks, combined with a softening of the company's Hartford prospects this month, drove down its stock price to a low of $9igh of $48.75, raising new concerns even for its supporters. The stock closed today at $13.625, up 12.5 cents.
 
'Need for Change'
 "I have no doubt that it's make or break for that corporation," said the Hartford City Council's majority leader, John B. O'Connell, who favors private management. "That's part of the concern. We're talking about a municipal operation, a no-risk kind of mental attitude over here, and we're concerned that we're going to turn over half our city budget to an entity that we're not sure of yet."
This week, however, a study by the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand reassured city officials of Education Alternatives' financial health, and plans were proceeding for the school board to vote.
"The need for change hasn't changed," Mr. Carroll said. "A solid majority still feels there is a solid role for a private management company in helping us bring about those changes."
Ms. Sutton, the company's spokeswoman, said no one could say what Education Alternatives' role in Hartford would be until a contract was finally negotiated. But in its proposal to the city, the company said it was not interested in being a mere consultant.
"In our opinion," the company stated in its proposal, "you do not need yet another consultant advising you what to do. You need someone to do it!"
The school system's test scores have been falling while its dropout rate has been rising even as Connecticut has sent tens of millions in school aid to the capital city each year. Two thirds of the system's students come from poor families.
In a desegregation lawsuit that was heard last year, lawyers for Hartford schoolchildren argued that spending even more money on the city's schools would not insure equal educational opportunity because of the disadvantages posed by the district's intense poverty and racial segregation.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 26, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about a private company's efforts to win a contract to manage the public schools in Hartford misstated the position of the American Federation of Teachers on "mainstreaming," the placement of special-education students in regular classrooms. The union opposes a practice known as full inclusion, in which all such students are placed in regular classrooms regardless of the severity of their disabilities; it does not oppose all mainstreaming.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Paine Webber to Bail Out a Fund Battered by Complex Investments

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The Paine Webber Group disclosed yesterday that it would spend $180 million to bail out a mutual fund battered by its holdings of the highly technical and often risky Wall Street securities called derivatives.
The rescue effort comes on top of $88 million the big brokerage firm spent last month to stabilize its mutual fund and to reimburse customers burned by what was advertised as a safe and secure investment. 
 The bailout, at $268 million, may be the largest ever in the rapidly growing mutual fund industry.
And it is the latest and sharpest example of the way Wall Street wizardry can go wrong -- and how derivatives can hurt ordinary Americans.
Derivatives are complex securities whose returns are based on -- or derived from -- other investments. In this case, these derivatives started life as everyday home mortgages that are lumped together and sold in pools to investors. But in Wall Street's derivative laboratories, they are diced and sliced and reassembled into what can turn out to be a Frankenstein's monster.
The Paine Webber story also raises fears among some analysts about what would happen if such a fiasco occurred at a firm that could not afford to cover investors' losses.
The money from the bailout announced yesterday will not go directly to investors. It is intended to shore up the value of the fund in an effort to stem its losses.
The Securities and Exchange Commission, which will rule on Paine Webber's rescue plan, is studying whether derivatives pose a pervasive problem in the $2.2 trillion fund industry. This is at least the fifth time this year a fund company has had to spend its own money to stabilize a fixed-income fund that had experienced enormous losses from derivatives. BankAmerica Corporation put money into its funds twice and Piper Jaffray Companies once.
Just last month, Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the S.E.C., wrote to the country's largest mutual funds to express his "continuing concern that mutual funds utilize derivative instruments wisely."
Barry Barbash, director of the commission's investment management division, echoed that concern yesterday. And he added: "This raises the broader question about what investors know about the funds in which they invest. It's a question of disclosure, which needs to be very tight."
The bailout will cost Paine Webber $34 million after taxes, which the company took as a charge in the second quarter, said Regina A. Dolan, the company's chief financial officer. That charge more than wiped out the company's earnings last quarter, leaving it with a loss of $25.1 million, or 35 cents a share.
The battered fund, the Paine Webber Short-Term U.S. Government Securities Fund, had been extremely popular with brokers and their clients because they were eager to earn more than the low interest rates available from safe certificates of deposit and money market funds. The fund, which opened for business in May 1993, quickly collected almost $2 billion from investors hunting for slightly higher returns.
But to get those returns, the fund's managers invested in derivatives called structured notes, because Wall Street created them -- structured them -- to meet specific investors' needs. Like a custom-tailored suit, however, such notes are hard to sell "off the rack."
New, highly technical and extremely complicated, most of these derivatives were created when interest rates were falling. After the Federal Reserve began raising interest rates in February, however, these derivatives backfired and fell sharply in value. Even worse, no other investors wanted to buy them, despite the fire-sale prices.
 
Price Fell Sharply
 So far this year the Paine Webber fund is off more than 7 percent, far more than most other, similar funds. Shocked investors fled, pulling out hundreds of millions of dollars, and some filed a class action lawsuit contending that they had not been told of the fund's risky nature.
In June, Paine Webber agreed to settle that lawsuit and to spend $33 million, or 6 cents a share, to compensate fund investors for some of their losses from investments that firm officials agreed had been inappropriate. The company also spent $55 million to buy some other derivatives from the fund, thereby shoring up its value.
In yesterday's action, Paine Webber said it would buy another, larger holding of derivatives at the price at which the fund now values them. That price is far less than the fund paid for them, but more than the firm would be able to get for them on the open market.
The firm decided to take this action after it told regulators it could not get other securities firms to bid on these derivatives.
Paine Webber was pressed to act by Federal securities law, which bars mutual funds from investing more than 15 percent of their assets in securities that cannot be sold easily. By yesterday, these two derivatives accounted for almost 25 percent of the rapidly shrinking fund.
The company also replaced the fund's managers, who resigned earlier this week, with Pacific Investment Management Company, one of the top fixed-income money managers in the country. Paine Webber also named its president, Paul Guenther, to oversee directly its entire $26 billion mutual fund business.
Paine Webber said it was not legally obligated to buy the derivatives. "It sounds corny, but that mutual fund had the Paine Webber name on it, and our reputation is important to us," said Thomas F. Eggers, director of the fund group.
Lawyers for fund investors had been pressing Paine Webber to get rid of these troubled derivatives, and were pleased by yesterday's decision, said Sam Schwartz, a lawyer with Bizar & Martin. "They were a destabilizing factor," he said, adding, "This is good for investors."
However, regulators and executives of other fund companies expressed concern that the giant bailout might set a bad precedent by making investors think they will always be rescued from unwise investments, or by leaving the impression, already prevalent among some, that funds are insured in the same way that bank deposits are.
Indeed, some industry consultants have suggested that investors should stick with large fund companies because they are better able to afford to reimburse investors.
But Jon S. Fossel, chairman of the Oppenheimer Funds, disagreed. "What they should do is look at the track record of a fund and only buy ones where the fund has already been though a bad market," he said. "The best offense is a good defense."
Even excluding the one-time charge, Paine Webber's second-quarter earnings were below Wall Street's expectations. With the exclusion, they fell 85 percent, to $9.1 million, or 12 cents a share, from $59.3 million, or 69 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected Paine Webber to earn about 24 cents a share.
Still, Paine Webber's stock was unchanged yesterday at $16.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Paine Webber said its net revenues fell 15.7 percent, to $579 million in the second quarter, from $686.5 million.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE CAMPAIGN;
Clinton Plan's Backers Set Out on Bus Cavalcade

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore. July 22

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration took its high-stakes health care gamble on the road today, using a bus trip, a Hollywood actress and a rock group to try to rekindle the cozier moments of last year's Presidential campaign. It hopes to ignite popular support as the complex issue heads for a floor debate on Capitol Hill.
Ignoring scattered boos and hand-painted signs opposing abortion rights and "rationed health care," a crowd of 10,000 cheered as more than 100 supporters of universal health coverage set off in four buses on a 3,384-mile cross-country trek carefully staged and financed by supporters of the President's plan. Their goal is to court Americans who have been watching the debate at a distance. 
 The caravan will be joined by hundreds more doctors, nurses and "reform riders" in the next two weeks. When the 16 buses in the "Health Care Express," along with caravans starting elsewhere in the country, reach Washington, participants hope to make their case to Congress with three days of rallies and lobbying in the first week of August.
 
A Rowdy Send-Ooff
 Starting here in a state known for its liberalism and its statewide endorsement of broad health care coverage, the journey began with a boisterous rally and shouts of encouragement from Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Mrs. Clinton jogged to the stand and then waited, nodding, as several of the bus riders told brief stories of their troubles with the present system. She then addressed the crowd filling Pioneer Square, almost shouting in the 100-degree heat, "This is economically, socially and morally the right thing to do!"
Mrs. Clinton, who is not riding on the buses, and other speakers criticized insurance companies for waging a high-cost advertising campaign against the health care overhaul and urged politicians to listen to their consciences and constituents. "The bottom line has to be guaranteed insurance," she said to cheers.
But the drama and the difficulties of the debate hit home long before the rock group Lovemongers, formerly Heart, struck its first note, or Meredith Baxter, the star of the television program "Family Ties," began her opening remarks. People waiting for the rally to begin fell into impassioned debates over abortion rights, high costs, excess bureaucracies and universal coverage.
Joseph Forsythe, a 49-year-old claims adjuster from Portland, said, "People really don't understand the issue if they are not on the inside." Just hours earlier, he said, he received an insurance claim with a $395 charge for a $62.50 procedure and a $265 fee for a $79 procedure.
"I think that's where a lot of this problem is coming from -- gouging," he said. "The only way we can possibly fix this is to do something now."
Others just as passionately disagreed.
"This whole Clinton health care scandal will be the greatest bureaucratic mess ever in the history of the earth," said Walter Taylor, a gray-haired man wearing a radio headset and who traveled from Salem, Ore., to register his complaint and hear the details of the plan. "They have no idea what it will cost."
 
Message for Congress
 The organizers of the trip -- Families USA, a Washington-based health care lobbying group; the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, and Health Right, a health advocacy group -- have worked with health care organizations and several unions to send Congress the message that Americans want guaranteed health care.
Carefully designed to appear as an almost spontaneous outpouring of outrage, the campaign comes with T-shirts, a slogan, "Pass it Now!" and the high spirits of hundreds of people who have found their lives darkened by inequities and unexpected pitfalls in the existing system.
Many of the riders have long been known to health-care specialists because they have lost jobs, insurance and in some cases any safety net at all, while faced with health problems like cancer and near-fatal accidents.
Most of those riders view the health-care issue literally as a matter of life and death and will remain on the bus until they reach their destination in Washington. But some of the more prominent participants in today's rally had committed themselves to rides of less than a hundred miles. Mrs. Clinton herself did not ride the bus but continued to Seattle, where she was scheduled to attend another health-care rally.
The $2 million national caravan is being financed by a loose consortium of groups supporting health care reform, including health care unions and other labor groups.
Arnold Bennett, a balding lifelong liberal who is the media director of Families USA, said the campaign was "for the folks who can't afford to buy $20 million worth of advertising but still want to get their voices heard."
Some of the populism has been carefully crafted. Bus riders were screened by the trip's organizers, who turned down those who did not completely agree the primary message: full coverage for everyone.
The message also has to seem urgent. So as the buses started their engines, Mrs. Clinton stopped to shake dozens of riders' hands. As the Rev. Rodney I. Page, executive director of the Ecumenical Ministries of Oregon, boarded a bus she stopped him in front of the cameras for a particularly warm send-off. But moments after the First Lady and the cameras left, Mr. Page got off the bus and boarded the one on which he had a seat, this time with no ceremony.

HEADLINE: Auto Makers' New Idea: Focus on Used-Car Sales

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 22

 BODY:
The nation's auto makers, historically obsessed with offering the freshest shapes and the most advanced gadgets, are increasingly shifting their attention to something older: the booming used-car market, estimated at twice the size of the new-car market in the United States.
For shoppers, the change will mean more well-maintained, low-mileage, recent-vintage cars that are laden with accessories. 
 Anticipating a rapidly growing supply of high-quality used cars starting later this year, as a large number of two- and three-year leases come to an end, auto makers are beginning to stand behind the second-hand cars their dealers sell in ways they never backed them before. The companies are issuing standards for how customers should be treated, in an effort to rein in fast-talkers who promise coddled Cadillacs but deliver clunkers. They are also setting standards for reconditioning used vehicles.
Further, they are lowering finance rates on used cars, providing lease deals for them, extending warranties and offering 24-hour roadside assistance to buyers. They are setting up computerized satellite auction systems to sell used cars more efficiently to dealers. And some are developing new cars with an eye to how they will appeal to second buyers.
Behind the strategy is the astonishing growth in new-car leasing. Auto makers are expecting a flood of used vehicles to begin rolling back to dealer lots, effectively turning the companies into the country's largest owners of used cars. When a company finances a lease it owns the car. The companies know they must sell those used cars at a good price when the leases end, or take big losses on them.
"You're seeing manufacturers being led not by their instincts, but by their investments, into used-vehicle wholesaling," said John J. Ferron, a senior partner at J. D. Power Associates, the automotive consulting firm in Agoura Hills, Calif.
After ignoring it for generations, the auto makers are zeroing in on a market of at least 30 million vehicles a year. It is generally a big moneymaker, with new-car dealers averaging more than three times the profit per sale on used cars than on highly competitive new-car transactions.
"We're in the transportation business, and what we tend to always talk about is the new-car market," said Michael D. Jordan, executive director of sales operations for the Ford Motor Company. "But there's a very big market here for used cars. There's no reason we can't compete successfully in it."
 
Of Growing Importance
 Auto dealers recognized the potential years ago. Since 1989, and for the first time since World War II, new-vehicle dealers have been selling more used automobiles than new ones -- and the gap has grown wider each year.
"As far as keeping a dealership these days, used cars are more important by far," said Kraig M. Quisenberry, general manager of Bay Ford in Port Orchard, Wash. "That's really the bread and butter for most dealerships."
To make the lowly used vehicle more appealing, auto makers are trying to elevate its status. While Ford of Britain set up a "factory" to recondition 100,000 used cars a year, Ford in the United States is reconditioning cars through its auction network, which handles used vehicles that the company buys back from fleet customers. Workers steam-clean the engines, repaint the cars if necessary and make any needed repairs. For its used-vehicle lease program, Ford then slaps on an extension of the new- car warranty covering 115 systems, from the engine to the brakes, for the period of the lease. People with the leases can also receive assistance if their cars break down.
General Motors' Cadillac Division runs a similar program. In addition, G.M. offers a companywide used-vehicle leasing program.
To handle the flow of off-lease vehicles, Lexus, the luxury division of the Toyota Motor Corporation, has set up a satellite system to sell reconditioned cars to its dealers. The company transmits a photo of the car and relevant data to dealers' television screens, and dealers bid by tapping the keys of their telephones, watching the price climb on the screen.
Like Cadillac and some of its other luxury competitors, Lexus is searching for a more dignified nomenclature as it focuses on used vehicles.
" 'Used' doesn't do justice to what we're trying to sell," said Gary Marcotte, manager of special markets for Lexus. " 'Used' is something you don't want." But, he said, " 'pre-owned' is something someone's taken care of."
Lexus began reconditioning and then marketing previously owned cars late last year; it expects to sell or lease 22,000 used Lexuses this year through its dealers. Ford has leased about 20,000 used vehicles so far this year, and expects to lease up to 100,000 in 1995.
 
The Leasing Gamble
 Through such programs, the auto makers hope to cultivate customers who cannot afford new vehicles now, but may be able to later. More important, they are trying to insure that the enormous gamble they have made on new-car leasing pays off.
Through leasing, auto makers have at least three opportunities for profit. First, when they sell a car to a dealer. Then, if the dealer leases a car the auto maker's finance arm can profit from the lease payments. The dealer and the auto maker can both profit when the car is later sold as a used car. But the companies are quite guarded about how much they make on all these transactions.
Now, every time an auto maker leases a new car it must guess how much the car will be worth when the lease is up -- its so-called residual value. If the company predicts that the residual value will be high, the person leasing the car will have smaller monthly payments, because those payments are based on the value that is used up during the lease.
For car makers, the risk is that they may have guessed residual values that are too high. If that happens, they can wind up trying to sell used cars at a loss. And the more such previously leased cars they try to unload, the further prices will fall.
So far, the companies seem to have guessed right. The used-car prices are higher than expected two or three years ago, meaning that Ford, the leader in leasing, is doing fine. At the moment, residual values of Mercury Cougars are coming in at 103 percent of projections made by Ford two or three years ago.
The great wave of recently leased vehicles has not hit yet, and some of Ford's competitors have suggested that the company is overexposed. "Quite frankly, we think that some of our competitors perhaps went a little too far in terms of their incentivization of leasing," said J. Michael Losh, chief financial officer for General Motors. Leases by G.M.'s financing arm account for about 12 percent of the company's retail transactions. By contrast, Ford finances leases for about 20 percent of its transactions.
 The volume of vehicles reaching the market after a two- or three-year lease will more than double this year to 1,073,000, according to Art Spinella, vice president and general manager of CNW Marketing/Research, a Bandon, Ore., company that tracks leasing. By 1997, he said, volume will grow to 2,750,000, with leases on most vehicles ending in the summer. By then, most auto analysts predict that new car demand will have slackened.
"You watch: July and August 1997, it'll be mayhem," Mr. Spinella said. "That's the reason some people are worrying about it now. But most aren't."
Ford says it is not concerned that prices will fall with the surge of used cars. "Two-year-old vehicles have always been in short supply in the industry," Mr. Jordan, the Ford sales director, said.
Another way to keep used-vehicle prices high in the United States is to keep the supply down. Mr. Jordan said Ford was considering exporting used vehicles for sale abroad.
Ford has also become more sophisticated about designing its vehicles, to keep residual values high. The developers of Ford's new Windstar mini-van decided against offering a "stripper" version, which would have been shorter and cheaper, with fewer standard features.
A cheaper version today would make the vans less valuable later as used cars. "In the short term you probably do sacrifice some sales," said David M. Ford, program manager for multipurpose vehicles at Ford. But, he added, "I'm not sure, longer term, it does you a lot of good having a stripper version that denigrates the image of the vehicle."
 
A Potential Threat
 Of course, one risk is that buyers may decide that two-year-old cars -- with detailed ownership histories and full warranties -- are better bargains than new ones.
Executives with several auto makers insisted that a two-year-old vehicle, even with a warranty, is clearly a used car, and would cause no such confusion. "That's one theory," Mr. Ferron of J. D. Power said. "The other theory is, that's hogwash." Mr. Ferron said that value-conscious buyers were increasingly willing to consider used vehicles.
That is what Catherine Williams did. A Milwaukee police officer, Ms. Williams recently bought a 1991 Subaru Legacy station wagon, after making a deal on a new Subaru subcompact. "I didn't have to get a trimmed-down version of the car," she said. "I got power everything, air-conditioning, a good stereo."
Detroit executives are sensitive about this issue because they made a horrendous mistake in the late 1980's. They pumped up sales by encouraging rental car companies to replace cars as often as every four months. Those so-called "program cars" turned up on used-car lots as low-mileage "nearly new" cars and began to attract new-car customers.
"We don't want to create the kind of problem with leasing returns that we created with daily rental car returns a couple years ago," Mr. Losh of General Motors said.
 So far, dealers say the only problem with the used-car market is too few vehicles. This market tends to parallel the market for new vehicles, rising for the same reasons: high consumer confidence combined with aging vehicles on the road, prompting buyers to trade up and trade in.
But used-car prices appear sensitive to changes in volume. This spring, for example, prices of used vehicles actually fell slightly, said Patrick C. Jackman, a senior economist at the Labor Department. That dip coincided with a boom in new-car sales, and hence in trade-ins, at the beginning of the year.
An important reason that used-car prices are high now, dealers say, is that new-car sales were slack for several years, meaning people were not trading in their cars and pumping up the used-car supply. Another reason is that the auto makers insist that rental companies keep their fleet cars longer. As the recovery continues and new-car buyers trade in their vehicles, Mr. Jackman said, used-car prices are likely to soften.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Prepares a Takeover Of Newark's Desperate Schools

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 22

 BODY:
The New Jersey Education Department said today that it was prepared to take control of Newark's troubled schools. It issued a damning report that portrays the district as badly mismanaged by officials who sit aloof in comfortable offices while students struggle through badly taught classes in filthy buildings and ultimately fail in great numbers.
Officials of the Newark district, the state's largest, have 20 days to respond to an order from Education Commissioner Leo F. Klagholz that requires them to demonstrate in court why there should be no takeover. Newark officials vowed again today to resist state control, meaning the long, complicated process of takeover could drag on for another year. 
 If that fight is unsuccessful, Newark would become the third district to be controlled by the state. Jersey City's school system, the state's second largest, was taken over in 1989 after a long battle. Paterson, the state's third-largest system, was taken over in 1991.
New Jersey's action is in line with a national trend toward fighting educational collapse not by focusing on money -- Newark spends as much per pupil on its public schools as Princeton -- but by directly attacking school administrations viewed as derelict. [News analysis, page 24.]
In its report today, the state spared almost no one and nothing in the school system from criticism.
"The Newark School District has been at best flagrantly delinquent and at worst deceptive in discharging its obligations to the children enrolled in public schools," the report said. "Already at risk of school failure because of economic disadvantage, children in the Newark public schools are placed at greater risk by school district personnel who fail to provide them with the opportunity to achieve academically in a safe, healthful environment."
Eugene C. Campbell, the Newark executive superintendent, could not be reached for comment about the report; school officials said he would be unable to comment anyway because he had not read the report until this morning. Evelyn Williams, president of the Newark school board, said she could not comment on the report until she had read it. But she said she was "absolutely, categorically opposed to state takeover."
Toni Randolph, a spokeswoman for the 48,000-student district, said state control was not the solution to the system's problems.
"We're willing to fight all the way," she said.
At a news conference this afternoon, Mayor Sharpe James of Newark said that the state takeovers of Jersey City and Paterson had yet to raise test scores in those districts and charged that political motives were behind the state's move.
"We should be very clear in our message that the children are the losers in this power play," he said. "A state takeover is a power play that helps certain assemblymen get re-elected."
The evidence against the system was laid out today in a report called a comprehensive compliance investigation that is the fourth stage leading to state takeover. Newark schools failed the first three levels of monitoring, and have failed to receive state certification since 1984, when the state began its current system of monitoring public schools.
Although the move toward state takeover in heavily-Democratic Newark comes under a Republican Governor, it has dragged on for a decade under both Republican and Democratic leadership. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has called takeover a last resort, but said that she will support the decision of the Education Commissioner and the state board. The Governor has no direct power in the takeover.
 
Struggle for Achievement
 The action also comes as New Jersey is struggling to raise its troubled urban districts to the level of educational achievement in its richer, suburban systems. Earlier this month, in declaring the state's method of financing public schools unconstitutional, the New Jersey Supreme Court said that the state must not only spend the same amount of money on students in poor urban districts as on those in wealthier systems, but must also guarantee urban students the same educational opportunity as their suburban counterparts.
Per pupil spending in Newark, $10,700 in 1992-93, is well above the state average of $8,571. Yet Newark's students fare poorly on every indicator of educational achievement used by the state.
The district's graduation rate is 54 percent, near the bottom of even the 30 so-called special needs urban districts that are the focus of school finance reform in the state. Its students routinely score at or near the bottom on state standardized tests: only 25 percent of eleventh grade students were able to pass all sections of a state high school proficiency test in 1993.
Average daily attendance in 1992 was 90 percent, one of the lowest rates in the state. But the report said that even that number might be inflated. Investigators found numerous instances of careless or nonexistent attendance records, the report said. At Weequahic High School in Newark, for example, all students were reported present for 16 consecutive days in June 1993. And one principal asked state investigators why they thought he would bother to keep attendance records at all.
The 1,100-page report portrays a system wounded by mismanagement, loose fiscal policies and blatant conflicts of interest. In one example, a senior business office official signed documents awarding contracts to a vendor for which he is a consultant. The vendor does more than $1 million in business with the district.
In another example, the district pays $18,300 a year to lease a hangar at Newark Airport for an aerospace class that has not existed for several years.
The report paints the school board as indifferent to parents and the community, disinterested and unfamiliar with issues of curriculum and instruction.
"Faced with a recent cutback in external funding for the Chapter One remedial program, for example, the board concerned itself primarily with staff assignments and job security rather than with the impact on the children's learning," the report said.
Educational programs are unchallenging and badly taught, the report said. Students lack sufficient textbooks, supplies and equipment. Instruction in most classes is textbook-driven and focused on rote memorization. There is little writing and little encouragement of independent reading, the report said. A number of teachers are uncertified; some were observed giving incorrect information to students to study.
 
Special Students Isolated
 Particularly disturbing, the report said, is the segregation of special education students in separate school buildings, rather than integrating them into neighborhood schools as required by Federal and state law.
The report found that many of the district's buildings had been remodeled or renovated without county and state approval, but still suffered from poor maintenance and neglect. Many schools are more than 100 years old.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a report issued yesterday, the New Jersey Education Department said that it was prepared to take control of Newark's troubled schools. Chart: "What Was Found: The Newark Schools -- Failing Grades
 Problems identified by the New Jersey State Education Department.
 
STUDENT ACHIEVEMENT
 From the third grade to the sixth grade, the percentage of children meeting state minimum requirements in basic skills tests drops off more sharply than anywhere in the state. And students identified as low achievers in eighth-grade "early warning tests" show little improvement in later tests. Consequently, the majority of students who remain in Newark schools through the 12th grade "are in danger of leaving high school without diplomas."
 The average daily attendance for 1992-93 was only about 90 percent, one of the lowest of any district in New Jersey. And the report says the actual rate may be lower because of poor bookkeeping; at one school a principal responded to a state request for attendance figures by asking "What would I do with that information.
 
INSTRUCTION
 Instruction is "unchallenging and often misdirected or inappropriate. Few instances were found ... of children being encouraged to generate their own ideas, to collaborate in problem-solving activities, to write in class, to read widely and independently or to use skills and facts in context."
 
STAFF
 Some teachers and other professional staff "were observed to lack an understanding of the subjects they were teaching and to give misinformation for children to copy into their notebooks."
 
SERVICES
 At one school the principal directs the custodians to lock all bathrooms and allows students to use bathrooms only when the whole class is scheduled to go.
 Public transportation is "hazardous." Children ride in school buses that are operated by improperly licensed drivers, lack proper safety equipment and have not been properly inspected.
Food services program is not properly monitored; cafeterias "often do not provide the size of portions or nutritional components described in their published menus."
 
ADMINISTRATION
 While the schools are "badly neglected," administrators work in "comfortable offices." The report says central administrators "accomplish little of value and drain needed resources from students."
 A significant backlog of authorized (many before 1986) but uncompleted captial projects totaling $122 million existed on June 30.
 An unsafe, vermin-infested building was leased for a school at an annual rent of more than $175,000. The report says two Newark Board of Education employees benefit financially from the arrangment.
 Prospective vendors were "strongly pressured" to contribute $1,000 to an "Executive Superintendent's Scholarship Fund;" this fund is not registered with the attorney general as required by a state law govering charities. (pg. 24)
