HEADLINE: CUTTING THE LOSSES: A SPECIAL REPORT;
Lessons in the Rubble of the Coliseum Deal

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER with SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
For a decade, it survived design flaws, political miscalculations and years of litigation. But in the end the collapse last week of a plan to build a huge office and retail center at the site of the New York Coliseum was brought about by two overriding forces: the dramatic changes in New York City's economy and the weight of years of bitter negotiations that left the parties mired in mistrust and inflexibility.
The demise of the project, which Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the developer and publisher, had intended to call Columbus Center, has left a trail of recrimination, with Mr. Zuckerman and the owner of the site, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, blaming each other for the debacle. 
 Although both the M.T.A. and Mr. Zuckerman insist they were trying to make the final deal work, each side suspects that the other never really wanted it to go forward. Clearly neither was willing to take on added economic risks to make it happen.
In fact, both managed to benefit somewhat in the way the deal finally ended: Mr. Zuckerman reduced his potential losses from $34 million to $17 million, and the M.T.A. was able to end its relationship with Mr. Zuckerman and start from scratch, something the agency had wanted to do for most of the last two years.
Meanwhile, the complex's 10-story office building remains occupied, and the Coliseum is used from time to time for exhibitions and shows.
Many experts now see the Coliseum saga as a case study in what not to do with important urban parcels. The plan was revised (and reduced) three times. It was approved twice by the Board of Estimate. It was struck down once in court and upheld once. It was intended by its government sponsors to yield the largest possible sale price with urban design a secondary concern and then rammed unaltered through the city's approval process -- decisions that helped provoke vehement opposition from planners, architects and civic groups.
But the decisive blow probably came on Oct. 19, 1987, the day the stock market crashed, eventually taking with it the economic boom in which Mr. Zuckerman's project was conceived.
"In a sense this was the quintessential 80's project; it only made sense in terms of the strong economy of the 80's," said Abraham Biderman, a former city Finance and Housing Commissioner who for most of the decade was Mayor Edward I. Koch's point man on Columbus Circle.
"It didn't happen because there was just a small moment in history, an ideal time, when it could have happened, and that was between 1985 and 1987," Mr. Biderman said. "After 1987, it just became much more difficult, but not impossible."
It finally became impossible in the last six weeks. Talks over the latest plan were abandoned when the developer and M.T.A. officials could not agree on what seemed, on the surface at least, like a small detail. How would the developer insure liability during demolition? What guarantees would he offer if an attached office building were to be damaged while the Coliseum's exhibition hall was being razed?
 
Distrust on Both Sides
 By the time that question came up, the years of revisions and renegotiations had clearly taken their toll, many of the participants said this week. Some M.T.A. officials suspected that Mr. Zuckerman was no longer serious about trying to build on the site at 59th and Broadway, and was concerned mainly with cutting his losses.
On the other side, the Zuckerman team suspected that the M.T.A., and its chairman, Peter E. Stangl, had no desire to complete a deal with Mr. Zuckerman and was raising new conditions in the hopes of scuttling the deal and starting anew.
Both sides dug in their heels, and by last Friday, four hours before yet another deadline, everyone agreed that there was no more point in talking. The endgame had been concluded; the project was dead.
For the parties, the outcome was mixed. Although the M.T.A. gets its chance to start over, it still faces the possibility of a lawsuit by Mr. Zuckerman seeking to recover his deposit.
Mr. Zuckerman was able to cut his potential losses by $17 million, but beyond that his balance sheet is unclear. He has said often that he also spent more than $100 million during the decade-long effort, much of it in fees for lawyers and architects, along with steel and marble ordered in the mid-1980's.
 
$95 Million From Salomon Brothers
 But Mr. Zuckerman received $95 million from Salomon Brothers, the investment banking company, when it withdrew as the project's prime tenant and co-investor in 1987. Although Mr. Zuckerman's partner, Edward H. Linde, said that the payment did not cover all the expenses, other experts said they could not see how their costs could have been that high.
"Zuckerman isn't coming out badly," said Peter D. Salins, director of the graduate program in urban planning at Hunter College and a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute. "He is making a healthy profit."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani did not get the compromise he had been seeking since taking office. His aides had pushed hard to mediate between the M.T.A. and Mr. Zuckerman, whose newspaper, The Daily News, endorsed Mr. Giuliani in last year's election.
Critics suggested that the Mayor was doing it to help Mr. Zuckerman get a better deal, but the Mayor said he wanted the project to go forward because it would mean construction jobs and a psychic boost for the economy. In the end Mr. Giuliani got no jobs.
 
Original Proposal
Perfect Marriage Quickly in Trouble
 When the city and the M.T.A. first dreamed up the project, in 1983 and 1984, the economy was booming, and continued expansion was an almost universal assumption.
The Jacob Javits Convention Center was about to open on Manhattan's West Side, eliminating the need for the Coliseum, built 30 years earlier by Robert Moses and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. A team assembled by the Koch administration and the Triborough's parent agency, the M.T.A., decided to seek proposals from developers interested in razing the Coliseum and an office building next door and redeveloping the property.
The prime consideration in the competition, it was decided, would be financial -- how much money the developers would offer. The money would be used to help rebuild the subway system and for other important city projects. Design and urban planning were secondary.
Fifteen developers offered proposals, and on July 11, 1985, Mr. Zuckerman's firm, Boston Properties, emerged victorious. He proposed to pay $455 million for the site, on which he planned to build a huge complex containing a hotel, office space, condominiums, stores and movie theaters. Salomon Brothers would be the prime tenant and Mr. Zuckerman's partner in the development.
The complex would contain 2.7 million square feet. Two towers, one 68 stories and the other 58 stories, would rise from a base that would curve in symmetry with the western edge of Columbus Circle.
It seemed to city and state officials like a perfect marriage. The development would raise huge sums of cash for subway renovations, provide as much as $100 million in annual tax revenues, and keep a major securities firm anchored in New York City.
"It was a worthwhile project, and the city would have benefited if it had gone through," Mr. Koch said this week. "I'm really saddened about it."
The project ran into trouble almost immediately. Architects, planners, citywide civic groups and West Side community groups objected both to its size and design.
Much of the criticism was aimed not at Mr. Zuckerman but at the city and the M.T.A., whose desire to maximize the sale price would have forced any developer to build an extremely large complex. Opponents took their fight to the Board of Estimate, the courts and the streets. Bill Moyers and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis were among the opponents' celebrated allies.
Typically, major development proposals are modified as they wind their way through the city's arcane approval process. Proposed buildings are often scaled down, and other changes are made to appease opponents and forge a consensus.
The M.T.A., the developers and the Koch administration took a different tack with Columbus Circle. They knew they had enough votes on the Board of Estimate, so they insisted that the plan could not be altered. Thomas W. Strauss, then the president of Salomon Brothers, threatened to withdraw if changes were made.
In February 1987 the proposal passed overwhelmingly. "We didn't perceive the need to compromise," Mr. Biderman said.
"In retrospect," he added, "it's clear that if we had been a little more accommodating at that point -- and we were acting in what we thought was in the city's best interest -- the outcome might have been different."
 
Renegotiations
City Reluctant To Force Closing
 In December 1987, the project's forward movement ground to a halt. Salomon Brothers withdrew from the project, saying it was forced to revise its "space requirements" after the stock market collapse.
Then, just four days later, a State Supreme Court justice ruled against the city on a suit brought by the Municipal Art Society. Acting Justice Edward H. Lehner invalidated the sale, saying that the city had acted illegally when it made the full purchase price contingent on the developer's obtaining a zoning variance.
Trying to keep his proposal alive, Mr. Zuckerman said he would scale back the plan, setting off a succession of revisions and renegotiations that cut the purchase price from $455 million to $357 million to $338 million. The third version of the plan, approved in May 1989, included a $33.8 million letter of credit that Mr. Zuckerman would forfeit if the deal fell through.
 
Political Considerations
 Lawsuits filed by other opponents, including community groups and local elected officials, kept the plan on hold for years. But even after the final lawsuit was thrown out in June 1992, the Dinkins administration did not press Mr. Zuckerman to close the sale of the land or lose his $33.8 million. The city was reluctant to start all over again and preferred to save the project by renegotiating its price and size one more time.
Two former aides to Mayor David N. Dinkins said he was also reluctant to force Mr. Zuckerman to complete the sale on the 1989 terms for fear that Mr. Zuckerman, who had acquired The Daily News, might retaliate by endorsing his opponent in the 1993 mayoral campaign.
The administration was also unwilling to push Mr. Zuckerman because he was deciding last year whether to build a new printing plant for The Daily News in New York or New Jersey, the Dinkins aides said. (He eventually choose New Jersey.)
M.T.A. officials, however, pushed the city to force Mr. Zuckerman to close the sale.
 
The Collapse
Neither Side Is Satisfied
 By November the dynamics had clearly changed. The Daily News did endorse Mr. Dinkins's opponent, Mr. Giuliani, who went on to win the election. A month later the Dinkins administration finally sided with the M.T.A. and issued a 90-day deadline to Mr. Zuckerman.
Senior Dinkins advisers insisted at the time that the decision did not represent political revenge as Mr. Zuckerman contended, but came only after they got a crucial assurance from the M.T.A. that the city would remain involved in planning for the site. Still, the two former Dinkins aides said this week that politics had also played a role.
With Mr. Giuliani in office, the alliances shifted again. Now the developer had a firm advocate in City Hall, and the M.T.A. essentially stood alone. Arguing that the slumping real-estate market had reduced the value of the Coliseum parcel, Giuliani aides began to pressure the M.T.A. to work out a new deal that would sharply cut the price Mr. Zuckerman would have to pay.
And as the pressure grew, so did the tensions and backbiting.
"In negotiations where there is so much at stake," one participant said, "you expect a certain level of tension. But clearly there was no love lost among this group."
The involvement of John S. Dyson, the outspoken Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, and his insistence that the two sides complete a deal, complicated matters, the participant said.
The day after the deal collapsed, Mr. Dyson said, "I have never dealt with as difficult and as unpleasant a bunch of people to do business with as the people at the M.T.A."
In June, the M.T.A. and the developers agreed to a compromise under which Mr. Zuckerman would get the north half of the four-acre site for less than a quarter of the original price -- $100 million. Of that, the city agreed to pay $20 million.
Some independent people thought Mr. Zuckerman should have been pushed to complete the purchase on the 1989 terms or withdraw from the project and lose his deposit.
"I like Mort Zuckerman," Mr. Koch said, "but I thought it was an error to let him out of the original deal."
"You're going to tell me that the market's changed and now the property is worth less that it was before?" he said. Then, answering his own question with an expletive, Mr. Koch said, in essence, too bad.
 
Both Sides Displeased
 Neither side was truly satisfied with the new deal. M.T.A. officials felt they were pushed into a corner, and the developer expressed displeasure at being forced to agree to a host of new obligations, including the $6 million cost of restoring the Coliseum garage.
The parties then turned to the task of writing a new contract that would formalize the agreement. But it soon became apparent just how difficult a deal the M.T.A. and the developers had devised for themselves when they agreed to cut the property in half.
One issue in particular illustrated the gulf between the parties. It concerned the M.T.A.'s request from the developers for some sort of financial guarantee to cover the potential damage during the delicate process of separating the office building from the exhibition hall.
Mr. Linde, Mr. Zuckerman's partner, agreed to three means of security, including construction and completion bonds to be posted before demolition began.
For the M.T.A. that was not enough. It sought security in the form of letter of credit or some other asset.
Deadline day, July 15, dawned with several key parts of the contract still unsettled. In addition to the issue of financial security over the separation work, the parties remained apart on the basic agreement as well as matters as mundane as the number of parking spaces in the garage the developers and M.T.A. would share.
 
Unable to Coax a Compromise
 After meeting less than two hours at the offices of the transit agency's lawyers, Bachner Tally Polevoy & Misher, little was settled, and the parties agreed to a timeout.
Mr. Linde left to consult with Mr. Zuckerman, who did not attend the sessions. The M.T.A.'s representatives met with Mr. Stangl, who also was not present.
Starting in the late afternoon, Mr. Dyson shuttled between the parties, now in separate conference rooms, in an effort to coax a compromise on the liability issue. But with four hours left before the M.T.A.'s deadline, the talks broke down. Each side accused the other of walking away first.
Many of the people who have been involved with the Coliseum proposal over the years say it offers some long-term civic lessons.
In a public-private partnership for a large development, they say, the government has to operate more like a business, not allowing projects to be continually renegotiated.
"I think we've created an overall environment that's bad for these partnerships in general," said Richard A. Kahan, a former developer who also once headed the Battery Park City Authority. "How does the private sector know when you can renegotiate with the government and when you can't?"
In addition, he said, the government sponsors and the private developers have to pay more attention to designing projects that have broad appeal to an array of critical constituencies.
"You can get the votes and you can win the litigation," Mr. Kahan said, "but you need a real partnership for it to work."

HEADLINE: Judge in Simpson Case Goes by the Rules

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 22

 BODY:
Judge Lance A. Ito, soon to become the most closely watched judge in the country as he presides over the O. J. Simpson trial, has two main standards for handling high-profile cases.
"Rule 1: Be cautious, careful and when in doubt, keep your mouth shut," he says. "Rule 2: When tempted to say something, take a deep breath and refer to Rule 1." 
 Those cautions, part of a course he teaches for judges called "Media and the Courts -- Handling the High-Profile Case," were quoted in a recent interview in which he told The Daily Journal, a local legal journal, that a judge "would have to be crazy" to want to try the Simpson case.
Judge Ito, the assistant presiding judge of the Los Angeles Superior Court, was named today by his superior, Judge Cecil J. Mills, to handle what has already become the most intensely covered and thoroughly second-guessed televised legal proceeding in history.
 
Appointment Wins Praise
 "I think you would have to be crazy to want that case," the 43-year-old judge said in the interview earlier this week. "Being the trial judge is the worst position in a major high-profile case. You can't call a press conference to explain your side of things."
The selection of Judge Ito, a former prosecutor, drew widespread praise today from defense lawyers, who called him intelligent, hard-working and balanced, with a dry sense of humor that he uses to defuse courtroom tensions.
"He is very sensitive to the needs of trial lawyers and allows them to do their work," said Blair Bernholz, a defense lawyer here. "But there's never any question who is in control of the courtroom. He keeps a firm hand."
Janet Kerr, a law professor at Pepperdine University who has advised Judge Ito as a technical expert, said: "I believe him to be a brilliant judge who's willing to listen intently to many different sides of an issue and who makes very well-reasoned decisions. He does have a very dry sense of humor. I think he adds a lot of personality in the courtroom."
After Judge Ito's appointment was announced, Mr. Simpson's chief lawyer, Robert L. Shapiro, called him "an excellent choice because he is one of the finest judges in the state of California."
 
Trial Judge of the Year
 Judge Ito, the son of schoolteachers, graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles with honors in political science in 1972, and from the University of California at Berkeley law school in 1975.
After working for a decade as a prosecutor, he became a Municipal Court judge in 1987 and was named to the Superior Court in 1989. The Los Angeles County Bar Association named him trial judge of the year for 1992.
Judge Ito's most high-profile case was the securities fraud prosecution in 1991 of Charles H. Keating Jr., the former owner of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. In a controversial ruling in the case, Judge Ito dismissed about half the charges. Then, when Mr. Keating was convicted, Judge Ito sentenced him to the maximum term of 10 years in prison.
In court this morning, Judge Mills informed the prosecutors and defense lawyers -- as judges routinely do at the start of cases -- of a potential conflict of interest: Judge Ito's wife, Margaret Ann York, is a former homicide detective and is a captain in the Los Angeles Police Department. As such, she is the highest ranking woman on the force. Lawyers for both sides in the case agreed to accept Judge Ito.
 
Victims Become Reluctant
 Judge Ito has handled domestic violence cases and has complained of the difficulty of prosecuting crimes in which the victims sometimes refuse to testify.
After one recent case was dropped when the victim changed her testimony to claim she had been mugged, Judge Ito told The Los Angeles Times: "Often there are serious injuries and implausible explanations as to how it happened. The problem is, 75 to 90 days later, when the case comes to trial, emotions have cooled down, economic realities have set in and victims often become reluctant."
In the Simpson case, Judge Ito has already presided over the pretrial hearing at which a grand jury investigation was halted and is one of the few people who know what is contained in a mysterious envelope that was presented in court earlier this month.
Mr. Shapiro had approached Judge Ito about an item of evidence he had uncovered, and after a closed hearing, the judge named a retired judge, Delbert Wong, to receive and seal the item. The nature of the evidence in the envelope remains one of the tantalizing unknowns of the case.

HEADLINE: Kimberley Journal;
The Revolution Won, Workers Are Still Unhappy

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIMBERLEY, South Africa

 BODY:
Second only to the African National Congress, South African labor unions provided the political muscle that overturned apartheid and the brains that now govern the country.
So naturally the black women who toil over knitting machines for 50 cents an hour in Taiwanese-owned sweater factories here expected the election of Nelson Mandela to bring payback time -- a union shop, better wages and a little respect. 
 "It's our turn to be treated as human beings," said Clara Monethi, a shop steward for the Southern African Clothing and Textile Workers Union.
Instead, at the first sign of post-election unrest in the mills of Kimberley, a mining and textiles center 300 miles southwest of Johannesburg, the Taiwanese owners abruptly closed their seven factories, and the union is now fighting to save 1,000 jobs.
Here, as in much of the reborn South Africa, the soaring hopes of workers have collided with the new economic reality, creating a fallout of strikes and disenchantment.
Unionists who regard themselves as heroes of the liberation struggle often find themselves pilloried as an impediment to foreign investment, a menace to economic discipline and potentially a threat to the Government they helped elect, the Government that is South Africa's biggest employer.
Businessmen who thought the election of a black President would mean a period of labor peace have also been sorely disappointed.
In the six months surrounding the April elections, South Africa has lost 1.2 million days of workers' time to strikes, up from the 700,000 in the same period last year, according to Andrew Levy and Associates, an industrial relations consulting firm.
Increasingly, the strikes are not organized walkouts but wildcat protests. Strong union leaders who had the experience and authority to channel worker grievances have been drafted into Parliament and Government ministries.
Johannesburg was unsettled last week by anarchic scenes of conflict reminiscent of past political resistance, when striking grocery clerks rampaged through Pick 'n' Pay grocery stores, and police officers routed them with snarling dogs and rubber bullets.
"A lot of management expected that after the election of a new Government, everything would be hunky dory -- 'Now we've given them power and they can shut up,' " said Renee Grawitsky of Andrew Levy and Associates. "That was naive."
During three decades when the African National Congress was banned, unions became a bastion of political resistance, promoting majority rule and foreign disinvestment as ferociously as better wages.
"What we got was a highly politicized trade union movement, and a militant trade union movement," said Duncan Innes, editor of a newsletter on labor issues.
In addition, South African labor, while relatively expensive, is mainly poorly educated and militant. It has dampened the enthusiasm of many Americans and Europeans scouting investment opportunities here.
Thanks to union successes, labor in South Africa costs twice as much as in Brazil or Mexico, and several times as much as in Thailand or China. Black workers are products of an apartheid education system that deliberately schooled blacks for menial work. Productivity is low.
"The Taiwanese don't understand the South African work ethic," said Pierre Hugo, the lawyer for the factory owners here. "In Taiwan, everybody is productive. In Taiwan, they work seven days a week and take off one Sunday a month to do shopping."
The Taiwanese are regarded by South African unions as hard cases -- secretive, low-paying and ill at ease with black workers -- but in their quest for cheap and cooperative workers they are not alone.
While some union leaders have endorsed more business-friendly arrangements like contracts pegged to worker productivity or profit-sharing plans, ordinary workers feel little sense of a shared stake in the economy. After decades of mutual hostility, they tend to see employers as rich, white beneficiaries of apartheid.
"They still see business as a kind of endless pot from which they can draw ever-increasing wages and there is no end to the process," Mr. Innes said.
He said one major American company recently came to ask him if they could avoid the union altogether by offering premium pay and benefits. No, he replied. Because of their role in fighting apartheid, unions are ingrained in South African culture.
"Workers see the unions as being important," he said. "It's politically correct. We can't bypass the unions. The challenge is to bring them on board."
The new Government is now in the uneasy role of intermediary between the workers who elected it and the business it courts.
Adding to the Government's sense of foreboding, the fastest growing and most militant unions are those representing mainly black hospital workers, teachers and other public employees. They are demanding large raises to match the pay of more privileged white civil servants.
Mr. Mandela's Government is sympathetic, but it also faces a quandary. The more money spent raising the pay of two million public employees, the less there will be for the five million blacks who have no jobs at all.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE EMPLOYER;
Pizza Hut Defends Its Insurance Plans

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Throughout the debate over national health insurance, the hottest issue has been how to pay for it. Today, that question boiled down to the cost of pizza.
At a Senate hearing today, Allan S. Huston, president of Pizza Hut, a division of Pepsico Inc., said that requiring employers to pay for their workers' insurance would mean lost jobs, lower wages and closed businesses. 
 These are the arguments that small businesses and operations like Pizza Hut, with its many low-wage workers, have pressed since President Clinton proposed a system of universal health care coverage financed largely by employers. Although Pizza Hut, with 10,000 stores in 47 countries, is neither small nor struggling, it says it has to keep its costs down to compete with less-expensive restaurants and home cooking.
 
'Double Standard'
 As they have in the past, advocates of universal insurance coverage retorted that some businesses were exaggerating their fears to duck responsibility to their workers. And they repeated their argument, made at a news conference last week, that if large chains like Pizza Hut or McDonald's could afford to insure workers in countries where they were required to do so, then they could afford it here. "An unacceptable double standard," the chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, called it at his committee's hearing today.
The question of employer payments is a central sticking point as Democratic leaders in Congress work to turn proposals passed by four committees into legislation for consideration on the House and Senate floors this summer.
Mr. Huston told the Labor committee today that if Pizza Hut had to provide health benefits for thousands of hourly workers its restaurants would have to "either raise prices, which will lead to a falloff in sales and eventually lost jobs, or eliminate jobs at the start."
Pizza Hut could not easily raise its prices, Mr. Huston said, because "customers have a choice: they can eat at home." Mr. Houston said an employer mandate could push the average price of an $11 pizza up by $1.10 because health insurance costs would start a snowball effect of higher prices begetting a drop in sales volume, begetting higher costs, begetting higher prices, and so on.
 
Adjusting to Shock
 But advocates of national health insurance said the increased costs would be more modest. Under the Senate Labor committee bill, for example, the increase would be limited to 12 percent of payroll. Pizza Hut says its payroll is 30 percent of its costs, so the presumed increase for an $11 pizza would be 40 cents.
If fast-food chains had to provide insurance, "some fewer hamburgers would be eaten, but my hunch is it wouldn't be a lot fewer," Uwe Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University, said in an interview. "This product is so favorably priced, people would adjust to the shock."
Mr. Clinton, speaking to governors this week, said, "If all your competitors are in the same boat you are in, you don't go broke doing this."
The Health Care Reform Project, a coalition of groups seeking to require employers to pay for insurance, also raised the issue in newspaper advertisements last week. The group noted that Pizza Hut provides health insurance to workers in Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Japan, where employers are required to do so.
 
Unwanted Spiral
 Mr. Huston said the requirement in Europe, and elsewhere where employee social benefits were costly, contributed to a "descending spiral of higher prices and unemployment." Without the cost burden, he said, his chain expanded much faster at home than abroad. He said the company had lost money for 10 of the last 11 years in its 65 German stores at a time when it was opening hundreds of new restaurants in the United States.
Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader and an opponent of employer mandates, took the Senate floor today to defend Pizza Hut, whose headquarters are in his home state of Kansas. "I don't know what company or industry will next be attacked by the White House, the Democratic National Comittee or their allies," he said, "but from the arguments they use, I know that they like their pizzas with a lot of baloney."
Pizza Hut store managers receive company-paid benefits, which they can use for medical, dental or other needs. Mr. Huston said most other employees are young, part-time workers who receive the $4.25 hourly minimum wage, or $170 for a 40-hour week. During their first six months of employment, they may buy basic coverage for $11 a week, though the company says 70 percent rely on family coverage provided by other employers. After six months on the job, hourly workers who bought the $11 basic plan receive a small additional contribution from Pizza Hut that increases the workers' benefits.
 
Big Mac, Fries and a Cola
 An executive of McDonald's was invited to the hearing today, Senator Kennedy said, but declined to appear. At the witness table, to underscore the absence of the executive, the committee's staff placed a Big Mac hamburger, french fries and a soft drink.
David Adelman, a restaurant securities analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, said the costs for a well-run, profitable, company-operated McDonald's store would typically be: labor, 25 percent; food, 30 percent; store overhead (rent, utilities, supplies, breakage and pilfering from the cash register), 23 percent; corporate overhead, 10 percent, and pretax profit, 12 percent.
The National Federation of Independent Business, a small-business group that lobbies vigorously against employer mandates, asked members last fall how they would deal with a 3.5 percent increase in their health care costs. Thirty-five percent said they would raise prices; 40 percent would reduce jobs, wages or benefits; 17 percent would cut profits, and 2 percent would shut down.
 
Shared Responsibility
 Opponents of the employer mandates also said they feared that employer contributions would eventually be raised if Government financing failed to cover health costs.
But 50 large businesses and business associations endorsed "shared employer responsibility" in a letter to Congressional leaders last week. Walter Maher, an official of the Chrysler Corporation, said the debate was "between those businesses that are providing benefits and those who aren't." He said the ability of American manufacturers to compete overseas was being weakened because they must absorb health care costs other American companies are not absorbing.
"The retail sector, fast foods, and much of the service sector don't provide health coverage," Mr. Maher said. "And they are not in global competition. We end up adding to the cost of production" for manufacturers who not only provide coverage but compete abroad.

HEADLINE: Robert Rodriguez, 43, Politician And Affirmative-Action Official

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Robert Rodriguez, a leader of New York's Hispanic community and former New York City Councilman from East Harlem-South Bronx, died on Sunday at the apartment of a friend in Albany. Mr. Rodriguez was 43.
The cause was a heart attack, the Albany County Coroner's office said. Mr. Rodriguez, who had been working for the State Department of Civil Service in Albany, was using the apartment of the friend, State Assemblyman Angelo Del Toro, a Democrat of Manhattan, while Mr. Del Toro was in New York City during the legislative recess. 
 At his death, Mr. Rodriguez was overseeing affirmative-action and diversity programs in state agencies for the Department of Civil Service. He joined the department 14 months ago to direct its Division of Diversity, Planning and Management.
Mr. Rodriguez had been active in community affairs in Manhattan, serving on the boards of Community School District No. 4, Metropolitan Hospital Center, the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, the East Harlem district of the Boy Scouts of America and the Edwin Gould Services for Children Foundation. He was a past chairman of the Community Mental Health Center, a Democratic district leader and a member of Community Planning Board No. 11 in East Harlem.
In 1979 he was a coordinator in New York's Hispanic community for Jimmy Carter's Presidential campaign.
Mr. Rodriguez was a member of the City Council from 1978 to 1982. He lost the Democratic primary that year to Carolyn B. Maloney, now a member of Congress.
He graduated from Alfred E. Smith High School in the Bronx and studied history at Nyack College. Before his election to the City Council, he was a senior employment consultant for the State Department of Labor's Equal Employment Opportunity Office in Manhattan.
More recently, he was director of labor relations in the city's Fire Department and chief of staff for Assemblyman Jose Serrano, after which he held executive positions at the SCS Business and Technical Institute in Manhattan and with the state's Hispanic Housing and Economic Development Task Force.
Mr. Rodriguez's survivors include his wife, Edith Delerme Rodriguez; his parents, Carmen and Juan Rodriguez; two sons, Robert J. and Jonathan R., and a daughter, Tina Rasheen, all of New York City.

HEADLINE: Will New York Accept Its Personal Credit Card?

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
It sounds like a David Letterman routine: New York, New York, the city that was tottering on the brink of bankruptcy 20 years ago, is considering creating its own credit card.
But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had instructed city officials to look into the possibility of entering a partnership with a bank or credit-card company to offer a New York City card -- with some of the proceeds from sales going to the city treasury. 
 The arrangement the city is considering -- called an "affinity card" in the industry -- has been used in recent years by universities, sports franchises, environmental groups and radio stations to raise money and promote themselves.
New York would not actually be involved in lending money or dunning deadbeats. Rather, Visa, American Express or some other major credit-card company would issue a card featuring the city's name and some appropriate logo. Customers could say "I Love New York" with plastic, and the city would get a cut of the credit-card company's profit. The company benefits because the city promotes the card and creates new customers.
The Mayor said such a card could be sponsored by the city as a whole or by some agency like the Housing Authority or the Human Resources Administration.
John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said the idea of an affinity card was first broached by several credit-card companies.
"They're now doing cities and they asked us if we'd consider it," he said, envisioning cards emblazoned with the Statue of Liberty, the New York skyline, or, perhaps, a picture of the Mayor.
Mr. Dyson said that university affiliation cards could provide a model of how such a card would work.
"The college or university gets a very tiny fee for that association with Mastercard, Visa card -- I guess we wouldn't do Mastercard anymore," said Mr. Dyson, still smarting over Mastercard International's announcement last week that it was relocating its headquarters and 550 jobs from Manhattan to Westchester. The city, he said, would pick "someone who's not leaving home without us."
Mr. Dyson said he thought such a credit card could bring $1 million a year into city coffers or more depending on how many people choose to use the card and the volume of sales that were generated.
Plano, Texas already offers a city Visa card. And closer to home, South Orange, N. J. is preparing to issue the South Orange Mastercard in September.
"You can't keep asking taxpayers for money," said William R. Calabrese, a pharmacist who is the South Orange Village President. "So we decided how to find extra sources of revenue. I own a pharmacy and see affinity cards all year long, so we went to see if a municipality could do it."
Mr. Giuliani said that he had asked Corporation Counsel Paul A. Crotty to examine the legal aspects of starting a city credit card and Budget Director Abraham M. Lackman and Business Services Commissioner Rudy Washington to examine the fiscal aspects.
Mr. Dyson said that the city had already discovered one potential stumbling block to a credit-card plan -- that a firm, which he did not identify, was already offering New York credit cards "without any authorization." City lawyers, he said, would have to press the company to "cease and desist" so New York can license its name.
Mr. Giuliani did not say how long it would take him to make a decision. In the meantime, can Mr. Letterman resist? What are the top 10 reasons for getting a New York City credit card?

GRAPHIC: Photo: New York City is considering the possibility of entering a partnership with a bank or credit-card company to offer a New York City card similar to the one, shown as a large mock up, South Orange, N.J. is to issue in September. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE RWANDA DISASTER: THE OVERVIEW;
PRESIDENT ORDERS PENTAGON ACTION TO AID RWANDANS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
President Clinton ordered the Pentagon today to mount an enormous, urgent airlift to funnel relief supplies from around the world into Africa in an attempt to control the catastrophe facing more than a million Rwandan refugees now in Zaire.
 The American relief mission, which White House officials said was designed to mobilize a worldwide effort, was described by the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, as "a race against time." But with every minute tolling another death at the cholera-stricken camps in Zaire, officials said it would take several days to mobilize the airlift fully. 
Setting up the airlift, involving installing the panoply of equipment that comes with modern airfields, is a task beyond the abilities of international relief organizations, and was the most significant new contribution on a day when Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali appealed for international aid to help alleviate the suffering of the Rwandan refugees. [Page 4.]
 Also today, the European Union pledged an additional $183 million in aid.
 "We're going to be doing everything we can, but there is going to be a time lag here," said J. Brian Atwood, head of the United States Agency for International Development.
 It will take time to supply the refugees with clean water, the one thing they need above all. Cholera, which kills by severe dehydration, is spread through contaminated water.
 In addition to organizing the airlift, the Pentagon was told today to take the leading role in providing water purification and distribution systems to supply 1.2 million refugees.
 But the tasks being undertaken by the Americans cover only about half of the needs described in recent days by relief organizations.
 Mr. Clinton also called on the United Nations to move as quickly as possible to deploy an international peacekeeping force to stabilize Rwanda and persuade refugees to return home. The Pentagon said that it expects to commit about 1,500 troops to the airlift, most of them in Africa, but that beyond security at the airfields, they would not be part of the peacekeeping force, which is being drawn largely from Africa.
 A new urgency seemed to grip the global relief effort today, with the world suddenly recognizing that every moment counts now that disease and hunger have replaced genocide as the main killers in the region. Cholera, in particular, can expand exponentially in the kind of conditions the refugees have created.
 Three months after the resumption of a civil war between Rwanda's two main ethnic groups, hundreds of thousands are dead and four or five million of the country's eight million people have been displaced. About two million of them have fled into neighboring countries, mainly Zaire.
 Mr. Clinton, calling the situation possibly "the world's worst humanitarian crisis in a generation," defended American relief efforts so far. "From the beginning of this tragedy, the United States has been in the forefront of the international community's response," he said.
 The United States has so far provided about 40 percent of all the relief aid in Rwanda, officials said, including about 100 planeloads of supplies, but they acknowledged that much more was needed.
 
'International Effort' Stressed
 "It's to be expected that we would do more than anyone else, but I do want to emphasize that this is an international effort, undertaken through the United Nations," Mr. Atwood of the Agency for International Development said.
 In all, the expanded American relief effort is expected to cost the Pentagon about $100 million, in addition to the $150 million or so already committed by the United States since the Rwandan crisis began in April. About $76 million of the American contributions so far were offered within the last week, too recently for their effect to have been felt yet.
 Mr. Clinton also urged the public to increase charitable donations to the many relief organizations struggling to assist the Rwandans.
 The expansion of the aid effort came after several days of intense criticism of the Administration, which was accused of not doing enough.This morning those criticisms continued in Congress.
 "We have the largest, best-trained army in the world that is catatonic," said Representative Harry A. Johnston, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa, scolding Michael Myers, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Humanitarian and Refugee Affairs, who was briefing the subcommittee on the expansion of aid.
 "It refuses to move," said Mr. Johnston, a Florida Democrat. "It is frozen in place."
 But military officials said they were now moving as rapidly as possible to get supplies, especially water purification equipment, to the scene.
 "It is, in fact, a race against time, and there's no luxury to be sitting on our hands, and we don't intend to do that," General Shalikashvili said.
 Officials said 20 million packages of oral rehydration salts, the first-aid treatment for cholera victims, would be delivered within two days, with other food and medical equipment following right behind.
 Two military transport planes were already bound for Zaire, and were expected to arrive there on Saturday, one carrying medical supplies and the other hauling six 10-ton forklifts, needed to unload an increasing flow of supplies into the camps.
 Beginning on Saturday, officials said, 42 flights would depart carrying 1,480 tons of food and other supplies requested by international relief agencies. The Pentagon is also considering dropping daily food rations by parachute beginning on Sunday.
 But the biggest problem is to provide an adequate supply of clean water, along with other sanitation equipment, and that is likely to take many days. To move water, purification equipment, trucks and other heavy supplies into the remote areas where the refugees have concentrated requires creating a logistical chain with its central base at Entebbe, Uganda, its rearward collection points in Germany and its front lines at the desperately under-equipped airfields in Zaire.About 1,500 military personnel are expected to be involved within a week or so.
 Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch said the Pentagon would take on these logistical tasks:
 *Providing air traffic control for the airfields at Goma and Bukavu in Zaire, and perhaps at other smaller airfields near the refugee centers, letting them operate 24 hours a day.
 *Providing military security at the airfields.
 *Deploying equipment for unloading aircraft from all over the world, trucks for distributing supplies, survey teams to assess where the supplies are most needed, and computer systems to track the supplies.
 *Controlling all flights into and out of Entebbe, fueling the planes, keeping supplies in warehouses and forwarding them to the refugee centers.
 The array of equipment to be moved in a few days is staggering: runway lights, radios, mess halls, pumps, piping, forklifts and the water purification devices themselves, hauled in from the island depot at Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean, Mr. Deutch said.

HEADLINE: Fed Nominee Gives Views on Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Janet L. Yellen, President Clinton's nominee to the Federal Reserve Board, dispelled some of the mystery surrounding her views on interest-rate policy today but did not take a clear position on whether she would support further increases in interest rates this year.
The views that Ms. Yellen sketched out at her confirmation hearing before the Senate Banking Committee today suggested that she might be slightly less willing than her future colleagues to raise rates to curb inflation, but would still fall within the mainstream at the central bank. 
 If confirmed by the full Senate, as seems likely soon, Ms. Yellen would become President Clinton's second appointee on the seven-member Federal Reserve Board. Alan S. Blinder, a former member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, joined the board last month.
 
 
Campaign Consequences
 Some Wall Street economists have speculated that the new nominees may be slightly more reluctant to raise interest rates and slightly more willing to tolerate inflation than the five Republican appointees. The Fed's decisions in the coming months will have a tremendous influence on the health of the American economy in 1996, when President Clinton is expected to seek re-election.
Mr. Blinder at his confirmation hearing in May and Ms. Yellen at her hearing today both sought to present themselves as middle-of-the-road economists who would prevent inflation from rising, while also trying to avoid pushing interest rates to levels that might induce a recession.
But a hint of skepticism about interest-rate increases arose in Ms. Yellen's remarks when she discussed the central bank's four decisions this spring to raise short-term rates.
"I agree with the Fed's decision to reduce monetary stimulus -- before the emergence of obvious inflationary pressure -- in order to avoid overshooting the natural rate" of economic growth, she said. "On the other hand, the appropriate amount of tightening involves some guesswork and it is difficult to know whether the actions that have been taken thus far will prove sufficient to prevent overheating, insufficient to the task at hand or possibly excessive."
By contrast, when Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, testified today before the House Banking Committee, he never mentioned any possibility that the central bank might have gone too far. He repeated warnings from his testimony to the Senate Banking Committee on Wednesday that he saw some warning signs of possible inflation ahead. As he also did on Wednesday, Mr. Greenspan indicated that a fifth increase in the central bank's short-term interest rate target this year was possible in the near future.
Mr. Greenspan warned in particular that the fall in the dollar might signal that investors expected inflation. In previous appearances before Congress this year, he has warned that such expectations can be self-fulfilling and that breaking them with higher interest rates is one of the Fed's top priorities.
 
 
 
Possible Inflation Threats
 In a list of possible sources of future inflation, Mr. Greenspan mentioned rising prices for manufacturing materials, backlogs for some goods and recent shortages of some types of workers, notably in the construction and trucking industries.
The overall tone of Ms. Yellen's comments was not that different from Mr. Greenspan's. She contended that the Fed's target should be to keep the economy growing no faster than growth in the economy's underlying capacity to produce goods and services. And she warned against tolerating inflation so as to achieve short-term reductions in unemployment, saying that inflation would inflict long-run harm to the economy.
But Ms. Yellen, 47, startled some in the audience when she emphasized the needs of working people. "What the Fed should be pursuing is the economic welfare of working people, of all Americans," she said.
The central bank has more commonly been known for its links and sympathies with Wall Street and big commercial banks.
Ms. Yellen is a professor of international business and trade at the University of California at Berkeley and is best known among economists for her writings on wages.
She said she would pursue all of the targets laid out by Congress in a 1978 Democratic amendment to the Fed's charter -- "maximum employment, stable prices and moderate long-term interest rates."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Nigerian Strike Pushing Up Oil Prices to Near $20 Level

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Crude oil prices rose yesterday with nervousness over Nigeria's three-week-long oil workers' strike expected to push a test of the key $20-a-barrel level next week, traders said.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, September crude oil futures rose 22 cents, to $19.61 a barrel. Nymex prices hit $20.43 on July 12 as a result of the Nigerian strike, the first time in a year prices had been above $20. 
 "This market is still a function of Nigeria," said William Brown at W. H. Brown & Company in New York. "The situation hasn't improved that much, so prices may firm a bit more."
Crude rose after the 150,000-member oil union in Nigeria walked out of a meeting with Government officials, abruptly stalling an effort to end a pro-democracy strike that has crippled most business activity.
"What we've seen in the last month is a reluctance to be short over the weekend because there is more risk to the upside near term," said Gerald Samuels, managing director of ARB Oil in Los Angeles.
Traders said oil prices were also affected by tight United States crude supplies, growing oil demand and maintenance work in the North Sea during August that will cut world supplies.
 
Market Awaits Fed Moves
 Gold ended firmer on the Commodities Exchange, but analysts said the market received little direction from Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. August gold ended 70 cents higher at $385 an ounce.
The market was awaiting moves by the Fed to raise interest rates following comments by Mr. Greenspan earlier in the week interpreted as signaling a rate rise soon, analysts said.
New York cotton futures closed their 2-cent limit up, buoyed by heavy buying by speculative funds. December cotton closed at 72.25 cents a pound on worries about tight supplies.
"This is the breakout we have been looking for the last two weeks," said Sharon Johnson, cotton analyst with Frank Schneider & Company. "Fundamentally, the current cash tightness appears to be the bullish factor behind the move."
Cotton hit a three-year high above 78 cents in May on estimates for heavy exports and smaller crops overseas before retreating on profit-taking.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
2d-Quarter Profit Down 28% at Bankers Trust

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Tough trading conditions and a drop in customer demand for derivative securities and risk-management services contributed to a 28 percent drop in second-quarter profits at the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.
Bankers Trust, the nation's seventh-largest banking company, said yesterday that it earned $181 million, or $2.09 a share, in the quarter, down from $251 million, or $2.90 a share, a year earlier. 
 Despite the drop in net income, Timothy Yates, the company's chief financial officer, said that in a number of respects the second-quarter results represented a "strong turnaround" from the first three months of 1994.
 
 
Higher Trading Revenues
 In a conference call with analysts, Mr. Yates said that income from the bank's proprietary trading operations totaled $52 million in the second quarter, compared with a $49 million loss in the first quarter.
Trading revenues were also sharply higher, at $124 million, up from $14 million in the first three months of the year. But the second-quarter number loses much of its luster when compared with the $405 million in trading revenues recorded in the comparable three months of 1993, a period when the bull market for securities of all stripes was surging.
The performance of the bank's derivatives business, once seen as a fairly stable and important moneymaker, shrank sharply.
Profits from derivatives, which are contracts derived from underlying financial assets like stocks, bonds and interest rates, were $50 million in the second quarter, less than half of the record $114 million the bank made on derivatives in the first three months of the year.
"Markets continued to be difficult," Mr. Yates said. To adapt, the bank assumed a risk profile that was "conservative, close to home and opportunistic," he said.
Mr. Yates said the derivatives business was affected by a decline in the use of sophisticated products by both corporations and institutional investors like pension funds and mutual funds.
Although Bankers Trust's earnings were below Wall Street's expectations of $2.43 a share, the company's shares gained 62.5 cents yesterday to close at $65.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Still, many analysts were disappointed by the earnings. "Frankly, we thought the numbers were horrible," said Lawrence W. Cohn, an analyst at Paine Webber Group. "The trading results were quite disappointing, and earnings included a substantial amount of what looks like nonrecurring income."
Among those one-time gains were income stemming from the refinancing of Brazil's commercial bank debt, insurance payments related to a January 1993 fire at the bank's headquarters at 280 Park Avenue in Manhattan, and securities and venture capital gains.
Unlike other big banks, Bankers Trust declined to specify how much Brazil added to its bottom line in the second quarter and refused to say how much all of the one-time earnings added to net income.
"They wouldn't say how much it was," Mr. Cohn said. "It was aggravating."
Outside of trading, Bankers Trust said revenues from funds management rose 6 percent from a year earlier, to $180 million, reflecting growth in services for wealthy clients and new securities-processing business.
Reflecting more difficult conditions, Bankers Trust said expenses were pared in the second quarter by just under 8 percent from the second quarter of last year, to $688 million. Much of that cut was a result of a 35 percent drop in bonus expense, reflecting reduced earnings.
Mr. Cohn said that if financial market conditions remained volatile, the drop in bonus expense would likely be followed by layoffs.
If current trends in financial markets continue for another three to six months, Mr. Cohn added, "bankers and everybody else on Wall Street will be cutting expenses, and people."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies Against Mark But Doesn't Gain vs. the Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against the German mark yesterday as more traders appeared to believe that United States officials want the dollar to rise.
But the dollar failed to advance against the yen because traders fear that there will not be progress in trade negotiations between the United States and Japan. 
 The dollar's rally against most leading currencies yesterday came after the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, told the House Banking Committee, "It is in our interest to have a stronger dollar."
Mr. Greenspan's comments echoed those made on Thursday by Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs, who said that a stronger dollar would restore faith in American financial markets and contain inflation.
For many traders, the two officials' remarks showed that the Fed and the Clinton Administration were no longer at odds over the currency.
"This is the first time since Clinton took office that the Fed, the Treasury and the White House are all on the same side about the dollar," said Angelo Evangelista, vice president in charge of currency trading at the Bank of America.
The dollar tumbled to a post-World War II low against the yen and a 20-month low against the mark earlier this month, in part because traders believed that the Administration wanted the dollar to remain weak.
 
'Edge of the Abyss'
 "Last week, the dollar was teetering at the edge of the abyss," said Marc Cohen, managing director at C-Wave Capital Management, a currency-trading fund in Fort Lee, N.J. "Now it's at a very important crossroads. It will rally across the board if there is a trade deal between the U.S. and Japan."
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.6020 marks, its highest level since July 4, before settling at 1.5985 marks, up from 1.5927 marks. The dollar fell to 98.95 yen yesterday, from 99.20 yen on Thursday.
Mr. Evangelista of the Bank of America said the Clinton Administration had reversed its dollar policy because the currency's weakness contributed to a slump in the bond market. That slump drove up the low interest rates that were central to Mr. Clinton's plan for stimulating the economy and reducing the Federal deficit.
"The U.S. was behaving recklessly with the dollar," Mr. Evangelista said. "They've learned from their mistakes."
In other currency trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 5.4650 French francs, up from 5.4510 francs late yesterday. The dollar strengthened to 1.3567 Swiss francs from 1.3465 francs and rose to 1,587 Italian lire from 1,582 lire. The British pound rose to $1.5275 from $1.5250. The Canadian dollar was steady at 72.61 United States cents.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Thrilling, Dangerous: Betting on Currencies

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty

 BODY:
YOU finish the newspapers, heave a sigh and call your broker. "The yen's done rising," you say. "It's the dollar's day now. Let's take a shot." You lean back, confident you've parsed the currency news as deftly as the billionaire financier George Soros . . .
It's a nice daydream -- but keep it that way, warned Maria Scott of the American Association of Individual Investors. Despite the yen's enticing recent rise, currency plays are too risky and complex for nearly everyone, "even for economists." 
 But Michael Schwartz, senior vice president at Oppenheimer, says investors less flush than Mr. Soros can use currency both to profit and to hedge. Two good vehicles are currency options and their low-priced cousins, currency warrants.
The profits from these bets on currency certainly can be fast and big. Imagine an investor, bullish on the yen's prospects against the dollar, who had spent $1,250 on June 24 for one three-month option to buy yen at 100 yen to the dollar. As the yen rose he could have sold the option on July 12 for $2,638 -- a 111 percent profit in 18 days. (Individuals rarely invoke, or "exercise," options; they are usually just bought and sold, or held as insurance until expiration.)
But there are caveats. Options are for relatively well-off investors, Mr. Schwartz said, and even they "should not go blindly into" this complex market, where fast turns can unseat even the most deft. The yen option worth $2,638 on July 12, for instance, fell to $1,519 on July 19.
And while option investors cannot lose more than the price, or premium -- which ranges from $5 for one warrant to several thousand dollars for an option -- they can lose much or all of that. If the investor was mistakenly bearish on the yen, he might have bought an option to sell yen, a "put," rather than buy them, a "call." But if he did, his premium of $1,556 would have dwindled to $587 by July 12 -- a 62 percent loss in 18 days.
Ms. Scott agrees with these cautions, and then some. Currency plays are exciting, but "they are more betting than investing," she said. Not only do currency movements confound the best, but to make money on them you must get two things right -- where the currency will go and when.
But some may want to play George Soros for a day with a prudently small sum. For them, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange is the place to be. It is the nation's largest marketplace for listed currency options, said Paul Adair, an exchange director.
It is a growing marketplace, too. Through mid-July, 51,225 currency options traded daily on average, up from 42,865 in 1991. Dollar-based options come in eight currencies and the option periods now include 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, 12, 18 and more months. The two nondollar options are the mark-yen and the mark-pound.
After choosing a currency and deciding between a put and a call, an investor must select the option period and the strike price, or the exchange rate that will trigger the option. If yen now trade at 98.5 to the dollar, for instance, an investor might buy a yen put with a strike price of 99.
All these factors affect the premium. Longer option periods cost more, for example, as do strike prices close to the currency's market price.
Similar to currency options in most respects, currency warrants are traded mainly on the American Stock Exchange. Like options, they can be used not just to speculate but also to shield foreign holdings from currency risk, said Nathan Most, a senior vice president at the exchange.
"Suppose I own some stocks in Japan," he said. "The market's been good there, and the rising yen has been an added benefit. But I'm concerned about the yen outlook." With warrants, such an investor can seal in gains against an iffy yen.
True, not many Americans directly own stocks abroad, Mr. Most said. But many do own the foreign stock certificates traded here known as American depository receipts, and the same hedging technique works for them, he said. A.D.R.'s trade for more than 300 large foreign companies, including Cadbury Schweppes of Britain, Elf Aquitaine of France and Sony and Toyota of Japan.
While many mutual funds that invest abroad hedge for themselves, investors can use options "for funds that do not hedge, or do not hedge all the time," Mr. Schwartz said. Such funds are common. Among funds that can hedge, "most do so 'occasionally,' " said Eileen Sanders, of Morningstar. A large handful never hedge, she said, including T. Rowe Price International Bond, Smith Barney International Equity A and some Templeton funds.
Ms. Sanders sees some limited circumstances in which fund investors might hedge with options or warrants, but "there is enough variety among funds to find one that hedges in your category." So why not let professionals do it?
Moreover, long-term investors will find it very expensive to hedge over the whole investment period. The $1,250 premium paid by Mr. Schwartz's yen investor covered about $62,000 in yen -- a 2 percent hit for three months, excluding $70 to $100 in commissions for the option.
Even an investor planning to unload some foreign stocks does not need option hedges, Ms. Scott said. It is wiser, she contends, to sell off the equities gradually, as the time approaches when the money is needed.

HEADLINE: TAXES;
Steering Clear of a Trap In Generational Giving

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
UNLIKE most Americans, who suffer an acute attack of manana syndrome when confronted with the need for estate planning, you have prepared a will, perhaps even trust documents.
Congratulations. Now you can rest assured that your assets will go to your heirs, including grandchildren, not the Government. And if there is a family business, it will not have to be sold to pay taxes. 
 But there is a villain that could upset these well-laid plans. It is the little-known generation-skipping tax, which is levied at a flat 55 percent on gifts and bequests in excess of $1 million that go to grandchildren or others in a second generation, and is intended to make up for estate tax that the Internal Revenue Service does not get to collect when one generation is bypassed.
Because the real estate and other assets of a family business often exceed $1 million, business owners need to be particularly careful to avoid springing this tax trap.
"As a general rule, most people don't have to worry about it," said Ross W. Nager of Houston, managing director of Family Wealth Planning Services for Arthur Andersen & Company. "The big exception is trusts. With insurance trusts, it is particularly surreptitious. Put in small dollar amounts, and one day it will sneak up and bite you."
In some ways the generation-skipping rules are parallel to those for gift and estate taxes, in which there is a $600,000 unified credit. Up to $600,000 may be left to heirs tax-free unless the credit has been reduced by individual gifts of more than $10,000 during one's lifetime.
Similarly, direct gifts to a grandchild of up to $10,000 are free from the generation-skipping tax.
Here's the rub: assets placed in a trust for grandchildren or left to them in a will may appreciate substantially, resulting in an unexpected tax burden.
Furthermore, gifts to a trust, like the annual premium on a life insurance policy, are not automatically covered by the $10,000 exclusion. Mr. Nager explained that donors could file a generation-skipping tax exemption election each year, so that, say, the $4,000 annual premium is exempt. Without this annual gift-tax filing, the tax could ultimately be levied on the entire proceeds of the policy. This filing is often overlooked, Mr. Nager said, because it is one line of the fourth page of a gift-tax return.
Similarly, someone who wishes to give a stake in a family business to a grandchild can do so by having the business appraised, giving stock to the grandchild over a period of years and filing the annual exemption election if the gift is more than $10,000 (or if any amount is put in trust for the grandchild). If the stock is left to the grandchild in a will, it might eventually be subject to tax at an appreciated value.
Charles Cangro, senior tax manager with Ernst & Young in New York, said, "The trick is to allocate the exemption early before the assets grow too substantially."
Tim Kochis, president of Kochis & Fitz, personal financial consultants in San Francisco, cautioned people to be realistic about their financial situation. "The important issue is whether one can afford to take an aggressive approach to making gifts," he said.
For example, many couples in their 60's with assets of $1 million to $2 million feel affluent and want to do something for their grandchildren. "But they may live another 20 or 30 years," he said, and a setback in terms of the market, health or inflation could deplete their savings.
"There is an appropriate balance between tax planning and cash flow and investment planning," Mr. Kochis said. "Also, there may be personal, psychological and family reasons for not doing so."
But psychology cuts both ways. Mr. Kochis described one client who was like a racer who kept running, unaware he had passed the finish line. He had amassed a net worth of about $15 million through a lifetime of hard work, "but still had a working-class mentality," feeling he had to struggle and could not help his grandchildren as he would have liked.
Mr. Kochis ran a number of "what-if scenarios" on retirement planning software, showing him that even if he lived to a very old age and his investment returns were exceedingly low, he could easily afford the gifts.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 954 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:
SADE: A Biography
By Maurice Lever. Translated by Arthur Goldhammer. Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $15.95.
This life of the infamous marquis shows that he came from a family of libertines, and attempts to link all his fictional debaucheries to actual events in his past. Although these connections cannot be verified, Lynn Hunt said here last year, Sade's lurid career unfolds "with verve and vivid detail."
IF IT BE NOT I: Collected Poems, 1959-1982
By Mona Van Duyn. Knopf, $15.
A former poet laureate of the United States, the author has created a rich body of work that comprises whimsical, sometimes rhyming poems and somber meditations. This collection, which incorporates her previous seven books, includes poems inspired by everything from the tribulations of Cinderella to a bout of conjunctivitis. Knopf has reissued it simultaneously with Ms. Van Duyn's most recent book, FIREFALL ($11), in which she explores a form she refers to as the "minimalist sonnet." Last year our reviewer, Rachel Hadas, said of both books, "However rich, Ms. Van Duyn's voice is never bland; particularity inflects her love of the world." 

UNDER FIRE: The NRA and the Battle for Gun Control
By Osha Gray Davidson. Owl/Holt, $13.95.
The author traces the history of the National Rifle Association, which began as an organization devoted to military preparedness and evolved into an uncompromising Second Amendment lobby only in the late 1970's. "There is a lesson in this book about the dangers of absolutism," Wendy Kaminer said here last year.
PARTICLES AND LUCK
By Louis B. Jones. Vintage Contemporaries, $12.
Here are 24 hours in the life of Mark Perdue, a gifted young California physicist who is suddenly confronted with the potential loss of his home -- and other metaphysical possibilities. Last year our reviewer, Carolyn See, said, "What a smart novel 'Particles and Luck' is."
EXPLODING THE GENE MYTH: How Genetic Information
Is Produced and Manipulated by Scientists, Physicians,
Employers, Insurance Companies, Educators,
and Law Enforcers
By Ruth Hubbard and Elijah Wald. Beacon, $12.
News reports that genes may be responsible for everything from cancer to homosexuality imply that heredity is somehow destiny, argue the authors. They caution against this reductionism while examining the profit motive in genetic research. "What is of particular value is the book's sharp eye for newspaper headlines," Daniel Callahan said here last year. In the same review he also praised THE HUMAN BODY SHOP: The Engineering and Marketing of Life, by Andrew Kimbrell (Harper SanFrancisco, $12), which discusses the implications not only of genetic engineering, but also of fetal tissue transplants and surrogate motherhood. "Mr. Kimbrell tells this story effectively and fully," Mr. Callahan said.
GREEN GRASS, RUNNING WATER
By Thomas King. Bantam, $9.95.
Lionel Red Dog, a Blackfoot Indian who makes his living selling televisions and stereos, is having a midlife crisis that revolves, in part, around the fear that he may have "gone white." His fate and that of several other Indian characters are intertwined in what our reviewer, James McManus, described last year as an "impressively ambitious and funny" novel. A more sorrowful look at Indian life is offered in MESSENGER BIRD, by Dan McCall (Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $9.95), the story of the two years a young surgeon spends on an Apache reservation in New Mexico in the early 1970's and the Sioux nurse he meets there. "The early medical anecdotes . . . are perfectly calculated to set up McCall's understated, elegiac plot," one critic said last year.
SLIM'S TABLE: Race, Respectability, and Masculinity
By Mitchell Duneier. University of Chicago, $9.95.
A sociologist chronicles the lives of a group of working-class black men he met at a Chicago cafeteria, finding in their experiences a bedrock of pride, honor and devotion to duty that is rarely noted in commentary on the nonwhite urban poor. In 1992 our reviewer, Roger Wilkins, said Mr. Duneier "sees the scale of their lives as fully human, rather than as diminished versions of grander lives lived elsewhere by people of another color." Values in the black community are also the subject of CLIMBING JACOB'S LADDER: The Enduring Legacy of African-American Families, by Andrew Billingsley (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14). High unemployment, the author argues, is the biggest factor contributing to the downturn in black marriage. "He combines an unflinching look at current troubles in the black family with an appreciation of its abiding strengths," Arlie Russell Hochschild said here last year. One black woman's struggles are detailed in VOLUNTEER SLAVERY: My Authentic Negro Experience, by Jill Nelson (Penguin, $9.95). The author describes the four years she worked at The Washington Post, where she maintains black staff members were often belittled and underpaid. Last year our reviewer, Patsy Sims, called it "an angry yet often funny memoir."
FISHBOY: A Ghost's Story
By Mark Richard. Anchor/Doubleday, $9.95.
A deformed boy stows away on an ocean trawler, where he becomes witness to the numerous depravities practiced by its murderous crew. The author "has folded a host of exquisitely rendered tales into a stunning novel," Margot Mifflin said here last year.
KIPPER'S GAME
By Barbara Ehrenreich. Harper Perennial, $12.
This journalist's first novel concerns a woman's search for her missing son, a brilliant computer hacker who is the recent inventor of a mysterious new game. Last year our reviewer, Michael Upchurch, said, "The notion of a link between intellectual curiosity and a physiologically based aphrodisia is an arresting one."
 LAUREL GRAEBER
