HEADLINE: Close To Home;
Remembering The Past; Repeating It Anyway

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
ONCE again, the United States finds itself weighing military intervention in the Caribbean, with ships and troops poised just offshore, waiting for an order to move in and restore order to a country that has plunged into chaos and misery. For nearly a century now, that has been the standard American response when events in the region geographically closest to the United States threaten to get out of hand, and for just as long a time, those interventions have almost uniformly failed to produce the results that policy makers in Washington had hoped for.
Since its first sustained foray into the region during the Spanish-American War of 1898, which yielded a protectorate in Cuba, permanent possession of Puerto Rico and a colony in the far-off Philippines, the United States has intervened militarily in the insular Caribbean and in Central America more than a score of times. Some countries, such as the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua, have been invaded and occupied more than once, a phenomenon that probably most eloquently expresses America's historic inability to remake neighboring societies to its own satisfaction. Indeed, it has often seemed that the more the United States tinkers, the worse things become.
 
Many Tactics, One Rationale
 The forms of intervention have varied, of course, from quick campaigns such as in Nicaragua in 1912, Grenada in 1983 and Panama in 1989, to long occupations in Haiti and the Dominican Republic early in the century. Then, too, there was invasion by proxy, practiced in Central America in the 1980's, and even the creation of a country by fiat -- Panama in 1903. The locations have also varied, with Spanish-, French- or English-speaking parts of the Caribbean all having to surrender sovereignty and self-determination at one time or another. 
 Almost always, however, the American rationale has been the same. In 1915, the United States explained that it was occupying Haiti, in the words of the Wilson Administration, in order to eliminate "a public nuisance at our doorstep." Last week, President Clinton used similar language in describing six American vital interests in Haiti. "First of all, it's in our back yard," he said, before stressing the need to protect Americans living here and his desire to install democracy.
But strategic and commercial considerations, such as control of sugar, bananas and the customs revenues needed to pay back bank loans, have usually loomed behind such statements of high principle. Especially during the early decades of the century, "there was a common strategic thread that pretty much covers all the military interventions, and that was the need to defend the Panama Canal and the approaches thereof," said Ivan Musicant, author of "The Banana Wars," a study of American interventions in the Caribbean Basin between 1898 and 1989. More recently, following the rise of Fidel Castro, the fear of Communist expansion, of "another Cuba," has been paramount.
In at least a material sense, many of the occupied countries benefited from the American presence. Highways, railroads, bridges and streets were built; telephone, electrical and telegraph systems installed or extended; docks, ports and lighthouses modernized, and schools and hospitals constructed in places that had none. Infant mortality rates fell and life expectancy rose as clean water was brought to rural areas and public health campaigns reduced the incidence of tropical diseases such as malaria, yellow fever and yaws.
At the same time, American administrators insisted on balanced budgets and reduced the foreign debt, which helped create conditions for economic growth. The presence of American troops also discouraged the continuing parade of civil wars and coups that had been routine in countries such as Haiti and Nicaragua. "The 19 years that the United States was in Haiti were the 19 best years of Haiti's entire existence," Mr. Musicant asserted. "We left that country a far, far better place than we found it."
But the United States also insisted on creating a professional constabulary to enforce public order, first in Panama and Haiti and later in the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua. The intention was to create an apolitical force that would guarantee that all parties played by the rules of the game. But those police forces quickly turned into armies, and that, in turn, paved the way for the emergence of despots such as Rafael Trujillo in the Dominican Republic, the Somoza dynasty in Nicaragua, and much later, Generals Omar Torrijos and Manuel Noriega in Panama.
 
A Need to Return
 Obviously, the citizenry of each country had the greatest difficulty in adapting to the system left by the United States when it withdrew. But those decisions have also come back to haunt later generations of American policy makers, and to foster further American involvement in the internal affairs of Caribbean countries. Even now, the United States finds itself in the awkward position of trying to secure the cooperation of Trujillo's protege, Joaquin Balaguer, in preventing leaks in the economic sanctions against Haiti. Mr. Balaguer, who is now 87 and has been nearly blind for more than a decade, keeps getting elected President, most recently two months ago in an election where international observers accused his side of fraud.
And in country after country, the presence and the paternalistic attitude of American troops and military governors, no matter how noble their stated goals, wounded national pride and fomented a nationalist resistance. Augusto Sandino of Nicaragua is the most famous of such resistance leaders, thanks to the young guerrillas who half a century later would come to power invoking his name. Haiti had Charlemagne Peralte and his army of irregulars known as "cacos," while in the Dominican Republic there was Vicente Evangelista and his "gavillero" movement. Both men were hunted down and killed during American occupations, while civil liberties were suspended and press censorship was in force.
Indeed, resistance was so widespread that the United States developed a corps of experts who moved from one country to another, snuffing out rebellions and imposing imported political structures. The Marine commander Smedley Butler, for instance, led forces in Panama, Haiti, Honduras and Nicaragua, and once likened the American role in the region to that of "trustees of a huge estate that belonged to minors." He later repented his actions and in a famous autobiography called himself a "racketeer for capitalism," who "helped in the raping of half a dozen Central American republics for the benefit of Wall Street."
Unfortunately, many of those who volunteered for such service had little respect or sympathy for the countries they ruled, did not understand the local language or culture and simply could not fathom the resentment their policies and attitudes, tinged with racism and condescension, generated. Woodrow Wilson's Secretary of State, William Jennings Bryan, once told the Haitian Ambassador in Washington that "the intelligent Haitians should feel gratified that it was the United States, rather than some other power whose motives might not be as unselfish as ours," that had chosen to occupy his country.
Given that legacy, if the United States should decide to invade Haiti again, it will be acting out of character. The last time United States troops landed on the island of Hispaniola, in the Dominican Republic in 1965, a civilian president elected with two-thirds of the popular vote after a long dictatorship, Juan Bosch, had been overthrown in a coup after only seven months in office and had been replaced by a military-dominated government. But when Lyndon Johnson sent in more than 20,000 troops, it was not to restore Mr. Bosch to power; it was to prevent the constitutional president from returning to office after his supporters began a rebellion. If G.I.'s go in this time, they will have the support of the Haitian people, at least initially. But that may not be enough to prevent history from repeating itself.

HEADLINE: The World;
When Money Talks, Governments Listen

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THINK about the meaning of these numbers: The global currency markets trade about $1 trillion worth of dollars each day. When the world's 17 largest central banks, led by the Federal Reserve, intervened last month to try to prop up the dollar, they dug deep into their pockets and came up with about $5 billion and change, which they threw into the market in an effort to bid up the value of the American currency. No wonder they had little effect on the dollar. The central banks were like a zoo keeper trying to calm a starved gorilla by offering it a raisin for lunch.
It really wasn't the fault of the governments, though. Raisins, it seems, are all they have sometimes, compared with the assets of the huge capital, currency and bond markets they are trying to influence. Whose world is this anyway? The answer is that it is increasingly Adam Smith's world -- a world in which the balance of power between global financial markets and governments is tilting toward markets. When it comes to global markets these days, the motto of governments is: "There they go, I must catch up, for I am their leader." 
 Twenty-two-year-old bond traders with ice water for blood tyrannize the President, passing judgment on his economic performance by raising or lowering interest rates; the markets devour central bank cash with nary a burp, and the portfolio managers, playing global Monopoly, move cash from country to country, deciding which governments deserve to "Pass Go" and collect $200 billion and which should go directly to jail and be starved of the capital to raise living standards.
This shift in power is driven by a combination of factors. The revolution in telecommunications and data transmission has knit Tokyo, Frankfurt, London and New York in a seamless web of financial interactions that operates at a speed, and in volumes, beyond the grasp of any single government. This technical revolution, though, has been accompanied and fueled by a political revolution. Over the past decade there has been a widening acknowledgment, from Albania to Alabama, that when it comes to allocating resources, markets work better than governments, whether the issue is providing telephone service or investment capital.
"Basically, governments have consented to a regime that allows markets to boss them around," said Stanford University economist Paul Krugman, "because the conventional wisdom, fed by experience, says that to throw up barriers to these market forces is to invite economic stagnation, if not disaster."
From the State of South Carolina to the government of Brazil, leaders believe that a central role of government is serving as a broker -- a broker between their constituents and the global markets. As more countries have gone capitalist, there is a huge global competition for cash and investors, so that governments can build the roads, power stations and telephone systems that are the foundation for higher living standards. Governments used to do that with their own cash -- as the Marshall Plan rebuilt much of Europe after World War II -- but they don't have it anymore.
So the role of governments now is increasingly to entice private investment -- to get B.M.W. to build a plant in Mississippi, or to get portfolio managers to invest in the Shanghai stock market -- by assuring stable currencies and sound economic fundamentals.
"During the cold war," said Labor Secretary Robert Reich, "we used the Soviet threat to get the public to accept certain changes and to build certain institutions, from the national highway system to the space program. They were all justified in national security terms. Today, with the Soviet threat gone, governments now use the global markets in the same way. We have to adopt this economic policy, initiate this training program for our work force, build this world-class airport, because if we don't we won't be able to attract global capital and raise our standard of living."
The role these markets have in promoting democracy is ambiguous. Markets demand stability, but they don't discriminate between the Singaporean form or the Jeffersonian form. "There is a brutal Darwinian logic to these markets," said the investment banker Felix Rohatyn. "They are nervous and greedy. They look for stability and transparency, but what they reward is not always our preferred form of democracy."
The struggle between markets and governments is not new. When the invention of the telegraph and the railroads knit the fragmented American economy into a single unit in the 19th century, it took 50 years for the Federal government to catch up and set up institutions like the Securities and Exchange Commission. Now national economies have been knit into a global economy, but so far national governments have not forged many super-national institutions to monitor it, because nations are reluctant to cede any sovereignty to global institutions.
 
An Enormous Challenge
 This creates an enormous challenge for regulators, says Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the S.E.C., which is responsible for upholding the standards of an American securities industry that is increasingly operating outside the S.E.C.'s grasp. "Morgan Stanley, dealing with a Tokyo insurance company, can have as big an impact on our system here as Morgan Stanley dealing with General Motors." The problem, though, added Mr. Levitt, is that many of the dealings between Morgan Stanley and a Tokyo insurance company are happening at a speed and in a global marketplace beyond the reach of his regulators.
The big debate in Congress over whether to ratify the new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is over how much sovereignty to cede to this super-national trade body. Opponents argue that GATT will give the World Trade Organization in Geneva the power to override certain American environmental laws and safety and health standards, if they violate the principles of free trade. This is often called the "GATTzilla versus Flipper" debate because GATT has ruled against American laws banning the import of tuna caught in nets that also sweep up dolphins.
A similar debate is going on in Asia with its new economic grouping, called APEC for "Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation." But it has no last name. Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation -- what? Organization? Institution? The reason APEC has no last name is because the member states were so worried about ceding sovereignty to it, they would not even call it an organization.
"Those in America who worry about the loss of sovereignty to GATT, or those in England who worry about a loss of sovereignty to the European Union, may seem at times like the King who stood on the beach and tried to stop the tide," said the Harvard University political theorist Michael J. Sandel. "But those who are worried have a point. These global markets are not accountable to any citizens. They don't necessarily reflect decisions that we have made on the basis of our collective values. One of the biggest challenges for democracy in our time is to develop political institutions that will be powerful enough to deal with global markets, but accountable enough to enable citizens to feel that they are still in control."

HEADLINE: July 17-23;
Math Team Makes a Perfect Score

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
In the decade since a bipartisan national commission warned that a rising tide of mediocrity was threatening America's schools, a string of embarrassments has heightened concern about the quality of education.
On one math test, scores for American teen-agers were far below their counterparts in Europe and Asia. 
 In an economics study most students failed to define basic terms like profit and inflation.
And a geography survey found that most high school graduates had trouble picking out countries -- even their own -- on an unmarked map.
A rare opportunity to crow came last week with the announcement of the results of a mathematics competition in Hong Kong that brought together 360 teen-aged math whizzes from 69 countries. The six high school students representing the United States each achieved perfect scores on a two-day, nine-hour mathematics test. That flawless result, the first in the 35-year history of the International Mathematical Olympiad, astonished the judges and exhilarated their coach.
"They're a tremendous model for how our country can achieve excellence," said Walter E. Mientka, the mathematics professor who was the team's coach.
All six students have attended public schools. Their parents include professors of math, chemistry, electrical engineering, systems analysis and women's studies, as well as two lawyers. SAM DILLON

HEADLINE: Sleepless in Central Park;
In Wake of Crimes, the Police Try Moving Out the Homeless

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

 BODY:
Long after the last baby carriage was hurried through the twilight and the last runner raced the dark to Fifth Avenue, the homeless of Central Park faded into the quiet of the trees. The city and its millions were just out of reach, and it was easy to pretend, in the softly beating heart of Manhattan, that the park was safe.
Robin Miller went to bed Tuesday night on an orange air mattress in a dark corner of the park. She used to sleep easy here, but recently the 40-year-old woman had tossed and turned, and kept a butter knife hidden in her grimy clothes. She sharpened it on a piece of concrete. 
 "Don't mess with me," she said, more to the night around her than one person in particular.
Homeless women are the most vulnerable women in New York, advocates for the homeless say. Their lives expose them to harm, and for many, the best escape is to become invisible. For years, Central Park has been a green curtain for homeless women and men.
Now the police are making it plain that they are not wanted there. The murder of one woman and the rapes of three others over the last two weeks prove, the police say, that it is too dangerous to sleep where cries for help can go unheard.
The officers who patrol the park have orders from their superiors to move the homeless out after a 1 A.M. curfew, but advocates for the homeless say the real reason behind the sweeps has less to do with safety than with esthetics.
Six homeless women have been raped in the park this year, but instead of generating a greater sympathy for the victims, the violence has drawn unwanted attention to the use of the park as a bedroom, some advocates said. The police, echoing many park users, said the squatters left a wake of cardboard shanties, tents, molded mattresses and filth.
George McDonald of the Doe Fund Inc., an advocacy group for the homeless, said it was shameful that crimes against homeless women had become an excuse to flush them from the park. Under the guise of protecting the women, he said, the park is being swept clean.
"It's incredible," he said.
The sweeps are apparently working. On Tuesday night, a few homeless camps were still scattered through the park. Ms. Miller sat with a friend in the southern section of the park. Her air mattress had a slow leak and every few minutes she would blow it back up again. It was her furniture.
She likes the green. Here, in the middle of the giant, clanking metropolis, the air is a little cooler, and every now and then you can hear a cricket fiddle to its lover in the dark.
"I got no other place," said Ms. Miller, who has been homeless for between two and three years.
By Friday night she was gone, and a canvass of the park from north to south between midnight and 3 A.M. found one homeless person: a weary-looking woman, dressed in a long winter coat and carrying two heavy plastic bags, who went through a garbage can before sitting on a park bench with her chin on her chest.
A mile or so north, just off Central Park West, were the signs of a hasty retreat. One man's freshly laundered clothes still hung in the limbs of a tree where he had put them to dry, not far from a pair of women's boots.
A new-looking shopping cart, a prized possession in some circles, was abandoned near a subway grate, and in another place a pair of men's briefs flapped in the breeze from a low-hanging limb.
The week before, the police had estimated the number of homeless campers at 150.
It was a precinct commander's comments about the murder and rape, not the crimes themselves, that caused the greatest commotion. The commander, Capt. William Bayer, said the homeless ruined the park for law-abiding people. He said the way to solve the problem was to "cut off the head of the enemy," meaning move the homeless out.
He later apologized for his remarks. But Captain Bayer only put into words what others feel about homeless people in the park, said Mary Brosnahan, the executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless.
"If you replace the word homeless with black, Latino, Jew or gay, it animates the issue that homeless people seem to be the last group not afforded equal protection under the law," she said.
Deputy Commissioner John Miller said the reality is that the park was never intended for overnight users and is too big, dark and secluded for officers to cover completely. The homeless take a great risk by sleeping there, he said.
He said it was insulting to beat officers and detectives to say they do not try hard enough to close cases against the homeless. And, he said, it is untrue.
On July 9, Cheryl Newbold, 31, was found stabbed to death in a tent in Central Park. Two rapes were reported that day, and a third -- a 51-year-old woman -- on July 16. The police have a suspect in the killing, a homeless man, and in at least one of the rapes.
Ms. Brosnahan said most violence against homeless people is from the outside, but the police said the homeless often prey on one another.
In one camp, half-hidden by trees and bushes, two homeless men and one woman said they had learned to trust only their closest friends.
At suppertime on Tuesday, they shared a quart bottle of apple juice and an aluminum plate of donated food. They said they slept on the ground, and had a plastic sheet as a makeshift tent in case it rained.
The young woman, who did not want her name used because her family does not know she is homeless, said she was once attacked by another homeless man, but still felt safer surrounded by other homeless in a secluded place like the park than in shelters, or on doorsteps.
On Friday night, they were gone.
In the sunlight, Central Park is a beautiful garden. A Russian immigrant, Anur Neseanov, peddled hot dogs and root beer. Kathy Yonek, an actress, walked a fat beagle named Tess. Jose Perez, a bus driver, chatted drowsily about the national economy with retiree Helen Fireison on a park bench in the shade.
Mr. Neseanov works hard all day and has no respect for people who do not, and says the homeless mess up the park for the decent people. Ms. Fireison and Mr. Perez feel for the homeless, but do not think they should have free run of the park at night, or the freedom to ruin it for others.
"What we need," said Ms. Fireison, "is to bring back the W.P.A."
But Ms. Yonek said the police sweeps were a silly solution. If the homeless are pushed out of the park, she said, they do not disappear. They do not leave the city, only congregate in another corner of it.
"Pardon the expression," she said, "but it's a cop-out."
Police officials said it was too early to judge the results of their curfew-enforcement effort. But Ms. Brosnahan said the homeless would seek out another outdoor place.
New Yorkers should not be surprised, she said, to see them on their doorsteps.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Delegates' Vote Sets Up a Primary

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 23

 BODY:
John Rowland, the former Congressman who nearly won the 1990 race for governor, was overwhelmingly nominated at the state Republican convention today to try again. But the Secretary of the State, Pauline Kezer, narrowly qualified to challenge him in a primary.
After an excruciating four-and-a-half-hour roll-call in which intense pressure was put on Kezer delegates to change their votes and avoid a primary for the party, Mrs. Kezer ended up with 196 votes, three more than the 15 percent she needed. 
 Both Republicans and Democrats now face Sept. 13 primaries for governor. State Senator John Larson, who won the Democrats' endorsement at their convention last week, is being challenged by the state Comptroller, William Curry.
The only major-party candidate who will not have to spend time and money on a primary is Eunice S. Groark, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s Lieutenant Governor, who was nominated by acclamation tonight by A Connecticut Party at its convention in Wallingford.
The race could become a four-way contest if Tom Scott, the leader of an anti-income tax group, successfully petitions to get on the ballot.
 
Hoping for Unity
 Mr. Rowland, well-known in Connecticut from the 1990 campaign, came into the convention hoping to block Mrs. Kezer from a primary so he could concentrate his resources on the general election while the Democrats fought among themselves.
With Mr. Weicker not seeking re-election, Republicans were hopeful that Mr. Rowland had the recognition and financing to enable the party to win the governor's office for the first time since 1970.
The main issue facing the Republicans, he told delegates Friday night as the convention opened in the Bushnell Auditorium here, was "Can this Republican Party leave on Saturday night poised for victory, united against the Democrats?"
After earning his reputation as a conservative within the party, Mr. Rowland, 37, is offering a broader message, saying the state's return to economic health depends on improving public schools and helping people on welfare to find jobs, in addition to cutting taxes and fighting crime.
But Mrs. Kezer, 52, had pursued a primary from the start of the campaign, arguing that Mr. Rowland was too conservative to win a statewide contest in a moderate state like Connecticut.
 
Seeking to Open It Up
 She too says economic development and fighting crime are major issues, but is also advocating laws permitting referendums and initiatives and other ways to open the state's decision-making process to voters.
Mr. Rowland secured the convention's endorsement less than halfway through the roll-call, as it began with towns from western Connecticut, where Mr. Rowland represented the Fifth District for three terms. As he received his 652d vote, clinching the nomination, Mrs. Kezer had only 49.
"After the last time around, I had a lot of soul-searching to do about whether to come back or not," Mr. Rowland said after the nomination was won. "I decided that I would see how things went in the state, whether I thought the economy had turned around or whether I thought the quality of life had improved.
"Frankly, I don't think it has. So that really got to be my major impetus to run again."
The early landslide for Mr. Rowland put even more pressure on Mrs. Kezer's delegates as they waited to vote. But even as a second round for the first ballot was held, in which delegates could step forward to change their votes, nearly all of her delegates stood firm.
"We fought for what was ours, and we didn't want to lose what was ours," Mrs. Kezer said afterward.
 
A Second Primary
 The Republicans will also have primaries for lieutenant governor, United States Senator and, it appeared likely, attorney general.
Mr. Rowland's choice for lieutenant governor, Jodi Rell, a state representative from Brookfield, won the nomination, but Mrs. Kezer's choice, Joseph Rucci, a New Canaan lawyer, qualified for the primary.
The Senate candidate favored by party leaders, former state Sen. Gerald Labriola, won the nomination, but Dr. Joseph Bentivegna, a political newcomer, qualified for a primary.
In the convention's closest vote, Richard Arnold, a Trumbull lawyer, won the nomination for attorney general by only 40 votes over Joseph Broder, a lawyer from Glastonbury. With primaries set for most of the party's statewide nominations, one appeared likely here, too.
The party also nominated Christopher Burnham, a former State Representative from Stamford, for treasurer; Rep. Gene Gavin of Westport for comptroller, and Andrea Scott, a clerk in the state House of Representatives, for secretary of the state.
At its convention in Wallingford tonight, A Connecticut Party was filling out the rest of its slate, which has the top line on the November ballot, almost entirely by cross-endorsing Democrats, including Senator Joseph I. Lieberman.
The main exception will be Mrs. Groark's choice for lieutenant governor, Audrey Rowe, Connecticut's commissioner of social services. Her selection creates the state's first ticket with women in both top spots. It also, for the first time, puts a black candidate on the ballot for Connecticut's second-highest office.

She narrowly won enough of the delegates' votes to force a primary election against Mr. Rowland for the nomination for governor. (Photographs by Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bell Companies Use Regulation To Stop Rivals

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

 BODY:
Even as the nation's local telephone companies make a final push to compete against long-distance and cable television companies, many of them are using the very regulations that restrict them to block rivals that attack their own businesses.
Just last month, for example, the Bell Atlantic Corporation accused a group of fledgling rivals of offering "illegal" telephone services and demanded that the Federal Communications Commission fine them $1 million for each customer they serve. 
 Likewise, when Teleport Communications announced plans to build a fiber-optic network to offer private-line services in Houston, the Southwestern Bell Corporation said Teleport was violating state law and demanded that Texas regulators issue a "cease and desist" order. When the state recently adopted rules to promote more competition, Southwestern Bell challenged them in court.
Such hardball tactics aim at thwarting new competitors by embroiling them in mind-numbingly intricate legal and business disputes.
These actions also go to the heart of a major policy battle in Washington. Congress is in the final stages of debate on a sweeping overhaul of the nation's telecommunications laws that would relax many restrictions on telephone companies in exchange for forcing them to give up their traditional monopolies. Most experts agree that what once seemed like a "natural" monopoly in telephone service is now on borrowed time, thanks to the rush of technology and changes in the marketplace.
But while most lawmakers agree that all of the rivals should be allowed to compete directly, they are deeply divided over just how fast to free the so-called Baby Bells. While competition is increasingly feasible in terms of technology, it remains almost nonexistent.
Indeed, only four states have allowed rival companies to compete with the established providers of local phone service.
The Senate Commerce Committee is expected to vote this week on broad changes in telecommunications law proposed by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina. On Friday, the Bell companies walked out of negotiations with Senate staff members, arguing that the bill would not let them into the long-distance business quickly enough.
The House of Representatives recently passed a bill supported by the Bells, and all sides in the debate are bracing for a final battle over the next two months.
 
 
Assault From All Sides
 The Bell companies argue passionately that they are hamstrung by restrictions at a time when they are under assault from a host of new rivals: cable television companies, long-distance carriers, specialized fiber-optic companies and new wireless telephone technologies.
"We feel like we've always played by the rules, doing what the regulators told us," said James Cullen, president of Bell Atlantic. "Now we're finding that all the lucrative markets are going to be opened. The feeling is that we're going into that with our hands tied."
But Robert Atkinson, senior vice president of the Teleport Communications Group of Staten Island, which has built fiber-optic networks in more than a dozen cities, said the Baby Bells had persistently indulged in "gamesmanship" to stop rivals. "It's delay, delay, delay," he said.
Some Bell companies have tried to declare the competitive services illegal. Some have refused to give rival companies telephone numbers to assign to customers, or have refused to let the rivals' customers list their numbers in telephone directories. Some have fought fiercely to stop long-distance companies from offering in-state long-distance service.
 
Suddenly, Unlisted Numbers
 When a tiny Texas company called Metrolink Telecom set up a special service between Houston and Galveston, Southwestern Bell tried to shut it down. Metrolink, which used lines leased from Southwestern, allowed people in Houston to call hotels in Galveston by making a local phone call. Southwestern Bell complained that the service was not allowed. When Metrolink refused to agree to a host of restrictions, Southwestern stopped listing the hotels' numbers in its telephone directory.
Last July, a Texas state court awarded Metrolink $5.7 million in antitrust damages. Southwestern Bell is appealing and has refused to pay.
And when Maryland regulators were preparing to certify a new company, MFS Communications of Omaha, to compete for basic telephone service, Bell Atlantic argued that MFS should reimburse it for almost all the revenue it lost from each customer who defected.
Invoking a team of economists led by Alfred C. Kahn -- who was one of President Jimmy Carter's top advisers on Government deregulation -- Bell Atlantic argued that MFS should pay it $34.95 a month for every business telephone line that it signed up, even though the cost of the line itself was only $12.81 a month. The rest of the "contribution," Bell Atlantic argued, was to cover the cost of subsidies that keep residential telephone service cheap. After enormous debate, Maryland officials cut MFS's payment to about $20 a line.
To be sure, some regional telephone companies have been more receptive to competition. Ameritech Inc., which is based in Chicago and operates local phone companies in the Midwest, has developed a detailed plan under which rivals would be allowed to plug into its network and provide a full range of local services. Just last week, Illinois approved an application by MFS to become a full-service telephone carrier.
 
 
Nynex Lets Rivals In
 In New York, where state regulators were among the first to press for competition, the Nynex Corporation has opened itself to full-service rivals like MFS and Teleport. "To Nynex's credit, it's worked out," said Lisa Rosenblum, vice chairwoman of the New York Public Service Commission. "They have seen that the world is very different."
Royce M. Holland, president of MFS Communications, suggested that regional companies that cooperate with competitors should be rewarded. "The regional Bell companies should no longer be viewed as a monolith," he said. "We think companies like Nynex and Ameritech ought to be let into the long-distance business five years before companies like Bell Atlantic."
Most experts agree with the Bell companies that the traditional regulatory practice of separating communications companies into protected fiefs is out of date, given that technology has created a trend toward competition among telephone, cable television and computer services.
Teleport and MFS have each built fiber-optic networks in more than a dozen cities that provide services to big corporate customers. Long-distance companies like AT&T and MCI Communications are edging back into local markets as both move to build nationwide wireless telephone networks. Both companies also compete against local Bell companies for in-state long-distance calls.
Perhaps most important, cable television companies are racing to offer both telephone and data communication services over their networks, which already pass by more than 90 percent of all American homes. Time Warner recently reached an agreement in Rochester to offer residential phone service, and Southwestern Bell applied to compete against Bell Atlantic in Maryland, using cable television systems it owns there to offer phone service.
 
 
Regulatory Hurdles
 Still, largely for regulatory reasons, the competition is more theoretical than real.
Only four states -- Illinois, Maryland, New York and Washington -- have authorized rival companies to offer what industry executives call "P.O.T.S." -- plain old telephone service. Rivals like Teleport and MFS generated only $251 million of revenues last year -- paltry beside the roughly $90 billion of revenues for the established telephone giants.
Telephone companies say the blame lies primarily with local regulators, who have used regulated telephone prices to construct elaborate subsidies. Residential phone prices are kept artificially low, they contend, while business services are inflated. These subsidies are possible only in a regulated monopoly environment, because competitors can instantly undercut prices that are far above actual costs.
"Companies like AT&T, Sprint and Teleport want to exploit business opportunities that exist solely because of the regulatory environment," said James Ellis, general counsel for Southwestern Bell, which has been an aggressive opponent of local competition. "It's an artificial situation."
 
 
Big Fines Demanded
 Even so, the Bell companies have been tenacious in raising obscure issues. In 1992, Bell Atlantic seized on a Federal court decision that required AT&T's long-distance rivals to disclose their prices. Bell Atlantic argued that the case also applied to its rivals and asked the F.C.C. to declare their services illegal. On June 30, Bell Atlantic demanded that the commission fine each competitor in its territory $1 million a customer.
Likewise, the BellSouth Corporation and other companies waged a shrill campaign two years ago to prevent the F.C.C. from forcing local telephone companies to let rivals set up their own equipment on Bell company premises. At one point, BellSouth's chairman, John L. Clendenin, wrote a blistering letter to an F.C.C. commissioner, Ervin S. Duggan, accusing him of failing to understand the issue.
At the local level, trench warfare has been persistent. In Texas, Southwestern Bell went to court to stop a small company called Centex Telemanagement from offering a package of services to small businesses. The company recently wrote off millions of dollars in legal expenses, and was sold to MFS Communications.
"If you're a competitor and you're thinking about investing a lot of money in this state, you start asking yourself, 'Why? Why should I go through all this?' " said Bill Magness, head of the Communications Coalition of Texas, an association that includes consumer groups, cable companies like Time Warner and aspiring rivals like Teleport Communications.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE WHIP;
A Republican Who Sees Himself as a Revolutionary on the Verge of Victory

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
While the Democratic leaders in Congress are struggling to write health legislation that follows President Clinton's principles, Newt Gingrich, the Republican whip, has united his party in the House of Representatives against such a bill and hopes to use the issue as a springboard to win Republican control of the House.
This would not be a modest accomplishment. Republicans now have 78 fewer seats than Democrats and have been a minority in the House for the last 40 years. 
 But Mr. Gingrich is not a modest man. He calls himself a revolutionary and freely compares what he is trying to do to the way Vaclav Havel, Lech Walesa and Boris N. Yeltsin brought down Communism in their countries.
In an interview in his office this week, Mr. Gingrich, in his rat-a-tat style, offered this capsule description of the state of American politics:
"We were faced with a system that was corrupt. The system refused to respond to the country as it changed. We adopted a series of positions that were very popular in the country -- a balanced-budget amendment, a line-item veto, no tax increases -- and the corrupt Democratic machine that should have responded remained rigid and stuck in place.
"It then won an accidental election for President with 43 percent of the vote, and instead of moving to the center, which would have required analyzing the Perot vote, which was anti-government and for cutting spending -- an amazing populist rebellion -- it moved to the left. What you got was Dukakis with a southern accent.
"Faced with that reality, whether it's the collapse of the Japanese system, the collapse of the Italian system, the collapse of the Russian system, the collapse of the Canadian governing party last year, we are the natural result. We are reformers. We are prepared to say bluntly what the machine is. And we're prepared to offer policies that are very popular in the country and very unpopular in this city. And that's fine with us. Our power base isn't in this city."
That sounds more like the grandiosity of a student radical from a generation ago than the cogent analysis of an experienced politician. But in the politically polarized world of the House, Mr. Gingrich's views are not seen as far-fetched.
Fifty-one years old and in his eighth term in Congress from a district on the outskirts of Atlanta, Mr. Gingrich has been the whip, the No. 2 position in his party's leadership in the House, since 1989. The Republican leader, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, is retiring after this session of Congress, and Mr. Gingrich is assured of getting the top spot.
 
Republicans in Lock Step
 As whip, he has united Republicans in the House to an extent no party in Congress has been unified in the last half-century. All the Republicans voted against the Clinton budget last year, and odds are they will vote as a bloc against a health bill if it bears any resemblance to what the President proposed.
Even if the President's health measure passes over their solid opposition, as his budget did, Republicans will still benefit politically, Mr. Gingrich holds. He says most Americans do not want radical changes in the nation's health system.
Among Republicans in the House, the mood resembles that of a well-drilled army on the advance.
"There is a tremendous amount of excitement in the Republican Party today," said Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, a soft-spoken moderate who is miles apart from Mr. Gingrich in temperament and ideology but who gives Mr. Gingrich primary credit for what he calls a resurgence of the party in the House. If Republicans capture the House, Mr. Leach will become chairman of the Banking Committee.
"It is all related to the possibility that this is an earthquake year and, if not this year, then in the next election," Mr. Leach said.
The Democrats, meanwhile, seem dispirited. Groping for the right word, Representative Romano L. Mazzoli of Kentucky said, "There's a kind of uneasiness and wariness, a jumpiness about how all this is going to work out."
The Republicans maintain that the health issue is their lever for prying control of the House away from the Democrats.
"This goes to the core of the difference between Democrats and Republicans," Mr. Gingrich said last week in an interview in his office in the Capitol. "I suggested to Hillary a year and a half ago -- I said, 'I would not ever try to change 14 percent of the national economy in one bill.' I said they should bring in a bill a year, and they should do five good things a year and minimum damage. I said: 'You can't write a comprehensive bill. Nobody is smart enough to write a comprehensive bill.' "
On Friday, after the House had completed its regular business for the week, Mr. Gingrich took the floor and proposed the legislative equivalent of a duel. He suggested that the Democrats and Republicans put their versions of health legislation forward before the August Congressional recess and that the House vote on one or the other, with no amendments allowed, the first week after Congress returns in September. He also challenged President Clinton to a debate during the recess.
Mr. Gingrich said that among the elements of the Republicans' legislation, still an unfinished product, would be insurance reforms, tax breaks for small businesses and the self-employed, tax-free medical savings accounts, rules making it more difficult to win claims of medical malpractice, more leeway for states to manage their Medicaid programs and a large increase in the number of Government-supported community health centers.
 
The Republican Bill
 Unlike what President Clinton wants, the Republican measure would not guarantee universal health insurance coverage and would not require employers to provide insurance for their workers.
"I think I can solve a third of the problems of the system this year and do almost no damage," Mr. Gingrich said in the interview. "I think next year we can work on solving another third. And then, we'll look and see what's left to be done and do that."
Democrats argue that he is simply being an obstructionist. Representative David R. Obey, of Wisconsin, said Mr. Gingrich and his allies "would rather embarrass the majority than move the consensus; they will do whatever is necessary to deny Clinton a political victory."
Mr. Gingrich denied the accusation. He noted that he had supported the President and rounded up support for the North American Free Trade Agreement last year. Mr. Obey, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, voted against it.
Even so, Mr. Gingrich is surely the most partisan and most ideological leader the Republicans have had in Congress at least since World War II.
For years, the Republican leaders in the House were men like Mr. Michel and Gerald R. Ford, men who befriended their Democratic counterparts and fought hard but always clean. Outnumbered, they could be counted on to compromise in a way that often left them with little more than crumbs.
But with Ronald Reagan's election in 1980, the character of the party in the House began to change. Gradually, the Eastern prep school graduates and Midwestern Main Street bankers who had been dominant retired and were replaced by young, die-hard conservatives more interested in cause than class and who favored combat over conciliation.
Out in the country, Republicans are split between social and religious conservatives on the one hand and economic conservatives on the other. In the House they are mostly one and the same.
A bell curve charting the views of Republicans in the House would not only be to the right of one showing the views of Americans as a whole, it would also be more conservative than one charting the views of Republican voters alone.
This could hurt Mr. Gingrich's effort to win control of the House for Republicans, said James Thurber, a political scientist at American University who studies Congress and the Presidency. "The middle has shifted for the Republican Party in the House," Mr. Thurber said. "The data don't show that the middle has shifted in the country."
 
Death and Taxes
 Mr. Gingrich disagrees. He argues that a new center is developing over issues like the death penalty and low taxes.
In any case, winning a Republican majority in the House is a formidable task, but one that for the first time in many years even Democrats concede is within reach. With Republicans holding 178 seats now to 256 for the Democrats, 40 seats would have to change hands for the Republicans to take a majority.
Mr. Gingrich maintained that his party's best forecasters are predicting they will win 34 additional House seats in this November's election. If that happens, Mr. Gingrich said, he knows of six disaffected Democrats who have told him they will switch parties to put Republicans over the top.
More neutral forecasters think a 34-seat switch is unlikely. Charles E. Cook Jr., who publishes a nonpartisan newsletter that handicaps every race, says the turnover is likely be 15 to 25 seats. But even if Mr. Gingrich is wrong and Mr. Cook is right, a majority could be well within the Republicans' grasp in 1996.
Much of what happens, of course, depends on Mr. Clinton. The more popular he is at election time this year and in 1996, the more likely the Democrats will do well in Congressional races. And Mr. Clinton's popularity could depend to a large extent on whether he gets the health legislation he wants and whether the public approves of that legislation.
That prospect, Mr. Gingrich said, fills him with anticipation. He cannot wait to become Speaker of the House.

HEADLINE: Eight Tell What They'd Do If They Had Coliseum Site

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The collapse of Mortimer B. Zuckerman's nine-year effort to build high-rise office and apartment buildings on the site of the New York Coliseum has left new uncertainty, and new possibilities, for what may be New York City's most highly coveted development parcel.
But what, if anything, will be built at Columbus Circle? Who will build it? And when? 
 One option is for the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to seek proposals from other developers quickly. Another is to put the Coliseum building to new uses, from stores to television studios. Yet another is simply to wait for an improving real-estate market to command a better price.
Few doubt that something, eventually, will be built. Eight people who have observed the saga of the Coliseum at close range offered their thoughts on the form that any development should take, and what should be done to plan for it. THOMAS J. LUECK
 
Edward I. Koch
Mayor, 1978-1989
We have a clean slate. That means the property can be kept off the market for two years while real-estate values go up. Then there should be a request for proposals that is not complicated but offers the total lot under the provision that a building will go up as a matter of right. That means no special approvals from the Planning Commission. Whatever current law allows in height restrictions should apply.
Building under existing codes should eliminate all lawsuits and will mean that finally you get a building up in a reasonable period of time. The only considerations should be the quality of architecture, the price paid for the property and the building's economic impact on the area. You don't necessarily take the highest price for the site if the building is not going to be high quality. Because of its economic impact, I would give points for a building that is a combination of housing and commercial space.
Finally, whatever proposal is accepted should require the developer to provide improvements to the subway station at Columbus Circle.

Robert A. Caro
Author of "The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York"
Every morning I walk by Columbus Circle and think to myself that this is a unique opportunity in the life of the city. The Coliseum site should be New York's version of the Etoile in Paris. It should be a great star,
something worthy of the city, of a new and shining New York.
In fact, it is a great star already, with broad avenues radiating from a circle and converging on it in all directions. It has a great park on one side, and a monumental entrance to that park. The foundation is in place to make it a symbol of a city that is at last going to be as great as it should have been.
I don't know what should go there, and I am not saying there shouldn't be apartments or offices, new jobs and revenue. But there should be something more.
This site is not something that should simply be left to developers. Its planning should be the responsibility of the city.
The young and idealistic Robert Moses would have agreed. It was the old Robert Moses -- the power broker Robert Moses -- who slapped down what we see now, this horrible Coliseum building. I always considered the Coliseum he built to be an example of the city's loss of vision.

Larry A. Silverstein
Manhattan developer, one of several builders who submitted proposals for the Coliseum project in 1985
It was a superb site then, and it is a superb site today. Nothing has changed except the value structure, which has been reduced from the halcyon days of the 1980's. The prices we felt we could obtain then for condominiums, and the rents for retail and office
space, are markedly different now.
But the reality is that the market is beginning to come back, and I have little doubt that if the property were put on the market in a year or two, developers will surface.
The type of project we envisioned in the 1980's is still the most appropriate for the site -- mixed use, with luxury condos and offices. Stepping back awhile, until the market recovers, may be the best approach.
I think a mixed-use building can be designed for that site that is very pleasing. But that assumes that the design is contextual and blends with the wonderful buildings along Central Park West. That means, to some degree, Art Deco.
There is no question in my mind that if there is an opportunity to do something that is sensitive to the buildings that permeate Central Park West, the public will support it and a building will go up.

Moshe Safdie
Architect who conceived Mr. Zuckerman's original plan for the Coliseum site
If I was the city, I would recognize that this is one of the most unique sites it has. I would demolish both the Coliseum and 10 Columbus Circle [the adjoining office building]. I would reinstate 59th Street as a visual corridor, if
not as a street, and I would redefine Columbus Circle as a public space. You need to define the circle as a pedestrian and vehicular route, and put more activity for people at street level.
By definition, whatever building goes up is going to be mixed use. I think there should be retail space and cultural activities, as well as condos and offices.
Having time is good. If a weak market means you wait two or three years, that's O.K. But this site demands ambition. The first thing the city ought to do is take the initiative to establish a compelling urban design framework. In the past it has been rather vague about what it hoped get out of this site.

Ruth W. Messinger
Manhattan Borough President
From 1980 to 1984, we had a comprehensive planning program for the entire Columbus Circle area, not just the Coliseum. It involved the M.T.A., the Parks Department, the Planning Commission. I think it now the appropriate time to re-create that kind of
collaborative effort.
The city could, as an interim step, reuse the Coliseum building as a convention hall. The Javits Center is overbooked, and we regularly get requests from people who want to put on trade shows. But ultimately the site has got to be developed.
It has always been hard for me to understand why what is potentially one of the most beautiful sites in the city is used as a motorcycle parking lot. It could be as great as any central square in Europe. It should be a circle, unlike the mishmash it has been for years, which flows naturally from Central Park. It should have statuary and a signature building.

Linda Davidoff
Executive director of the Parks Council
Looking toward a 21st-century New York that is a magnet for people, the city and the M.T.A., instead of cashing in every nickel that can be squeezed out of the site from a high-rise commercial development, should look for ways to build a splendid civic space.
Whatever structure goes up should help announce the entrance to Central Park. It should provide seating and viewing areas looking across Columbus Circle to the park. An open plaza should be incorporated into the lobby, flowing into the outside open space. And all the street-level space should connect with a splendid new subway concourse below ground, with clear views from the circle and the park to the concourse and back again.
It's important for the public agencies not to make the errors of the past, by giving approvals for a giant slab high-rise that would cast a shadow over the park and overwhelm Columbus Circle.

Richard Seth Hayden
Partner in Swanke Hayden Connell, a Manhattan architectural firm. His office, at 4 Columbus Circle, overlooks the Coliseum.
The wonderful thing about Columbus Circle is that it was once actually a circle. But it has been terribly broken up by the design of the present building. Part of going forward should be to bring it back as a circle.
Whatever is built should echo the circle
shape in its facade instead of the straight lines of the Coliseum. At least the first six to eight stories should be related to the streetscape, where we have the statue in Columbus Circle as a center point and the entrance to Central Park.
A little replanning is in order. There has been so much negativism surrounding this project that it would be refreshing to take another look.
We need to establish urban design guidelines. But it could be like the lovely intersections of Paris.

Kent L. Barwick
President of the Municipal Art Society
This is the finest site in New York. But we should not use it simply to raise enough money to balance the city's books for the next 10 years.
What really went wrong in this project that the city stepped out of its role as a referee
between the interests of builders and the public, and became a developer itself. It sold zoning.
Now we have a great opportunity to take a great public space next to the city's most beloved public space -- Central Park -- and make something coherent out of it.
No development is not the answer, and it is not realistic to expect something like a two-story cultural center. We are going to have two substantial New York City buildings, but we should be riveted on one simple thing -- the city has got to take a leadership role to determine the best development. It has to determine some basic design guidelines for the site.
This is exactly the moment not to rest but to plan and to provoke public discussion about what should be built. While the real-estate market is flat or just beginning to recover, it is time to establish basic design guidelines.

HEADLINE: The Key Issue on North Korea

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 23

 BODY:
The announcement on Thursday that despite the death two weeks ago of its absolute ruler, North Korea had agreed to resume high-level talks with Washington on its nuclear program has restored the hint of optimism that was injected into the crisis a month ago.
But Government officials, diplomats and experts say the prospects for real progress in halting the North's suspected nuclear weapons program remain about as clear as the muddy pond bristling with 8,000 radioactive fuel rods at a major nuclear complex in North Korea. 
 The fate of the nearly opaque pool of water is one of the most pressing issues the two sides will face when they meet in two weeks. In fact, what happens to the pool, believed to contain the raw material for four or five nuclear bombs, could determine the course of this dangerous standoff in a matter of weeks.
If the United States cannot persuade North Korea to abandon plans for quickly extracting the bomb material, plutonium, from the spent uranium rods, the talks appear likely to break down. That would push the two countries closer to a military confrontation long before they have had a chance to tackle the range of political and economic issues they have said they want to discuss.
"This issue will be the touchstone of the North's intentions," said Leonard S. Spector, an expert on nuclear issues at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "If this gets resolved in a positive way, it will demonstrate good faith. If they respond in another way, it would create very serious problems."
 
An Array of Complex Issues
 A senior American official involved in the issue added: "It's true. This must be handled first, and pretty quickly."
Even if the problem is resolved in time, it would still leave an array of immensely complex issues on the table. North Korea has asked for a modern light-water nuclear reactor for electric power generation to replace its outmoded graphite-core models. But who would finance a deal that could ultimately cost well over $10 billion, take a decade or more to complete and require the upgrading of North Korea's entire power transmission system?
Who would pay for and manage the modernization of North Korea's antiquated coal-fired power plants, which would be needed to sustain the economy until the new nuclear plant was built? How would the United States react if the North Koreans continued to refuse access to two nuclear waste sites, which may hold the key to determining how much plutonium the North already has?
And would North Korea, one of the most closed societies on earth, really be willing to reverse four decades of hostility to the non-Communist world and open up to build the political bridges it says it wants?
Even though the negotiators have so little time to overcome some of these hurdles, there is a sense of promise mixed in with the uncertainty, because of the unusual series of events over the last few months.
The turning point came in June. After 18 months of broken agreements by North Korea on opening its nuclear facilities to international inspections, the Government defied the International Atomic Energy Agency and removed the spent six-foot-long fuel rods from a small reactor at a complex at Yongbyon, about 60 miles north of the capital, Pyongyang.
If the rods were reprocessed, something the North Koreans said was necessary for safety reasons, the yield would be more than 20 pounds of plutonium, which can be used to create a nuclear explosion. The agency and the United States insisted that such a step had to be resisted vigorously, and so Washington pushed for United Nations trade sanctions. North Korea responded by vowing it would interpret an embargo as an act of war.
 
A Conciliatory Turn
 But suddenly, after mediation by former President Jimmy Carter, North Korea's hard-line leader, Kim Il Sung, took a sharp conciliatory turn. He agreed to freeze his nuclear plans and to hold the first summit meeting between North and South Korea since the two countries were created in 1948 if the United States would hold high-level talks.
The meetings with the United States began on July 8, and after one day American officials said they were encouraged. But the announcement the next day that Kim Il Sung had died of a heart attack put the talks on hold and left everyone wondering if the new mood could be sustained.
The first sign came this week, when North Korea agreed to resume the meetings with the United States on Aug. 5 in Geneva. It was the first tangible sign that Kim Jong Il, Mr. Kim's son and presumed successor, would continue his father's policies.
That still leaves the problem of the spent fuel rods. Two inspectors are currently at Yongbyon, intently watching to see if the North Koreans try to remove the rods and begin reprocessing.
 
Reactor as the Carrot
 Ultimately, the United States is seeking to have the rods removed entirely, so there would be no possibility that the uranium would be reprocessed. The inducement would be, in part, the light-water reactor, which the North Koreans have been requesting for the past year.
The modern light-water reactors produce far less plutonium than the graphite-moderated reactors used in North Korea. But they also use a fuel that the North does not produce, and they are very costly.
That is one of the reasons the discussions of the light-water reactor are so crucial: if North Korea accepts a deal -- abandoning its current nuclear program in favor of the new reactors and aid -- it would mean the biggest shift in foreign policy since the country began the Korean War in 1950. It would mean cooperation had replaced a war footing.
That is what is at stake.
"We're prepared to put more on the table than security issues," said Robert L. Gallucci, Assistant Secretary of State and head of the American delegation. "It's a very full agenda. But the nuclear issue has to be dealt with first."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: News Analysis

HEADLINE: U.S. May Thwart China's Trade Goal

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 23

 BODY:
China, which has staked its national prestige on becoming a founding member of the World Trade Organization, must comply with the international group's rules before entry, a Clinton Administration official said here today.
In some of the bluntest language directed at Beijing over trade issues this year, Charlene Barshefsky, the deputy United States trade representative, accused the Chinese of widespread shortcomings in their compliance with global trade rules and demanded that the Chinese move toward resolving a list of outstanding trade grievances with Washington. 
 "First and foremost, the multilateral system has rules, and these are rules to which there are no exceptions, and there can be no exceptions for China," Ms. Barshefsky said. "As no one country is special and can have its own special series of rules, China is not special and should not have any unwarranted special rules that apply to it."
 
The U.S. Complaints
 The United States has complained that China has not complied with international rules on access to its markets and protection of copyrights and patents. China has argued that its status as a developing country should be taken into consideration.
The World Trade Organization, the successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the body that is intended to promote global free trade by lowering tariffs and other barriers, will be formally constituted on Jan. 1.
Beijing has repeatedly declared that it intends and deserves to be a founding member of the trade group and has accused Washington of raising obstacles to its membership by making excessive demands. But Ms. Barshefsky said China's admission required more than polemics.
"We have indicated to the Chinese that we recognize the importance China attaches to this date," she said, "but we have indicated also that China has much to do if it is to meet this deadline it has set for itself. But we must have a protocol of accession that is on strict economic terms. This is not a political decision."
But a senior official at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris said the American position was at odds with that of Europe.
 
$23 Billion Trade Deficit
 "What's interesting is why the U.S. is taking a harsher position than others," said the official, who spoke only on the condition that he not be identified. "The Europeans have indicated they would rather have China in earlier than later. The U.S. is taking a harder line, and it has to do with the bilateral trade imbalance. If the U.S. really wants to block China it can, but it depends on what other games the U.S. is playing."
Indeed, last year the United States ran a $23 billion trade deficit with China, and in the first five months of this year the deficit was $9.2 billion.
Ms. Barshefsky's comments, made at a news conference at the United States Consulate here this morning, came after a visit to Beijing, where she outlined the Administration's demands for changes in China's trade policies and enforcement of laws that it has already enacted.
Chief among the bilateral issues addressed to the Chinese, the deputy trade representative said, was China's failure to enforce laws protecting copyrights. For many years, China has been a big source of pirated musical compact disks and video laser disks, the United States has asserted. In addition, virtually all the computer software distributed in China is illegally copied and distributed, Ms. Barshefsky said.
"China has changed its legal regime with respect to intellectual property rights," she said, "but there is no enforcement of the laws that have been very carefully crafted."
She said piracy and theft of American-produced music, videos and software in China was costing American companies $1 billion a year.
Ms. Barshefsky said the Administration had demanded that Beijing take immediate steps, which would not only go a great distance to resolving bilateral trade friction with Washington, but which would assist in China's effort to join the World Trade Organization.
At the top of the list was an insistence that Beijing move swiftly to close 26 factories in southern China that churn out, by Ms. Barshefsky's estimate, 75 million pirated compact disks and video laser disks a year.
Ms. Barshefsky said she had also told the Chinese Government that China must move to open its market for services to American companies.
 
Administration's Approach
 The Clinton Administration has been unequivocal in its assertions that the resolution of bilateral trade issues will have a direct bearing on how it views China's application to the World Trade Organization. In testimony earlier this month before the Senate Banking Committee, Treasury Under Secretary Lawrence H. Summers acknowledged that China's desire to be a founding member of the organization was the principal lever the Administration could use to persuade China to open its markets.
The O.E.C.D. official said China's compulsion to join the new trade group from the outset was driven by national prestige and by its desire to beat Taiwan, which has met virtually all the terms for membership. "It's national prestige," he said. "That's it. On the other hand, China's real concern is that it gets in before Taiwan, and Taiwan is pretty much ready to go."
"If the U.S. said no," the official said, "it would be extremely difficult for China to get in. The whole thing works on consensus. No one wants a blowup. But actually the Europeans rather enjoy the U.S. taking the hard line, while they take the soft line."
Ms. Barshefsky, consistent with the hard line adopted by the Administration, placed the burden of qualifying for membership squarely on Beijing. "We want China in the GATT and the W.T.O.," she said. "China surely must be in the great international institutions and multilateral system. But China is not special. China must make adjustments."

HEADLINE: Rebellion Of Greens Is Brewing In the West

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., July 22

 BODY:
The politics of environmentalism is once again provoking outrage in the West, where anger among farmers and ranchers crystallized a generation ago in the Sagebrush Rebellion.
But this time it is environmentalists who are rebelling, fielding a third-party slate in New Mexico. 
 Political analysts here say that the Green Party, often referred to as the Greens, is not to be taken lightly in a state swelling with newcomers drawn largely by the natural splendors of soaring mountain peaks and lush valleys. As voters, such newcomers are far more likely to join the Sierra Club than the Cattlemen's Association.
Even the state's Democratic Party leaders, while discounting the chances of a Green victory in November elections, have expressed fears that the third party could help Republicans wrest the Governor's office from Bruce King, a Democrat seeking his fourth term.
"I wouldn't count the Greens out by any means," said Roger Morris, a political analyst and writer here who served in the Administrations of Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Lyndon B. Johnson. "There are a lot of people who have come to New Mexico looking for an alternative way. And they're going to give support and money to the Greens."
 
Experienced Candidate
 While third-party candidates generally face daunting odds, two Governors were elected as independents in 1990: Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in Connecticut and Walter J. Hickel in Alaska.
The Green Party here achieved instant credibility by virtue of its candidate for governor: Roberto Mondragon, a former Lieutenant Governor (as a Democrat) and Spanish-language radio broadcaster.
With his political background, Mr. Mondragon has helped to dispel the image of the Greens as pie-in-the-sky idealists without any practical experience in government. And as a native of Guadalupe County who grew up tending goats and chickens near the banks of the Pecos River, he lends ethnic diversity to a movement sometimes dismissed as a fashionable hobby for well-to-do whites.
"The Green Party stands for what the state Democratic Party ought to stand for," Mr. Mondragon said as he sat in the shade of a cottonwood tree in the plaza of downtown Santa Fe.
The party is also backing candidates for lieutenant governor, state treasurer, land commissioner and a Congressional seat.
 If the Greens achieve a measure of success in the New Mexico elections, environmentalists and political experts say it could presage similar campaigns in other Western states.
New Mexico, while culturally distinctive with its Spanish and ancient Indian cultures, is a traditional bellwether in national politics. Since it joined the union in 1912, the state has backed the winning Presidential candidate in every election but one, in 1976, when voters here supported Gerald R. Ford. And the changes taking place in New Mexico, with more new jobs being created in boutiques than on ranches, mirror the economic and political trends throughout the West.
 
Attracted to Party Stands
 Mr. Mondragon, who was elected to the New Mexico Legislature at the age of 25, worked in the Presidential campaigns of Robert F. Kennedy, George McGovern, Edward M. Kennedy and Jesse Jackson. He said he had never belonged to an environmental group but had accepted the offer to run as a Green because the party took liberal positions on a wide range of issues, from abortion rights to health care for all Americans.
"There used to be room for liberals in the Democratic Party here," he said. "But there isn't room anymore. If you look at the contributors for the Democratic Party today, it's the same people that you'll find on the list of contributors for the Republican Party."
On environmental issues, Mr. Mondragon said, the Green Party would take "a more realistic approach" than some environmentalists might favor. He said, for example, that he "wouldn't want to sacrifice the job of a local person for the sake of a tree."
But he said the Democrats in New Mexico had neglected the state's interests on many environmental issues. As examples, he cited Democratic support for a planned nuclear waste storage site near Carlsbad and tax breaks for Albuquerque corporations that consume huge amounts of water. And he said Democrats had failed to deal with the pollution of the Red River Valley by tailings from a molybdenum mine near Questa.
With his shoulder-length gray hair and beard, black boots and silver bracelet, Mr. Mondragon has a counterculture style that fits easily into the artsy world of Santa Fe. He has been known to draw a crowd simply by sitting on the hood of his car and strumming a guitar. It is less clear how voters in business suits in suburban Albuquerque and Las Cruces will warm to his candidacy.
He has said he will not accept contributions from individuals of more than $100. Mr. Mondragon, who appeared in the 1988 movie "The Milagro Bean Field Wars," hinted that "some Hollywood actors" might help his campaign raise money. The movie was produced by Robert Redford, who has long been active in liberal politics and environmental causes.
 
Republican Appears to Lead
 A survey of 500 registered voters on the governor's race, published in The Albuquerque Journal last Sunday, found the Republican candidate, Gary Johnson, leading with 37 percent. Governor King had 29 percent and Mr. Mondragon 9 percent. About one-quarter of the voters said they were undecided. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points for the survey, conducted July 12 through 14.
Political analysts say the poll was taken much too early in the campaign to be meaningful, especially since the Green Party announced its candidates only a few weeks ago. Even so, Mr. Morris said it was "astonishing" that Mr. Mondragon would draw nearly 10 percent of the vote even before his candidacy became widely known.
The Greens, a loose-knit political movement in the United States not connected with the political parties of the same name in Europe, also plans to sponsor candidates this fall in Alaska, Arizona, California and Hawaii.
The fortunes of the Greens here rest largely on the difficulties of the two major political parties. Governor King, a 70-year-old rancher with a folksy style and the reputation of a deal-making politician, appears to be vulnerable after a bruising Democratic primary. In a three-way contest, he won the nomination with just 39 percent of the vote.
And the Republicans enter almost any statewide race with a disadvantage, since they are outnumbered by Democrats nearly 2 to 1. If elected, Mr. Johnson, a self-made millionaire in the construction business, would be only the second Republican Governor here in more than 20 years.
 
Help Seen for G.O.P.
 Ray Powell, the Democratic Party chairman, expressed surprise and chagrin that Mr. Mondragon would run under the Green banner, a candidacy that Mr. Powell said could only help the Republicans.
"He has worked all his life for the benefit of disadvantaged people," Mr. Powell said. "And the only possible thing he's going to accomplish here is helping Gary Johnson, a man who is antagonistic to everything Roberto has ever stood for."
But John Rensenbrink, who publishes The Green Horizons newsletter on environmentalist politics, said the Democratic Party had not earned the loyalty of environmentalists.
"In some cases, it's true that our entry might result in a Republican winning," Mr. Rensenbrink said. "But the Democrats just have not come through for us."
Mr. Mondragon said he did not consider himself a spoiler, insisting, "We're in this to win."
