HEADLINE: A Rights Leader Minimizes Racism as a Poverty Factor

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
In a marked departure from the longtime stance of many other civil rights leaders, the new head of the National Urban League is minimizing the significance of white racism as a factor in the poverty of inner-city blacks.
In a speech that he is to deliver on Sunday, Hugh P. Price, the league's president and chief executive officer, says that although racism is "still a well-documented and undeniable reality," intensified economic competition and employers' resulting need for better-educated, better-skilled workers are larger contributors to urban poverty. 
 "We must not let ourselves, and especially children, fall into the paranoid trap of thinking that racism accounts for all that plagues us," says the text of the speech, a copy of which was provided by the league. "The global realignment of work and wealth is, if anything, the bigger culprit."
The speech, the keynote address of the National Urban League's convention in Indianapolis, is the first policy statement by Mr. Price, a 52-year-old former vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation, since he assumed the leadership of the league on July 5. In tone and content, it reflects a sharp distinction from other civil rights leaders, most notably the Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
 
'Racial Inclusion'
 For instance, while in recent months Mr. Chavis has publicly embraced black figures like Louis Farrakhan who have long advocated keeping political distance from whites, Mr. Price's speech emphasizes "racial inclusion."
"For all our suffering," the speech says, "we cannot become so fixated on our problems that we ignore our commonality of interests with others. All the problems I've addressed this evening -- inadequate schooling, idle and alienated youngsters, and chronic unemployment -- cut across racial lines. If we're ever to deal with them on a scale remotely equal to their size, we must coalesce with people of other complexions who feel the same pain, even if it isn't as acute."
And in a clear rebuff to Mr. Farrakhan, Mr. Price singles out Jews for praise, calling them "longstanding allies" for civil rights.
"Many whites of good will have accompanied us on our long journey for racial, social and economic justice," Mr. Price says. "None has matched the Jewish community as long-distance runners in the civil rights movement."
 
Focus on Underclass
 The speech is also noteworthy for its scarcity of references to goals that have been of primary interest to the black middle class: the setting aside of some government contracts for black-owned businesses and some scholarships for black students, the placement of more blacks in corporate board rooms and executive suites, and other affirmative action efforts. Instead, Mr. Price focuses on the inner-city poor, at one point asking the black middle class for financial contributions to a program intended to help poor youths.
"It's a moral imperative," Mr. Price said by telephone from Indianapolis, referring to his emphasis on the urban underclass. "And as a pragmatic matter, their pain affects us. The cynicism of kids growing up in the inner cities contributes to behaviors that are reported on the evening news, which ensnare all of our kids in negative stereotypes."
In his speech, Mr. Price urges blacks who can afford to do so to donate $500 or $1,000 to pay for counselors and other workers in the fledgling inner-city-youth program. The program, he says, would be run by community groups, other nonprofit bodies like the Y.M.C.A. and churches, and the Urban League would help raise the money and monitor how it was spent.
"There is that old saying that it takes a village to raise a child," Mr. Price said in the telephone interview. "Well, the black middle class has moved out of the village. That's the natural order of things. I don't ask the middle class to move back. But they have to move back spiritually, or at least financially."
In his address, Mr. Price also argues that business and government should be pressured to set aside jobs and training positions for poor people regardless of race, a stance that departs from civil rights groups' quarter-century-old advocacy of race-based preference programs.
Mr. Price contends that such a shift is needed both to respond to court rulings that have limited racial set-asides and to build political support.
"What if employers reserved training slots and real jobs for residents of neighborhoods or census tracts with high unemployment rates?" he said. "The way I see it, this wouldn't be a politically contentious race-based approach. Instead, it's a more palatable alternative which recognizes that poor people of all races need decent jobs."

HEADLINE: World Bank, At 50, Vows To Do Better

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
Marking its 50th anniversary, the World Bank vowed this week to be more selective about where it handed out loans and more sensitive to the environmental effects of its projects. It also promised to put more emphasis on human development programs rather than huge dams and power plants.
At a news conference at the World Bank's headquarters in Washington, the president of the bank, Lewis Preston, issued a "vision" statement detailing where the world's biggest lender intends to go in this new era dominated by free markets. 
 The World Bank, which originally focused on lending money to developing countries for projects like building roads, was born at an international conference at Bretton Woods, N.H., in July 1944.
In its statement, titled "Embracing the Future," Mr. Preston said the bank aimed now to meet five basic challenges. They include promoting broad-based economic growth that particularly benefits the poor and investing more in human development programs that support education, nutrition, family planning and the role of women. Human resource development now accounts for 17 percent of all World Bank loans, as opposed to 5 percent a decade ago.
 
'Increasing Diversity'
 Other goals are protecting the environment; stimulating private sectors so developing countries can become more competitive in the global economy, and reorienting governments to become more efficient at complementing the private sector, particularly in developing countries and former Communist lands.
"Given the increasing diversity among developing countries, the emphasis on each of those roles will vary according to specific circumstances," Mr. Preston said.
"In some of the middle-income nations of East Asia and Latin America, for example, those that can now attract high levels of private investment, the bank's financing will be relatively less important than its advice. By contrast, in the low-income countries of South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa, both our advice and large levels of financing will remain important for some time to come."
The needs of the centrally planned economies are different, Mr. Preston added. There, the bank's technical aid "will be important in helping to build market systems where there is little private-sector capacity and the bank's money will be catalytic in leveraging much larger flows of private capital."
 
The Critics Respond
 No sooner was Mr. Preston's report out than the bank's critics were responding. An ad hoc coalition known as the "50 Years Is Enough" campaign, made up of environmentalists, human rights advocates and some competing aid groups, suggested that the best change for the bank would be to go out of business.
The bank, the group said, should stop inflicting on the world a development approach that ignored the environment and a financing approach that emphasized macro-economic adjustment policies -- particularly cuts in Government spending and subsidies -- which tend to fall heaviest on the poor.
Doug Hellinger, managing director of the Development Gap and part of the "50 Years Is Enough" coalition, said: " 'Embracing the Future' should be entitled 'Shoving Aside the Poor.' In this new global economy the gap between rich and poor is widening and the destruction of the natural environment is accelerating."
At the news conference on Tuesday, Mr. Preston acknowledged that if there was one major mistake the bank made in its first 50 years, it was paying too little attention to environmental effects from projects.
 
200 Environmentalists Now
 "I think that the mistake the bank has paid the highest price for was not recognizing the importance of the environment," Mr. Preston said. "Initially they perceived that there was a conflict between development and environment. That mistake, I think, has in terms of the criticisms of the bank eroded some of the support the bank is entitled to."
Mr. Preston argued in an interview that this criticism was now "very much out of date" because in the 1980's there were three environmentalists on a staff of 11,000 employees and today there are 200.
Mr. Preston acknowledged that in the 1970's the bank had a clear-cut orientation toward helping state-owned enterprises become more efficient, but since then it has focused increasingly on getting countries to open their markets and sell off state-owned enterprises to put them in more efficient private hands. The bank, he said, has now financed more than 400 privatizations.

HEADLINE: As Vote Nears, Detroit Edges Closer to Gambling

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 23

 BODY:
Detroiters have rejected proposals to legalize casino gambling four times, most recently last year. But the success of gaming in a Canadian city just across the Detroit River may inspire voters to change their minds on Aug. 2.
On that day, Detroit residents will vote on two proposals, one to allow a casino on a moored riverboat and another to allow a casino owned by American Indians in Greektown, a downtown restaurant district. 
 The results could hinge on voters' feelings about the success of the new casino in Windsor, Ontario, which officials say has drawn nearly $1 million a day, much of it from Detroit, across the border.
Windsor, a staid blue-collar city of tidy small homes and just under 200,000 people, would not have been anyone's candidate for Canada's Reno. Since Casino Windsor, Ontario's first such operation, opened in a renovated art gallery on May 17, 19,000 people a day, on average, have been gambling, and casino and city officials say 80 percent to 85 percent of them come from the United States.
Those officials project that the crowds will get even bigger after a permanent casino is completed in 1995 at a cost of $300 million. As a result, many Detroit residents say it is time to grab a piece of the action.
 
Momentum Toward Approval
 "I think it would be a very good idea to have a casino in Detroit," said Sonya Grant, a 30-year-old student at Wayne State University and a former real estate broker. "I've been to the one in Windsor, but I don't like the idea of all our money going over there when we really need it here."
There have been no polls on the casino proposals, but the opposition to gambling in Detroit appears to be softening at a time when several states are turning to gambling as a source of revenue. After roundly rejecting casinos three times, the voters were more evenly split last year, with 51 percent opposed to legalizing gaming and 49 percent in favor.
Another factor in the vote may be black ministers. Their opinions are influential in Detroit, where 75 percent of the voters are black. Although the ministers solidly opposed the previous proposals, some prominent ministers are supporting the gambling proposals this year.
Gambling is still solidly condemned by the Council of Baptist Pastors and the city's new Mayor, Dennis Archer. While he is seeking economic growth, Mr. Archer said, "Casino gambling is not the answer."
But other Detroit residents are impressed with the 1,700 jobs that officials say Casino Windsor has created. The Detroit News, reversing its position, is supporting the proposals.
Some Windsor residents worry that Detroit casinos could end their city's miniboom. The Mayor there, Mike Hurst, said, "The casino is a very welcome part of our downtown revitalization, but just one part."
Mayor Hurst offered some advice for cities that are considering a casino: "The key is to do a lot of preparation, recognize that there is a down side to casinos, and don't put all your eggs in one basket."

HEADLINE: A Party for a Cleared Police Officer Stirs Up Racial Tension

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 22

 BODY:
A month after Officer Donald Brown's welcome-back party, people here are still talking about it.
Officer Brown, who is white, had been on a paid leave of absence for killing an unarmed black man last winter, a case that had already caused an uproar, not least because of what many saw as the Police Department's unlikely portrayal of it: as an accident growing out of a mistake that stemmed from a hoax. 
 A grand jury cleared Officer Brown of wrongdoing, and a police commission decided not to hold disciplinary hearings, so his friends and colleagues decided to give him a party at the Ale House, a downtown tavern.
"Congratulate Don on a job well done (Keep up the good work)," read the invitations, which were posted at Police Headquarters.
 
Marches of Protest
 The party-givers say they were just trying to cheer up a colleague who had been devastated by the shooting. But to many others, the party sounded like a celebration of the death of Benjamin Schoolfield, the 20-year-old man whom the officer had shot to death. Blacks also point to a ham that was given to Officer Brown as a present at the party -- a gift traditionally exchanged, they say, by white vigilantes of the Old South.
Elected officials, white and black alike, have since denounced the party -- held on June 16 and attended by more than 200 people, about a third of them police officers -- as at least tasteless. Marches have been held to protest the gathering, and the police are now conducting an internal investigation of it.
The case has also led to a searching discussion of race and racism in this old, economically struggling New England city, the home of Merriam Webster dictionaries, George Washington's first arsenal, the Basketball Hall of Fame, Smith & Wesson guns, a growing number of violent street gangs and, according to the 1990 census, 156,983 people, of whom 28,484 are black.
"Why would they congratulate someone for a shooting?" said Chelan Jenkins, an 18-year-old friend of the Schoolfield family who has helped organize marches and vigils to protest both the shooting and the party.
To the protesters and their sympathizers, the party only heaped insult on injury; it came as the furor over the killing itself had not yet cooled.
 
Report of a Stolen Van
 The events that led to the killing began when a woman dialed 911 and reported that her van had been stolen at gunpoint. That call, the police now believe, was a hoax, perpetrated by the woman because she was afraid to tell her boyfriend that she had lent the van to an acquaintance, who in turn lent it to Mr. Schoolfield.
But when Officer Brown and his partner saw the van, a gray 1977 Dodge, on the night of Feb. 7, they assumed that armed robbers were driving it, the police said. Only a week earlier, three police officers in New England had been shot to death in the line of duty -- an extraordinary number for so brief a period in this region -- and Officer Brown had gone to one of the funerals, in Paxton, about 40 miles east of Springfield.
After the officers pulled the van over, Officer Brown, 27, who had been on the force for 17 months, got out of the police car. It is at this point that the police account becomes implausible, in the view of civil rights advocates here.
"Donald Brown approached the front of the van, and the window broke," Sergeant Reid said. "He misjudged his distance. He ran up to the van, and it just so happened that the gun and him went through the window. There was a struggle for the weapon. Brown was trying to retrieve his weapon from the van, and at the same time the van goes in reverse and the gun discharges, which propels Brown into the middle of the street."
 
What Did a Gift Mean?
 Despite the official rulings in Officer Brown's favor, rights organizations have persuaded the United States Justice Department to open an inquiry into the shooting. Tensions worsened when the Western Massachusetts Order of Black Law Enforcement Officers said that during the party last month, a ham was presented to Officer Brown. The ham, the group said, was a ritual gift of Old South vigilantes.
The Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, says he heard of the ritual when he was growing up in eastern North Carolina.
"When African-Americans would escape from prison," Mr. Chavis said in an interview, "a posse would be formed. The people who brought him back, dead or alive, would be presented with hams. It's something that white vigilantes would be rewarded with sometimes for committing acts of racial violence."
At its recent convention in Chicago, the N.A.A.C.P. passed a resolution condemning both the shooting and the party.
To Chester J. Ardolino, the president of the Patrolmen's Union in Springfield, the N.A.A.C.P. response was an overreaction. "I don't think anybody was intentionally intending to offend anyone," said Mr. Ardolino, who was at the party. "At the worst, it was in poor taste."
Mr. Ardolino confirmed that a ham had been presented as a gift but said that he -- and, to his knowledge, everyone else at the party -- had been unaware of any ritual significance to it.
 
'An Unfair Shake'
 Officer Brown, on the advice of his lawyer, would discuss neither the shooting nor the party in detail. But in his first interview since the shooting, he said: "I have definitely gotten an unfair shake. It appears that there's a political game going on here."
He is supported by the Chief of Police, Ernest M. Stelzer. "I can see it happening," Chief Stelzer said of the police account of the shooting. "At night, under those circumstances, you're running with your weapon drawn."
A majority of the civilian commission that oversees the Police Department apparently agreed with that view; it voted 3 to 2 against holding disciplinary hearings. But Henry M. Thomas 3d, the panel's chairman, who is also the executive director of the local Urban League, said hearings should have been held. "I don't think anybody walked away with a confirmation of how the window got broken," he said. Mr. Thomas, who is black, and a Hispanic member voted for the hearings; the panel's three white members voted against.
Dante L. Molta, an investigator for the lawyers representing the Schoolfield family, says he has interviewed five witnesses who say that Officer Brown shot Mr. Schoolfield through the van's window.
Not likely, says the Hampden County District Attorney, William M. Bennett. He says forensic tests found no traces of glass on the bullet or in Mr. Schoolfield's wound, so the bullet could not have passed through the window. "I think the whole situation was a tragic accident," he said. "Period."
Mr. Bennett acknowledges that Officer Brown suffered no cuts or other injuries as a result of slamming his arm through the window. "Difficult to do," he said, "but not impossible."
Still, many people find it hard to believe that Officer Brown broke the van's window by smashing into it. "To accept it, you have to stretch the imagination a bit," said Benjamin Swan, who headed the local chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. before he became a State Representative. "It left a lot of people in wonderment."
Mr. Schoolfield's family is now considering suing the city, the Schoolfields' lawyers say.
 
Bellwether Effort on Race
 A 32-year-old cousin, David Broxton, remembers Mr. Schoolfield, who was unemployed at the time of the shooting, as always playing Sega video games and basketball, a sport that was invented in this city just over a century ago.
"He was going to move to Oakland, Calif., with his father the next month," Mr. Broxton said, shaking his head. "He was going to do construction work with his father."
Springfield had thought that it quelled racial tensions half a century ago, a result of a program taught in the city's schools that these days would probably be called multicultural. Its efforts were chronicled in a 1945 book, "The Story of the Springfield Plan: One Community's Total War Against Prejudice," and a Warner Brothers film, "It Happened in Springfield."
But now residents are not so sure. Speaking of the welcome-back party for Officer Brown, Chief Stelzer said, "It just caused a lot of unnecessary tension and ill feeling throughout the department and the community."

HEADLINE: Benefits Are an Important Consideration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The New Faces of U.S. Manufacturing" (July 3), Louis Uchitelle writes that at the Rotoflow Corporation "automation has helped to keep the average blue collar wage at $13 an hour." This I did not say in my interview with him and it is totally incorrect. Average rates may be $13 an hour, but this is because of prevailing market rates and not because of automation. In fact, automation usually requires higher skilled workers (albeit fewer in number), and they can command higher pay rates for these skills. We have machinists earning over $19 an hour and, in general, wages at Rotoflow have been growing much faster than the national average. 
 Mr. Uchitelle doesn't even touch upon a significant portion of remuneration -- benefits. The impression from his article is that our employees are only payed $13 an hour and not much more than laborers in the garment and furniture industries. However, in the last few years we have introduced: family medical Insurance, 90 percent paid for by Rotoflow; sick leave; short- and long-term disability insurance; 401 (k) and pension plans, and annual leave of two, three or four weeks based on years of service.
I feel a balanced article should have made reference to the total remuneration package for our employees. We pay "market rates" in terms of the hourly rate but supplement this with the above benefits, thereby giving a compensation package well above the average.
 
FRANK VAN GOGH
Gardena, Calif., July 12
 
The writer is president of the Rotoflow Corporation.

HEADLINE: Squeeze the Dominican Republic

BYLINE: By Ronald V. Dellums; Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California, is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee and a member of the Congressional Black Caucus.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Frustration over the Haitian military's refusal to restore the democratically elected Government, anxiety over waves of refugees heading to our shores and horror over capsized boats have generated calls for the forcible removal of Haiti's military. The Administration wants to preserve this option, and has sought explicit United Nations endorsement.
Macabre and protracted repression by Haiti's military has led many who have always opposed United States intervention abroad to embrace this position. Yet U.S. policymakers should consider the use of force -- anywhere -- only as a last resort. 
 The Administration has properly placed our enormous leverage on the side of democracy in Haiti. Since President Clinton appointed William Gray 3d as special envoy in May, U.S. policy has been far more resolute. To achieve our goals without military intervention, however, the White House must further refine its refugee policy and its push for comprehensive sanctions.
While rough seas and a crackdown by the Haitian military have stemmed the flow of refugees, there is no guarantee that this trend will last. And as long as the U.S. refuses to provide safe haven to any Haitian refugee intercepted at sea, our appeals to regional countries to do so will be met with understandable resistance. If we are to address charges of racism in our refugee policy, we must agree to provide safe haven to a reasonable percentage of boat people.
In addition, the Administration has not yet done all it can on sanctions. The U.S. has been maddeningly slow to use its full leverage to shut down the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic. As soon as darkness falls, constant trade across it makes a joke of the embargo.
Only last week, the Administration pledged $15 million in military materiel, including helicopters, vehicles and communications equipment, to help the Dominican Republic seal the border, as Mr. Gray recommended two months ago. Mr. Clinton must not allow interagency squabbling, long the Achilles' heel of U.S. policy on Haiti, to undermine his authority. Yet the failure of the Dominican President, Joaquin Balaguer, to enforce sanctions cannot solely be ascribed to a lack of means to do so: it reflects both a lack of political will and longstanding links between business and military leaders in Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
President Clinton, therefore, ought to quickly incorporate into his Haiti policy provisions in the Governors Island Reinforcement Act, which now has more than 100 bipartisan co-sponsors in Congress, that would deny U.S. aid to the Dominican Republic if it continues to violate the sanctions.
Mr. Balaguer must be made to understand that $22 million in foreign aid for 1994 and the $180 million quota the U.S. reserves for Dominican sugar are at risk. And the Administration should make clear that, in return for military assistance, it expects quick, substantial progress on sealing the border.
The Haitian crisis is too dehumanizing for Haitians, too costly politically and economically for the U.S. and too threatening to democracy in the region for the Dominican Republic to be anything other than a committed partner in this effort. By not putting pressure on the Balaguer Government now, the Administration makes a military solution unavoidable.
A firm U.S. commitment to these strategies can restore democracy to Haiti without military force. But opposition to the use of force should not be misconstrued as a lessening of U.S. resolve that Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and his high command must step down and of our commitment to restore the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the exiled President.
Many lament that sanctions will hurt only those we are trying to help. Yet while sanctions may hurt, Haiti's military kills -- more than 4,000 people since the 1991 coup. With neither airtight sanctions nor military intervention, the status quo will prevail. This would be a defeat not only for President Aristide and Haiti but for democracy throughout the region. And it would be a major failure for the Administration in light of its commitment to promote democracy abroad.
The Dominican Republic is Haiti's lifeline to the outside world, just as South Africa was Rhodesia's in the 1970's during Rhodesia's attempt to circumvent sanctions. The international community prevailed against white supremacy then, and we must prevail against despotism and military rule now.

HEADLINE: War Fever Over Haiti

 BODY:
President Clinton, feeling less pressure from refugees and sensing opposition at home, is having second thoughts about the urgency of invading Haiti. First, he wants a new, Desert Storm-style United Nations resolution that he hopes can persuade Gen. Raoul Cedras and his cronies to leave on their own. Yet the U.N. strategy, which would authorize member countries to use "all necessary means" to restore President Aristide to power and disarm his opponents, also relies on the logic of a military solution.
Meanwhile, U.S. forces conspicuously practice invasion preparations off the Haitian coast and White House and State Department aides pepper the airwaves with pointed warnings. Federal prosecutors investigate drug charges against Haitian military leaders in ways that are certain to recall the indictment of Manuel Noriega that became a key justification for the 1989 invasion of Panama. 
 Physically removing General Cedras and his cronies from Haiti should be easy work for a large enough expeditionary force. But then what? Military force is a notoriously blunt instrument for solving political problems.
Unlike many opponents of military intervention, this page fully endorses the return of President Aristide to power and harbors no illusions about the intentions of General Cedras and his murderous cohorts. But invasions, even of small countries with weak armies, are not a rational solution to Presidential frustration, the need to look tough or lack of other ideas. To invade would be an irresponsible use of the world's most formidable military force.
The Administration hopes for a U.N. vote this week. But it will take another month at least to recruit countries to join in an invasion and a subsequent peacekeeping force. Administration hawks should use the delay to throw off their war fever.
The Clinton Administration has yet to present compelling arguments that invading Haiti is in the best interests of the United States. Human rights are being massively and flagrantly abused. But over the long months when Washington looked the other way for fear of having to grant asylum to fleeing refugees, the terror was almost as bad. Similarly, drug allegations have been kicking around for years, but until very recently, Washington seemed eager to talk down their significance.
The surge of refugee departures has fallen off drastically in recent days, since Washington began denying boat people any chance of entry to the U.S., while providing safe havens elsewhere. At last, the Administration has found a politically sustainable refugee policy.
Meanwhile, public opinion remains skeptical or downright hostile to the use of U.S. military force in Haiti. The Constitution and the precedent established in the Persian Gulf war would require Congressional, not just U.N., approval for an invasion.
Horrible things are going on in Haiti. Democracy has been hijacked. People are being terrorized and a pitiful economy is being strangled. These are good reasons to put the strongest diplomatic and economic pressure on the junta and to provide sanctuary to fleeing refugees. They are not good reasons to send in the Marines.

HEADLINE: Hidden Arsenal: Gun Owners, Their Weapons and Their Reasons

 BODY:
Born of the frontier, America has always been an armed society. Scratch the surface and guns turn up in surprising places, for surprising reasons. As he traveled the New York area recently, a photographer for The New York Times asked people whether they were armed, and discovered a netherworld of weaponry. 
 Surveys show that close to half the country's households keep a firearm, and Federal officials estimate that 200 million guns or more may be in circulation. Even in places like New York, where the law severely restricts gun ownership, people keep guns for all kinds of purposes, from hunting to target shooting to collecting to self-defense to the furtherance of criminal deeds.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CENTRAL BRONX;
4 Strip Malls Planned for Store-Scarce Neighborhoods

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Four shopping strips are to be developed in the next year in the central Bronx under a city program intended to encourage the growth of retailing in inner-city neighborhoods. Two others are planned for the South Bronx.
Over the last two decades, three neighborhoods in these areas -- Tremont, Crotona Park and Mott Haven -- have seen a tremendous growth in low-cost housing units, but the population boom has not been matched by a growth in stores and other services. Fearful of crime and red-lining, retailers, especially national or regional chains, have stayed away. 
 "In those areas, you'll see thousands of people with virtually no commercial space around them," said Michael K. Pride, of the city Economic Development Corporation's Bronx bureau.
Mr. Pride said this was the first time the agency was testing its Neighborhood Retail Development Program in the Bronx. Several such retail strips have already been developed in Brooklyn. Under the program, the city sells public lands to developers at reduced interest rates and subsidizes construction costs. Although contracts have yet to be signed, the agency has chosen four local developers to build six retail sites, two in each neighborhood.
The Procida Organization, which has already built low-cost residential units in those areas, will build one strip in each. Christine Procida, a co-president of the company, said she hoped to open two of the three sites by the end of 1995.
In two sites -- on the corner of Freeman Street and Boulevard in Crotona Park East, and on Third Avenue between East 174 and 175th Streets in East Tremont -- the developer expects tenants like drug stores, video stores, dry cleaners and check-cashing centers. Clothing stores are likely to move into a third strip on East 149th Street and Brook Avenue in Mott Haven, she said.
These three sites, varying from 30,000 to 50,000 square feet, will be developed for about $10 million, Ms. Procida said.
"We like these three sites because they're in areas where our firm has built a lot of residential housing," she added. "We've been in this area. We know the marketplace. And we feel that it's an untapped market."
Independently of the city program, Procida is building a retail strip on East 180th Street and Crotona Avenue in East Tremont, which is to open next month. That center will include a Rite Aid Pharmacy as well as a dry cleaner, pet shop and Chinese food store, Ms. Procida said.
"Traditionally, in the inner city, we have local merchants that do well, but the main retailers haven't come to the inner city," she said. "They're starting to realize that there is a market here. They're not diving in, but they're getting their feet wet. Now, in the Bronx, people can't just go down the street and pay for affordable goods."
The Neighborhood Retail Development Program was initiated in 1992 under the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins. Speaking in the wake of the Los Angeles riots, the mayor emphasized the importance of building complete neighborhoods in New York -- with residential, as well as commercial, buildings. The city set aside $7.5 million in construction subsidies to spur the creation of businesses in areas with large populations but few services.
The communities in which the program was first tested were in Bushwick, along Broadway between Gates and Cornelia Streets; Brownsville, at Rockaway and Pitkin Avenues; and Coney Island, along Mermaid Avenue between West 29th and West 31st Streets. The city had built hundreds of low-, moderate- and middle-income housing units in these neighborhoods, but few businesses opened to meet the rising demand.
Often, banks have shied away from financing projects in poor neighborhoods. But Chase Manhattan and Chemical Banks agreed to make construction loans available to developers chosen by the Economic Development Corporation. NORIMITSU ONISHI

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLETS POINT
Enough Yankees Already. The Mets Have Their Own Plans;
Industrial Park To Be Revamped Somewhere Else

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Auto shops in buildings made of cinder blocks with plastic roofs perch alongside the dirt road. The sewers have not drained water in more than a decade, and the dirt road is almost always flooded, forcing drivers to crawl around huge puddles. Mountains of used tires have formed, overnight and illegally, on street corners.
And amid all this there is the chaos of an unregulated mini-economy. Equipment spills out of stores onto sidewalks and streets. Cars swerve to avoid collisions. A man shows two others how to use a circular saw in the middle of the street. 
 This is the Willets Point Industrial Park, a 13-block collection of small auto shops, food distributors and light manufacturers, just east of Shea Stadium. Bordered by 126th Street, Willets Point and Northern Boulevards, the industrial park is home to about 125 businesses that employ 3,000 people, according to the Willets Point Business Association.
But to many outsiders this industrial park -- as the businesses call themselves -- has long been an eyesore taking up space in a valuable real estate area. And although ground-breaking for the new domed Shea Stadium and an adjoining entertainment center is years away, the city says it is ready to begin taking steps toward relocating the Willets Point businesses.
"Our plan would look at total relocation," said Rudy Washington, commissioner of the city's Department of Business Services. "The massive size of the Mets' project would smother any existing businesses in the area." He said the timing and costs have yet to be determined, but the Mets have offered to defray some of the costs.
"Some people may be upset, but they should look at relocation as an opportunity," he said, since the businesses could move closer to demand centers. "We're not moving you out of the Taj Mahal."
Anne Fodera Rosengarten, an owner of the House of Fodera, a food distributorship, said she was worried the Willets Point businesses would have little say in their move.
"They've mentioned the Brooklyn Navy Yard, but I don't want to go to Brooklyn," she said. "What if I want to move to Nassau County or New Jersey? Will they pay for that? We're talking about a financially strapped city here."
This is not the first time that plans for development have threatened the Willets Point businesses.
In 1986, Donald J. Trump and others proposed building a domed stadium to win back the Jets, who left Shea Stadium for New Jersey in 1983. But neither the Jets nor any other football team could be lured to Flushing Bay.
Since that plan failed, new businesses, many of them Korean-owned, have opened despite the lack of paved roads and a deteriorated sewage system.
But the city has postponed spending $20 million on repairs. One frustrated business paved a side street on its own.
Daniel Feinstein is the owner of Feinstein Iron Works, which has been in Willets Point for 22 years and employs 20 people.
"I'm paying the same taxes here that I would in Long Island City on a paved street," he said. N.O.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:
Tough City, Gritty Streets, And Rock's Hidden Roots
 Did you realize that Elvis Presley recorded "Hound Dog" on 24th Street? Or that the tenement on Led Zeppelin's "Physical Graffiti" album cover is on St. Marks Place? 
 These are just a few of the facts that have been accumulated by Danny Fields, who used to manage rock acts, and Sal Cataldi, partners in a new venture called the Rock and Roll Tour of New York.
The bus tour, which began six weeks ago, starts and concludes at (where else?) the Hard Rock Cafe, at 221 West 57th Street.
Mr. Fields, a former manager of the Ramones, Iggy Pop and Lou Reed, who also worked as a publicity agent for the Doors, "has lots of inside stories to tell," said Mr. Cataldi.
"We go places like the original Peppermint Lounge, where a guy named Killer Joe Piro invented the twist," Mr. Cataldi said, "to Joni Mitchell's old apartment on West 16th Street where she wrote 'Chelsea Morning' -- the song that inspired Hillary and Bill -- to the last places that Kurt Cobain went to in his final trip to New York City."
Tickets for the two-hour tour are $25.
 
 
Now Lending in Queens: Household Finance
 As part of a nationwide expansion into urban areas, the Household Finance Corporation has opened a branch at 159-11 Jamaica Avenue in Jamaica, Queens.
The corporation, which offers home and consumer loans, was founded in 1878 and calls itself "the oldest consumer finance company" in the nation, according to George Shea, a company spokesman.
"Because of the growing economy in Jamaica there is a great demand in lending services," said Mr. Shea, noting the growth of the black middle class in Jamaica and other neighborhoods in southeast Queens.
 
 
A Temporary Closing To Reinvent Rumpelmayer's
 Rumpelmayer's, the very pink ice cream parlor that has been a sweet stomping ground for children since the 1930's, has closed temporarily, for what its management calls a "substantial renovation."
The ice-cream parlor, in the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South, closed July 4 and will reopen by Oct. 1 as an updated version of its old self.
"It's not going to be as pink," said Ralph Stephenson, managing director of the St. Moritz. "But it will have subtle pink tones."
When it reopens, Rumpelmayer's will have "three different modes of dining" -- a sidewalk cafe in front; a confectioner's shop with candy and lots of ice cream in the middle of the shop, and a quiet dining area in the back.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Trying to Turn Downtown Around

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
IN MORE than two decades of public service, Carl Weisbrod has held some of the most important and challenging economic policy jobs in New York City government. But while Mr. Weisbrod's newest job, as the first president of a new Business Improvement District for lower Manhattan, is outside of government, it may prove to be the most ambitious one yet.
The aim of the business improvement district is to help reverse the economic erosion of the city's downtown economic center, where the recession and technological and other changes in the financial industries have left many buildings with vast amounts of vacant office space. 
 Armed with a budget of $8.6 million from a self-assessed tax of downtown property owners, the new district is scheduled to start operating on Jan. 1. Awaiting formal approval from the City Council, it has already been cleared by the City Planning Commission. Other sections of the city, like Times Square and the Grand Central Terminal area, already have used the business improvement districts to help clean up the neighborhood and improve public safety.
In lower Manhattan, where the problems run even deeper, it is a sign of the critical role the new district is expected to play in the area's development that a person of Mr. Weisbrod's stature and experience has been recruited to head it.
Last week, Mr. Weisbrod sat in his temporary office at the New York City Partnership, across from Battery Park, for an interview. Here are some of his comments.
 Q. Why does downtown need a business improvement district?
 A. What makes a business improvement district so attractive is that the community itself, the business community and the taxpayers in a smaller geographic area, get to determine their own priorities for providing supplemental services to improve the quality of life. Moreover, the crucial thing about lower Manhattan is that it provides an enormous tax base for the city as a whole. That base needs to be preserved and enhanced. It's one of the economic engines that drives the city, and the engine has got to run pretty smoothly. So this is not a parochial issue.
 Q. What can a business improvement district can do about downtown's problems?
 A. Well, to start with, we will have to focus on the need for a greater diversity among the kinds of businesses that are down here. Financial services is still the core industry in lower Manhattan and will remain so. But the economic landscape is changing. Just take one example. We're aiming to locate a software and information technology center downtown, which should end up not only serving the financial industry but also helping to attract new types of business. Remember, the perimeter of lower Manhattan is strong, and that's where development is taking place. It's the heart of downtown that is struggling and really needs attention.
 Q. But what makes you think you can reverse the exodus from downtown?
 A. In order to make lower Manhattan more attractive, we're also going to need to generate more round-the-clock activity. There's a synergy between a residential population and commercial operations. The larger the residential population, the more the services that population needs, and the more those services will be able to support a broader, more diversified commercial population as well. We are going to have to look at breaking down the historic barrier zoning has erected between residential and commercial activity.
 Q. What else can you do to attract people downtown?
 A. Tourism is obviously another important area. This is the birthplace of the city and, in fact, technically it is the birthplace of the nation. Just look around those four corners of Wall and Broad Streets. It's where George Washington took the oath of office; it's where the anarchists tried to bomb out the House of Morgan. It's where John Peter Zenger was acquitted of criminal libel and established for the first time the legal principal that truth is an absolute defense. What we can do is market downtown's history more clearly, market it in different languages. I think New Yorkers and residents of the region have yet to discover the truly world-class attractions of lower Manhattan.
 Q. What are your biggest obstacles?
 A. There are transportation problems. The subway connections to lower Manhattan are great, but this should be . . . a place where people can transfer from subway to commuter rail, where people can come by ferry and also join up with other forms of transportation. We also have one of the most magnificent harbors and waterfronts in the world. Certainly the most magnificent urban waterfront. It's legendary, it's majestic, but it has to be opened up more physically so we can appreciate it. Ultimately, we should create a pedestrian esplanade running from Battery Park City, looping around to South Street and then up to the East River Park.
 Q. So, if you are successful, what would downtown look like a decade from now?
 A. I think it would have a much more diverse economy. We'd see a lot of foreign investment. It would be closer to a 24-hour, 7-day-a-week community with increased street life on the weekends and in the evenings. The waterfront would be more accessible. Many people might even find it possible to walk to work. Lower Manhattan would be seen as the hottest part of the city where people wanted to live and work.
 Q. That sounds like quite an ambitious dream.
 A. Well, we wouldn't get anywhere if we didn't aim high.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carl Weisbrod, the first president of the Lower Manhattan Business Improvement District, in the canyons of his new realm. (Catrina Genovese for The New York Times)

CAREER: Joined city government in 1970, left in 1972 and returned in 1978 to direct Office of Midtown Enforcement. Executive director of Planning Commission, 1986-87. Director of Times Square redevelopment project, 1987-90. President, City Economic Development Corporation, 1990-93.

HEADLINE: COPING;
Just When You Thought the Worst Was Over

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
I KNEW I had it bad when the car turned onto a drive marked F.D.R. and the words "formal dining room" danced before my eyes. Maybe, I thought, I should have held out for an FDR, even though I think I did pretty well with my EIK w/Hrwd Flr, not to mention my Lo Mt and Gt Clsts.
They tell me that buying property ranks just below divorce and death in the stress sweepstakes. I believe it, especially in the funhouse mirror of New York real estate, where an agent once tried to convince me that a mini-refrigerator placed in a hallway detracted not a whit from the apartment's ambiance. 
 But with interest rates at a 30-year low and a recession-stricken market flooded with desperate sellers, I knew it was my time to buy. And so, feeling very grown-up and nervous and elated all at the same time, I became part of that 1994 first-quarter rise in condominium and co-op purchases recorded by the Real Estate Board of New York.
Now, there are plenty of books about how to negotiate mortgage rates, refinancing and the like. But I have yet to find a guide to help the first-time buyer make the necessary psychic adjustments after the deal is closed.
Fact, is, having survived brokers and closings and writing checks with many zeros, you are just getting to the good part.
From my present vantage point, at the beginning of the third quarter of 1994, I've come to believe that, as a first-time owner, life should be temporarily weird. You are obsessed with your new status, your new toy. You own a piece of the city, which is kind of like having a relationship with a manic-depressive with a lot of bad hair days.
As in any new venture, friends and relatives will weigh in with their opinions about things like knocking down walls, about which colors to paint the ones that stay up and about what to do about the floors.
I was also told that I should buy a dog. I was told that my place was big enough for children, even though I am single and live alone. I was told that ownership meant I would be stuck in New York forever, because the city was going down the tubes and people were fleeing in droves.
My advice about all this advice: Ignore it as soon as you put the house-warming gifts away.
This property-owner business does lead to a heightened desire to keep up with "the market." Now that I have absolutely no reasonable use for real-estate advertisements, I read them more avidly than ever, out of a perverse need to reassure myself that I got a sweet deal.
Like me, you will rejoice when you read in the newspaper that the entire area is slowly emerging from its five-year real-estate hibernation. Your heart will sink over phrases like "partial recovery." At parties, you will seek out the groups gossiping about purchase prices.
And you will start obsessing about facts of apartment life that you had learned to take for granted back in that simpler time when you were just a renter. The day will come when a neighbor casually says something like, "Yeah, the concert pianist with insomnia who lives under you is back from his European tour and he heads that committee determined to buy a new roof and increase the maintenance."
I've learned about the homeless man who was found living in my building, and about the time the mailroom door was stolen off its hinges. I discovered that the lights flicker. At my first shareholders' meeting, there was talk of mice, leaks and a slow super. I am afraid of scratches on my hardwood floors and disgusted by litter on the block. All of these things worry me. I'm starting to take them personally.
Still, it's been an overwhelmingly positive experience. Really. I moved into my Riverside Drive co-op apartment on a Friday back in April. I danced from room to room. I ran my fingers over the appliances and thought, "These are mine." I caressed my glass doorknobs, marveled at my mirrored closet doors and admired the classical lines of the (non-working) fireplace. I rose early to see the sunlight bursting through my eastern-exposure bedroom windows and stayed up to see the Hudson shimmering in the night.
Unlike all those unwanted advisers, friends in various stages of this property thing are like a support group. A lawyer friend and her husband hope to close soon on a huge apartment near Central Park. She admitted to me the other day that, like me, she still peruses the real estate classifieds to compare what they're getting with what they're selling.
"I'm living for my own bathroom," she said. "I love my husband to death, but I want my own bathroom."
Here's my advice:
Be nice to the neighbors, don't do anything drastic for a while, and go ahead and obsess. This is New York! Neurosis rules! Besides, you probably really did get a good deal.

HEADLINE: Co-ops Anxiously Await Bribery Details

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
MARTIN KARP is baffled. He doesn't know if his co-op was a victim in the wide-ranging scandal involving scores of apartment managers and superintendents, who allegedly received millions of dollars in kickbacks and bribes from vendors.
His 258-unit co-op, at 250 East 87th Street in Manhattan, has used the Charles H. Greenthal Company as a managing agent for the last two years; the firm has employed two agents who have been indicted; neither, though, worked for his building. 
 His building's previous manager was Brown Harris Stevens, an old white-glove firm that has had 17 of its past and present managing agents charged in the scandal; two worked for Mr. Karp's building.
"We aren't sure what to do," said Mr. Karp, who is a retired management consultant and the vice president of his co-op board. "The indictments are sealed, and we don't know the basis for the indictments. Maybe they have nothing to do with our building."
Such uncertainty has been pandemic among co-op and condominium boards in New York ever since last month when the Manhattan District Attorney's office, after a three-year-investigation, announced that 86 managing companies and management agents, as well as the president of one co-op board, had been indicted or pleaded guilty to charges of extorting payoffs from contractors and suppliers in exchange for steering business their way.
"Everyone is in such limbo," said Mary Ann Rothman, the executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, a trade organization for 1,800 member co-ops and condominiums in the New York area. "It's just complete panic time. Everyone is waiting for the other shoe to fall."
Because the investigation is ongoing -- more charges and pleas are expected -- and the charges alleged thus far are sketchy, apartment owners are in the dark concerning what buildings and vendors are involved, how the payoffs worked and how much money has been lost by paying bills from plumbers, painters and other contractors that, according to the District Attorney's office, were inflated, often by 10 percent, to cover the costs of paying off managing agents and supervisors.
The uncertainty is especially troubling to co-op boards because they aren't sure whether they are currently employing a corrupt managing agent or vendor and if they should sever relationships. They also worry that if they switch agents or vendors, there is no guarantee that the new ones won't be charged in the future.
"The District Attorney's office invited us to the dance, but it's making us sit on the sidelines like wallflowers," said Errol Brett, a Manhattan lawyer who represents 120 co-op and condominium boards. "The D.A. knows who the co-conspirators are, and it is incumbent upon him to, without jeopardizing their investigation, let us know who the other players, the contractors are, so the buildings can re-evaluate their contracts and not enter into any new contracts with those vendors who are under investigation."
The District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, has said it might be months before apartment owners learn if and how they were bilked, and whether they can collect from a restitution fund. Brown Harris Stevens has already contributed $1 million to the fund, which may grow to as much $5 million.
Daniel J. Castleman, the District Attorney's director of investigations, said that by the end of September, co-op boards should have a list of buildings involved with the charges. He also predicted that by Thanksgiving the identity would be known of many, if not all, of those who have pleaded guilty, as well as some of the vendors. "Eventually, all of the identities of the vendors will be known, but it is an ongoing process that will take time," he said.
Mr. Castleman explained that it was difficult to document the fraud in particular buildings because agents often worked in several buildings. "It is not as simple as releasing a list," he said. "Such a list does not yet exist. We didn't approach the investigation building-by-building, but agent-by-agent and contractor-by-contractor. So, we have to go back and review our databases, which are substantial, to pull out any reference to particular buildings."
He said the indictments had either been sealed or contained little information since investigators didn't want to show their hands until required to. "In response to defense motions, we will have to put out more specific information about each charge," he said.
Mr. Castleman added that the names of vendors who were cooperating with investigators were being kept secret because some felt they had reason to fear for their economic livelihood and, possibly, their lives.
He also said that there was little the District Attorney's office could do to assuage the anger felt among some apartment owners that the vendors are escaping prosecution.
"There is a range of conduct," he said. "There are some vendors who were actively bribing people. There are others who were extorted. You have to take a look at the particular facts with individual vendors."
He said that some vendors might be charged in the future, but that, for the most part, they had entered into agreements to cooperate, meaning that they have immunity from prosecution for any crimes to which they confess. They can be charged, however, for illegal activities that investigators learn about on their own or through others.
"We chose to focus on agents, because it is the agents who owe a fiduciary responsibility to their boards," Mr. Castleman said. "While we have no illusion that some vendors are not angels, we have chosen to attack the problem where we believe it should be attacked."
"Does that mean that some vendors are going to escape prosecution?" he asked. "Yes -- but that's the reality in this type of investigation."
ANOTHER law enforcement official, who refused to speak unless promised anonymity, noted that the investigation could continue for two or three more years with spin-offs into other related fields, like commercial real estate, rental housing, public housing, institutional real estate.
"Essentially," the official added, "kickbacks in every facet of the real estate industry in New York."
In the meantime, board presidents, board members and apartment owners all wait and wonder. Robert S. Deutsch, for example, is a lawyer and the president of a co-op at 3777 Independence Avenue in Riverdale in the Bronx. His building was managed by Darwood Management and one of the indicted agents, but it is now managed by Regal Management; the co-op switched managing agents in 1992.
"There was unhappiness over the way the building was being managed," Mr. Deutsch said. "There was concern that they were not purchasing materials at the cheapest available price."
Mr. Deutsch said that he was not concerned that Regal would be implicated in the District Attorney's probe. His board, is not sure, however, whether they should take action against Darwood Management, though it seems likely. "We have taken the precaution of advising the D.A. of the facts and the concern we have, but we are truly in limbo as to how to proceed," he said. "We are awaiting the outcome of the investigation, and waiting to see whether we are put on a list for restitution."
Such patience, however, may not satisfy shareholders in many co-ops, and boards may find themselves under increasing pressure to seek restitution. Indeed, if a board doesn't act expeditiously, it might become the target of angry shareholders, who could hold a board liable for lack of oversight or for failing to act in a timely or prudent manner in recovering damages. Some shareholders -- citing a former co-op board president who has pleaded guilty to felony fraud and agreed to return $100,000 -- may even be suspicious of collusion by some boards.
Dennis Greenstein, a Manhattan lawyer whose firm represents 155 boards, noted that some boards had received letters from shareholders intimating that their board knew about a managing agent receiving kickbacks. "What happens is that there are people who don't understand the process, and there are discontents in every building," he said. "But the number of people is very very limited, and their claims are very vague. There are also absolutely no claims that I am aware of that have any substance."
He added that most board members had directors' and officers' liability insurance to protect them from such claims. "As long as there is no bad faith, dishonesty or self-dealing, they are protected," he said.
Even so, Mr. Greenstein recommended that boards inform shareholders promptly and often about any steps being taken in light of the District Attorney's charges.
He does not recommend initiating legal action at this time. Instead, the board should first have its accountant or treasurer audit the building's expenses since 1988; a six-year statute of limitations for breach of contract and fraud claims exists in New York. In particular, auditors should peruse emergency repair bills, higher than normal fuel costs in the winter and any unusual costs for construction projects that were higher than the original bids.
MR. GREENSTEIN noted, though, that auditors might find it very difficult, if not impossible, to uncover the kinds of fraud and kickbacks that have been alleged by the District Attorney. "What we are advising buildings to do if they did have large capital improvements, like $50,000 or $100,000 or more, they should look at the project and have it reviewed to see if there is anything that is inflated," he said. "The account should also look at other buildings and compare expenses."
He further cautioned that boards should not go overboard on their audits. "We are in the incipient stages of this, and, right now, I don't recommend spending thousands of dollars on auditing fees before a board has more information," he said.
Mr. Brett, the Manhattan lawyer, further suggested that boards develop a list of suppliers and contractors that were hired by their building since 1988 and how much each were paid. The list will be of assistance when the names of the vendors who allegedly bribed managing agents is released. "We also want to see if there is any pattern developing with one managing agent using one developer over a period of time," he said.
He also recommended that boards put in a clause in their purchasing contracts requiring vendors to state whether they are under investigation by the District Attorney. "Just in case they are under investigation, if they say they aren't that would be breach of contract, and the board would be able to terminate it," he said.
Thus far, few boards have terminated their managing agents because of the charges. Many managing-agent concerns that have not been implicated, however, have reported a surge of boards inquiring about their services. For example, Oskar Brecher, the managing director of American Landmark Management Corporation in Manhattan, manages 86 co-op and condominium buildings with 8,000 units in the five boroughs.
"We have been interviewed to a pretty significant extent," he said. "We have in the neighborhood of 20 buildings that have called since the scandal hit, and we are in the final stages of discussions with five buildings."
There has been a class action suit filed against Brown Harris Stevens on behalf of the 30-unit co-op at 103 East 84th Street on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The suit, however, was filed largely to prevent the company, which has the financial wherewithal and legal expertise, to reach a speedy but small settlement with a "friendly" co-op, according to Stuart Saft, chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives and a partner in the Manhattan law firm that filed the suit. Such a settlement would prevent other co-op's from initiating a suit that could result in a larger settlement or judgment.
Instead of a lawsuit, Arthur Weinstein, a lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, advised that, even though damages could not be documented at this time, boards should file an insurance claim, particularly since it was not clear when insurers would deem the 120-day statute of limitations for claims has expired.
How to file a claim where there are no documented damages yet? Mr. Weinstein recommended a letter to the insurance company that issued the policy with an employee dishonesty clause. "This may stop the statute of limitations and put them formerly on notice of any claims that may exist," he said.
HE said boards could put their insurance carriers on notice of a potential for claims stemming from the District Attorney's investigation. Boards should also ask their insurers for guidance about whether they should dismiss a manager that has been indicted but not found guilty. (Provisions exist in the employee dishonesty clause that requires boards to take action against an employees who commit theft.)
Meanwhile, as boards struggle for information, management companies implicated in the scandal are contemplating or have already hired internal auditors to scrutinize contracts, bills and budgets for unusually high or low costs for services and supplies.
But self-policing, though, doesn't satisfy many people outside the industry. Mark Cherkasky, a former investigator with the District Attorney who worked in the building managers' case and is now a managing director at Kroll Monitoring Services in Manhattan, a new division of Kroll Associates, an international investigative security and consulting company, suggests hiring a firm like his that not only audits managers, but may also try to bribe them -- to test their honesty.
Some people in the industry, however, believe self-policing is akin to the proverbial fox guarding the hen house. For example, Jerome Belson, president of the Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, believes that building managers should be licensed by the state. "It is very unusual when an association is asking for more supervision rather than less," he said. "But we feel it is important to point out the fiduciary responsibility of building managers. and increase their standing as professionals."
"We have been advocating licensing for the past several years," he added. "Building managers are every bit as important as taxicab drivers or a manicurist."
Licensing, however, is often pooh-poohed, even by those, like Mr. Saft, who represent victimized co-op boards. "The problem here isn't competence but honesty," he said. "And you can't license honesty."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Examining the Broad Brush Cuomo Uses to Paint Rival

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 23

 BODY:
Racing to define George E. Pataki before the obscure Republican Senator can define himself, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's re-election campaign is seeking to depict Mr. Pataki -- and the Republican Party in general -- as devoid of principle and willing to shift with the political breeze.
Central to that strategy is Mr. Cuomo's suggestion that his challenger has been inconsistent on the crucial issues of abortion, taxes and gun control. But as is often the case in campaigns, the full truth about Mr. Pataki is not as simple as Mr. Cuomo's characterization of him. 
 In a July 12 television interview, the Democratic Governor said: "He used to be supported by Right to Life and now he's pro-choice. He was a mayor who raised taxes 30 percent and now he's against taxes. He used to say he was for a ban on assault weapons, but then he voted not to ban assault weapons." Those assertions are a melange of truth, half-truth and misrepresentation, an examination of Mr. Pataki's record shows.
Although the 49-year-old Mr. Pataki spent three years as Mayor of Peekskill in Westchester County and eight years in the Assembly before joining the Senate in 1992, his record began to receive serious scrutiny only after he was designated the Republican Party's gubernatorial candidate at its state convention in May.
Mr. Pataki still must survive a primary challenge from Richard M. Rosenbaum before taking on Mr. Cuomo. But in a year when polls indicate that the voters may be willing to vote for any credible alternative, the Governor clearly considers Mr. Pataki his main threat.
In an interview this week about his record, Mr. Pataki acknowledged -- in greater detail than previously in the campaign -- that he had not always believed in the right to an abortion, as he says he now does. He said that the birth of his first child, Emily, who is 15, had a profound impact on his views.
On assault weapons, Mr. Pataki has offered a variety of explanations, some of them at odds with the others and with reality, for his April 25 vote against a Democratic amendment that would have banned many semiautomatic firearms in most circumstances. After first saying no vote had been taken, he later said he had voted to sustain a ruling that the amendment was not germane to the bill being debated. Neither was true. Now he dismisses the vote as procedural, but says he would have voted against the amendment anyway because he supports a stricter ban.
Mr. Pataki's record on taxes, however, has been significantly distorted by Mr. Cuomo and his aides. They have charged that real property taxes rose 30 percent during the three years that Mr. Pataki was mayor of Peekskill. But more than two-thirds of that increase came in the budget for Mr. Pataki's first year, which had been enacted by his Democratic predecessor.
Mr. Pataki called the Governor's charges about his record "utter absurdity," and said they were "sort of a sad commentary."
But he is likely to hear them often between now and November, because the Governor's advisers fear that the most dangerous opponent may be a candidate nobody knows.
 
Abortion Rights
 Throughout the campaign, Mr. Pataki has generated angry opposition from abortion rights advocates for referring to himself as an "unequivocal supporter" of a woman's right to choose. They argue that he has voted repeatedly against Medicaid financing of abortions for poor women and favors requiring the notification of parents before most girls under 16 can have abortions.
But Mr. Pataki, a Roman Catholic who said he has struggled intellectually, emotionally and religiously with the issue, also makes abortion rights groups nervous because of what he refers to as "an evolution" in his thinking. He said this week that he was "supporting pro-choice candidates against pro-life candidates" in the late 1970's, when he served as counsel to Senator Bernard G. Gordon, who supported abortion rights.
Then his daughter was born. "There's no question that has an impact on how you think, not just about abortion but about life," he said.
Mr. Pataki said he did not recall whether he favored making abortion illegal at that point. "Whether I would have called myself pro-life, certainly in the past there was a time when I would not have said that unequivocably it is the woman's decision regardless of what happens," he said.
Gustave S. Allmacher, the Conservative Party chairman of Cortlandt, a town near Mr. Pataki's home, said Mr. Pataki "was viewed at the time as being pro-life." So did Geraldine P. Oftedahl, chairwoman of the New York State Right to Life Committee, which endorsed Mr. Pataki in 1988.
When asked when he began referring to himself as "pro-choice," Mr. Pataki said, "It's been years, going back to before the '90 Republican convention." Mr. Pataki served that year as chairman of the platform committee, and drafted a plank that expressed the state party's "commitment to the right of privacy and reproductive rights."
Mr. Allmacher and Ms. Oftedahl said they did not recall Mr. Pataki's advertising himself as an abortion-rights supporter until 1990, when Mr. Pataki said he thought seriously about running for Governor.
Mr. Pataki has voted against annual bills to authorize Medicaid financing of abortions. But he currently says he will support Medicaid financing if the state requires health care providers to counsel women about birth control and abstinence when they receive abortions.
 
Assault Weapons
 Senator Richard A. Dollinger had tried several times during the previous four months to offer an amendment restricting possession of assault weapons to another gun licensing bill, a measure that had been proposed by Mr. Cuomo and had already passed the Assembly. Each time it was dismissed cursorily as non-germane by the presiding officer, a parliamentary procedure used by the Republican majority to kill Democratic proposals without a roll-call vote.
On April 25, however, the amendment was ruled germane and was debated at some length. And Mr. Pataki voted against it, along with every other Republican.
Mr. Pataki, who says he supports the concept of banning assault weapons, has been asked often to explain that vote. Some Democrats have suggested that his vote reflected the politics of the moment, when Mr. Pataki was battling Herbert London for the support of the Conservative Party, which abhors gun control.
When Gabe Pressman charged in an interview on WNBC-TV in late May that Mr. Pataki had voted against the bill, he responded, "No, we have not had a vote on assault weapons."
Then in a July 9 interview on WPIX, Mr. Pataki called the bill "an attempt to amend a bill that was on the floor that was ruled non-germane and I voted to sustain the ruling of the chair." He said it was "political gimmickry to try to create a vote."
In an interview this week, Mr. Pataki, who has made much of his independence from his Republican colleagues in voting against the state budget, described the measure as typical of the minority amendments "that as a routine matter are opposed by all Republicans."
But, he said, he probably would have voted against the bill anyway, because it would allow some gun collectors and competitive shooters to be licensed to own assault weapons. "The simplest thing, I believe, is you draw up a list of those guns that are assault weapons that pose an undue risk to the safety of the state and you ban them," he said.
 
Tax Rise in Peekskill
 Mr. Pataki's economic program centers on a large package of cuts in both income and business taxes, many of which he has yet to detail. But property taxes increased while he was Mayor of Peekskill from 1982 to 1984. They did not, however, increase by any amount near the 30 percent claimed by Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Cuomo's calculation is based on a 21 percent increase in 1982, a 6.4 percent increase in 1983 and a 2 percent increase in 1984. But the 21 percent increase was proposed by the city manager and approved by the Common Council -- the mayor is one of seven members -- in late 1981, before Mr. Pataki took office.
Indeed, the third budget that Mr. Pataki controlled included no tax increase, according to Peekskill officials. That was at least partly because the city, which had a $12 million budget in 1985, began to receive large payments from Westchester County to compensate for the city's acceptance of the county's garbage incinerator. It received $1.6 million from the county in 1985, up from $200,000 in the three previous years.
Cuomo aides have suggested that Mr. Pataki should be held responsible for the 21 percent increase in 1982 because he did nothing to change it after taking office on Jan. 1. After all, they have said, Mr. Pataki and the new Republican majority on the Council changed spending priorities in the budget after taking office. And they pointed out that Mr. Pataki characterized the budget as "realistic and responsible," according to Common Council minutes.
But Peekskill's deputy corporation counsel, Stephen J. Mignano, said there is no authority in state law or in the city's charter for changing tax rates once they are set. The charter requires the tax rate to be set by Dec. 1 of the previous year.
Cynthia M. Munk, a spokeswoman for the State Comptroller, said her office's lawyers agreed with that general proposition as a matter of state law, although they had not studied Peekskill's charter.
Joel R. Benenson, the Cuomo campaign's spokesman, said his campaign's lawyers also had been unable to find such a statute. But he said the campaign would stand by its use of the 30 percent figure anyway.
"It is an accurate statement," he said. "While he was Mayor of Peekskill, taxes went up 30 percent. He reopened that budget and he didn't cut spending to give the tax money back the next year."
Said Mr. Pataki: "They're trying to backtrack after making a major distortion."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Love Among the Risk Takers and Risk Averse

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
IT seems they stood and talked like this before. She remembers, instantly, where (the Isle of Capri overlooking the bay of Naples) and when (22 years ago). It isn't long before he remembers, too. Now on a veranda with a drop-dead view of Boston Harbor, surrounded by stars as if in possession of them. And yes, they are thinking of asking for the moon.
In "Later Life" A. R. Gurney establishes his most romantic setting yet. The scenic designer for the production at Westport Country Playhouse, Richard Ellis, has lived up to his part of the celestial bargain. 
 And Austin (Frank Converse), who is divorced, and Ruth (Maureen Anderman), who is separated, are not only available -- "relatively free and clear" -- but connecting. That, Ruth observes, is "something very rare in this world that is falling apart." Who among the audience isn't rooting for the final clinch?
In the best of all possible fantasy worlds, Mr. Gurney would oblige. But it is his sense of missed second chances that has made him write a ruefully truthful play rather than a satisfyingly dreamy one.
Austin and Ruth had their brief encounter after college and before marriage. Austin, then a Navy man, is still at sea. On the surface, he is shipshape. This is, remember, a Gurney play.
"A prince of a man" in the Groton School yearbook, he came from one of Boston's finest families, married the boss's daughter (from one of Boston's finest families), became a banker -- and remained a perfect gentleman.
But inside Austin is raging. All the top-drawer values that defined his breed are dying out. This is, remember, a Gurney play, a darker and deeper one than ever. Austin, overcome by a sense of dread, cannot move. Even Austin's psychiatrist misunderstands him.
In a coup of casting, concept and good economic sense, the inimitable Carole Shelley of the original Off Broadway cast and John C. Vennema, an Off Broadway replacement, play motley guests at the cocktail party inside. Under David Saint's graceful direction, they come onto the veranda to eavesdrop on Austin and Ruth. Mr. Vennema is a recovering smoker, a computer junkie and a crotchety elderly man asking to go to his retirement home in Florida.
Ms. Shelley is his wife who won't go. They are an overly gregarious couple, just moved to Boston, determined to show off their multicultural tolerances. Ms. Shelley also performs the roles of a hilarious series of snooty besotted and bewildered women.
As the overpriviledged Austin with a "Puritan sense of damnation," Mr. Converse, all pent up with pursed lips and furrowed brow, is made to look like a cloning of Charles Kimbrough, the play's original star. This is bothersome for Mr. Converse is giving a deeply felt attractive performance. Ruth, whose life has been a catalogue of disasters, in contrast to Austin's success, stability and sheer luck, is nevertheless a spirited risk taker, even if it means she is bent on destructiveness. Married four times to three men, she is on the run from an abusive ne'er-do-well.
Ms. Anderman, recreating her original role, wears the camouflage of charm and elegance perfectly. Her passion for life surfaces, but so what?
Ruth keeps on dancing. Austin goes on standing there. If his psychiatrist cannot understand why, who can?
"Later Life" by A. R. Gurney at Westport Country Playhouse, 25 Powers Court, off Route 1. 227-4177. Performances through Saturday.
