HEADLINE: A $326 Million Private Toll Road to Spur Growth

BYLINE: By JAMES R. HARDCASTLE 

DATELINE: LEESBURG, VA.

 BODY:
THE first private toll road to be built in Virginia in over 130 years is on budget and ahead of schedule, much to the delight of Northern Virginia land owners who expect the road to bring growth through an empty portion of Loudoun County.
The $326 million toll road is called the Dulles Greenway, a 14-mile highway from Leesburg, about 35 miles northwest of the Washington Monument, to Dulles International Airport, where it links with the existing state-owned Dulles Toll Road. Leesburg is the county seat of Loudoun County, whose population stood at 57,400 in the 1980 census, shot up to 86,100 in 1990 and continued its climb to an estimated 102,100 in April. 
 The Dulles Greenway and the five interchanges that will be built along its course will open up some 10,000 acres to development south of what has been a major area of residential growth in the Washington metropolitan area. Half this acreage is already zoned for commercial or residential development and is accessible to existing sewer and water treatment operations.
The investors in the toll road are led by the local Bryant family, which is betting $68 million that it can preserve its scenic open space by channeling the growth the road will bring and achieve a return on its money at the same time.
Cheering the investors on are land owners along the road who have contributed millions of dollars in land to make the deal work. Indeed, in one case, a group of landowners paid $4 million to purchase key parcels of land needed for the Greenway to insure that the road would run close their property, which they hope to develop.
How long it will be before the road makes a profit after it opens in early 1996 is anyone's guess. But in any case, it will put Leesburg a lot closer to the employment centers and in time attract new businesses out to the new Greenway corridor, said John Stokely, the developer of Ashburn Farm, one of the large planned residential communities in eastern Loudoun.
"Once it opens there will be a jump in land sales and residential absorption," he predicted.
Charles E. Williams, a retired major general in the Army Corps of Engineers, and former head of the New York City School Construction Authority, who serves as chief operating officer of the project, said that nine months into the 30-month construction schedule, 46 percent of the work on the road had been completed, suggesting that the opening might occur before the scheduled date.
The two most difficult hurdles the road's sponsors had to clear were financing the venture, which is the major privately bankrolled toll road to be proposed in the United States during modern times, and getting the needed right of way and easements from 26 land owners without the power of eminent domain. The road was first proposed in 1986.
"The marvel of it is that it is going to be happening at all after all the fits and starts it has been through," said John T. Hazel Jr., a Northern Virginia lawyer and real estate developer whose firm represented the venture in the early days of the project.
DEVELOPING the Greenway is the Toll Road Investors Partnership II. One general partner is the Shenandoah Greenway Corporation, an investment firm owned by Magalen Ohrstrom Bryant of Middleburg, Va., and her children. The other is Autostrade International, the operator of more than 2,800 kilometers of toll roads in Italy. Brown & Root Inc., a construction subsidiary of the Halliburton Company, has a $145 million fixed-fee contract to build the road and is a limited partner.
The road project will allow drivers willing to pay a $1.75 toll on the Greenway and an additional 85 cents on the state-owned Dulles Toll Road to drive to Washington or its closer-in suburbs without stopping for a traffic light or toll booth. Toll booths at the Greenway and the state-operated Dulles toll road will be compatible, equipped with automatic vehicle identification systems that will allow drivers to pass through tolls at speeds up to 45 miles an hour. Leesburg commuters unwilling to pay the toll will be required to stop at 23 lights as they drive along jammed highways to Washington.
To Mrs. Bryant and Michael Crane, her son by a previous marriage and the chief executive of the toll road partnership, the Greenway is a natural. Their family has been active in preserving open space in the western Loudoun and neighboring Fauquier County hunt country since Mrs. Bryant's father, George L. Ohrstrom, bought an estate near Middleburg in the 40's to pursue his love of fox hunting.
The family is still among the largest shareholders in the Dover Corporation, a New York-baased manufacturing company founded by Mr. Ohrstrom in the 1930's. During the 1970's and 1980's, the family became actively involved in obtaining scenic easements in the area -- covenants that assure the preservation of open land.
With the Greenway, "we're trying to preserve as much of the open space as possible by encouraging development to go where it's always been planned," Mr. Crane said.
Mrs. Bryant and her family put $22 million in equity into the toll road partnership. An additional $46 million of her family's capital is tied up in lines of credit that serve as guarantees against project risk.
The Greenway's investors decided that for political and regulatory reasons they would avoid becoming involved in real estate development in the Greenway corridor. They will seek return of capital and profits through tolls set by regulators at the State Corporation Commission.
The project will operate at a deficit in its early years, said Timothy Sutherland, president of C. C. Pace Resources Inc. of Fairfax, the project's investment banker. State reglators will allow toll road investors to receive a return on equity of up to 30 percent in the early days of the project.
ONCE toll revenues exceed debt service costs by 15 percent, the allowable return begins a five-step decline to 14 percent and that return remains in effect until the road reverts to the state at the end of 42.5 years. The state will allow investors to recover allowable earnings not achieved in the early days of the project out of revenues in the later years of the project.
Currently, Routes 7 and 50 are the only arterial roads linking Loudoun County to the metropolitan area's center. Almost all of the development in the county is now taking place along Route 7, which is already operating well in excess of capacity. There is essentially no development along the Route 50 corridor between Dulles Airport and Middleburg in southern Loudoun County.
One of Northern Virginia's premier developers, the Mobil Land Development Company, a Mobil subsidiary that is the developer of Reston, Va., and 13 other planned communities, announced in March that it had entered into a 50-50 partnership with a Northern Virginia builder-developer, the Van Metre Organization to build a 1,500-acre community that will be the first to use the Dulles Greenway as its principal gateway. The Broadlands project is zoned for 3,883 dwelling units, 3.6 million square feet of office space and 475,000 square feet of retail space.
James C. Cleveland, the president of Mobil Land, said the fast pace of construction of the Greenway after its groundbreaking last Sept. 29 clinched the deal. Because Van Metre was willing to donate right of way along a mile and a half of the Greenway, it was in a strong position to negotiate when the road was designed. As a result, the project will be served by three of the Dulles Greenway interchanges.

HEADLINE: The Contagion of Rebellion

BYLINE: By T. H. Breen; T. H. Breen is the William Smith Mason Professor of History at Northwestern University. His books include "Tobacco Culture: The Mentality of the Great Tidewater Planters on the Eve of Revolution."

 BODY:

THE PRICE OF NATIONHOOD
The American Revolution in Charles County.
By Jean B. Lee.
Illustrated. 388 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95. 
 EVEN contemporaries found it difficult to explain why so many ordinary colonists took up arms against George III. The odds in such a contest were terrible. But logic of this sort failed to discourage the Americans -- at least initially -- and in large numbers they united with strangers living in other parts of the continent to create a new nation.
Studies of Revolutionary America usually assume an urban point of view, focusing on violent protests in Boston, New York and Philadelphia. Moreover, popular narratives of rebellion often conclude with colonists taking a stand against British troops at Lexington and Concord. The long war and the subsequent challenge of rebuilding an exhausted nation seldom figure in our understanding of the birth of the Republic.
"The Price of Nationhood" takes a different perspective. In her study, Jean B. Lee, a professor of history at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, reconstructs the experiences of the people who lived in rural Charles County, Md. The county's extensive southern boundary ran along the Potomac River, and most of its inhabitants, black slaves as well as white freemen, cultivated tobacco. However isolated the members of this agrarian community may have been, they joined other Americans in toppling royal authority. Their decisions at critical moments throughout this period deserve close attention, for as Ms. Lee reminds us, "without the support of rural communities, the Revolution could not have succeeded."
Ms. Lee forces us to rethink the traditional chronology of the Revolution. Her story of Charles County begins with a complaisant colonial society, but instead of stopping with the Declaration of Independence, she follows this community as it mobilized for war, adjusted to the opportunities and disappointments of a postwar economy, ratified a new Federal Government and, at the end of the century, struggled to keep pace with other regions in a rapidly expanding democracy.
The opening section of "The Price of Nationhood" recaptures the subtle textures of a lost colonial world. Before independence, the planters of Charles County produced splendid tobacco. Each year merchants flocked to the small port towns of the Potomac, exchanging British manufactured goods for the valuable crop. At midcentury, Charles County was a distant outpost of the old empire. Its imaginative horizons, which extended to London and Glasgow, did not yet include much of the rest of colonial America.
Although powerful gentry families dominated this rural society, special privilege was not in itself a source of resentment among white colonists. They accepted a hierarchical order in which the wealthiest gentlemen of Charles County presumed to speak for the entire community. Local government ran smoothly; the planters appeared prosperous. Indeed, one English visitor concluded that the people of Charles County seemed "to live very well, and [to be] exceedingly happy."
However happy the colonists of Charles County may have been, they soon succumbed to the contagion of rebellion. Parliament's insistence after 1765 on taxing Americans without representation provoked the rural planters. But Britain's ill-conceived policies were not in themselves sufficient to transform loyal subjects into revolutionaries, Ms. Lee maintains. Imperial authority in Charles County collapsed because external debates about rights and liberties gave powerful new meanings to local controversies. Political disputes that might once have been easily contained suddenly acquired explosive potential as ordinary white people in Charles County interpreted issues dividing their community within the framework of a radical ideology not of their own making. Ms. Lee effectively links the two levels of experience, showing how moderate planters staked out ever more extreme positions until by 1775 everyone seemed to have become, in the words of one frightened loyalist, "liberty mad."
In Charles County, the political madness never got out of hand. Throughout a long, difficult war, the local gentry remained firmly in control. No one advocated a radical new social order. Perhaps because they were so fearful of sparking unrest among the slaves, the poorest whites never gave serious thought to storming the great houses of the old colonial elite. Members of the leading families stepped forward in the crisis, recruiting soldiers for the Continental Army, organizing local defenses and gathering food and supplies for the American troops. William Smallwood, a wealthy planter who had frequently been elected to Maryland's colonial assembly, served with distinction as a general in the army. To be sure, the ordinary people of Charles County sometimes dragged their feet, but at war's end in 1783 the entire community could justly celebrate its role in defeating the British.
The postwar period revealed the full social implications of revolution. Charles County was a very different community from the one that had welcomed independence. The experiences of war itself -- perhaps even more than exposure to radical new republican ideas -- eroded the old hierarchical structure. The elite maintained dominance, but it found that it had to be more responsive to the needs of ordinary planters. And they in turn voiced their economic demands more aggressively. Although the African-Americans did not substantially improve their lot -- and Ms. Lee sedulously retrieves the stories of obscure slaves -- white men and women redefined "the complex gradations of freedom characteristic of the colonial social order." Indentured servitude for poor whites virtually disappeared in Charles County. As Ms. Lee explains, "Men in the aggregate enjoyed greater political power; women, higher status; and everyone, religious liberty."
The narrative of revolution in Charles County concludes on a bittersweet note. Nationhood did not restore prosperity. The tobacco market collapsed, and proud gentry families found they could no longer pay their debts. During the 1790's white people began leaving Charles County, many migrating to the fertile lands to the west. They left behind a struggling, uncertain community whose population was dramatically poorer and blacker than it had been in the colonial period. "Gone were the intensity of the nation's formative years, the expansive commercialism and the self-assured gentry leadership," Ms. Lee writes. "Drained of many of its people and much of its economic vitality, the county slipped quietly into the 19th century."
The decline of Charles County probably would have occurred even without revolution. Still, one wonders whether the local patriots of 1776 would have supported independence so enthusiastically had they comprehended the full price of nationhood.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE CAMPAIGN;
Health Care Bus: Lots of Miles, Not so Much Talk

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, July 24

 BODY:
From Oregon through Idaho and on to Utah, passengers on a cross-country bus trip in support of health care change have moved with a cheerful mien across the Western landscape, sharing personal stories and anxious accounts of the need for Congress to overhaul the American health insurance system.
But so far, they have spoken mostly to themselves. 
 The three buses that make up the first caravan on what will become a five-route health care crusade financed by supporters of President Clinton's health plan have moved from town to town making barely a ripple in the health care debate. In contrast to the bus journeys that Bill Clinton made during his campaign for the Presidency in 1992, there are no cheering crowds or passionate exchanges. Scattered protests have mostly been avoided, and long stretches of the road pass with no people in sight at all.
"We can't be 'reform riders' if we don't talk to people," said Christa Jaeger, a temporarily exasperated member of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. The union is one of three organizations behind a $2 million tour that will culminate in Washington the first week in August with rallies and the delivery of what the organizers hope will be thousands of letters urging Congress to pass a broad health care bill.
 
Avoiding Confrontation
 Though trip organizers vow that big rallies and intimate exchanges are coming, so far they have been few and far between. Instead, since the buses were sent off by Hillary Rodham Clinton in Portland, Ore., the traveling band has chosen to keep a low profile and avoid confrontation as it tries to win positive press coverage on a difficult issue.
In Boise, Idaho, last night, a handful of protesters so spooked the tour's organizers that they chose to skip their own rally and instead diverted the buses to a church not yet ready to serve them dinner. Local reporters covering the event were not allowed into the church, so as the "reform riders" stood to tell one another, and a tiny audience, stories of health care woe, it raised a modern variation on the classic philosophical question: "If a tree falls in the forest but no one hears it -- did it fall?"
This morning, as the buses headed to Salt Lake City for a reception, the riders agreed to face the protesters head-on -- and soon were given the opportunity. At a noon stop here, the buses were met by a small band of protesters bearing signs opposing "socialized health care" and declaring that the Idaho system works quite well. The mild-mannered debates that sprang up marked one of the first times the bus passengers had a chance to get their message out.
On Friday, as the buses snaked through the mountains of central Oregon, mechanical difficulties and logistical problems left the caravan running hours behind schedule. When the group arrived for a rally in Pendleton, a 300-seat auditorium lay silent and empty.
 
Disquieting Stories
 Later, at the Umatilla Indian reservation in La Grande, Indian tribal leaders provided a gracious feast but few listeners. And tribal officials complained that Federal promises of health care for all Indians had long since fallen behind the tribe's needs.
Roberta Wilson, the chairwoman of a tribal health and welfare commission, rattled off a catalogue of ills, noting that American Indians had the lowest birthrate, the shortest life span, and the highest suicide, alcoholism and unemployment rates in the nation.
The bus riders themselves are full of disquieting stories, too. At the same stop in Oregon, Elizabeth and Lawrence Clifton moved their fellow passengers to silence as they detailed the difficulties they have wrestled with since their daughter was struck by a car in 1991 and fell into a seven-month coma.
"We thought we were covered," Mr. Clifton said. Instead, the family entered a maze of insurance regulations that turned them into advocates. Among their myriad frustrations, he said, was the insurance company's willingness to pay $150 a month -- year after year -- to rent a hospital bed while it refused to cover a one-time $350 bill to buy a used bed.
Such stories seem to have deeply touched the few people the riders have so far reached. But the extraordinary complexity of the debate has been clear both on and off the buses. Although they agree on the basic concept of universal health care, many of the passengers disagree on other points, including coverage for abortions, employer financing and the "single payer" option in which the Government pays all the health bills.
Many in the audiences have revealed the depth of the division, too. At the Pendleton stop, Ron Pahl described his family's health care problems to a small audience waiting for the buses. But later he told a reporter that he did not support an overhaul because he opposed provisions requiring employers to finance workers' insurance.
On the bus, there is deep concern that change take a responsible course. Dianne Brownson, a 49-year-old nurse from Pasco, Wash., said she joined the trip because she believed that health care was suffering a general decline. "I've seen young people die because they can't get insurance," she said. "That shouldn't happen."
As they moved east today, through a dusty landscape dotted with small churches, large cornfields, sprawling cattle ranches and narrow, twisting rivers, the riders played cards, shared stories and vowed to move to the debate off their buses and into the heartland.
"We're not hiding," said Edward Kerns, a 37-year-old paraplegic from Portland who was injured in a car accident 16 years ago. "We are learning as we go. I would have liked to talk to those protesters. But I don't know too much about politics. I think we are a little green, yet. And we are heading into more conservative country."
As the buses pulled up here, Daniel Lumley, a 30-year-old from Seattle who lost an arm and a leg in a motorcycle accident, cheered his fellow passengers on. "The troops no longer are retreating," he said cheerfully, after warning them about the crowd of about 50 people outside, about half of them protesters.
Then, as an aside, he added, "If they get rough, I'll take my leg off and beat them with it."
With that resolve, the passengers all disembarked.
 
DIARY
HEALTH CARE DEVELOPMENTS
 
YESTERDAY
 
Democratic Congressional leaders and Vice President Al Gore predicted that Congress would adopt a national health insurance bill guaranteeing coverage to all Americans.
 
IN CONGRESS
 
The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said Congress would stay in session as long as it took to pass a health care bill. Varying bills have emerged from committees. The Senate is to begin debate the week of Aug. 1; the House, on Aug. 8.
 
AT THE WHITE HOUSE
 
Vice President Gore acknowledged that the goal of universal health care coverage might have to be phased in over years to win Congressional approval. He said the President would not accept a Senate Finance Committee proposal that would seek to insure about 95 percent of Americans by offering business incentives, tax credits and subsidies to the poor.
 
WHAT TO EXPECT THIS WEEK
 
Senator Mitchell and Representative Gephardt will decide on what the bills they will put before Congress will contain and what sections they will take from measures recommended by two committees from each house. Pressure is building on Congress to pass some form of health care legislation before adjourning for the fall elections. Under ferocious deadlines, Congressional budget overseers are trying to calculate what some alternatives will cost.

HEADLINE: An Energetic Trustbuster, but Not a Boat Rocker

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 23

 BODY:
To the surprise of nobody, Anne K. Bingaman, in her first year as the top Justice Department trustbuster, has transformed a dormant antitrust operation into a fountain of activity, the ideal place for a veteran of the corporate litigation trenches to fulfill herself in making policy.
"This is the dream of my life," Ms. Bingaman, who is 51, said in her Southwestern twang a few days after announcing that the Government had forced the Microsoft Corporation, the software giant, to change some of the ways it does business. "I get out of bed every day and ask how could I be so lucky." 
 Ms. Bingaman, a liberal Democrat who is married to Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico, has surprised many Washingtonians not only by publicly espousing some conservative-sounding views but by praising her Reagan-era predecessor, William F. Baxter. Ms. Bingaman calls Mr. Baxter, once her professor at Stanford and now a good friend, a "phenomenal" antitrust intellect who left a "monumental" legacy.
 
Merger Rules Remain
 Despite the urging of some colleagues, Ms. Bingaman has made no effort to overhaul the formal guidelines used by the division since 1982 in evaluating mergers, preferring to let stand what Mr. Baxter is said to regard as his crowning achievement.
"A lot of people seemed to think I was going to wholesale rewrite the guidelines, but I think that would have been precipitous, frankly," Ms. Bingaman said. The need for amendment would have to be demonstrated, she added, since the guidelines "appeared economically sound."
But while the philosophical gap with her Republican predecessors appears not particularly large, the Assistant Attorney General's dynamism makes for maximum contrast in style. Not only is she finding and bringing cases at a rapid clip -- some of them innovative -- she eagerly proclaims results, a practice that in itself can make companies think twice about cutting corners.
To be sure, antitrust, like economics, is a field in which practitioners largely agree on most basic issues and find their differences often grotesquely magnified when injected into politics. "There's a popularization about antitrust" that tends to produce sloganeering and distortion, Ms. Bingaman suggested.
Her skills in salesmanship were evident in the Microsoft settlement, which some computer-industry executives belittled as too narrow, leaving untouched the core of Microsoft's power.
Ms. Bingaman bristles at such talk. "We looked at every aspect of this," she said. "We brought the case that was there to bring. I'm extremely proud of this result. We've got 100 percent of what we could ever hope to achieve in a court."
She pulled out a legal pad and sketched a diagram of the settlement terms, which she said Microsoft had "fought like tigers" to avoid, opening the market to makers of competing operating systems. She challenged those who "think this isn't a big deal" to ask some intended beneficiaries, like I.B.M. and Novell.
"We think it's excellent for Novell and good for the industry," said David R. Bradford, senior vice president and general counsel of Novell, the software producer in Provo, Utah.
The critics were less impressed, arguing that the consent decree failed to address the most important aspects of Microsoft's strengths.
"Microsoft will continue to be very powerful," Martin Goetz, a co-founder of Applied Data Research, the nation's first software company, said at the time. "The Justice Department hasn't listened to the cries of the software companies."
And Richard Shaffer of Technologic Partners, a research firm in New York, said Microsoft "is the winner" and "the Standard Oil of its day."
 
Beyond the Borders
 The Microsoft settlement overshadowed another case announced earlier this month in which the division teamed up with Canadian counterparts to break up what the regulators said was a price-fixing conspiracy in thermal paper for facsimile machines that involved the North American operations of the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan.
The international dimension is becoming a Bingaman trademark. She is the first antitrust chief to name a deputy to work exclusively on such cases, and these cases represent the division's work at the frontiers of its authority. The fax paper case was preceded by one in which the division won agreement from Pilkington P.L.C., the British glass company, to stop licensing only one user of its technology in each country, a practice that kept American glassmakers from opening factories overseas.
While the policy change, which allows the department to pursue antitrust cases against foreign companies that inhibit American exports, came during the Bush Administration, Ms. Bingaman cast the international push as more of a jobs issue.
This has raised questions among some specialists, including Donald I. Baker, a division chief under President Gerald R. Ford and now in private law practice here. Mr. Baker said he found the Pilkington case "an echo of the Clinton campaign" and called such action "quite confrontational," and running the risk of retaliation.
Over all, however, Mr. Baker characterized Ms. Bingaman's first 13 months as "pretty successful," though perhaps helped by increased corporate worry over legal costs that might make some companies more inclined to settle than to litigate.
With a score of merger cases challenged, revised or abandoned in the last year, including the July 15 agreement imposing conditions on AT&T's purchase of McCaw Cellular, Ms. Bingaman boasts of setting a 12-month record for such activity.
While retaining the guidelines on mergers, she lost no time repealing guidelines governing vertical restraints of trade -- those involving companies at different stages in the chain of commerce, like a manufacturer of photographic equipment and a local camera store.
In the next few months, she intends to bring cases involving manufacturers' specification of minimum prices for their products, and the methods, like termination of dealerships, they use to enforce compliance.
She said she rejected the argument that retail price maintenance often benefited consumers by supporting dealer networks that are able to provide better advice and service. "I'm a believer in vigorous price competition, period," Ms. Bingaman said. "I think it's up to the public to decide if they want service, and it's not up to us to be engineering what kinds of stores people buy products in."
Ms. Bingaman -- who said she had wanted to be a lawyer since, at age 9, she met "my great, great hero in life," Adlai E. Stevenson -- was suitably wary about disclosing other possible targets of antitrust action. But she couldn't help musing, as a consumer with a 14-year-old son, John, about the high price of breakfast cereal, for which she pays up to $6 a box. That just "drives me nuts," she said.
The job also seems to have resulted in a more satisfying personal life. Ms. Bingaman now rides to work with her husband from their home in northwest Washington in their 1986 Chevrolet, providing nearly an hour a day of additional togetherness. "This job saved my marriage," she quipped, adding that she "used to be able to afford a car" of her own.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
American corporations are expanding operations overseas, creating jobs there and reviving an old debate here: why can't the goods and services that these foreign workers produce be supplied from the United States? A weak dollar and falling labor costs have made American products increasingly competitive, and yet overseas investment is rising at twice the rate of exports. [Page A1.] 
 The problems with derivatives that Paine Webber and other fund companies have had recently are part of a much larger and simpler problem that has plagued the mutual fund business. The problem is the intense competition that compels fund companies to turn to risky strategies and untried investment gimmicks that can backfire and hurt investors. [D1.]
Anne K. Bingaman has proved to be an energetic trustbuster as Assistant Attorney General. And while she has had some kind words for a Reagan-era predecessor, she is very different in style from the Republicans. [D1.]
Companies The S.E.C. is investigating whether Prudential Securities improperly required its former chairman to destroy documents relating to the firm at a time it was facing hundreds of lawsuits over its business practices in the 1980's. The destruction requirement was included as part of a severance agreement with George L. Ball, the former chairman, after he was forced out early in 1991. [D1.]
 
The Media Business
 The war of words between CBS and the Fox network is escalating. In the last two weeks, the chairmen of the two companies, Laurence A. Tisch of CBS and Rupert Murdoch of Fox, took turns disparaging the other network in unusually blunt terms. Nonthe two networks are cooperating on a possible deal that would create a swap of stations in two cities.
Bill Carter: Television. [D1.]
National Geographic is changing, but slowly and quietly. The 106-year-old magazine has a new editor and a smaller staff. [D6.]
Viewer participation is a hit on Brazilian television, where a drama series asks its audience to vote on its ending each week. As many as 80,000 viewers of the show, "Voce Decide," or "You Decide," participate in the call-in voting each week, and the total would be far higher if the network had more telephone lines. [D6.]
Radio advertising has been surging this year at stations big and small around the country. Stations have helped to sell themselves by doing more qualitative research. The strong showing in advertising also reflects the successful syndication of program hosts like Rush Limbaugh and Howard Stern. [D6.]
 
International
Cultures and economic pasts clashed after General Electric acquired Tungsram of Hungary, a maker of light bulbs. Although originally hailed as a deal that would show other Western companies how to turn former Communist-run enterprises into money makers, the acquisition became a headache for General Electric, which had to tackle a learned inclination toward waste and indifference. Now G.E. says it has turned the corner at Tungsram, and the operation has been profitable for a year. [D1.]

 The National Inventors Expo showcased recently issued patents for everything from bed exercisers to a guard to keep baby out of the bathtub. Teresa Riordan: Patents. [D2.].

HEADLINE: Iowa Farmers Rebel Against Subsidies, Seeking New Setup

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: COGGON, Iowa

 BODY:
Few people get a better deal from the Government than farmers, big-city politicians often complain. Growers of the biggest crops can collect checks from the taxpayers for producing nothing at all. And farmers who produce too much can sell the excess to Washington rather than eat a big loss.
After 60 years of this Depression-born system, which currently gives farmers about $11 billion a year in subsidies, an insurrection is rising in, of all places, Iowa. 
 Here in the nation's bread basket, in a state of 102,000 farms, representatives of 11 leading farm organizations have formed a coalition with the single purpose of pressuring Congress and the Clinton Administration to scrap the system of subsidies in 1995, when a new five-year farm law is enacted.
The current system, a labyrinth of regulation and bureaucracy, restricts farmers' production to prevent surpluses. In return, it pays premiums to many to raise the prices they would otherwise get for their crops.
But in recent years, Federal money for subsidies has dropped precipitously, a measure of the long, slow erosion of farmers' political clout in Washington.
Against that backdrop, the farmers' coalition, the Iowa Farm Bill Study Team, proposes replacing the current system with something much simpler -- a safety net of guaranteed income, which they call revenue assurance.
Under revenue assurance, instead of paying all participating growers a per-bushel subsidy as it does now, the Government would make payments only to farmers who suffered steep plunges in revenue from setbacks like ruinous drought, flood or collapse in prices. And then it would pay a farmer only enough to restore his revenue for that year to 70 percent of his average revenue during the previous five years.
The Department of Agriculture calculates that under the revenue assurance plan, farms would end up with less than half the aid they now receive. But the Iowans say farmers would be freed of most Government control over what they produce, so they would make up losses in aid by producing as much as they wanted of whatever they wanted.
The Department of Agriculture's immense regulatory bureaucracy would shrivel, the coalition argues, and with it, the reams of paperwork that farmers must complete under the current system.
Some farm-state lawmakers and most of the national farm lobby deride the idea. They argue that the current system insures that the country will have a cheap and reliable food supply and helps farmers to survive hazards that no other important industry faces. The historically cohesive farm lobby now faces the phenomenon of dissent within.
 
Official Sees Tests Program
 But what intrigues some members of Congress and the Administration is not the proposal itself so much as its source. "What catches everyone's attention is that this doesn't come from me, or the Office of Management and Budget or a university," said Joseph Glauber, the principal agricultural consultant at the Department of Agriculture and part of the Administration team working on the new farm law. "It comes from a bunch of farmers."
With next year's law not yet in the works, few members of Congress have started discussing details. Mr. Glauber said the Administration's review was just beginning. But he predicted that Congress would create a pilot program based on the Iowa plan, which could be expanded if it is successful.
Another group that is intrigued by the idea is the influential American Association of Agricultural Economists, which has scheduled a full day to discuss the plan when it meets here in August.
Primarily, the Iowans say, they are simply being pragmatic. They argue that their plan would protect them from new cuts in farm supports next year and in future farm bills. As farmers have declined in numbers and political power, Congress has been chipping away at the old programs amid efforts to pare Federal spending.
"There aren't very many people who are going to be affected by a cut in agricultural programs," said Doran Zumbach, the leader of the Iowa group. "One-hundred percent of the people in this country are eaters, and just 2 percent are producers."
He says most members of Congress were not even in office in 1990, when the last bill was enacted, and they face other demands for Government largess. "Farmers can yell up and down all they want," he said. "They are going to have less."
Mr. Zumbach is a corn and soybean farmer in Coggon, 40 miles north of Cedar Rapids along arrow-straight roads through emerald green vistas of newly tasseling corn.
On the wall of his home office, above a computer, fax machine, printer and a terminal that reports minute-by-minute changes in commodity prices, is a long row of wall plaques proclaiming Mr. Zumbach a frequent winner of statewide growing contests.
Mr. Zumbach is vice president of the Iowa Corn Growers Association and chairman of the Iowa coalition, whose members include representatives of the Iowa Farm Bureau Federation, the Agribusiness Association of Iowa, National Farmers Organization, the Iowa Institute of Cooperatives, and the corn, soybean, dairy, pork, sheep, cattle and poultry associations.
He and other team members were in Washington on July 11 and 12, lobbying the White House, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Department of Agriculture and the staffs of farm state lawmakers in Congress.
 
A Complicated Arrangement
 The current system is an extraordinarily complex arrangement of policies and regulations. Its principal beneficiaries, growers of corn, sorghum, barley, wheat, rice and cotton, agree to plant no more land than the Government asks. In that way, the Government tries to prevent surpluses and resulting plunging prices. In return, farmers receive deficiency payments representing the difference between the price they get for their crops and arbitrary, invariably higher target prices that Congress sets.
For example, the target price for corn under the current five-year program is $2.75 a bushel, which is well above the $2.40 a bushel that farmers are now typically getting for their corn on the open market. So the Government pays them an extra 35 cents a bushel.
Farmers are not required to participate, but most do. And they withdraw from the system only at great peril to their incomes. Because the subsidy paid in any year is calculated on the acreage planted with a subsidized crop in the previous year, returning to the system means going for an entire year without any Federal money.
 
What the Farm Lobby Says
 For years, the agricultural lobby and its allies in Congress have argued that besides protecting food supplies and farmers from disaster, the system protects family farms and rural communities.
But many economists and urban politicians say the system favors giant corporate farms on which no one lives. They say it forces small family farms out of business and discourages diversity in farming.
Other critics argue that the system encourages farmers to squeeze greater harvests of subsidized crops out of the acreage to which they have been limited; to do this, they damage the soil with overuse of herbicides and pesticides, while diverse crops would help sustain the soil.
Both arguments have taken a toll on Congress's support for the current system of the price- and income-support system. In the last farm bill, four years ago, Congress removed 15 percent of each farmer's land from the base that qualifies for support. And last year, Congress pushed wool, mohair and honey producers out of the system entirely.
 
Decline Since 1986
 Payments to farmers, which reached a record $25.8 billion in 1986, have averaged only $10 billion over the last five years.
Mr. Zumback argues that the Iowans' plan to bring a farmer's revenues to 70 percent of average provides no more than a safety net.
Since farmers' profits, the money they live on, are from 5 to 10 percent of revenue, "they have suffered a huge loss before revenue assurance ever kicks in," he said.
Foes of the plan say farmers could make out like bandits, taking a year off and still collecting most of their income. But Mr. Zumbach says they would then risk losing future aid because the revenue on which the aid is based would plunge. He says efficient farmers, free to grow more and more varied crops would have an opportunity to earn more than they can now.
 
Aid Expected 1 in 5 Years
 He calculates that a farmer would need revenue assurance about every five years. "I would hope I would never need it," he said. Had revenue assurance been available earlier, he said it would have kicked in three times in his 25 years of farming, most recently last year, when the floods in the Midwest cut his corn revenues to 60 percent of previous five years.
The Iowans would keep some features of the current system. One is the compensation they receive for keeping land fallow at the Government's request for environmental purposes.
Another would be the "nonrecourse loan." At the end of a harvest, farmers take a low-interest loan from the Government based on another, Government-managed price for the crop, known as a loan rate, and consign the harvest to the Government.
If later, usually within nine months, the market price rises above the loan rate, the farmer sells the crop and repays the loan. But if the market price falls below the loan rate, the Government keeps the crop, and the farmer keeps the loan, owing nothing.
 
Protection From the Market
 The loan system would help to protect farmers from having to sell their crops the moment they harvest them. With all farmers selling at the same time, prices would plunge.
Many agricultural economists see merit in the Iowa plan, although they say it needs much more scrutiny. Robert T. Thompson, the Reagan Administration's top farm economist, said, "I'm encouraged by this -- farmers getting their heads together and coming up with something that might well be a better mouse trap.'
In Congress and the national farm organizations, few people flatly reject the idea of replacing the current system with revenue assurance. They see it as a last resort but disagree over the political proximity of the resort.
Iowa's Democratic Senator Tom Harkin said: "If you assume that all supports are going to be thrown out, then this might look good. But that's not going to happen."
 
Urban-Rural Coalition
 But some urban legislators are impressed with the Iowans' proposal. Two are Representatives Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, and Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, ideological opposites on most issues who were instrumental in cutting spending from the 1990 farm bill.
"It seems to me this is an enormously more rational approach to supplementing the income of people on the land," Mr. Armey said.
Mr. Schumer promised battles royal over the law next year and said the Iowa plan might bear the seeds of a truce.
"If Iowa farmers are smelling in the winds that it's going to be harder to sustain agricultural subsidies as they are now," he said, "they're right."

HEADLINE: U.S. CORPORATIONS EXPANDING ABROAD AT A QUICKER PACE

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
American companies are once again rapidly expanding their operations abroad -- demonstrating that no matter what the incentives for keeping business in the United States, the urge to spread factories, offices, stores and jobs overseas is irresistible.
The surge in these investments and the jobs they create overseas comes just when exports should be climbing more rapidly than investment abroad. A weak dollar and falling labor costs have made American products increasingly competitive. Yet overseas investment is rising at twice the rate of exports. And for each dollar earned from exports, American companies take in nearly $2 from the sale of what they produce abroad. 
 "If you are going to be really important in the world market, you are going to grow by producing in many countries, and not by exporting, which has its limits," said Robert E. Lipsey, an expert on overseas investment at the National Bureau of Economic Research. "There are circumstances where this might not be the case, but by and large that is the story."
The issue, of course, is jobs, and who will hold them. American companies employ 5.4 million people abroad, 80 percent of them in manufacturing, and the hot issue in the late 1980's, during a similar surge in overseas investment, was this: Why can't the goods and services that these foreign workers produce be supplied from the United States? Why must companies migrate abroad, shedding some of their national identity and loyalty?
Now that debate is likely to revive, although perhaps with less intensity. American investment overseas remains concentrated in manufacturing, particularly in Europe, Canada and Japan, but manufacturing was an area of more rapid growth in the 1980's than it is today. This time companies like Wal-Mart and Morgan Stanley & Company are leaders -- and that tones down the job issue.
Opening a factory in Europe or Mexico or East Asia often suggests that one in the United States may be closed. Wal-Mart's new retail investments in Canada, Brazil and Mexico, on the other hand, or Morgan Stanley's eight offices in East Asia do not suggest cutbacks at home.
"What we are sending abroad, apart from money, is our skill and experience as investment bankers, and you really have to be on site to do this sort of thing," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley, in a telephone interview from Hong Kong, where he was helping his local colleagues advise the Chinese Government on the privatization of an airline.
Morgan Stanley employs 410 people in Hong Kong, and expects to increase that to 500 by year's end, Mr. Roach said. Most of the firm's Asia offices, including two in China, have opened since the late 1980's.
The new surge in investment, in all types of businesses, showed up in recently released Commerce Department data. This investment by American companies in overseas operations rose last year to $716.2 billion, when measured as the cost of replacing the buildings and equipment. The 7.2 percent increase, coming after two years of much less growth, matched some of the better years of the 1980's. In the first quarter of 1994, investment increased even more quickly.
 
Manufacturing Lags Behind
 But while manufacturing still dominates the numbers, representing nearly 40 percent of the total, manufacturing investment rose by only 7 percent last year. Outlays for retail, finance and the like went up by twice that percentage or more.
"It is our belief that, with trade barriers coming down, the world is going to be one great big marketplace, and he who gets there first does the best," said Donald Shinkel, a spokesman at Wal-Mart, which had no stores overseas in the 1980's.
The investment surge, after two years of relatively little growth, coincides with incipient recoveries in Europe and Japan after periods of recession. As business has picked up, sales and profits have risen at American operations abroad, making more money available for investment. These reinvested profits accounted for more than half the outlays last year, the Commerce Department reports.
Booming economies in East Asia, particularly China, Singapore and Hong Kong, also drew investment, and so did nearly every Western Hemisphere country, with Canada, Mexico, Argentina and Bermuda among the leaders -- Bermuda being an offshore haven for American banking and insurance companies, while Canada, Mexico and Argentina attracted mainly manufacturing investment.
But the European nations and Japan attracted the biggest share of the manufacturing investment. They almost always do, although they are industrial countries with stronger currencies and higher average labor costs than in the United States.
American manufacturing companies engage in three types of overseas investment, and the one involving the industrial countries is perhaps the most difficult to justify -- given that exporting from the United States can be less expensive, said Raymond Vernon, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
Still this investment does not draw the greatest criticism, which has been reserved for companies that relocate labor-intensive operations, like auto assembly, or apparel manufacturing, or the assembly of some electronics products, to low-wage countries like Mexico or Thailand. "The United States is simply not the lowest-cost producer in the world, and moving abroad to these countries is inevitable," Mr. Vernon said.
Then there are the Wal-Marts and Morgan Stanleys trying to penetrate new markets in the only way possible, by putting a store or an investment house on site. Since these companies do not hold back operations at home to expand abroad, their tactics are seldom criticized.
Finally there are the situations in which a company can export its product inexpensively enough, particularly when the dollar is weak, but chooses instead to manufacture abroad, mainly for "insurance," as Mr. Vernon puts it. Of course, foreign companies, particularly the Japanese, adopt the same strategy for the United States, establishing many factories here that create jobs for Americans. But they employ 4.9 million Americans, which is 500,000 fewer than the American corporate payroll abroad.
Jobs are also created in the United States when American companies, investing abroad, export parts or machinery to help make their products overseas. But this "American content" makes up only 9 percent, on average, of the merchandise produced, the Commerce Department says. The rest is obtained overseas.
The Gillette Company embraces the strategy of manufacturing abroad rather than exporting, generating jobs overseas rather than in the United States. That has happened most recently in the case of Gillette's new Sensor XL razor blade cartridge.
The cartridge, simple for consumers to use, is difficult to manufacture, involving 10 welds with high-technology laser machines. Production started nearly two years ago at Gillette's main plant, in Boston, but all the output was exported to Europe. "We introduced the product in Europe because razor blade sales there are greater than in the United States," said Thomas Skelly, a Gillette senior vice president.
The new Sensor model is to be sold in the United States starting this year. But rather than expand the Boston operation to handle the additional production -- and add jobs, perhaps -- Gillette is adding the extra capacity to its Berlin plant, a high-technology factory that will take over the European market.
 
Currency Issues Discounted
 Cost is not the issue; blades are small and not difficult to ship, and the weak dollar gives the United States an advantage -- but one that Mr. Skelly, and other corporate executives, dismiss as insignificant. "In the long run, these currency fluctuations, up and down, don't mean a whit in the decision where to manufacture," he said.
Over the years, Gillette has put 62 factories in 28 countries and each tries to operate as if it were a regional company, adjusting as quickly as possible to local competitors. Being close to a market is a priority, promising better returns than exporting from the United States, Mr. Skelly says.
"We are also concerned about having only one place where a product is made," he said. "There could be an explosion, or labor problems." If the Boston workers struck, for example, Gillette would supply the Sensor XL to Europe and the United States from the Berlin plant, and vice versa.
The upshot of this approach is that Gillette employs 2,300 people in the manufacture of razors and blades in the United States and 7,700 -- more than three times as many -- abroad.
Some of those workers are making blades at Gillette plants in Poland, Russia and China, where production costs are less than in the United States. But that is not the case in Germany. "You could ship the blades from here, but you set up there for insurance," Mr. Vernon said. "And the justifications for this approach are not so clear cut."

HEADLINE: G.E. Finds Tough Going in Hungary

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, July 23

 BODY:
Five years ago, amid handshakes and grins, the General Electric Company agreed to acquire Tungsram, a maker of lighting products and one of Hungary's industrial gems, in a deal that many believed would show other leading Western corporations how to turn Communist-run enterprises into money makers.
Almost immediately, other ambitious American companies took notice of General Electric's investment in Eastern Europe, and it became a beacon of hope for Hungary's workers and Government leaders. 
 But as losses mounted, General Electric soon faced the reality of what happens when grand expectations collide with the grim realities of an embedded culture of waste, inefficiency and indifference about customers and quality.
The Americans huffed that the Hungarians were lackadaisical; the Hungarians thought the Americans pushy. The company's aggressive management system depends on communication between workers and managers; the Communist system had forbidden it.
The Americans wanted sales, marketing and pampering of customers; the Hungarians believed these things took care of themselves. Hungarians expected General Electric to deliver lush Western-style wages. But the company came to Hungary to pay lower wages for making and exporting light bulbs, auto headlights and other products to Western Europe. After a series of raises Tungsram workers now average $2 an hour.
"Human engineering was much more difficult than product engineering," said Charles P. Pieper, the General Electric executive brought in 19 months ago by John F. Welch Jr., chairman and chief executive, to rescue G.E.'s investment. Now the company says it has turned the corner at Tungsram and the operation has been profitable for a year.
Getting there meant laying off half of Tungsram's nearly 20,000 workers including three of every four managers. The company began weekly huddles between Tungsram and American managers linked by conference call and it created a system of worker team meetings to devise ways to work more efficiently.
It also invested in new equipment to increase productivity and reduce waste. When General Electric arrived, half of what the workers made was scrapped because of defects. Now, the company says it has raised productivity by 50 percent.
 
Timing Not Understood
 Outside analysts who have studied General Electric's acquisition say it will turn out to be a wise investment in the long term. "But once they made the strategic decision of buying a Communist-run company in Eastern Europe, General Electric didn't understand how long it would take to bring things up to par," said Paul Marer, professor of international business at Indiana University.
A former employee, Istvan Kosa, 40, a financial analyst, said he understood General Electric's strategy but that emotionally it was draining.
"For those who lived through it, it seemed cruel," he said. "We were forced into a situation where we had to sit down two or three times a year and decide how we were going to reduce the number of employees and reorganize the cost. When I started in that accounting unit in 1991 there were 36 of us, when I left there were only 8."
 General Electric has long been considered by business leaders as one of America's most admired companies. It has never had an annual loss, and until a scandal at its brokerage firm subsidiary this year it had a string of 73 quarters in which it had recorded rising profits. Its chief, Mr. Welch, is a fierce competitor who wants to dominate each of General Electric's 12 businesses.
 
Toiling for Capitalism
 Mr. Welch's ambitions have reached the most remote Tungsram plant, where his drive for productivity raised some unusual parallels. "In Hungary many of us had to attend the Marx-Engels-Lenin university and learn slogans," said Janos Szlivka, the leader of the Independent Trade Union of Tungsram Employees at the Kisvarda factory in eastern Hungary. Instead of "Work, work, work for the Worker's Brigade," Tungsram employees were told to toil so General Electric could "become the most productive company on earth."
Mr. Szlivka pulled out a copy of a General Electric book given to him at a motivational seminar and thumbed through the pages. "Welch's slogans," he said, " 'If we're not No. 1 or No. 2 in a business, improve it, close it or sell it.' The workers don't like it."
General Electric says that in ordering layoffs it was careful to first edge out those near retirement. Employees received nine months of wages, well above what Hungarian law requires and were given counseling for other opportunities. But many women on Hungary's generous three-year maternity leave have not been rehired. And as General Electric bore down on productivity goals in 1992 and 1993, many workers were dismissed because the company no longer believed that they were needed.
 
Machines, Not People
 Those who stayed were told to work harder. The company adapted its American system of "action workouts" at Tungsram to wring more efficiencies out of the workers. These "workouts," or teams of workers tackling specific problems, reflect Mr. Welch's belief in a "boundaryless" culture in which employees remove obstacles to work more efficiently. The goal, General Electric assured skeptical Tungsram workers, was to make quality lights to improve sales which in turn would increase orders to the plants.
But workouts resulted in more machines and fewer people, making them a hard sell on the factory floor.
Mr. Szlivka, the union official, said these efficiencies had gone as far as humanly possible. "I don't know if the workers can be squeezed any more," he said.
If General Electric methods were demanding for the workers, they were an ordeal for the managers.
"For the first year, it was very difficult to know whether I could live up to the expectations or not. Not only for me but for the other managers," said Miklos Horvath, 54, the manager of the Tungsram plant in Nagykanisza, in southwest Hungary.
 
Classes in English
 Mr. Horvath, like most of the survivors, had to attend English classes, a daunting undertaking at his age. He knew if he could not perform smoothly in weekly conference calls with his American peers he would not last.
Many did not. "A lot of people who were not driven and who couldn't stomach it left," said Ivan Volgyes, a G.E. consultant.
General Electric agreed to pay $150 million for 50.1 percent of Tungsram in 1989, but in less than four years it announced that it had "lost the equity value of the company" and pumped in another $195 million of fresh capital. Still more money followed and all told, General Electric has invested $550 million in Tungsram and now virtually owns it.
Tungsram, which accounted for 3 percent of Hungary's gross national product, was a low-cost way for General Electric to enter the Western European market where it had never been much of a force in the lighting business. Tungsram had 7 percent of the Western European market in 1989, and Mercedes-Benz was a big customer of its headlights. Tungsgram's share was better than General Electric's 2 percent slice of the market. General Electric also believed that Tungsram would be the vehicle for taking on Philips, the big Dutch electronics company, and the Osram unit of Siemens of Germany.
 
Hard-Headed Guidelines
 But a year into the deal, General Electric discovered outdated equipment, poor distribution and sales, and arcane accounting procedures that had disguised losses.
To cut costs, Mr. Pieper issued hard-headed guidelines for layoffs: "I said, 'If we have 10 people in an area look at the requirements for the next 10 years. If we need six, consider not laying off four but laying off six and adding two later.' "
Company officials now say the combination of General Electric's productivity drive and Hungarian scientific ability is bringing results. With Tungsram and a British subsidiary, the former lighting business of Thorn EMI P.L.C., General Electric now has 16 percent of the market, company officials said.
"I hope now you're looking at a winning culture," said Mr. Pieper, who is based in London. "Our yields today are equal to the best we have in the world."
 
Better Productivity Cited
 Mr. Pieper attributed much of the improved picture to better productivity. "This is where the workouts are important," he said.
For example, a war room plastered with productivity goals was opened at the Nagykanisza plant so adjusters could move from the factory floor to a conference table and figure out how to rejigger machines to save time and improve quality.
In one instance, the time it took to reset a machine from making one kind of lamp to making another kind was reduced from 955 minutes in March 1993 to 480 minutes to 200 minutes three months later.
In May, General Electric persuaded the Hungarian Government to grant another five-year tax holiday on profits, arguing that a similar break in the first five years had meant little because there were no profits.
 
Higher Wages Sought
 So as the operation turns profitable and some assembly-line workers are being rehired at the Tungsram plants in Kisvarda and Nagykanisza, the question of higher wages looms. Mr. Szlivka, the union leader, says the workers feel cheated because they were told in 1990 that with fewer workers wages would rise.
But pay has failed to keep up with inflation. Last year, Hungary's inflation was 28 percent but Tungsram wages rose only 6 percent. This year, with inflation at 22 percent, the union won a 16 percent increase.
A national survey by the union last year showed that 36 percent of Tungsram workers lived in families that were on the Hungarian poverty line, a far higher number than in 1988.
General Electric says that Tungsram wages, which average $320 a month, are in the top 25 percent in each of the eight plant towns.
"Labor is so cheap here," Mr. Szlivka said. "In England, people who work in this industry make 10 an hour. They make 1 an hour here. The past four years have really meant that people have had to work more and the money they make doesn't even come near the inflation level. So it shouldn't be any surprise they are not crazy about General Electric."
But General Electric's experience has not translated into a ground swell against foreign takeovers.
"I don't think General Electric has made people against foreign investment," Mr. Szlivka said. "The workers are not against development but at the same time they want to be able to make a living. The workers don't understand why they make less money if the products they produce are as good as Philips's. Why is there such a difference in wages? Since the Iron Curtain was removed, people can see what is happening elsewhere."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Surge in Advertising Across the Radio Dial

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:
Helped by qualitative ratings and research that provide a snapshot of listeners' buying habits, radio advertising has been surging this year at stations big and small around the country.
Advertising revenues rose 12 percent in May, the last month for which data are available, from May 1993. The gain was the fourth double-digit increase in five months. 
 "Radio is taking some business from other media, largely because radio broadcasters have become a good deal more sophisticated in how they market their stations," said Tom Moon, the managing editor of Radio Business Report, an industry newspaper published in Alexandria, Va. "There's less emphasis today on selling by raw audience numbers and more on saying, 'Here's a profile of your consumers, and here's how that matches the profile of our listeners.' "
Qualitative ratings might be useful, for example, for a classical music station that is not ranked among a market's top 20 stations in total audience. The profile might show, how-ever, that the station is in the top 10 among people who take at least 10 business trips a year, or among people with graduate-school educations. That information might not help the station attract soup advertising, but it would be useful in courting airlines or makers of luxury cars.
 
Fast-Paced Growth
 As the American economy has strengthened, advertising has increased in all markets and at stations of all sizes, said Gary R. Fries, president of the Radio Advertising Bureau, which is based in New York and is the industry's sales and marketing arm.
"Radio's recovery started more than a year ago, before the economy was recognized as growing, and it's growing faster than the economy, faster than ad spending in general, faster than most other media," Mr. Fries said.
The bureau conducts a monthly survey of radio advertising in 115 areas around the country, and has found that percentage increases in smaller markets are similar to those in bigger markets, a spokeswoman said.
Unlike most daily newspapers and the television networks, which seek the broadest audience possible, radio has generally thrived by developing formats that carve out specific pieces of the listening audience. And while the growth of cable television, video games and personal computing has reduced the time that many people spend with traditional media, time spent listening to the radio has actually increased, largely because so much radio listening is done in the car and elsewhere outside the home.
For many years, radio relied on ratings provided by the Arbitron Company of New York to measure its total audience, and the time spent listening, within broad age groups. These ratings, of course, benefited the stations with the largest audiences and hurt others.
 
Audience Portraits
 As recently as last year, owners and executives of some stations that specialized in classical music or jazz were bemoaning the reliance of media buyers on the raw Arbitron numbers.
No longer.
"We used to do body-count research, but now we do qualitative research," Mr. Fries said. "Any radio station can tell you a profile of their listeners."
Statistics released earlier this month by the Radio Advertising Bureau show that local and national ad revenues were each up 12 percent in May, and rose an equal amount for the January-May period, compared with 1993.
 "July-August-September looks like the same type of increases, even though summer has traditionally been not as spirited a time as other seasons," Mr. Fries said.
Radio stations can now use software provided by Arbitron to tap into a data base and pull out specific findings. A New York station that wants to seek advertising from northern New Jersey retailers, for instance, can break down the cumulative Arbitron numbers to see just how many listeners it has in New Jersey, and what their demographics are.
The Arbitron data base, compiled from listener diaries, can divide the audience statistics by age, sex, family status and education. The new software also allows stations to link up with other data bases and obtain census data and spending patterns compiled by other companies.
 In addition to Arbitron, a number of small companies offer qualitative research into listening and buying habits.
 
New Programs, New Rules
 The strong ad performance reflects the successful syndication of program hosts including Rush Limbaugh, Howard Stern and Don Imus, and rule changes adopted by the Federal Communications Commission in 1992, industry executives and industry watchers say.
The new rules increased the number of stations a single entity could hold to 30 AM and 30 FM stations, from 12 of each, and allowed one owner to have more than two stations in a single market.
"The impact has been huge," said Gerry Boehme, senior vice president for research at the Katz Radio Group, a company in New York that helps local radio stations court national and regional advertisers. "You can cut costs, change marketing." By putting more money into marketing and defining its audience more precisely, a station might even wind up creating a new format, he said.
At the time of the rule change, some broadcasting critics, and at least one F.C.C. commissioner, said the higher limits would reduce program diversity.
Not so, insisted Mr. Boehme. Echoing the traditional industry view, he said: "It's a real positive for consumers, because stronger operators have taken over stations and pumped in more money. That's led to more format choice for the consumer, and strong stations can promote better and differentiate themselves."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Upbeat in Revenue" shows revenue growth in 1994 of local and national radio advertising, based on the changes from the corresponding month of 1993. (Source: Radio Advertising Bureau)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Utility Investors Find They've Become Real Estate Owners.

BYLINE: By Laurence Zuckerman 

 BODY:
MUTUAL funds that specialize in utility companies have traditionally been conservative investments favored by retired or elderly investors seeking to supplement their incomes. So it may come as a surprise to them that many utility funds are rounding out their portfolios by investing in a sector that some consider to be highly speculative: real estate.
The Stratton Monthly Dividend Shares fund has about 65 percent of its $137 million portfolio invested in electric and telephone companies, but 24 percent of the fund is invested in six real estate investment trusts, or REIT's. Eaton Vance's Total Return Trust, which normally has from 75 to 100 percent of its $533 million portfolio invested in utilities, has about 18 percent invested in real estate trusts. 
 "How could they do that?" asked H. Dale Hemmerdinger, president of Atco Property and Management, a Manhattan property owner. "I think that is a highly dangerous speculation for a fund which is supposed to be very secure and low risk."
But the fund managers wonder if Mr. Hemmerdinger has had a good look at utility stocks recently. The sector has taken a beating since fall amid interest rate increases and deregulation concerns.
"Talk about risk," said Edwin W. Bragdon, a vice president at Eaton Vance and portfolio manager of the Total Return Trust. "Utilities dropped 30 percent in nine months and REIT's went up. At least in the short term it was not a bad idea. In the long run we'll see how it turns out."
After several sharp ups and downs in the 1970's and 80's, a flood of REIT offerings have poured out of Wall Street in the last 18 months. These latest trusts generally own and manage portfolios of properties in a sector of the property market, like multifamily apartments, office buildings, hotels or shopping centers.
By law, a REIT is exempt from corporate taxes, but must distribute at least 95 percent of its net income to shareholders in the form of a dividend. The relatively high yield and growth prospects of the trusts especially appeal to the managers of utility funds that emphasize current income.
"We need a high yield, and not many other areas beside electric utilities and REIT's offer that," said James W. Stratton, the founder of Stratton management and the firm's chief investment officer. In the first quarter, the Stratton fund offered the highest yield, 7.8 percent, of any utility fund tracked by Lipper Analytical Services.
Strictly speaking, there is nothing to prevent utility fund managers from buying REIT's. Most sector funds require managers to invest up to 65 percent of assets in the given specialty, leaving them free to invest the rest in cash or other securities. The funds regularly disclose their holdings to investors so that no one who reads the documentation carefully should be surprised.
But critics point out that the real estate market is not nearly as regulated as are utilities and is not providing an essential service that is always in demand, like electric power. It is also subject to much wilder boom-and-bust cycles.
"Traditionally, real estate has been a rich man's game because it is very risky," Mr. Hemmerdinger said. "Think of all the people who have gone broke" in recent years.
The trusts are also very difficult to analyze unless you have a sophisticated understanding of the real estate business. "Does my mutual fund manager who knows everything there is to know about utility stocks know what there is to know about real estate?" asked Barry Vinocur, editor in chief of Realty Stock Review, which closely tracks REIT offerings.
Several fund managers agree, saying that they carefully scrutinize the management of the REIT's they invest in. "This is a sector that has gone through boom-and-bust times," said Sheldon Simon, manager of the $1 billion Putnam Utilities Growth and Income Fund, which has about 2 percent of its assets invested in property trusts. "There's no reason to think that you wouldn't find trouble if you invest in the wrong REIT."
Other managers say they have to diversify to get the stability they are seeking, because utility stocks are so sensitive to rate changes. "If I bought 100 percent utilities, then I would be completely at the whim of the bond market," said Christopher H. Wiles, who manages two utility funds for Federated Investors in Pittsburgh.

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Food Stamps

 BODY:
The number of households in the region receiving food stamps has jumped 51 percent since the start of the decade. The area's sluggish economy has been the main reason, but the Agriculture Department also says the Clinton Administration's efforts to issue food stamps to all who qualify has increased the rolls. If the local economy continues to improve, the number of food stamp recipients should begin to decline in the next year or two. The statistics released earlier this month on overpayment and error rates for food stamps concerned mistakes involving the issuance of food stamps. They did not reflect the smaller, but growing, problem of merchants buying food stamps, usually at 60 to 70 cents on the dollar, and redeeming them at full price from the Federal Government.

HEADLINE: New Head of Landmarks Panel Looks to Future

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
A 38-year-old lawyer has been named chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, and she says she will move quickly to look at the future of buildings in lower Manhattan and to cultivate public-private partnerships in the care of landmarks.
 The chairwoman, Jennifer J. Raab, a litigation associate in the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, was named to the post last week by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. She was the issues director for his 1989 mayoral campaign. 
Although Ms. Raab is little known in preservation circles, news of her appointment was greeted with cautious enthusiasm by leading preservationists. It was also welcomed by the Real Estate Board of New York.
 "I see landmarks as New York's treasure, our history and legacy," Ms. Raab said. "I'm very excited to be able to bring my skills as an advocate to something I really believe in: safeguarding the landmarks process in New York."
 
Deeper Implications
 Given the interest of City Hall in promoting real-estate development --which can conflict with historic preservation -- Mr. Giuliani's choice of a landmarks chief may have significant implications.
 In lower Manhattan, for example, are dozens of buildings from the late 19th and early 20th centuries that are architecturally significant but economically stagnant, full of embellishments but devoid of tenants. Many owners would just as soon raze these buildings, few of which are official landmarks.
 Ms. Raab said downtown was "one of the first things I have to look at," though she shied away from specifics.
 She said she did not anticipate any "discontinuity" between her tenure and that of her predecessor, Laurie Beckelman, who is to become a vice president of the LaSalle Partners real-estate concern.
 Ms. Raab said Ms. Beckelman's focus on Harlem landmarks is "something I certainly want to continue."
 Noting that the commission's budget and staff had been shrinking "without any shrinking of the needs in preservation," Ms. Raab also raised the prospect of public-private partnerships.
 While the commission is best known for creating landmarks and historic districts, its broader role is regulatory. Owners may not alter or demolish designated structures without approval from the commission. There are some 19,000 structures under its aegis, roughly 2 percent of all properties in New York City.
 Ms. Raab's appointment is subject to review by the City Council. Absent any controversy, she could take over the 11-member panel in September.
 
Praise From Officials
 About her successor, Ms. Beckelman said: "She's a lawyer and I think she'll be passionate in upholding the landmarks law. And it's good that she has a strong relationship with the Mayor. I think she'll fare well."
 The Real Estate Board "knows her to be a capable attorney, bright and fair," said Warren Wechsler, its first senior vice president.
 Similar words came from Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society, who said Ms. Raab seemed "very intelligent and caring about the city" and "is thought not to be an ideologue."
 Peg Breen, president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy, said "someone who isn't out of the preservation school" may be able to "help drive across the message that preservation is really a part of the economic development, tourism and culture of the city."
 Ms. Raab was a member of the legal team in 1992 that successfully defended, on behalf of tenants, the landmark designation of an entire Upper East Side housing complex, known as the City and Suburban York Avenue Estate. Its owner at the time, Peter S. Kalikow, sought to strip four of the 14 buildings of landmark status to build a new apartment tower between 78th and 79th Streets.
 Ms. Raab holds degrees from Cornell, Princeton and Harvard Universities. She has worked for the City Planning Commission, the South Bronx Development Organization and the law firms of Tufo & Zuccotti and Cravath, Swaine & Moore.
In 1988 she directed the unsuccessful State Senate campaign of Joseph B. Rose, who is now chairman of the City Planning Commission. Ms. Raab is married to Michael Goodwin, the deputy editorial page editor of The Daily News.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jennifer J. Raab, whom Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has named the chairwoman of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)
